The agency has come under fire for refusing to forward nursing home residents' mail automatically when they move. Elderly-rights advocates say the policy treats residents like prison inmates by placing the burden on the home to forward mail. The Postal Service will reconsider its practice as part of a broad review, spokesman Lou Eberhardt said Thursday. The review ``is not a cursory glance,'' Eberhardt said. ``They are going to assemble various sections of the Postal Service _ delivery, marketing, mail processing _ and sit down beginning next week.'' The purpose, Eberhardt said, ``is to determine whether changes should be made not only from a standpoint of the nursing home portion, but mail for homeless, mail being handled by agents. It's hard to say exactly where it's going, but it may require some procedural changes where nursing homes are concerned.'' Since residents of a nursing home are at the same address, the Postal Service says the home should be the ``agent'' of their mail. The mail is delivered in bulk, like at a prison, and then distributed. While other people may submit change-of-address cards to the local post office, nursing home residents must rely on the institution to write their new address on individual letters. Once the mail is readdressed, the post office delivers it at no extra charge. Allowing automatic forwarding is not ``practical operationally,'' the Postal Service says. Since mail for individual residents is not sorted at the post office, the agency says it could not easily distinguish mail that needs to be forwarded from the rest. ``It's absurd,'' Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., said in an interview Thursday. ``The Postal Service says `We can only deliver in bulk.' But people are paying for first-class postage on that mail.'' The agency review will include other possible problem areas. ``There are a lot of people getting mail who are homeless,'' Eberhardt said. He said most get their mail through general delivery boxes, and the Postal Service wanted to see if the system is working. Heinz wrote the agency in March questioning whether nursing home residents should be classified ``with inmates, who have lost important civil rights, or with short-term hospital patients.'' He said he has received no response. Heinz acted after a Pennsylvania ombudsman for the elderly complained of problems created when a nursing home was shut down by the state last year, and the owner was not around to forward the mail. A local agency ended up getting the letters to 30 displaced residents. Also lobbying is Sister Mary Gregoria Rush of the Roman Catholic Diocese of St. Petersburg, Fla. She wrote the agency, lawmakers and first lady Barbara Bush seeking to change ``this policy that treats nursing home residents like they were in jail or something.''

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Urges Convictions Be Thrown Out in Bomb Factory Case
DOC.TEXT: The government says it will ask an appeals court to throw out the convictions of seven people who served prison sentences for allegedly running an IRA bomb factory. The announcement marked the collapse of all the convictions stemming from two Irish Republican Army bombings of pubs in Guildford and Woolwich in 1974, in which seven people died. ``I don't believe the convictions can be allowed to stand,'' Home Secretary David Waddington told the House of Commons Thursday. Hours earlier, England's senior prosecutor told a judicial inquiry that the convictions were ``unsafe and unsatisfactory'' because of questions about the reliability of scientific tests which were the core of the prosecution case. Four people convicted of the bombings were released in October, after the director of public prosecutions said police had lied about some evidence. The mainly Roman Catholic IRA is fighting to end British rule of Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland and unite the province with Ireland. Six of those convicted in the bomb factory case have served their sentences and the seventh, Guiseppe Conlon, died in prison in 1980. ``I only hope and pray now that it will go as soon as possible to the appeals court to take the burden off our family, because it has been a living nightmare,'' said Anne Maguire, who served 10 years in prison. Her husband, two sons, two relatives and a family friend were also convicted. Waddington said he would not refer the case to the Court of Appeal until the judicial inquiry, headed by Sir John May, completes its work. The government's case was based on forensic evidence indicating that all seven had traces of nitroglycerin on their hands. Allan Green, the director of public prosecutions, said he considered the convictions unsatisfactory because recent tests had shown that the defendants might have been contaminated by touching something, such as a towel, that had been touched by someone else who had handled explosives. Testimony at the inquiry revealed that the tests were done by an 18-year-old junior technician, and the results could not be verified because all the samples were used up. ``The scientific evidence given to the jury may have misled them into excluding the possibility of innocent contamination,'' Green said. Mrs. Maguire was convicted in 1976 along with her husband, Patrick; their sons, Vincent and Patrick; Guiseppe Conlon, Patrick Maguire' brother-in-law; Sean John Smyth, Mrs. Maguire's brother, and a family friend, Patrick Joseph O'Neill. Earlier this year, Waddington ordered an investigation into the convictions of six men for pub bombings that killed 21 people in Birmingham in November 1974. That investigation continues. In the House of Commons on Thursday, Waddington faced calls from Labor Party legislators for a full public inquiry into the Birmingham case. ``I will consider carefully what the May inquiry says about the forensic evidence in the Maguire case. I will take fully into account any implications it might have for the safety of other convictions,'' Waddington said. In an interview with Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency, Mrs. Maguire said she was not bitter about the convictions, ``just very, very hurt that this could happen in my children's country.''

DOC.HEAD: Mayors Demanding Money, Blaming Washington for Urban Woes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: First formal event at 4 p.m. EDT; lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: The nation's mayors, much like the White House and Congress, aren't quite sure how big of a peace dividend will result from planned cuts in defense spending. But they want half _ whatever the amount. The mayors open their annual summer meeting here today poised to demand that much of the defense savings be funneled to cities to help ease education, drug and housing problems they increasingly blame on the White House and Congress. ``The federal government has walked away from the cities of America and now we are beginning to see the dangerous results,'' said Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn, a leading spokesman for the mayors. ``There are signs that cannot be ignored, even through the best set of rose-colored glasses,'' Flynn said. He listed among his examples gang violence in his and several other cities and recent tensions in New York resulting from court proceedings against whites accused of participating in a mob attack last summer that left a black teen-ager dead. ``This isn't a Republican or a Democratic problem alone or a big-city problem alone or a liberal or conservative mayors' problem alone,'' Flynn said. ``This is an American problem that is gnawing at the social conscience of the American public.'' Flynn this year moves up to the vice presidency of the U.S. Conference of Mayors, which is dominated by big-city Democratic mayors who are frequent critics of the Republican Bush administration. But even the organization's Republicans are voicing rising frustration with White House priorities. ``We have considerable mandates placed upon us by the federal government with less and less funding to carry them out,'' said Republican Mayor Robert Isaac of Colorado Springs, Colo., who takes over as president of the conference. ``We are not asking for a handouts. We are asking for fairness.'' The mayors will debate dozens of policy statements on an array of issues, with a clear consensus in advance of the meeting in favor of a proposal to demand that cities get half of any peace dividend. But after a decade of cuts in federal aid to cities, few mayors are optimistic their demand will be met. ``I'm not so naive as to believe the White House and the Congress are going to listen to us mayors,'' Flynn said in an interview Thursday. ``What we as an organization have to do is generate political support. American cities are in deep trouble.'' The mayors also will consider adopting dozens of policy statements on health care, housing and other issues _ many similar to stances taken at past meetings. Another asks the federal government not to hurt local real estate markets by selling at bargain-basement prices properties it controls because of savings and loan failures. Isaac, whose area has been hard hit by S&L failures, also is lobbying to get the federal government to surrender some of the properties to local governments for affordable-housing programs. ``Money for housing programs has been drying up,'' the Colorado Springs mayor said. ``I see this as a tremendous opportunity to do some good.'' The six-day meeting opens today with the first joint meeting of organization task forces on drug control and homelessness. At a meeting last week to plan the conference, several mayors said street tensions in their cities appeared to be on the rise heading into the summer months. ``This isn't a time for happy talk,'' said Flynn. ``A decade of neglect of America's cities has created an abominable mix that presents a dangerously tense situation for this summer and years to come.''

DOC.HEAD: Air Force is Willing to Delay Missile Modernization for Stealth Development
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force, looking to bolster support for the B-2 bomber, is willing to delay modernization of its two land-based nuclear missiles to develop the stealth aircraft. President Bush's nominee for Air Force chief of staff, Gen. Michael J. Dugan, said publicly Thursday what has been hinted for weeks: The service has proposed to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney that work on the missiles be delayed. When asked if the Air Force had recommended that option, Dugan told the Senate Armed Services Committee: ``I understand that. I accept that, approve that and I support that. One needs to look at affordability issues in every regard.'' Cheney must decide whether to slow down development of the single-warhead Midgetman missile and delay plans to move the multiple-warhead MX missile from fixed silos to railroad cars. In April, the defense secretary said the Bush administration supports the MX rail-garrison program, which totals $2.8 billion in the defense budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The budget also calls for $202 million for the Midgetman. ``This is a proposal. It hasn't been reviewed. It's subject to lots of further discussion,'' Dugan said. The commander of the Air Force in Europe said he supports the proposal and indicated that his No. 1 concern is the B-2 stealth bomber, the radar-evading plane that at more than $815 million a copy has resulted in increasing congressional opposition. ``I rank the B-2 at the head of my list for all strategic modernization programs in the Air Force,'' Dugan said. His second priority is the Midgetman missile and third is the MX missile on railroad cars, which the service should have as a hedge with research and development funds available, he said. ``I find a logic to that set of priorities,'' said committee Chairman Sam Nunn, D-Ga. Sen. John Warner of Virginia, ranking Republican on the committee, concurred. In an interview with Defense News, the outgoing chief of staff, Gen. Larry Welch, said the United States ``ought to pause intercontinental ballistic missile modernization until we have a clear view of where we're going to go in the next step of arms control.'' Nunn indicated that Dugan and Adm. Frank B. Kelso, Bush's choice for chief of Naval Operations, who also testified before the panel, would win swift committee approval.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney To Suggest Cuts In Military Construction
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, in anticipation of Pentagon budget cuts, is freezing military construction for another five months and will ask Congress to cancel a large number of construction projects, his spokesman says. Next week, Cheney is expected to send Congress a list of military construction projects that he would like to see eliminated, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said Thursday. Cheney's move comes as Congress has been pressing for sharp reductions in Pentagon spending and reductions in the nation's military forces. His request is expected to cause some controversy on Capitol Hill. Decisions to halt construction projects are seen by some as an attack on pork barrel padding of the defense budget. But it also fuels the debate between those who want to cut Pentagon spending and lawmakers who want to protect local jobs. The secretary decided to extend a worldwide freeze on military construction in order ``to help ensure the department proceeds with the projects for which there is a genuine need,'' Williams said. Cheney will select his candidates for cancellation from a list of some 207 projects _ including the controversial Navy ``home ports'' in Texas, Alabama, Mississippi and New York. Last month, Cheney ordered the 207 projects to be reviewed for possible cancellation. Because funds for the projects already have been approved, the secretary must ask Congress to withdraw the funding through a process known formally as ``rescission.'' Williams said he could not say exactly how many of the 207 projects might be cancelled, but added, ``It is fair to say that the secretary believes that funding should be cancelled on a substantial number of military construction projects.'' ``I would expect a decision on this next week,'' Williams said. The freeze, which will run through Nov. 15, affects more than $7 billion in construction. The 207 specific projects under study for cancellation have been valued by the Pentagon at $1.2 billion. Cheney first put a freeze on construction in January and extended it in April. It was due to expire on June 15. The 207 sites under study included the so-called strategic home ports in Ingleside, Texas; Mobile, Ala.; Pascagoula, Miss.; and Staten Island, N.Y. The majority of the 207 projects under review were located overseas, in particular in West Germany. Planned improvements or construction of hangars, maintenance facilities, family housing projects, schools for military dependents, and medical units were among the items targeted. However, some of the domestic sites targeted carried hefty price tags. Besides the four ports, the review also included a $110 million project at a rocket test facility at Arnold, Tenn.; $60 million in improvements at Fort Hood and Red River Army Depot in Texas; and a $37 million project at a consolidated maintenance facility at Tooele, Utah.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Closes Lower
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,538.40, down 129.71 points or 0.40 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Peace Corps to Send 122 English Teachers to Poland, Hungary
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Ceremony begins at 9:30 a.m. EDT; lead planned
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is giving a White House send-off to 122 English teachers who are bringing the Peace Corps to Poland and Hungary for the first time. The volunteers, in Washington for their final orientation, were selected from the thousands of Americans who answered Bush's call earlier this year for the Peace Corps to help the two East European nations fill the vacuum created by the collapse of communist rule. ``It's almost as if the Peace Corps had been in training for 30 years for this moment,'' Paul D. Coverdell, the Peace Corps director, said. Today, they will hear from Bush in a Rose Garden ceremony. Coverdell said the effort to create an English-language teaching network in Poland and Hungary may open ``a good solid decade of activity'' with expansion possible into the fields of environmental protection and business development. After four decades of communism in Eastern Europe, the first Peace Corps volunteers in Poland and Hungary are truly pioneers, Coverdell said. ``It's a new relationship,'' he said. ``Anytime you are the first there's pressure because everybody's eyes are on you.'' Coverdell said the Peace Corps is aware of how different the task in Eastern Europe will be compared to the developing countries of the Third World where education is substandard. In Hungary and Poland, Peace Corps volunteers will be dealing with ``a well-educated constituency that is dramatically under-resourced,'' he said. One of the challenges, he said, is that ``they will be head to head with an enlightened people. They will be sitting across the table from someone who is clearly a match.'' The volunteers, ranging in age from 21 to 77, come from 31 states coast to coast. Felix Lapinski, 66, a former official of the Agency for International Development and of Polish descent, said he is looking forward to his assignment to help Poles master English, a language he says has become ``the access language'' of the modern era. Coverdell says English is vital as Eastern Europe turns to face the West because it has become ``the language of commerce, science, mathematics and computer technology.'' ``In the very, very recent past, English was a closet language in Eastern Europe; you had to learn it secretly,'' says Jerry Welch, the Peace Corps' deputy director for Central Europe and other regions. Welch noted that lessons in Russian, once a requirement, now have been all but abandoned. ``Now they have a need for a large number of English teachers,'' Welch told volunteers. ``I think you will not find that you are any kind of threat to existing English teachers,'' he assured them. ``They are few in number and overwhelmed.'' Coverdell says that far from draining the resources of the Peace Corps, the opening to Eastern Europe has struck the popular imagination and sparked as much interest in the idealistic organization as at any time since it was launched 30 years ago by President Kennedy. He noted that almost 30 countries around the globe have indicated interest recently in Peace Corps programs. ``The Peace Corps is now widely understood,'' Coverdell said. ``I think it was a great idea and I think it has proved itself. I think it has won over virtually all of its original skeptics.''

DOC.HEAD: 2 Live Crew Performs, But Not As Nasty As They Might Wanna Be
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with show over, quote from police chief, editing to conform. Picks up 7th graf, `He said band ...'
DOC.TEXT: The band 2 Live Crew proved Thursday night it could perform without breaking any laws, and even the police chief admitted he liked the rap concert. ``I consider it the PG version,'' Gwinnett County Police Chief Wayne Bolden said. ``This is the first rap concert I've been to and I'm kind of enjoying it. I like the beat.'' The band, whose X-rated lyrics got its star arrested in Florida, performed about 40 minutes at a teen nightclub before an estimated 320 people, including three police officers. The band had canceled an 8 p.m. concert, and a promoter blamed the decision on ``all the hype'' about the group's problems with the law. ``They had a fear that they would be arrested whether they did the clean show'' or an adult version, said promoter Chris Lyons of Salt and Pepper Entertainment. Lyons said the band missed its morning flight from Miami as it sought assurances there would be no arrests if they kept their show in this Atlanta suburb clean. The band did not arrive from the Atlanta airport until after 11 p.m., delaying the 10:30 p.m. show about an hour. Bolden said he met with band members when they arrived and ``told them about the obscenity law. I also told them they could not play any songs from the album,'' ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be.'' He said band members ``thanked him for the explanation.'' Bolden had threatened to arrest the rappers if they performed any songs from the sexually explicit but popular album. Lyons said, ``All the hype about the show was that they would do an X-rated show at a teen venue.'' Among those waiting outside the nightclub in anticipation of the concert that was cancelled were eight people protesting attempts to squelch 2 Live Crew's music, which features explicit lyrics. They carried signs reading ``Does anyone remember the Bill of Rights?'' and ``A bad rap for the First Amendment.'' ``I don't like the music, but I still see it as a First Amendment thing,'' said Donna Williamson, 38, of Duluth. ``If the music is that bad, it will die a natural death.'' Police had hoped to meet with the group earlier Thursday at their hotel, but the hotel canceled the reservation, saying it had been made ``under false pretenses.'' Police spokesman Larry Walton said officers wanted to meet with the performers at their hotel ``to try to get some assurances as to what they're going to do'' in their shows. He said police did meet with the club's owner, Ed Kramer. Dan Marone, manager of the Gwinnett Place Marriott, said he refused to let the performers stay at the hotel because they falsely claimed that Democratic gubernatorial candidate Andrew Young planned to hold a news conference at the hotel on their behalf. Young's campaign spokesman, Nehl Horton, said the candidate never planned a news conference involving the band. ``We have no association whatsoever with 2 Live Crew,'' Horton said. ``Andy's name has been tossed around haphazardly and without authorization. He doesn't condone their music.'' Lyons declined to say where the group would stay. He said he was not aware of the hotel's accusations concerning a Young news conference. Chief Assistant Solicitor David Fuller advised Gwinnett police earlier this week that the ``Nasty as They Wanna Be'' album violates Georgia's obscenity law because it contains graphic descriptions of intercourse and sodomy. Florida police arrested two of the Miami-based rappers last weekend after they played songs from the album at an all-adult show. A record store owner also was arrested for selling the album. The arrests came after a federal judge ruled that the album was obscene. That ruling, which was limited to three south Florida counties, is on appeal to the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta. The album also has come under attack by authorities in at least two other states. In Columbia, S.C., solicitor James Anders on Wednesday deemed said he will give Richland County record store owners 10 days to clear the album from their shelves. ``We reviewed it, and we definitely feel it's obscene,'' he said. Police in San Antonio started calling 84 local record stores Tuesday to tell them the album may violate Texas obscenity laws. Lt. Jerry Pittman, commander of the vice squad, said if his office receives complaints in the next few days, officers will go out, buy the album and press charges.

DOC.HEAD: House Democrats want HUD Probe to Include Possible Perjury by Pierce
DOC.TEXT: House Democrats are pressing an independent counsel to widen his probe to include allegations that former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. lied to Congress. The lawmakers wrote to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh on Thursday asking him to refer the allegations against Pierce to the independent counsel appointed after revelations of scandals at the Department of Housing and Urban Development. The letter, signed by all 22 Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee, cited testimony last month by former assistant HUD Secretary DuBois L. Gilliam as new evidence suggesting that Pierce lied when he was questioned last year by Congress about the HUD scandals. Gilliam, who is serving an 18-month prison term for conspiracy and accepting an illegal gratuity, testified that Pierce ordered him several times to make grant awards to developers with Republican political connections. In testimony last year to the House Government Operations employment and housing subcommittee, Pierce insisted he ``did not have hands on'' involvement in disbursing money through the Moderate Rehabilitation Program, saying that he ``never told these people to fund anything.'' In their letter to Thornburgh, the 22 Democrats said Gilliam ``described at least two instances in which Mr. Pierce was directly involved in abuses of the Moderate Rehabilitation Program.' The letter said Gilliam ``may have contradicted Mr. Pierce's earlier testimony,'' citing Gilliam's statements that the former Cabinet secretary was ``the big dealer'' in HUD grants. Gilliam told the panel last month that Pierce used the HUD secretary's discretionary grant program as ``a private political slush fund.'' After reviewing Gilliam's testimony, Thornburgh asked independent counsel Arlin M. Adams to broaden his investigation to include allegations of political favoritism in the operation of the discretionary grant fund and the Urban Development Action Grant Program. Adams was originally appointed to investigate whether Pierce and former top aides showed political favoritism in the operation of the Moderate Rehabilitation Program. The independent counsel is taking steps to widen his investigation and has granted immunity to Gilliam, according to a source who spoke on condition of anonymity. Adams has also issued grand jury subpoenas to Pierce and his former associates, sources said. Thornburgh sought appointment of the HUD independent counsel after reviewing allegations turned over to the Justice Department by Judiciary Committee Democrats. But the attorney general rejected the lawmakers' request that the investigation include allegations of perjury against Pierce. Thornburgh said at the time that the questions Pierce was asked and the answers he gave were so ambiguous that they did not provide any evidence of perjury. Robert Plotkin, one of Pierce's defense attorneys, said Gilliam's testimony does not change Thornburgh's earlier conclusion that there was no ``specific and credible'' allegation of perjury that warranted further investigation. Gilliam ``was never asked directly about anything that Pierce testified about that was of a specific enough nature for him to be able to contradict anything,'' Plotkin said. But Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., one of the signers of the letter said ``Gilliam has added new cause to look into perjury.'' ``Gilliam's testimony both takes the potential perjury into new areas as well makes the case stronger,'' Schumer said. ``I think it merits a serious look by the independent counsel. Let the independent counsel determine matters of the depth of the evidence.''

DOC.HEAD: Administration Accuses Japan of Failing To Honor Trade Commitments
DOC.TEXT: Ambitious U.S.-Japanese trade talks are stalled with American officials threatening not to sign a landmark agreement if the Japanese fail to open further their markets to U.S. goods. The ongoing dispute flared into the open Thursday when Bush administration officials charged that Japan was failing to honor commitments made in April to attack the root causes of America's $49 billion trade deficit with Japan. In April, both countries signed an interim agreement pledging to make fundamental economic reforms to reduce the huge trade imbalance between the two economic superpowers. In the agreement, known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, Japan pledged to boost its public works spending and move toward breaking up the cozy relationships between Japanese firms that keep foreign companies from doing business in Japan's market. The United States pledged to intensify efforts to reduce the federal budget deficit, improve its education system and boost its low savings rate. The interim report was due to be followed in early July with a final report fleshing out the broad commitments and setting up a monitoring arrangement to insure compliance. However, talks on the final report have made little progress with the U.S. side pushing for specifics to back up the Japanese promises and the Japanese insisting they have gone as far as they can go. White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater told reporters Thursday the administration intended to ``keep the pressure on'' to ensure that ``all the commitments make it through to the final report.'' A senior administration official, briefing reporters on background, was even more blunt, warning that the United States might refuse to sign a final report unless the Japanese are more forthcoming. ``It would be highly regrettable that if, at this stage, this process lost momentum and reversed itself,'' the official said. He charged that top Japanese officials have failed to provide sufficient guidance to their negotiators. Secretary of State James A. Baker III is scheduled to meet Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama in San Francisco on Friday. The administration is hoping those discussions will get the trade talks back on track. The next round of talks on structural barriers is scheduled for June 25-26 in Tokyo with the final report due before the Houston economic summit meeting on July 9. If not cleared up before then, a trade fight between the United States and Japan would threaten the upbeat mood at this year's economic meeting of the world's seven richest industrial countries. Officials briefing reporters Thursday said key sticking points in the current negotiations revolve around how much more Japan will spend on public works projects and how it will toughen its antitrust penalties. The administration is also bothered by the Japanese insistence that they do not need to reduce their huge trade surplus because the excess money is needed to supply capital for the reconstruction of Eastern Europe, the unification of Germany and debt-strapped nations in Latin America. The administration says the new position is a negotiating ploy that fails to take into account other ways to raise needed investment capital besides running huge trade surpluses that destabilize the global economy. Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher, testifying before the Senate Banking Committee on Thursday, said he hoped the Japanese were not trying to stonewall American negotiators to test the administration's resolve. ``They did take some very good first steps but they have got a lot farther to go, as we do,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bennett Says Cocaine Prices are Up, Anti-Drug Efforts Paying Off
DOC.TEXT: Rising wholesale cocaine prices show anti-drug efforts are ``starting to pay off,'' and causing shortages, national drug director William J. Bennett says. ``It looks as if we are beginning to have a positive effect on the flow of cocaine into this country,'' Bennett said Thursday. ``This can change. This can bump up and down, as time goes on, but it looks like some real impact is occurring. ``We're putting some tremendous pressure on drug traffickers and I think it's starting to pay off,'' he said, crediting Colombia's crackdown on the cocaine cartels and interdiction and investigative efforts by U.S. agencies. But Bennett warned: ``No one should be lulled into thinking that this is the end.'' Drug traffickers, thwarted in efforts to bring cocaine into the United States, ``will now try to divert, do other things, try to get more in other ways,'' he said. ``We've got to be ready for them at the next place.'' The Drug Enforcement Administration disagreed with Bennett's conclusion that increases in wholesale cocaine prices in Los Angeles and New York City reflect a shortage in cocaine. ``The story is that we are very, very cautiously optimistic that the changes in price that we are seeing in some markets reflect tremendously successful law enforcement efforts,'' said DEA spokesman Frank Shults. However, he added, ``we are not saying the United States has experienced any cocaine shortage,'' and there is ``absolutely no'' indication of a nationwide trend. The good news, Shults said, is that the DEA has found that a kilogram of cocaine today in New York City can fetch as much as $35,000 at the wholesale level, up from official estimates last fall of $14,000 to $18,000. In Los Angeles, wholesale prices have risen from $10,000 per kilogram in lots of 10 or more and $15,000 for smaller amounts last fall to $25,000 today. Shults said one recent case there involved a price of $35,000. ``In undercover operations, we're finding people saying, `I'll pay any price,''' he said. The wholesale price of cocaine also has gone up in Boston, but it has stayed about the same in Miami and it has gone both up and down in Phoenix, where a kilogram still can be bought for a ``bargain'' $11,000, Shults said. Traffickers in New York also have been making deals for half-kilo amounts of cocaine, when they used to trade only in lots of 10 kilograms or more, he said. In addition, when agents seized a large shipment of cocaine in Baltimore recently, it was not pure but already had been diluted, which the DEA saw as a ``very, very good sign,'' he said. ``We believe very strongly that the enforcement activities of the United States, of the Andean nations of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia, have had the effect of disrupting the major cocaine cartels,'' Shults said. But he acknowledged the possibility that entrepreneurs are simply demanding more for their goods, scaring buyers into thinking there are shortages. ``There could be gouging,'' he said. ``There could be stockpiling. There could be a shortage.'' Bennett said a cocaine shortage could trigger increased violence, even though he has long cited the violence that accompanies drug trafficking as a reason to eliminate the drugs. ``We've got a long summer ahead of us, and in some of our communities where there is a shortage of cocaine, there will be violence as a result of that,'' he said. ``There will be the same number of dogs fighting over a smaller number of bones. And we can anticipate some of that this summer.''

DOC.HEAD: German Art Has Town Talking, Lawyers Negotiating
LaserPhoto DN2
DOC.TEXT: People who knew Joe T. Meador say they can't believe the quiet hardware store owner stole millions in medieval art from a German church while he was a soldier during World War II. The possibility that Meador stashed the precious cache in a Whitewright bank vault was the talk of this farm town Thursday, when The New York Times quoted unidentified sources as saying he was responsible for one of the century's biggest art thefts. ``I just don't believe he was that kind of a man,'' said 73-year-old Mary Bryant, who said she had visited Meador's home but could not remember seeing any sumptuous works of art. ``He didn't seem the type of guy to me that would do something like that,'' said Troyce Spencer, who also lives in this town of 1,760 people about 60 miles north of Dallas. The newspaper said Meador, in the final days of World War II, took the objects from a church in Quedlinburg, an ancient castle town in what is now East Germany. The Times based its report on interviews with art experts, lawyers and neighbors of Meador. Stolen was a small, silver display case inlaid with enamels and precious stones, with side panels of carved ivory; a liturgical ivory comb; a manuscript dated 1513; several rock crystal flasks and gold and silver crucifixes, and other treasures. The Army investigated the theft but dropped the matter in 1949 when Quedlinburg became part of East Germany. Dietrich Kotzsche, a German authority in medieval decorative art, said the Quedlinburg treasures, dating to the 9th and 10th centuries, could be worth millions. The Times reported today that the church in Quedlinburg has retained two lawyers to seek the return of the art. Meador died in 1980 at age 64. He co-owned a family hardware and farm tool business and grew orchids in a greenhouse behind the two-story Victorian home he shared with his mother, Mabel. ``He was the type of fellow that didn't mix with people much,'' said Odell Caraway, a member of American Legion Post 225 to which Meador once belonged. ``As far as I know he's never been involved in any kind of crooked stuff.'' Willi A. Korte, a West German government official who specializes in the repatriation of cultural property, and Thomas R. Kline of the law firm Andrews & Kurth of Washington and Dallas, said they planned a trip to Dallas today to negotiate with Meador's relatives, the Times said. Neither those lawyers nor John S. Torigian, an attorney for Meador's brother, Jack, could be reached for comment Thursday by The Associated Press. Meador was an officer in the 87th Armored Field Artillery, which occupied Quedlinburg and guarded a mine shaft where the Times said the treasures were kept. The items disappeared a few days after U.S. troops took over the area in 1945, the newspaper said. Three longtime Meador employees said Thursday they had never known their boss to show off any art works. The Times reported that a source it did not identify said the treasures are in the vault of the First National Bank of Whitewright, reportedly as collateral for a loan. Harrell Stowers, the bank's executive vice president, would not confirm that information Thursday when asked by The Associated Press. Jack Meador, his wife, Jean, and Meador's sister, Jane Meador Cook, also would not comment Thursday. How the treasures got to Texas is a secret that may have died with Meador. Most of the people interviewed Thursday said they didn't know Meador had even been in the Army or World War II. ``We haven't had this much excitement since the machine gun deal,'' said Mayor Clarence Tillet Jr., who explained that a judge once charged four machine guns in the town's name to avoid paying sales tax.

DOC.HEAD: Orange Is Color of Love Among Guppies, Researchers Find
DOC.TEXT: Orange guppy males can wind up either as a favorite of females or as dinner, according to a study published today in the journal Science. Female guppies with the mating urge like finned suitors with flashy bright patches of orange. Unfortunately, predators also favor the guys with the big, bold colors. Princeton University researcher Anne E. Houde said female guppies ``do indeed seem to prefer males that have overall brighter colors ... such as how much orange they have in their patterns.'' But that also is a combination that attracts big fish, birds and other predators. Houde and John A. Endler of the University of California, Santa Barbara, researched the color preferences of guppy love by taking fish from six different locations in Trinidad, a tropical island where the vividness of guppy colors varies from stream to stream. They found that when a female guppy showed a preference in her mate selection, she went for the guys with those dazzling orange colors. But not all female guppies made their selections on such superficial criteria, Houde said. For females from streams where most males were dull hues, she said, color didn't seem to be a factor. And how do you tell when guppies get romantic? Male guppies, Houde said, swim to a female and make a courtship display, ``like a little dance.'' ``If she is interested then she will start gliding toward him and there will be a mating,'' Houde said. ``If she's not interested, she will seem to pay no attention whatsoever. She has to have that initial response or there is no mating.'' Females also have a roving eye and may mate with two or three male guppies. Unlike most fish, guppy eggs are fertilized and hatched internally. The females give birth after three weeks. Broods average 10 to 15. Houde said that by studying mating choices among the guppies, scientists hope to learn more about the forces that shape evolution. Species colors may also be affected by choices made by predators. And, predators, she said, tend to eat brightly colored guppies more often than the duller ones. ``For whatever reason that females have preference for particular males, then that is an evolutionary force,'' she said. ``And for whatever reason the males are subject to predators, that's an evolution force.'' Houde said female guppies may choose orange mates because that is color of health in the guppy world. ``Females are able to identify males who are healthy and resistant to parasites because they can put on a good show of orange,'' she said. Infected or diseased males have duller colors. Science, which published the study, is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Kills Four, Damages Roads, Houses in Central Philippines
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake hit the central Philippines, killing at least four people and injuring 15 and damaging roads, bridges and houses, a civil defense official said today. The earthquake, which measured 6.2 on the Richter scale, struck Thursday at 4:47 p.m. and was followed by five aftershocks, said Julio Sabit of the Institute of Volcanology and Seismology. Preliminary readings indicated the quake was centered just outside Kalibo on central Panay Island, 260 miles south of Manila. The quake was felt from the northern tip of Mindanao Island to Manila on Luzon Island, Sabit said. Four people were killed in Kulasi, a town in Antique province, said Rodrigo Roldan, regional director of civil defense in the city of Iloilo. No further details of the deaths were immediately available. Roldan said 15 other people were hospitalized for cuts and fractures suffered after several houses collapsed. The quake also caused a landslide in Kulasi, he said. The earthquake partially damaged a movie house, cracked the walls of a Roman Catholic church, and toppled the head of a statue of Jesus Christ in the town center of Kalibo, Roldan said. It damaged roads and bridges in the Kulasi and another town, Balite, and partially destroyed the wharf in Altavas. It also destroyed a rural health center and a rice mill in Balite. Roldan said churches in the towns of Makato and Quartero also were damaged. The Richter scale is a gauge of energy released by an earthquake, as measured by ground motion recorded on a seismograph. An earthquake measuring 6 is capable of causing severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: House Votes to Charge Large Landowners Full Price for Water
DOC.TEXT: Owners of huge farms in the West who have gotten rich by using water subsidized by the federal government will have to pay full price if legislation approved by the House becomes law. The price tag for some producers would be in the millions of dollars, but the bill's author, Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., said, ``It will stop the raid on the federal treasury.'' ``This was about excesses,'' Miller said Thursday after the House passed his bill. ``This was about people who pushed the Congress too far looking for special treatment.'' The federal government has been building dams in the West since the early part of the century to supply water for farming. Miller attached his amendment to a water projects bill that authorized spending for modifications to the Buffalo Bill Dam and reservoir in Wyoming. Basically, it strengthens the Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 by defining ``farm'' and ``farm operation'' in greater detail for determining eligibility for cheap water. The original legislation said subsidized water could go to farms no larger than 960 acres. However, it left a loophole that allowed corporations to reorganize their property into smaller entities and continue to get cheap water without actually breaking apart their businesses. A farm owner named repeatedly during debate was the J.G. Boswell Co., one of the largest agricultural producers in the nation. The corporation runs a 23,000-acre farm in California's Central Valley, but it continued to get subsidized water legally by reorganizing into an employee-owned company. Under the House bill, Boswell and others who have formed partnerships that send profits to a main office would have to pay full price for water. ``These aren't separate farmers,'' said Miller. ``These are a scheme to continue the flow of federal taxpayer dollars to the land. These are a scheme to start farming the treasury as opposed to farming the land.'' He said 98 percent of the farmers in the program are in compliance with Congress' intent in the law. He said the others were only a handful of people. ``But they're very powerful people,'' he said. ``They're very big in the political contribution business. They're very big at fund-raisers. They're very big in party politics.'' Miller's amendment passed the House by a 316-97 vote. Another amendment offered by Rep. Sam Gejdenson, D-Conn., and approved 338-55, would phase out irrigation subsidies used on crops that are subsidized under agriculture programs. Similar legislation is pending in the Senate. Rep. Charles Pashayan Jr., R-Calif., who opposed the bill, said it would harm small farmers. Its ``result will be to discourage production of that very thing at which Americans are the very best at in the world: namely food and fiber,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: High-Rolling Thrift Executive Falls From Life of Luxury
LaserPhoto DN1
DOC.TEXT: A financial wizard who tumbled from the top of a savings and loan empire in just a few years says the government has made him a scapegoat for the nation's thrift troubles. Donald Dixon said he will plead innocent to 38 counts of a federal indictment, which alleges conspiracy, fraud and furthering racketeering. ``For the moment, the U.S. government is making a scapegoat of me because they're unaccountable for their role in the $500 billion or greater loss the American taxpayer has to pay,'' he said Thursday, shortly after he was freed on a personal recognizance bond by U.S. Magistrate John B. Tolle. Dixon, who had surrendered to the FBI, was forced by federal regulators in 1986 to relinquish control of Vernon Savings and Loan Association, where seven former officers and employees have been convicted of bank fraud charges. Dixon owned the thrift. Prosecutors say Dixon, who lived a life of luxury and hobnobbed with the powerful, was an example, along with his thrift, of the abuses that led S&Ls into disaster. The Dixon case is an effort ``to bring to justice people who break the law, who use savings and loan associations as personal piggy banks and who may have thought they could just walk away free and let the American taxpayer shoulder the cost of their greed,'' said Timothy Ryan, director of the Office of Thrift Supervision in Washington. Dixon is accused of using thousands of dollars from Vernon Savings on pleasure trips, prostitutes and illegal contributions to politicians, including former House Speaker Jim Wright and Jack Kemp, a former Republican congressman from New York who is now secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and Sens. Jake Garn, R-Utah, and Alan Cranston, D-Calif. Dixon flew on corporate jets, relaxed on a corporate yacht and enjoyed a salary and benefits running into the millions with the thrift's money, government attorneys said. Dixon had a California beach house, Rolls Royces and an art collection. He bought his wife $110 bottles of perfume and traveled to the spas and restaurants of Europe. In his home town, Dixon bought tiny Vernon Savings in 1982 after success heading two homebuilding and development companies, Dondi Homes and Raldon Homes. Vernon Savings, in less than four years under Dixon's lead, grew by a staggering 1,600 percent, even though S&Ls are prohibited from growing more than 25 percent per year. It became one of the top 20 Texas thrifts with $1.6 billion in deposits. After moving Vernon's headquarters to Dallas, Dixon offered high rates that attracted depositors from across the country. The deposits were guaranteed for up to $100,000 by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp., and millions of dollars flew in. Vernon went on a lending binge with deposits as new rules allowed S&Ls into commercial developments. Loans also were allowed on projects with little capital behind them and no down payments. Court documents show Vernon officers developed an efficient way to create as much loan-fee income as possible and paid little attention to traditional lending practices. The thrift's executives fudged their required filings with regulators to make it look healthier, the government said. At the end of 1986, Vernon Savings reported a positive net worth of $17 million, which regulators say was actually a negative $350 million. Ninety-six percent of the thrift's loans were overdue. In 1986, federal regulators forced out Dixon. The next year he and other Vernon officials were sued by regulators trying to recover the thrift's losses, and Dixon filed for personal bankruptcy. That case is pending. The charges against Dixon carry a maximum penalty of 190 years in prison and a $9.5 million fine.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Closes Higher, Stock Index Falls
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed higher against the Japanese yen Friday, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell moderately. The dollar ended the week at 154.52 yen, up 0.99 yen from Thursday's close of 153.53 yen. After opening at 154.50 yen, the currency ranged between 154.25 yen and 154.60 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues shed 129.71 points, or 0.40 percent, to close at 32,538.40. The Nikkei index gained 296.34 points Thursday. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds declined to 87.74 points as of 3 p.m. (2 a.m. EDT), down from Thursday's close of 88.09. The yield stood at 7.025 percent, up from the previous day's 6.955 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Composer of ``Brother Can You Spare A Dime'' Dead at 93
DOC.TEXT: Jay Gorney, whose song ``Brother Can You Spare a Dime'' became the musical symbol for the Great Depression years in the United States, has died at age 93. Gorney died Thursday from Parkinson's disease at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged. Gorney composed for the musical theater in the 1920s and 1930s and worked on shows such as ``Merry-Go-Round,'' ``Earl Carroll's Sketch Book,'' ``Touch and Go,'' and ``Meet the People.'' He wrote ``Brother Can You Spare a Dime,'' for the 1932 show ``Americana.'' His film scores included ``Mona Lisa'' and ``They Can't Get You Down.'' Gorney was born on Dec. 12, 1896, in Bialystok, Russia, and emigrated to the United States when he was a child. He and his family settled in Detroit. He worked his way through the University of Michigan by writing school songs and leading school bands. He was admitted to the bar, but gave up law after one year to pursue songwriting full time. Gorney is survived by his wife, Sondra, a daughter and two sons. Funeral services will be private.

DOC.HEAD: Funniest Videos Offers More Grand Prizes
DOC.TEXT: ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' has upped the ante for amateur videomakers. Instead of a single $100,000 grand prize, the ABC-TV program will offer three $100,000 awards in the fall season, entertainment president Robert Iger announced Thursday during the network's annual affiliates convention. While the Sunday night program has become enormously popular, it also has drawn criticism for showing videos of children and animals in potentially dangerous situations. This year's $100,000 grand prize winner went to footage of a man losing his pants while trying to catch a baseball.

DOC.HEAD: Stunt Pilot Killed in Plane Crash
DOC.TEXT: A stunt pilot practicing for an air show was killed when his plane crashed in a field, authorities said. Steven Van Eck, 38, of Zeeland, was practicing maneuvers when his single-engine plane crashed about 12:30 p.m. Thursday, the Ottawa County Sheriff's Department said. Van Eck, the only person aboard, was flying the Kevlar and carbon-fiber plane he planned to use at the Battle Creek International Balloon Championship and Air Show, which begins Saturday, organizers said. A pamphlet about Van Eck said he had won several awards for stunt flying. Authorities said they didn't what caused the crash. The Federal Aviation Administration was investigating.

DOC.HEAD: Fundamentalist Leader Forges Religion Into Potent Force
With PM-Algeria
DOC.TEXT: The philosophy professor who led the fundamentalist Islamic Salvation Front to an unexpected election victory this week has formed the country's most potent political force in less than 17 months. Sheikh Abassi Madani serves as president of the party's 14-man governing council. Almost always clad in white, he can be soft-spoken in private and a fiery orator in public. In March 1989, he created the Islamic Salvation Front after voters backed a new constitution legalizing opposition to the ruling, secular National Liberation Front. The surging Islamic party now claims 650,000 members and 3 million sympathizers, many drawn from the ranks of unemployed youth with limited economic prospects. Madani, 59, and his party want to revolutionize Algerian society, turning the clock back from the failed one-party socialist model the ruling party tried to impose for 28 years. Tuesday's election marked the first free vote since independence from France in 1962. The fundamentalists want to make Algeria an Islamic republic and impose religious law, the Sharia, that would strip women of most of their civil rights. Madani was born in 1931 at Sidi Okba in southern Algeria, a region strong in religious tradition. He studied the Koran and once worked as a truck driver. He obtained his doctorate in philosophy from a British university. Madani has been jailed twice in his life. He took up arms with the National Liberation Front in 1954 against the colonial French rulers. Madani was captured during a failed bomb attack and spent the next seven years in prison. After liberation, Madani criticized the ruling party for abandoning Islam in favor of socialism. But few heard his voice until after socialist leader Houari Boumediene died in 1978. Boumediene's successor, President Chadli Bendjedid, relaxed free speech laws at the same time the Iranian revolution was capturing the imagination of Islamic fundamentalists throughout the Middle East. Madani began a two-year prison in 1982 for organizing a fundamentalist protest. After he was freed, he renewed his efforts to place fundamentalist imams in the country's 10,000 mosques. The Islamic Salvation Front has targeted the country's schools and universities for membership and succeeded in forcing many female students and teachers to wear the hijab, or Islamic scarf. It also seeks adherents in the Algerian army. Top brass recently forbade soldiers to wear beards, a badge of fundamentalism. But, as Madani noted Wednesday, many in the army voted for his party anyway.

DOC.HEAD: Study Says Cable TV Rates Rising at Twice the Inflation Rate
DOC.TEXT: Basic cable television rates climbed at twice the rate of inflation last year, according to a report that refueled the drive in Congress to re-regulate subscriber charges. The prices for the lowest-cost basic service and most popular cable services in 1989 increased an average of 10 percent, from $14.50 to $15.95, the congressional General Accounting Office said. The total average cable bill went up 5 percent, from $25 to $26.36. The inflation rate was 4 percent to 5 percent rate for the year, said GAO, the investigative arm of Congress. GAO reported last year that basic cable rates increased 29 percent from December 1986 to October 1988. Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., who requested the GAO survey, said the results showed that Congress ``must consider legislation that will rein in the renegade operators'' in the cable industry. He said the report should erase ``any lingering doubts on the need to move forward'' with legislation that ``enhances competition and ensures reasonable rates.'' The House Energy and Commerce telecommunications and finance subcommittee, which Markey chairs, is expected to approve a cable regulation bill later this month. A Senate subcommittee approved its own bill last week calling for more competition for cable and renewed rate regulation of mostly basic, over-the-air broadcast channels. The National Cable Television Association said the GAO report ``reconfirms that the average cable subscriber's monthly bill increased at about the rate of inflation in 1989, and is still further evidence that cable rate increases have leveled off.'' It said cable ``is still a very good buy.'' But Gene Kimmelman, legislative director of the Consumer Federation of America, said the leveling off, if any, was being achieved by cable operators lowering the costs of premium services such as HBO and Showtime, while raising basic rates. ``But you have to have basic to get premium,'' Kimmelman said. ``That's where they've got you over a barrel.'' Between Nov. 30, 1986, and Dec. 31, 1989, rates for the lowest-priced and most popular service increased by 43 percent, from an average $11.14 to $15.95 per subscriber, GAO said. Average total cable bills went up 21 percent, from $21.78 to $26.36 during that period. About 20 percent of the subscribers to either the most popular or lowest priced service experienced price increases in the three years greater than 60 percent, GAO said. From 1984 through 1989, the average increase was 65 percent. During 1989 the number of channels available to cable subscribers increased by one or two, on average. Since the cable industry was deregulated in November 1986, the average number of basic channels available has risen from 24 to 31 channels. GAO said cable systems that were regulated in November 1986 had greater increases through last December than the 24 percent of the nation's cable TV systems that were not regulated in November 1986. The GAO based its results on questionnaires returned from 1,530 of the nation's approximately 9,000 cable systems.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney Says Simon's Presidential Campaign Used Senate Employees
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer is asking the Senate Ethics Committee to investigate Sen. Paul Simon's hiring practices, but a spokeswoman for the Illinois Democrat says the request is a partisan ruse. In his 13-page complaint, John J. Curry Jr. of Chicago says several employees were hired in Simon's Senate office and given campaign duties while he ran for president in 1987-88. Once his bid for the Democratic nomination ended, so did the Senate jobs, Curry says. He also says some of Simon's top Senate aides were given significant campaign roles but never lost their public salaries and in some cases received raises. The attorney said his allegations are based on Senate and federal election records. He lists names, dates and amounts of money. Curry filed a separate complaint with the Federal Election Commission, alleging an improper relationship between Simon's presidential campaign and a political action committee the senator once headed, called the Democracy Fund. Ellen Golin, spokeswoman for Simon's Senate re-election campaign, called the Ethics Committee complaint ``part of the Republican dirty tricks strategy.'' She said the committee gave Simon a copy of the complaint in late May, and he is preparing a response. ``There are in excess of 100 erroneous allegations there,'' Golin said Thursday. ``This lawyer didn't have concern for the facts.'' In an interview, Curry acknowledged being a Republican but said his decision to file the complaint was not part of an organized Republican effort to discredit Simon. He said he decided to study the documents after hearing allegations from others. Curry's complaint, dated April 11, says: ``Sen. Simon, directly or indirectly, allowed his official Senate allowances and staff to be used to supplement the limited financial resources available'' to his presidential campaign. ``It appears,'' the complaint says, ``that Sen. Simon acted negligently with respect to his obligation as a senator to observe the strictures of both federal law and the standing rules of the Senate.'' The Ethics Committee's chief attorney, Wilson Abney, would not comment on the complaint. Curry released a letter from Abney that shows the committee received the complaint. Besides payroll allegations, the complaint says at least five of Simon's Senate employees lent money or services to his presidential campaign. It also questions whether some Senate-financed plane trips taken by Simon and his staff were actually related to his campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Non-farm Lawmakers Oppose Subsidy Payments to Farmers
DOC.TEXT: Some non-farm area lawmakers are ready to pounce on the 1990 farm bill approved by the House Agriculture Committee because they oppose paying subsidies to farmers who already make a decent living. But committee Chairman Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, said, ``This is a farm bill that I will be proud to defend on the House floor and it's one that deserves the support of my House colleagues.'' Debate is likely to begin the week of June 25. Ready to attack is a group called the Coalition for Common Sense Agriculture. Led by Reps. Richard Armey, R-Texas, and Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., the group of non-farm area lawmakers oppose paying thousands of dollars in subsidies to farmers whose earnings are higher than the average taxpayer. ``Though the House Agriculture Committee has made progress by imposing a freeze on subsidies, it is clear that some parts of the 1990 farm bill do a disservice to American taxpayers,'' Armey and Schumer said Thursday in a joint statement. Rep. Silvio Conte of Massachusetts, the ranking Republican on the Appropriations Committee, already has introduced a bill that attacks the farm payment programs by limiting farmers to $50,000 a year in government payments. ``Too much of the farm budget is going to wealthy corporate farms, not enough to family farmers, and too much of the money does nothing to improve the supply and price of food for Americans,'' Schumer and Armey's statement said. ``These trends need to change so that our agriculture policy reflects common sense rather than special interests.'' Committee members have argued vehemently that government programs supporting farmers stabilize food prices and help the government manage the industry. The Agriculture Committee completed work on the bill with a marathon session beginning Wednesday and ending early Thursday morning in which lawmakers added changes in conservation measures to a host of other programs, passed weeks earlier, that guide agriculture policy for the next five years. De la Garza said the bill assures farmers a reasonable income but meets tight federal budget demands. ``It also gives farmers more flexibility to plant according to market signals, it provides authority for expanded food safety research and it allows for modest increases in our domestic food assistance programs,'' de la Garza said. He said it would protect U.S. competitiveness in the world market and prevent large stockpiles of surplus food. ``I am particularly proud of the committee's conservation package,'' he said, characterizing it as a balance between agriculture production needs and environmental quality goals. Major provisions of the bill include: _A freeze on target prices for cotton, rice, wheat and feed grains. _Loan rates of $5.25 a bushel for soybeans during 1991-92 with possible increases in subsequent years. _A flexibility program that allows farmers who grow government supported crops to transfer 25 percent of their acreage into an experimental crop without losing that acreage in calculations for price supports. _A dairy program that sets a minimum support level of $10.10 per hundred pounds of milk. _Continuation of present peanut, sugar, honey, wool and mohair programs. _A trade program that allows donation of commodities to the world's poorest countries, puts deadlines on multi-year agreements and forgives loans to the poorest countries. It also would authorize assistance to private voluntary organizations and cooperatives in administering food programs and reauthorize the Food for Progress program, which donates food to countries that encourage private enterprise and agricultural reform. _A requirement that the government spend at least $500 million annually in the Export Enhancement Program, which helps U.S. commodities compete with other countries in the world market. _Availability of $5 billion annually for credit guarantees on commodity sales to foreign countries under the government's six to 36-month credit program known as GSM-102.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Negotiators Setting Up Bitter Floor Fight on Campaign Spending
DOC.TEXT: Senate negotiators, unable to agree on campaign spending ceilings, are likely setting up a bitter fight before the Fourth of July recess. ``We're hung up on the same point we have been hung up on all along,'' Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., said after a 90-minute meeting Thursday. ``We're just going to have to buck it up'' to the Senate's two party leaders, George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Bob Dole, R-Kan. Boren said if negotiators cannot break the deadlock on spending limits in the next few days, he advocated bringing the issue to the full Senate. `We may need to take some votes to get the negotiations going forward,'' he said. Mitchell had vowed earlier to bring a Democratic campaign finance bill to the floor for action within the next two weeks, with or without a compromise. Both Mitchell and Dole were expected to meet with their negotiating teams Friday. Teams of five Republicans and five Democrats appointed by Mitchell and Dole agreed on several issues that had divided them in the past four weeks of closed-door negotiations.. Sen. Don Nickles, R-Okla., said a majority of Republicans may now be willing to consider a package that includes a ceiling on how much candidates can raise from outside their states, but with no ceiling on in-state contributions. The same concept was proposed in March by a task force of academic experts and campaign professionals appointed by Mitchell and Dole. But Republicans balked at any kind of ceiling on contributions and Democrats insisted on limits in bills the two parties brought to the Senate floor last month. Boren said Democrats are willing to abandon their call for a public financing scheme in which taxpayers could voluntarily pay an extra $3 a year when filling out their returns to pay for about half the cost of congressional campaigns. He also said Democrats are willing to outlaw political action committees, as the Republicans proposed in their bill, and at least make unions publicly disclose the estimated $45 million in unreported funds they spend on get-out-the-vote and other political efforts. However, he said all those concessions are conditional upon Republicans accepting some kind of spending limit. ``Everybody on the Democratic side made it clear we are not going to let public financing or zeroing out PACs stand in the way of an agreement,'' Boren said. ``But we cannot yield on overall spending limits.'' Both Boren and Nickles acknowledged that the rough agreements on specific issues forged by the negotiators, particularly a cap on aggregate contributions from outside a candidate's state, lack unanimous support on either side. ``There's still a lot of flexibility,'' Nickles said. ``There's not too many people falling on swords on too many issues.''

DOC.HEAD: Barry Speech Brought No Apparent Movement Toward Plea Bargain
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry's announcement that he will not run for a fourth term brought ``no movement at all'' toward a plea bargain agreement, a source close to the defense team says. Jury selection is drawing to a close in Barry's cocaine and perjury trial with no sign of a settlement in the case. Jury selection began June 4 and U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson has said the panel of 12 jurors plus six alternates will be seated Monday. The pool of prospective jurors now stands at 83 in a process that was ending at mid-day today. ABC News and The Washington Post filed a motion Thursday objecting to being excluded from a portion of the jury selection process. Challenges by lawyers in the case to particular jurors are taking place in private bench conferences. The judge then announces which prospective jurors have been excused from possible jury duty, but the reasons are not given. ABC and the Post argue that such an approach impinges on the First Amendment. ``We're just getting ready for trial,'' Barry lawyer R. Kenneth Mundy said as he left court Thursday. Jesse Jackson called on Mundy and U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens Mundy to resume plea-bargain negotiations. ``We certainly hope ... that there will be a move toward the bargaining table to work out some honorable agreement under the law,'' Jackson said after a meeting with local ministers. ``The contrition of that speech cannot be ignored. The mayor has admitted his problem ... and expressed his regret.'' Barry's supporters have said the mayor bowed out of the race in part because he hoped such a move would elicit sympathy from the jury or push his attorney and Stephens to reach an agreement. Opening statements are scheduled for Tuesday. Stephens has said Barry's political plans would not affect his determination to proceed to trial. The Washington Times reported today that Stephens plans to present evidence of fraud and corruption in city government to a new grand jury to be seated next month, raising the possibility of new charges against Barry and other city officials. The mayor has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor charge of cocaine conspiracy, and three felony charges of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use. Barry, 54, went on local television Wednesday night to announce his long-rumored decision not to run for a fourth, four-year term. That opens up the mayor's race to a field that includes the district's delegate to Congress, Walter Fauntroy, as well as two city councilmen.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Approves Budget That's Not a Budget
DOC.TEXT: The Senate approved a fiscal 1991 budget, sort of. By voice vote late Thursday, the Senate passed a budget resolution chock full of numbers and fancy legislative language. But rather than an attempt at setting fiscal policy, the vote was a procedural step toward preventing a backlog of legislation while Congress and the White House engage in a budget summit. Under Senate rules, the annual spending bills needed for the operation of government agencies cannot be considered until a final budget resolution is adopted. The House on May 1 approved a $1.2 trillion budget spelling out federal spending priorities, including a shift from military spending to domestic programs. The Senate then stopped short because lawmakers thought it would hamper the bipartisan budget talks. ``This is simply an instrument by which we allow the appropriations committees to move forward under Senate rules and procedure,'' said Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn. The process ``is not over by a long shot,'' he said. ``A very complicated matter but not a very important event,'' said Sen. Pete V. Domenici, R-N.M., ranking Republican on the Budget Committee. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., was less generous. ``It is fundamentally a giving up on the budget process,'' he said. The Senate resolution approved Thursday sets a $503 billion cap, the same as this year, on spending for domestic and defense programs outside of entitlements and interest on the national debt. The resolution includes language assuming the number will be changed and policy decisions inserted once the budget talks with the White House are concluded. Both the House and Senate must agree on a single budget resolution for it to become binding on the two chambers. It doesn't require the president's signature. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said Thursday the House did not intend to abandon its plan. House-Senate talks are expected to begin next week, even as the budget summit continues.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Moves to Restrict Dial-a-Porn Access
DOC.TEXT: There are now new federal rules intended to keep kids from listening to dial-a-porn services. Under the regulations adopted Thursday by the Federal Communications Commission, dial-a-porn companies must require either credit card payments, access codes or scrambling, they must notify phone companies of the adult service, and the calls must show up on customers' phone bills. Phone companies, where possible, are required to block access to the adult services unless a customer asks to have access to them. The new rules are designed to comply with a 1989 Supreme Court ruling that said consenting adults may have access to indecent, but not obscene, commercial sex messages by telephone. The high court threw out a law passed by Congress that had banned phone sex messages. In other 5-0 votes, the commission: _Proposed strict disclosure and access rules for companies that provide ``dial 0'' operator services to the traveling public. _Proposed rules that would deny broadcast and other communications licenses to convicted drug users who have been denied federal benefits by a judge. In its dial-a-porn decision, the commission readopted rules it had imposed in 1987. Federal law at that time said sex messages could be transmitted to consenting adults as long as dial-a-porn providers adopted FCC rules to deny access to minors. But Congress, fearing that enterprising youths still could gain access to telephone sex messages, banned such services outright in April 1988. The congressional action negated the 1987 FCC rules. In overturning that law, the Supreme Court said the statute could apply only to commercial material that was judged obscene _ meaning ``patently offensive'' and without redeeming value _ not merely indecent. FCC Chairman Alfred Sikes, noting the constitutional concerns raised by such laws, said the FCC's ruling Thursday was ``an act of humanity by civilized people.'' Regarding operator-services companies, the commission said it was acting because its survey earlier this year found significant non-compliance with industrywide rules the FCC issued a little more than a year ago. The proposed rules on the companies would include not only the companies that contract with long-distance carriers to provide pay phone and hotel service, but also the owners of the business premises themselves.

DOC.HEAD: Judiciary Panel OKs Balanced-Budget Provision
DOC.TEXT: A constitutional amendment that would require a balanced federal budget has won approval from the Senate Judiciary Committee. The panel voted 11-3 on Thursday to send the amendment to the full Senate. If approved by two-thirds of the Senate and the House, and then by 38 states, the amendment would prohibit federal spending from exceeding revenues except in time of war or if both chambers waive the requirement by a 60 percent vote. The amendment also would require that a majority of each chamber of Congress _ instead of just a majority of those present and voting _ approve any tax increase. The amendment would take effect in the second fiscal year after ratification. Balanced-budget amendments have been approved before by the committee. The provision most recently was subjected to a full Senate vote in 1986 and failed by one vote. It passed the Senate in 1982 but died in the House. Thursday's action came as House, Senate and White House negotiators continued their budget ``summit'' in the Capitol, aimed at reducing the federal deficit. Democrats and Republicans have been unable to agree on how to bring the fiscal gap below $100 billion.
DOC.HEAD: Bush Proclamation Praises Fathers
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has recognized America's fathers as playing ``a very important role in shaping the character of our nation.'' In a proclamation noting Sunday's celebration of Fathers Day, Bush said Thursday the day is a time to ``thank dads everywhere for all they do.'' ``As children, we cannot fully fathom the depth of our father's love for us. Neither can we fully realize the weight of his responsibilities,'' said the president, himself a father of five and grandfather of 12. Children rarely ``perceive in their father's tender gaze the worries, frustrations and concerns'' that are a part of parenting, the proclamation said. ``With each passing year, and especially as we have children of our own, we become ever more grateful for our father's love and discipline, and for the many sacrifices he has made. We begin to see clearly how being a father requires faith and fortitude,'' Bush said. Father's Day is a time to ``thank dads everywhere for all they do, throughout the year, for our families and country,'' Bush said.
DOC.HEAD: Democrats Abandon Second Attempt to Override
DOC.TEXT: Senate Democrats have dropped the idea of trying to override President Bush's veto of the $2 billion Amtrak bill. The House last week voted overwhelmingly to override but on Tuesday the Senate failed to get the two-thirds majority needed to pass the bill over the president's objections. The vote would have been 65-35, except Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, voted on the president's side so that he could, under Senate rules, ask for a reconsideration of the vote. Only members of the winning side may ask for a second look, and Mitchell promptly did so. But apparently the Democrats could not find the two additional votes they needed. Sen. J. James Exon, D-Nebr., chairman of the Commerce Committee's subcommittee on surface transportation, said Thursday night that the Democrats would propose a new bill deleting the provision which drew the veto, an expansion of Interstate Commerce Commission power to regulate railroad takeovers. Bush has vetoed 11 bills, and has yet to be overridden by Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Tar Balls Head to Shore From Spill That Will Get Oil-Eating Bacteria
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Norwegian hearing scheduled to resume at 10 a.m. EDT. Dispersal of oil-eating bacteria set to begin at 10:30 a.m. EDT.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HT1
DOC.TEXT: Gulf Coast residents braced for tar balls to wash ashore today from a 30-mile oil slick left by the burning Mega Borg. No one knew Thursday where the globs of tar would wash up, but the west end of Galveston was a likely spot, Coast Guard Capt. Thomas Greene said. State officials were to dump oil-eating bacteria on the brown slick today. The Norwegian supertanker continued to spew oil today from a tank ruptured by a fire whose cause is the subject of a hearing in its third day. The Mega Borg's chief engineer said Thursday at the hearing that one of the ship's pumps had been leaking fuel about six hours before the first explosion rocked the ship late last Friday and triggered a series of fiery blasts. Norway consul general Erik Leikvang, who convened the hearing in Galveston, played down the information, saying, ``The leak may seem an obvious factor to some, but it may not be obvious to the experts.'' Some tar balls ranging from 1 foot to 18 inches in diameter washed ashore Thursday on the west end of Galveston. Officials could not say whether they occurred naturally, came from previous spills or washed in from the Mega Borg. ``Tar balls are ugly but they're not that environmentally damaging,'' said B.J. ``Buck'' Wynne III, chairman of the Texas Water Commission. Texas Land Commissioner Garry Mauro said 500 volunteers were prepared to scour beaches. Mauro and Wynne were to head the experimental operation to spread oil-eating bacteria on the spill. The process, called bioremediation, uses naturally occurring bacteria to reduce oil to an emulsion of fatty acids that are consumed by marine life. Bioremediation has been used in waste spills, but not in open waters to clean up oil, officials said. The Mega Borg, which was carrying 38 million gallons of light African crude, has lost about 3 million gallons since the explosion, but officials said most of that has either burned or evaporated.
