Salvage crews said they skimmed more than 76,000 gallons of oil from the waters around the vessel 57 miles from Galveston. Four fireboats showered the Mega Borg with water cannons and the rear section remained awash. The flow of oil from a hole in the vessel's 5.5 million center tank apparently slackened, officials said. Salvage crews today planned to transfer oil from the ruptured tank into an empty tank to stop the flow, cut off the fuel to the fire and correct the listing of the ship. Two men were killed in the explosion and two others who remain missing are believed to be dead. Seventeen others were injured, none seriously. The ship's chief engineer, Balinder Singh, told the Norwegian maritime inquiry that a pump, located in the pump room where the explosion is believed to have originated, leaked as the tanker's oil was being transferred to a smaller ship. He said he stopped the leak by tightening a coupling about six hours before the explosion. Lars Foyen, a representative of Det Norske Veritas, the Norwegian equivalent of the American Bureau of Shipping, testified that 14 pieces of machinery, including pumps used to transfer the oil cargo, were overdue for inspection. Aasmund Saglokken, a former tanker captain and field expert on the investigative board, said the leak should not be blown out of proportion. ``We can't draw any conclusions from this,'' Saglokken said.

DOC.HEAD: Quebec Court Imposes Long Sentences in Cocaine Case
DOC.TEXT: A Canadian court has sent a warning to drug traffickers by imposing stiff jail sentences of up to 25 years on a New Yorker and two Colombians who smuggled millions of dollars worth of cocaine into the country. Prosecutors say the case involved the biggest cocaine seizure in the country's history. ``A strong and clear message should be sent to anyone _ Canadian or not _ who gets involved with hard-drug offenses: that they will not be treated leniently in Canada,'' Justice Jacques Ducros of Quebec Superior Court said Thursday. He also said he was imposing long sentences because of the large quantity of drugs involved in the seizure. At the time of the arrests, police seized cocaine estimated to be worth between $200 million and $250 million. The three were arrested April 1989 after undercover police intercepted a shipment of 1,100 pounds of cocaine flown from Colombia to Montreal and replaced most of the drug with brown sugar in an elaborate sting operation. One defendant, 24-year-old Richardo Delgado Marquez of New York, was sentenced Thursday to 25 years for conspiracy. He also received 10 years for possessing cocaine for the purpose of trafficking. Delgado Marquez has spent much of his life in Colombia. A second defendant, 27-year-old Fernando William Mendoza Salazar of Colombia, received 22 years in prison on charges of conspiracy. He was sentenced to 10 years for possession of cocaine as well. Flor E. Mery-Correa, 32, was sentenced to 18 years in prison for conspiracy and 10 years for possession of cocaine for the purpose of trafficking. She lives in Medellin, Colombia, that country's drug-trafficking capital. Their sentences are to be served concurrently, and defense lawyers said they plan to appeal. The trio was found guilty two weeks ago. Two pilots involved in the trafficking operation were each sentenced in November to 22 years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Strengthens Against Yen, Share Prices Fall
DOC.TEXT: The dollar strengthened against the Japanese yen today, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell moderately. The dollar closed the week at 154.52 yen, up 0.99 yen from Thursday's close of 153.53 yen. After opening at 154.50 yen, it ranged between 154.25 yen and 154.60 yen. About $7.44 billion changed hands in spot trading, down from Thursday's $15.9 billion. The dollar opened higher after its overnight advance against most major currencies on overseas markets except New York, where it closed at 154.20 yen, down from 154.75 yen on Wednesday. The dollar then stayed in a narrow range as many traders stayed on the sidelines, said Masahiro Yamagida, a dealer with Sanwa Bank. ``Everyone is basically awaiting the release of U.S. trade figures,'' said Kozo Yoshida of Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. The U.S. Commerce Department was to announce the nation's merchandise trade figures for April later today. Some traders said they expected the U.S. trade deficit would decline significantly from the previous month's larger-than-expected $8.45 billion deficit. In the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 129.71 points, or 0.40 percent, to close the week at 32,538.40. The Nikkei index rose 296.34 points on Thursday. Toshiyuki Nishiguchi, an analyst with Daiwa Securities, said the yen's weakness and rising interest rates depressed many investors, prompting small-lot selling. He said the day's trading was thin without fresh incentives. Volume traded on the market's first section totaled 450 million shares, unchanged from the previous day. In bond dealings, benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 87.79 points, down from Thursday's close of 88.09. Their yield rose to 7.015 percent from the previous day's 6.955 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Tot's Wild Ride Leaves Mom Gasping, Him Laughing
DOC.TEXT: It'll be a long time before Dana King gets to borrow his mother's car again. Maybe about a dozen years _ when he's old enough to drive it. The 3-year-old boy took a wild ride through his neighborhood Thursday afternoon when he climbed into his mother's car, which was parked on a steep hill in front of their house, and shifted it into neutral. ``I heard the horn, I went out and it was halfway down the hill,'' said his shocked mother, Brenda King, 24. ``I was terrified. I thought I had lost him.'' The car, which traveled about 300 yards, went down the street, jumped a curb, knocked over a fire hydrant and sent water spraying, vaulted a construction ditch, skimmed past a house, hit a railing and stopped halfway across a retaining wall with the front half hanging six feet off the ground. Although his mother was shaken and breathless, Dana came off without a scratch. In fact, she said, he was laughing.

DOC.HEAD: Romanian Opposition Leader Detained By Miners
With PM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A gang of miners attacking government opponents in Romania's capital stormed the house of an opposition leader, ransacked the home, beat his colleagues and briefly detained him, he said today. Ion Ratiu, head of the Romanian National Peasant Party, told British Broadcasting Corp. television that he had fled his home when the trouble in Bucharest started, and returned after receiving assurances from the government that he would be safe. But shortly after Ratiu returned Thursday night, a gang of miners broke in, beat up his associates and took him away. He was later released. ``When they caught me they said, `Oh, we've got you, criminal.' And I said, `Why do you say that I'm a criminal?' I didn't show any fear and probably that is what saved me from being roughed up,'' Ratiu said. The television showed pictures of Ratiu's home in shambles, furniture turned over and papers strewn across the floor. Many personal belongings had been stolen, the report said. Late Thursday night, Ratiu's son, Nicolae, called Western news agencies in London to report the attack. He said men who claimed to be police were operating with the miners. In Bucharest, Health Ministry officials said Thursday that at least five people were killed and 350 injured in two days of violence between supporters and opponents of the governing National Salvation Front. The front, largely composed of former Communists, spearheaded the December revolution that toppled former dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. It is headed by President-elect Ion Iliescu, whose appeal for help brought the miners into Bucharest Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Roadblocks May Be Slow to Go Up Despite Court Ruling
With PM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Michigan motorists won't see sobriety checkpoints on the state's roads anytime soon, even though the U.S. Supreme Court approved their use. Bethany Goodman, executive director of the Michigan chapter of Mothers Against Drunk Driving, said she had hoped Thursday's 6-3 ruling would mean roadblocks could be used by the Fourth of July weekend. ``I believe that a lot of lives would have been saved had a stop not been put on the implementation of sobriety check lanes,'' she said, ``and the sooner the better that we get these things implemented.'' But the issue first returns to the Michigan Court of Appeals to determine if the tactic violates the state constitution. ``We've always considered our chances under the Michigan Constitution were better than under the U.S. Constitution,'' said Mark Granzotto, general counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union in Michigan. The organization challenged the checkpoints on behalf of six lawmakers. The appeals court could take a year or more to rule, MADD legal counsel Michael Rizik Jr. said. The checkpoints were used just once in Michigan, in May 1986 under an executive order from Gov. James Blanchard. Wayne County Circuit Court Judge Michael Stacey quickly barred them with an injunction. ``I hope everyone understands how dangerous and precedent-setting the (Supreme Court) decision is,'' said Howard Simon, executive director of the Michigan ACLU. Checkpoint supporters say they will be an effective tool in fighting drunken driving, which killed 705 people in Michigan in 1988, the last full year for which the state police had figures. Critics say other methods of catching drunken drivers or keeping them off the road are more efficient. Dissenting Supreme Court Justice John Paul Stevens called checkpoints ``elaborate, and disquieting, publicity stunts'' that do little if anything to improve highway safety. In Michigan's only checkpoint, in May 1986 on a state highway, 126 drivers were stopped. Of two detained for further examination, one was arrested. An appeals court upheld Stacey's ruling barring the checkpoints. The Michigan Supreme Court declined to step in and state Attorney General Frank Kelley asked the U.S. Supreme Court to hear the case. ``I was confident from the beginning that the stopping and observing of drivers at check lanes is no more a constitutional intrusion of privacy than security checks at airports and public buildings such as the Supreme Court,'' Kelley said. Democratic state Rep. Morris Hood, who has sponsored a bill that would prohibit all Michigan law enforcement agencies from setting up checkpoints, countered, ``An intrusion is an intrusion.'' ``There is no such thing as minimal intrusion,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Hessman To Leave ``Head of the Class''
DOC.TEXT: Howard Hessman has quit his starring role in ABC's comedy series ``Head of the Class.'' The actor will ``pursue various non-series projects,'' ABC said in a statement Thursday. He previously co-starred in shows such as ``One Day At a Time.'' Hessman played teacher Charlie Moore on the ABC program about a honors class for four years. His character will be eliminated, the network said. ``Head of the Class'' is not on ABC's fall schedule. It is set to begin production this summer as a back-up series.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Minister In Good Condition After Hospitalized For Chest Pains
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister David Levy was in good condition today after being hospitalized in a cardiac intensive care unit for chest pains, hospital officials said. Tests showed that the 52-year-old Levy did not have a heart attack, said Dr. Udi Cantor of Haemek Hospital in the northern town of Afula. Levy arrived at the hospital late Thursday from his home in nearby Beit Shean. Dozens of well-wishers called the hospital, but doctors ordered that no phone calls be transferred to the foreign minister's room. ``But if Baker calls, we will transfer the call,'' Cantor added. He was referring to U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III who, in testimony Wednesday, recited the White House telephone number and urged Israeli officials to call ``when you're serious about peace.'' An Israel radio reporter ended a report on Levy today with the remarks: ``For the information of Secretary Baker, the number here is Afula 06-524-141.'' The Moroccan-born Levy, a fiery orator, is regarded as a possible successor to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir in the right-wing Likud bloc.

DOC.HEAD: Risky Business: High Schoolers' Sex Habits, Ignorance Could Mean Trouble
DOC.TEXT: A ``large number'' of American high school students are at risk of AIDS because of their drug use and sexual practices, according to federal health researchers looking at 42 new youth surveys. The surveys, taken in schools in various cities and states, also found continued ignorance among a large number of high schoolers regarding what does and doesn't cause AIDS. For example, in most surveys, less than half the kids knew that mosquito bites don't cause the disease. ``The levels of misinformation are truly concerning, but not knowing that a mosquito bite does not cause AIDS doesn't put a student at risk for AIDS,'' said Dr. Laura Kann of the Centers for Disease Control. ``We are most concerned about the findings related to sex and drug use.'' The 1989 surveys reported Thursday by the CDC were conducted in 30 states, 10 U.S. cities and two U.S. territories. Between 7 percent and 40 percent of the students reported having four or more sex partners. Between 2 percent and 5 percent said they had injected cocaine, heroin or other intravenous drugs. Since the human immunodeficiency virus which causes AIDS is spread through sex and sharing of drug needles, Kann said: ``There are a large number of students throughout the United States that are at risk for HIV infection because of the behaviors they practice. ``We need to do a better job of providing students with HIV education that would help them avoid behaviors that put them at risk.'' The surveys indicated at least some students knew they were taking risks. Between 93 percent and 100 percent in the various surveys knew that AIDS can be transmitted by drug needles, and between 74 percent and 98 percent knew that it can be spread by sex without use of condoms. Misconceptions about AIDS are still common. Only 32 percent to 75 percent in the various surveys said correctly that AIDS cannot be acquired by giving blood. Between 22 percent and 67 percent knew that AIDS doesn't come from mosquito bites. And between 44 percent and 85 percent knew that public toilets don't spread AIDS. The findings, both in behavior and awareness, were similar to those in a smaller group of surveys conducted in 1988. The surveys from the participating cities and states do not represent a national sampling. And state-by-state comparisons of the results are not statistically relevant, the Atlanta-based CDC said, because different locations reported different response rates and some may have asked only some questions to some students.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``I consider it the PG version ... This is the first rap concert I've been to and I'm kind of enjoying it. I like the beat.'' _ Police Chief Wayne Bolden of Gwinnett County, Ga., after a club appearance of the 2 Live Crew, who were warned not to perform songs from their sexually explicit album, ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be.''

``Everybody seems to understand that we have to get this done before the elections in November. ... You don't have to be a rocket scientist to see what's driving this thing.'' _ Sen. Dale Bumpers, D-Ark., on efforts in Congress to pass a proposed amendment to the Constitution that would prohibit flag burning.

``We are appealing to the Congress, to the government and to the people of the United States of America to come to our aid ... This is an SOS call. Save our souls.'' _ Pentecostal Bishop W. Nah Dixon, leading a march of church leaders and protesters to the U.S. Embassy in Monrovia, Liberia, that asked for American peacekeeping troops to help end a 5{-month tribal war.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Spill Spreads To Major Port
DOC.TEXT: A huge oil slick caused by the collision of two freighters has floated near the mouth of a leading northeastern port, officials said today. The 40-square-mile slick is near the Dalian port and is continuing to move east in the direction of North Korea, Zhu Li of the Dalian Marine Safety Supervision Bureau said in a telephone interview. The State Oceanography Bureau in Beijing said it was China's largest oil spill ever from an ocean vessel, but it could not assess the seriousness of the environmental damage. The spill has received little attention in the official media and there has been no outcry over responsibility. The spill was caused by the June 8 collision of two Japanese-owned freighters in the Bohai Gulf, east of Tianjin. One vessel, the Maya 8, sank and began leaking its fuel oil. It was not carrying any cargo. The second ship, the Spring Falcon, loaded with magnesium ore, rescued the Maya 8's crew and continued its journey to Japan. Both the Oceanography Bureau and the Marine Safety Supervision Bureau said they did not know how much oil the Maya 8 was carrying. The People's Daily, which reported the slick's spread to near Dalian, said that as of Thursday oil continued to leak from the vessel but the flow had slowed. The slick near Dalian appeared to be only one portion of the oil leak. Initial reports after the collision said oil was covering more than 480 square miles. Ms. Zhu said she did not know whether the spill would affect shipping and fishing in the gulf. She said that by cutting off the oxygen supply to the water, the oil spill had produced a red tide _ a proliferation of red organisms that can harm fish and plant life. Efforts are being made to clean up the oil, she said, but she could give no details. She did not know the cost of the cleanup.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rejects Prosecutors' Stand on Seized Noriega Assets
DOC.TEXT: The government must return millions of dollars of Manuel Noriega's assets unless it can prove he obtained them illegally, a federal judge has ruled. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler on Thursday rejected prosecutors' claims that the U.S.-ordered seizure of at least $20 million in Noriega's assets was not subject to normal legal review because it involved treaties with third countries. ``The power of the executive to deal with foreign governments is unquestionably great, but it does not extend so far as to impinge on a criminal defendant's right to due process,'' the judge said. Hoeveler warned that if the U.S. attorney's office balks at having to prove the money was illegally obtained, he will order it released. The judge set a hearing for Wednesday. The issue arose when Noriega's attorneys asked to withdraw from the case, saying they could no longer work because the government had taken all of the former Panamanian leader's assets. Prosecutors tried to pay the defense attorneys directly, but the deal fell through. The defense attorneys then asked the judge to order the government to release the assets so they could pursue the expensive case. The defense has estimated the government will spend almost $40 million on the Noriega trial, and says it will need about $5 million. Diane Cossin, spokeswoman for the U.S. attorney's office, said prosecutors had no immediate comment. Defense attorneys hailed the ruling. ``It's a huge victory,'' lead Noriega attorney Frank Rubino said. ``This is a unique order _ he's saying he will order this money freed if the government doesn't want to act.'' The judge said the failure of the government to justify the seizures effectively deprives Noriega of his constitutional right to counsel and protections against illegal search and seizure. The government acknowledges freezing 27 Noriega-linked bank accounts valued at about $20 million. During the December invasion of Panama, troops also found $5.8 million in cash in Noriega's quarters, which it turned over to the new Panamanian government. The defense says U.S. troops also took homes, cars and other property. Rubino said he welcomed the chance to show those assets were legally earned, noting the defense has long claimed Noriega received $11 million from U.S. intelligence agencies. ``We are ready, willing and able to show General Noriega has received substantial amounts of money from various intelligence agencies, which is not tainted or drug money,'' said Rubino. Noriega, who surrendered to U.S. troops Jan. 4, is being held in the Metropolitan Correctional Center outside of Miami on a February 1988 indictment accusing him of taking $4.6 million in bribes from Colombia's Medellin drug cartel to turn Panama into a way station for cocaine trafficking.

DOC.HEAD: Support Group Offers Strength, Hope to Facially Disfigured
DOC.TEXT: Lee Sharapa says she felt like a freak after cancer surgery disfigured her face, but the 44-year-old homemaker fought back with help from a loving family and a support group called Let's Face It. The surgery five years ago destroyed the symmetry of Mrs. Sharapa's face. She said many of her friends didn't understood what it was like to be stared at on the street. Today, Mrs. Sharapa has come to terms with looking different and is helping others with facial disfigurements feel less isolated through the group at Michael Reese Hospital and Medical Center. ``I think the group is going to be very, very beneficial,'' Mrs. Sharapa said. ``Just (in terms of) self-esteem. To make a person know that they're not the only one in this boat.'' Three people attended the first meeting Tuesday. Mrs. Sharapa hopes it will grow to as many as 20 people. Similar groups meet elsewhere in the United States and other countries, including Britain, the home of Christine Piff, who wrote a book called ``Let's Face It'' after her own cancer surgery. Chicago nurse Laurel Barbour decided to start the Michael Reese group after attending a medical meeting in New Orleans where she met Betsy Wilson, who founded Let's Face It in the United States three years ago in her hometown of Concord, Mass. ``I think it must be awful to be facially disfigured and to have to walk around,'' Ms. Barbour said. Disfigured people can get encouragement from each other that ``I can't provide for them as a nurse at all,'' she said. Ms. Wilson lost her jaw to cancer surgery in 1972 and said she drew inspiration from Ms. Piff, whose 1985 book documented the ordeal of losing an eye and part of her palate to cancer surgery. Ms. Piff launched a Let's Face It movement in Great Britain to counter the insensitivity she was subjected to. An estimated 350,000 people in the United States each year suffer facially disfiguring injuries, diseases, burns or surgeries, Ms. Wilson said in a telephone interview this week. ``A lot of people just become reclusive or alcoholic, and they die that way, in seclusion,'' she said. ``This is what's exciting about this. It's given a lot of people a lot of hope. We're able to share our humor and our humanity together, young and old.'' Massachusetts-based Let's Face It has no formal membership but mails newsletters to about 4,000 people. It is merging with a Canadian counterpart, a Toronto-based group called About Face, Ms. Wilson said. ``There are (similar) groups all over the United States with different names,'' she said, including an Indianapolis organization called Face to Face, which runs a weekend camp for facially disfigured youngsters. ``One of our goals is to educate the public to value the person behind the face,'' said Ms. Wilson, who appeared on the ``Oprah'' TV show in December and has made other public appearances to support the cause. Another goal is to educate the disfigured themselves, she said, including teaching them how to interpret people's reactions. ``Most children stare at you because they think you hurt. It's compassion, not cruel curiosity,'' Ms. Wilson said. Dr. Norman Bernstein, clinical associate in surgery and psychiatry at the University of Chicago who has worked with disfigured patients for 30 years, blamed society for many of their problems. ``Our society and most societies are frightened and troubled and angered by people who do not look right,'' he said. ``Television has made it worse, with all those millions of dollars in advertising about appearance.'' Mrs. Sharapa said living with disfigurement once seemed overwhelming at times, but she has come to regard it as ``just part of life'' with the help of a loving family and friends. ``To me, I'm no different inside than I was five, 10 years ago,'' she said. ``Maybe this has made me a stronger person, a better person. I hope it has.''

DOC.TEXT: The dollar firmed against key currencies in European trading this morning. Gold prices rose after dropping sharply on Thursday. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 154.52 yen, up 0.99 yen from Thursday's close and offsetting a 1.02 yen drop on Thursday. Other European dollar rates compared with late Thursday: _1.6951 West German marks, up from 1.6920 _1.4355 Swiss francs, up from 1.4330 _5.7040 French francs, up from 5.6940 _1.9070 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9045 _1,244.00 Italian lire, up from 1,242.75 _$1.1695 Canadian, down from $1.1700 The British pound was quoted at $1.7080, unchanged from late Thursday. DOC.HEAD: Governor: Abortion Bill Too Cruel Without Exceptions
DOC.TEXT: Louisiana's House passed the nation's toughest state abortion bill and sent it to the Senate, but Gov. Buddy Roemer promises a veto unless exceptions are made for victims of rape and incest. The House voted 74-27 Thursday to sentence people to up to 10 years in prison for performing abortions. The House twice rejected amendments with the exceptions Roemer wants. ``A bill that treats rape and incest for what they are _ unusual, extraordinary, violent, degrading _ and gives the mother a choice there, I can live with that,'' the Democratic governor said. Proponents of the measure said they hope the conservative U.S. Supreme Court eventually will receive the bill and use it to overturn the court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision legalizing abortion. State Rep. Woody Jenkins, the bill's Democratic sponsor, said he can't concern himself yet with Roemer's long-standing veto threat. ``The governor will have to consider it and make the decision himself,'' Jenkins said. ``If he would veto the bill, we would certainly try to override it.'' The Louisiana Legislature hasn't overridden a veto in 70 years, Jenkins said. The bill could be in trouble in the Senate, where a number of lawmakers agree with Roemer, said Sen. Mike Cross. He will handle the measure when it comes up for a Senate vote, expected in about two weeks. The Senate bill might contain exceptions for rape and incest. The House bill would impose prison terms of up to 10 years and fines of up to $100,000 on people who perform abortions. It would not penalize women who receive abortions. Jenkins has claimed that abortion is tantamount to abuse against women. He focused debate on whether life begins at conception and repeatedly referred to House committee testimony to that effect by Dr. Jerome Lejeune, a French geneticist. The Louisiana Legislature has a history of enacting tough abortion laws, all of which have been stayed or declared unconstitutional during the past 15 years. Opponents called the measure an affront to women, especially the poor. ``What the House has done will awaken a strong majority in this state,'' said Robin Rothrock, leader of an abortion rights coalition. ``People will come to this Capitol and tell the Legislature to stay out of our business.''

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstoms Drench Plains; Rain in East
DOC.TEXT: Torrential rains pounded Nebraska early today during a series of thunderstorms in the central Plains. Rain fell over parts of the East and the northern Plains. Fair weather prevailed over much of the West. In the East, showers drenched northern New England and thunderstorms hit Philadelphia. Rain also fell in western Pennsylvania and Washington, D.C. Hot and muggy weather was expected from the southern Plains across the Southeast. Showers and thunderstorms were likely in the central Appalachians and Carolina coastal areas. Much of the Midwest and northern Plains early today had rain or thunderstorms. Rain fell in Minnesota and North Dakota and thunderstorms were over Iowa and Nebraska. Torrential rains drenched eastern Nebraska, forcing the evacuation of the town of Platte Center, which has a population of 367, police said. Flooding swept cars from a parking lot and cars blocked highways, the National Weather Service said. No deaths or injuries were reported. Thursday was the third night of severe weather to pound Nebraska. In Kansas on Thursday, a tornado in Osborne County damaged a farm building, uprooted trees and downed several power poles. Another tornado touched down at Whichita, but caused no damage, police said. Softball-size hail was reported near El Dorado, Kan., and winds gusted up to 70 mph, authorities said. There was 5 inches of snow at Monida Pass in southwest Montana. The high Thursday in the Lower 48 states was 106 degrees at Presidio, Texas. DOC.HEAD: Elizabeth Taylor Released From Hospital
LaserPhoto LA4
DOC.TEXT: Doctors at St. John's Hospital have sent Elizabeth Taylor home to recuperate after a two-month battle with illness that nearly claimed her life. The violet-eyed actress, with hair coiffed and makeup on, waved and smiled to reporters Thursday night as she drove from the hospital in a red, compact car toward her Beverly Hills home. ``She's so happy to be going home, she's very excited,'' said spokeswoman Chen Sam. Miss Taylor, 58, will recuperate at home for a couple of months, Ms. Sam said. The New York publicist quoted Miss Taylor as saying, ``I am finally glad to be going home. My sole concern at this time is focused on my getting well and carrying on with my life. ``Throughout this experience, I have learned how precious life is, how much I love it and yearn to live more of it. I am grateful to everyone who has supported me through this difficult period.'' Miss Taylor had been in St. John's since April 16. She had been in the hospital's intensive care unit for treatment of viral pneumonia. At one point in late April, her breathing was assisted by a ventilator. She first entered Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital on April 9 with a persistent fever and a sinus infection, doctors said. When her condition worsened, she was transferred to St. John's. On April 17, Miss Taylor responded to persistent rumors and issued a statement saying she had been tested for the AIDS virus and the tests were negative. A pulmonary specialist at St. John's said her life was in jeopardy the weekend of April 21-22, when she was put on the respirator to aid her breathing. On May 11, her doctor announced that she had developed a yeast infection of the blood and would undergo intravenous therapy. Through Ms. Sam, Miss Taylor's physician Michael Roth said, ``Though Miss Taylor has shown tremendous improvement which permits her to leave the hospital, her overall recovery depends on a significant period of convalescence which I believe she can do from home.'' The screen beauty has won two Oscars. She starred in ``Butterfield 8,'' ``Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' and more than 50 other films. From the day a 12-year-old Elizabeth Taylor fell off a horse during filming of ``National Velvet'' and hurt her back, medical problems hounded her, sending her to hospitals for at least 19 major operations and countless treatments. Miss Taylor's health woes, including her near-death bouts with pneumonia in 1961 and 1990, became as much a part of Hollywood lore as her Oscar-winning performances and seven marriages.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Yankees Owner Held Up Mandela Ticket Sales
DOC.TEXT: Ticket sales for a Nelson Mandela rally at Yankee Stadium were held up for two days, until the city promised to pay up to $50,000 if the field's turf is damaged, a newspaper reported today. The rally featured the South African anti-apartheid leader is scheduled for June 21. Tickets were supposed to go on sale Tuesday, but sales were held up until Thursday while the city Parks Department negotiated with Yankees' owner George Steinbrenner over liability for possible damage to the field, the Daily News reported. The city agreed to pay up to $50,000 to replace any damaged turf, the newspaper said. Howard Rubenstein, a spokesman for Steinbrenner, said ``George just wanted to make certain that if the turf is destroyed, it's replaced.'' About 50,000 tickets, priced between $5 and $500, finally went on sale Thursday after the agreement was signed, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Leaders Reject Coalition With Ex-Communists
DOC.TEXT: The main opposition alliance has rejected an offer to form a coalition government with the former Communists, who are expected to win a majority in Parliament in weekend runoffs. Two smaller opposition parties also ruled out a coalition with the governing Socialist Party, the heirs to the Communist Party which ruled this Balkan nation since 1944. The United States said widespread voter intimidation may have figured in last Sunday's first-round balloting, the country's first free elections in 58 years. But Zhelyu Zhelev, leader of the 16-party opposition Union of Democratic Forces hailed the showing the opposition alliance made in so short a time. Zhelev late Thursday ruled out any coalition with the Socialist Party. The Communist Party changed its name to the Socialist Party in April. Bulgaria is the only country in the Soviet Union's disintegrating East bloc where former ruling Communists remain the strongest political force. Socialist Party chief Alexander Lilov, a longtime Communist ideologist sidelined by former Bulgarian strongman Todor Zhivkov, reiterated at a news conference Thursday night that his party is reluctant to go it alone. He called for a government of national consensus to lead Bulgaria out of its current economirompted investors to sell shares to take profits chalked up earlier in the week, dealers said. Shortly after midday in London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 7.9 points, or 0.3 percent, at 2,395.1, its session low. Volume came to 241.4 million shares at midday, compared with 330.8 million shares at the same time Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Controversial Rappers As Clean As They Have To Be
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Skyywalker in 2nd graf, Sammuel in 10th graf are cq
DOC.TEXT: A show by the rap group 2 Live Crew wasn't as nasty _ or as long _ as the audience wanted. But the group's leader said it proved that 2 Live Crew could put on a clean show for teen-agers. ``They said 2 Live Crew can't do a clean show and still rock. What we're going to do is we're going to prove them all wrong,'' Luther ``Luke Skyywalker'' Campbell said during Thursday night's performance. ``I consider it the PG version,'' said Gwinnett County Police Chief Wayne Bolden as the group finished its last song. ``This is the first rap concert I've been to and I'm kind of enjoying it. I like the beat.'' ``I can't see where they violated obscenity laws, but half the words I can't understand anyway,'' he added. Campbell and another member of the Miami-based rap group were arrested in Florida last weekend after they played songs from their sexually explicit ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' album at an all-adult show. A Florida record store owner who sold the album also was arrested. The arrests followed a federal judge's ruling that the album violates Florida's obscenity law. The ruling is being appealed. The controversy prompted the band to cancel one of two concerts planned at a club for teens Thursday night. Tickets sold for both shows were honored and the band played to an estimated 320 people _ roughly half the Ozone club's capacity. In a brisk 35 minutes, the band performed versions of some of the songs from ``As Clean As They Wanna Be,'' which lacks the profanities. Each time group members stopped short of singing vulgar lyrics, teen-agers in the audience gleefully shouted them out. Ornard Howell, 18, of Duluth described the show as ``awesome. But it was too short.'' Another fan, Phil Sammuel II, agreed: ``I paid $16.50 for that ticket, I need a refund. It was too short. It wasn't what I expected.'' During the show, Campbell held up signs that read ``no censorship'' and lead the crowd in chants of ``no censorship'' and ``freedom of speech.'' Campbell said the group waited to leave Miami until they had talked to representatives of the Gwinnett County Police Department to make sure they would be allowed to perform a clean show without hassle. They left when they got it. ``The man talked to us like we were civilized people,'' Campbell said. ``The thing is, we'll go to jail but we don't want to go to jail for something that's real crazy. We don't want to make no small-town sheriff a big hero.'' Bolden said he met with band members when they arrived and ``told them about the obscenity law. I also told them they could not play any songs from the album,'' referring to ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be.'' He said the band thanked him for the warning. Chief Assistant Solicitor David Fuller had advised Gwinnett police earlier this week that ``As Nasty as They Wanna Be'' violates Georgia's obscenity law because it contains graphic descriptions of intercourse and sodomy.

DOC.HEAD: Lyme Disease Up More Than 60 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Lyme disease, a summertime threat in the great outdoors, is up 62 percent in a year in the United States. The national Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday that Lyme disease is up 15-fold in the seven years since nationwide reporting began. Preliminary 1989 reports indicate 7,402 cases, compared with 4,574 in 1988 and 491 in 1982. Georgia had the greatest percentage increase, with 715 cases, up from 53 the year before. New York had the largest number of cases _ 2,916, up from 2,637 a year earlier. Other states in the top five were Connecticut with 754, up from 362; New Jersey with 649, up from 500; and Pennsylvania with 585, up from 306. For those headed outdoors this summer, preventive measures are warranted, the CDC said. They include avoiding tick-infested areas, using tick repellant, wearing protective clothing in the outdoors and frequently inspecting for the small pests. Lyme disease, which can cause a red bulls-eye rash, aches and nerve pain, has been found most often in the Northeastern, mid-Atlantic, north-central and Northwestern states, the CDC said. The disease is treated with antibiotics, but treatment can be difficult unless it's caught early. In Georgia, where the disease was up 12-fold last year, it's probable that there were indeed more Lyme disease cases _ but also better reporting of it, state health officials said. ``We think one major factor was recognition,'' said Tom McKinley of the state Office of Epidemiology. ``Also, we have had an increased population of deer in Georgia, and also an increased population of the deer ticks, which are responsible for transmission.''

DOC.HEAD: Dairy Princess Found Guilty of Murder
DOC.TEXT: A college student once honored as her county's Dairy Princess faces life in prison after being convicted of murder for strangling another young woman in a quarrel over a man they both dated. Jurors deliberated about 7{ hours before returning the verdict against 20-year-old Lori Esker about midnight Thursday. Prosecutors had argued that she was obsessed with 26-year-old Bill Buss and plotted the Sept. 20 killing of Lisa Cihaski, his new girlfriend. Conviction of first-degree intentional homicide carries a mandatory life prison sentence. Ms. Esker will be eligible for parole in 13 years, nine months. Ms. Esker wept as sheriff's deputies escorted her from the courtroom to the Marathon County Jail today. Members of Ms. Cihaski's family hugged each other, some weeping, as the verdict was announced. Ms. Esker ``always had to be number one and she's still number one. She got number one,'' said Vilas Cihaski, the victim's father, referring to the first-degree conviction. Ms. Esker's parents showed no emotion as the verdict was read and their daughter was led away. They declined to comment. Ms. Esker's lawyer, Stephen Glynn, said strangulation is not something ``that a jury can easily accept as unintentional.'' Buss, who sat near the front of the courtroom, said afterward: ``My life will never return to normal again because Lisa will never be back.'' He was about to become engaged to Ms. Cihaski, a one-time homecoming queen who worked as an assistant catering manager at a motel near Wausau. According to testimony, Ms. Esker drove 150 miles from River Falls, where she was a college student, waited in the parking lot where Ms. Cihaski worked, strangled her with the victim's narrow belt, pulled a ring off her finger and drove back to River Falls. Nine days later, she told investigators the killing was in self-defense as the argument over Buss escalated. Friends and college classmates testified Ms. Esker repeatedly said she hated Ms. Cihaski and would get Buss back somehow. Ms. Cihaski's grandmother, Ada Sigharter, said the conviction ``never brings my Lisa back but she (Ms. Esker) got what she had coming. Our Lisa was just a super gal. There were no skeletons in her closet, no way.'' Ms. Esker surrendered her crown as 1989 Marathon County Dairy Princess _ an award based on talent and leadership in agriculture _ after her arrest last September. ``I can't really say I feel joy over something like this,'' District Attorney Greg Grau said. ``It is just a terrible case, a tragedy. ... I just hope that some of the wounds that have existed in the community because of the case can now start to heal and people can get it behind them and go on.'' He again reiterated that intent was the issue. The length of time Ms. Esker had to hold a belt around Ms. Cihaski's throat before she died _ 2 to 8 minutes _ proved Ms. Esker intended to kill her, Grau had told the jury in closing arguments. Ms. Esker's lawyer intends to appeal. ``It is a real tough situation seeing somebody that young who is potentially going to be in prison for a very long time for something I am absolutely convinced she did not intend,'' Glynn said.

DOC.HEAD: Mazola Stops Ads After Claims Questioned
DOC.TEXT: The manufacturer of Mazola Corn Oil announced that it would drop claims that imply the product reduces cholesterol. CPC International Inc., based in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., said Thursday it had signed agreements with the Federal Trade Commission and attorneys general in 10 states. In a statement, CPC said its future advertisements would avoid the ``use of statements which might be misinterpreted to mean that the use of corn oil would, by itself, lower serum cholesterol.'' Massachusetts Attorney General James Shannon said he and his colleagues challenged ads that made claims such as, ``Mazola does what? They said it could turn back my cholesterol. I didn't believe it until my level dropped 17 percent.'' The states alleged that the advertisements stressed the cholesterol lowering properties of these products without placing proper emphasis on the importance of the total diet. ``Today's consumers want to eat right and they are often swayed by the claims made by food producers,'' Shannon said. ``But any food touted as a magic cure without stressing the need for an all-around healthy diet does consumers more harm than good.'' CPC said the ads in question already had been withdrawn for other reasons months ago. The company said it continues to believe that the interpretation of the advertising by the states and FTC ``does not reflect consumer understanding of this advertising.'' The company also said it has supplied numerous studies supporting its position that a low-fat, low-cholesterol diet which includes Mazola Corn Oil can help lower cholesterol levels. CPC did not admit any violations of law, and said it was trying to avoid expensive legal proceedings. The agreement calls for the company to pay $100,000 to cover the costs of the investigation, Shannon's office said. The other states involved in the action were California, Florida, Illinois, Iowa, Minnesota, Missouri, New York, Texas and Wisconsin.

DOC.HEAD: Fundamentalist Victory Shakes North Africa
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Algerians switching to traditional dress, demands that alcohol sales be curtailed. Pickup 7th, `In final...' ^By MICHAEL GOLDSMITH
DOC.TEXT: Islamic fundamentalists who scored a surprise victory in local elections told bar owners today to curtail alcohol sales, and many Algerians abandoned Western garb for traditional dress. Hundreds of fundamentalists staged all-night celebrations in the capital, parading through the streets with banners reading ``God is great'' and ``Islamic Republic.'' ``The army and people are with you, Madani!'' youths shouted, referring to Sheikh Abassi Madani, leader of the Islamic Salvation Front, which decisively won Tuesday's elections. It was the first free vote in Algeria since independence from France in 1962. Many men who normally wear Western clothing appeared on the streets today in the traditional floor-length shirt, or khamiss. Some cafe owners reported visits by fundamentalists. Omar Ghermache, who runs the well-known La Pecherie restaurant, said a band of young men wearing khamisses and beards advised him ``to serve alcohol from now on only to Europeans.'' Madani has said women will not be forced to wear the Islamic scarf, or hijab, but his followers have steadily pressured female students and teachers to adopt the traditional garb. The government has not yet replied to the demands of Madani to dissolve Parliament and hold early national elections. It also has not responded to suggestions that the governing National Liberation Front propose a coalition with the fundamentalists. The National Liberation Front was Algeria's only legal political party until constitutional reforms were implemented last year. In final results announced Thursday by Interior Minister Mohamed Salah Mohammedi, the Islamic Salvation Front won 853 of the 1,539 municipal councils at stake. The National Liberation Front carried 487, and the anti-clerical Rally for Culture and Democracy gained 87. The rest went to small parties and independents. The fundamentalists captured 32 provincial councils, Mohammedi added. The governing party took 14, the Rally for Culture and Democracy one, and independent candidates one. The turnout was 65 percent of the 12.8 million registered voters, an unusually low total for Algeria. Two parties opposed to both the governing party and the fundamentalists boycotted the elections. Madani told the French TV network TF-1 that Algeria was in no danger of being swept by radical Iranian fundamentalism. ``We are Moslems _ not fundamentalists,'' he said. However, his party advocates the use of Islamic law and restricts women to a subservient role. Fundamentalists in other North African countries hailed the results of the election. In Tunisia, the leader of the unauthorized Islamic Fundamentalist Party, Rachid Ghannounchi, said the election ``was a divine day, by the grace of God, which will have consequences for the entire Maghreb.'' The Maghreb consists of Algeria, Tunisia, Morocco, Libya and Mauritania. Fundamentalist opposition leaders in Morocco hailed the results. The Al Alam newspaper said the June 12 election day will stand as a major date in history. Iran's official Tehran Radio said Algerian voters ``have given proof of the fact that the great force of Islam is a decisive factor in political life of all North African countries.'' ``In this favorable terrain, Islam can spread very quickly,'' the radio said. Iran's government came to power in a 1979 Islamic revolution. Moderate governments from Egypt to Morocco appeared reluctant to comment on the election results. But the Moroccan newspaper Al Bayane, usually close to government thinking, said that democratic reform in Algeria had benefited ``a movement known for its authoritarian and intolerant leanings.'' ``The entire union of the Arab Maghreb is shaken by the way in which its central pivot, Algeria, has been rendered fragile,'' it said. Libya bans Islamic fundamentalism and Egypt suppresses it, although the Moslem Brotherhood holds seats in Egypt's parliament. In Algiers, the uncertain political future dominated conversation Thursday. Many Algerians are anxious to know whether the military will remain on the sidelines and how women will be affected by the fundamentalists' gains. In France, extreme-right leader Jean-Marie Le Pen predicted a flood of new Algerian immigrants fleeing Islamic repression. Le Pen favors expelling the Moslem immigrants already in France. Politicians across the spectrum said fear of a new wave of immigrants would benefit Le Pen's National Front at the ballot box. ``One extremism creates another,'' remarked centrist politician Jacques Barrot. ``We've got to break this vicious circle.''

DOC.HEAD: Army Strikes Back at Tamils; Death Toll Believed to Reach 270
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with army attacks on Tamils. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Government troops killed at least 22 Tamil rebels today in attacks in northern and eastern Sri Lanka that occurred shortly after five soldiers died in a guerrilla ambush, military officials said. A senior government minister flew to the rebel stronghold of Jaffna, seeking an end to five days of bloodshed. The deaths brought to about 270 the number of people killed since Monday. The fighting is the worst since peace talks began in May 1989 between the government and the rebels, who are seeking an independent Tamil state. Earlier today, the military said Tamil guerrillas, known as Tigers, killed at least 23 of 69 policemen captured when rebels overran a police station in Kinniya in northeastern Trincomalee district on Wednesday. It was the second reported mass killing of captured police officers during the latest outbreak of violence. About 114 policemen, who surrendered Monday at the eastern Kalmunai police station in eastern Sri Lanka, were lined up on the ground and shot and killed by rebels, a surviving policeman said. Witnesses have said an additional 110 government troops, rebels and civilians have been killed in the fighting throughout Sri Lanka's embattled northeast. Today, troops struck back at rebels, recapturing several of the 20 police staions taken by rebels and chasing guerrillas out of at least two communities. Earlier today, five soldiers died and one was injured when rebels ambushed a jeep patrol south of Vavuniya, 135 miles northeast of Colombo, officials said. At least six rebels were killed when troops recaptured two police stations and cleared guerrillas out of Trincomalee, a seaport town, officials said. Twelve rebels were killed when troops recaptured the police station in Muttur, the officials said on condition of anonymity. Police commandos also recaptured Pottuvil police station in eastern Sri Lanka, killing four guerrillas, officials said. And troops cleared Northern Vavuniya of rebels, officials said. Justice Minister Shahul Hameed left Colombo, the capital, this morning for the rebel stronghold of Jaffna in northern Sri Lanka to meet Tamil Tiger rebel leaders in an effort to end the fighting. But elsewhere, rebels continued their attacks on at least four army camps and a police station, the officials said. Ten soldiers at a camp on a pier at Talaimannar in the northwest were injured when they came under heavy fire overnight before escaping to a naval base, officials said. The other army camps under attack were Kiran, Kalavanchukudi and Muttur on the east coast. Rebels also attacked a police station in the east, officials said. This week's fighting shattered a cease-fire that took effect when the government and rebels opened negotiations 13 months ago to end the 7-year-old Tamil revolt against the Sinhalese-dominated government. The Tamils, who are mainly Hindu, represent 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. They claim they are discriminated against by the majority Sinhalese, who are predominantly Buddhist. The Tigers took virtual control of the Tamil-dominated north and east after India withdrew its peacekeeping force in March after an unsuccessful 32-month mission to disarm the rebels. The latest round of fighting began after a Tamil man told the Tigers he was assaulted by a Sinhalese policeman at the Batticaloa police station on Sunday. At least 11,000 people, including 1,200 Indian soldiers, have been killed in the Tamil war since it started in 1983. Another 6,000 have been killed in violence instigated by Sinhalese extremists who claim the government has been too weak in dealing with the Tamils.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Meets Mandela and Blesses Efforts to End Apartheid
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II today received black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela and gave his blessings to efforts to dismantle the apartheid system of racial segregation in South Africa. The pope did not respond directly to Mandela's request that the Holy See support mantaining international economic sanctions on South Africa. The sanctions aim to pressure the white-minority government to end apartheid. Papal spokesman Joaquin Navarro said the Vatican considers sanctions a political issue but that apartheid was an ethical problem to be addressed by the pope. Mandela, leader of the African National Congress, is on a six-week tour of Europe, Africa and North America, in part to persuade foreign governments to maintain the sanctions despite recent reforms by South African President F.W. de Klerk. John Paul received Mandela in a 25-minute audience. As reporters were let into the pope's private library at the end of the talks, John Paul told Mandela: ``Thanks be to God that we can meet.'' Mandela was freed in February after more than 27 years in prison. In the past, the pope has praised Mandela as a ``man who suffers for the rights of his people.'' Last year the Vatican issued a major document on racism that harshly condemned apartheid. Turning to reporters, Mandela said the ANC believes sanctions need to be maintained and ``I asked them (the Holy See) to express themselves very clearly on this issue. ``I asked our father (the pope) to bless this initiative because we are sure his blessing would help because his stands on issues like apartheid and anti-Semitism have been so clear they have won respect from the whole world.'' John Paul replied in English: ``God bless your initiatives.'' In a statement, the Vatican said the audience granted to Mandela was ``further confirmation of the Holy See's commitment in favor of a peaceful political evolution in South Africa'' and the ``progressive overcoming of the system of apartheid.'' It said such changes should lead to a society ``based on pacification and reconciliation among all components of that nation, with the guaranteeing and respect of the fundamental rights of all citizens.'' Earlier today, Mandela received honorary citizenship of Rome. He thanked Italians for their support against ``one of the most brutal forms of oppression the world has ever seen.'' Mandela also met with President Francesco Cossiga and Senate President Giovanni Spadolini. South Africa has 5 million whites, 28 million blacks, about 3 million people of mixed race, and 850,000 Asians and Indians. Apartheid establishes a racially segregated society in which South Africa's blacks have no vote in national afairs. Reforms recently implemented by de Klerk include freeing Mandela, legalizing the ANC, and lifting most of a 4-year-old national state of emergency.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Says U.S. Criticism Encourages Arab Aggression
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today blamed U.S. criticism of Israel for stirring up growing Arab hostility toward the Jewish state. ``Aggressive intentions ... begin to surface in the Arab world as soon as they see cracks or breaches in the wall of friendship between Israel and the United States,'' Shamir said in an interview today in the Jerusalem Post. A top aide to Shamir, meanwhile, suggested Israel would not accept an earlier U.S. compromise plan on peace talks. The comments by Shamir and his aide followed sharp remarks by U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, urging Israel's new right-wing government to move to restart the stalled peace process. Baker, testifying before a Senate committee Wednesday, sarcastically recited the telephone number of the White House switchboard and said: ``When you're serious about this, call us.'' Baker proposed in October that Israelis and Palestinians meet in Cairo for preliminary peace talks. Palestinian delegates would include people deported from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and others who have homes in both the territories and Israeli-annexed east Jerusalem. The formula was intended as a compromise between Israel's refusal to talk to the PLO and the stance by the PLO that Palestinians outside the territories should be included in talks. A top Shamir aide, asked today whether the Baker plan was still relevant, said: ``We are asking to start from the beginning ... to get the process on a track that will not lead us to negotiations with a delegation composed by the PLO, and that will lead us into the danger of a Palestinian state.'' ``It is unacceptable that they (the Americans) return exactly to this point and propose the same questions to the new government that has been formed,'' said Yossi Ben-Aharon, director of the prime minister's office, speaking on Israel army radio. Baker said on Wednesday that ``there won't be any dialogue, there won't be any peace'' if Israel's new government makes unacceptable demands for Palestinian participation in peace talks. The Baker comments drew angry reaction today from some members of the Shamir coalition. A senior legislator of Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc complained that the United States, which pays $3 billion in aid to Israel every year, was acting like a colonial ruler. ``After all, we are not a colony. We are a sovereign state,'' Eliyahu Ben-Elissar, head of Parliament's Defense and Foreign Affairs Committee, said on Israel radio today. ``We are not obligated to give positive answers to everything the Americans ask for, everything Baker proposes.'' In the occupied territories, Israeli troops destroyed the homes of four Palestinians and sealed a fifth today as punishment for attacks on soldiers and Arabs accused of collaborating with Israel, the army said. Since the suspects lived in typical Palestinian fashion within extended families, the houses destroyed and sealed were home to 74 people. The demolitions raised to nine the number of houses destroyed this week in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Three houses were sealed. Israel's practice of destroying and sealing houses of Palestinian suspects been criticized by the United States and human rights groups as collective punishment. The Israeli Information Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories said at the end of May that 293 Palestinian homes had been destroyed and 173 sealed since the start of the 30-month-old uprising.

DOC.HEAD: New York-bound Jet Evacuated after False Report of Fire in Cockpit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with no fire on plane. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A dozen people were hurt in the emergency evacuation of a New York-bound TWA jet at Heathrow airport today after a faulty cockpit indicator warned of a fire, authorities said. A TWA spokesman, Sam Nakamura, said a problem with an air-conditioning unit had caused the fire-warning light to go on, even though there was no fire. An airport spokesman said 10 people were treated at the scene for minor injuries and two people were taken to hospitals after the 222 passengers and 14 crew members slid down chutes while evacuating the plane. Nakamura said the Lockheed Tri-Star had taxied out and was awaiting clearance for takeoff when there was an ``indication'' of a door problem. The aircraft taxied off the runway, and then there was indication of a fire, Nakamura said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS WILMINGTON, Del., item to CORRECT dateline to WILMINGTON, N.C.
DOC.TEXT: Joe Wright, a member of the Wilmington 10, died Wednesday of sarcoidosis, a chronic disease often mistaken for tuberculosis. He was 37. The Wilmington 10, nine black men and one white woman, were active in protests against what they said were racial injustices in New Hanover County schools during the early 1970s. In 1972, the men were convicted of firebombing a grocery store and shooting at emergency personnel responding to the fire during racial violence the year before. The woman was convicted of being an accessory to the burning. They received sentences ranging from 23 to 34 years. Wright's record had been cleared this year of the conviction resulting from the Wilmington 10 trial.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Iran Sign $600 Million Settlement
DOC.TEXT: Iran agreed today to pay the American oil company Amoco $600 million for facilities seized during the 1979 Islamic revolution, according to an official of the claims panel. It was the first major settlement of more than $1.8 billion worth of U.S. corporate oil claims filed against Iran at the Iran-United States Claims Tribunal, arbitrating financial claims by the two nations since 1981. Settlement of the oil claims would be a major step toward resuming oil trading ties between Iran and the United States. The two nations severed ties after the Islamic revolution, led by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and the seizure of American hostages, who were held by Iranian militants at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran for 444 days. The Hague-based tribunal was set up as part of the Algiers Accord of 1980, which paved the way for the release of hostages. It has been the only official forum where American and Iranian officials have been meeting throughout their nations' decade-long confrontation. American and Iranian officials have stressed their talks deal only with financial arbitration and do not consider the fate of the six American hostages still being held in Lebanon. But another smaller settlement was reached at the tribunal last month shortly after two Ameican hostages were freed in Lebanon. The tribunal has three American, three Iranian and three third-nation arbitrators, and has so far settled $3.2 billion worth of government-to-government and private claims, including today's settlement. Oil accounts for 90 percent of Iran's foreign exchange earnings, and the absence of the American market has been a major financial blow to a nation whose economy was ravaged by the eight-year Persian Gulf war with Iraq. President Hashemi Rafsanjani has been seeking to restore and expand trade links with the West, but he has faced opposition from Islamic militants who want no dealings with the United States. Today's settlement concerned claims by two Amoco subsidiaries against the National Iranian Oil Co., according to the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity in line with tribunal policy. The Amoco Iran Oil Co. filed the largest of the two claims, worth $540 million, for the expropriation by Iran of four offshore drilling fields in the gulf, known as Nowruz, Ardeshir, Cyrus and Darius, the official said. The Darius field includes Kharg island, the shipping point for most Iranian oil. The second claim, for $60 million, was filed by Amoco International Finance Corp. and related to Iran's seizure of a petrochemical plant on Kharg, the official said. The Amoco package as a whole ``was one of the most strongly contested claims ... It removes a lot of work from the tribunal,'' the official told The Associated Press. Today's settlement leaves pending more than $1.2 billion worth of claims from oil companies which did business in pre-revolutionary Iran, according to the official. It followed last month's settlement of about 3,000 financial claims totaling $105 million, known as the ``Small Claims'' package. The Small Claims package was signed shortly after the release of American hostages Frank Reed and Robert Polhill by pro-Iranian kidnappers in Beirut. The biggest item still on the tribunal's agenda is an Iranian claim of up to $11 billion for military equipment ordered by the Shah's government but never delivered because of the U.S. embargo imposed on the government of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. The U.S. government contends that much of the material Iran is claiming compensation for is not under its control, but belongs to individual contractors who were never paid. Washington claims it has found buyers for some of the equipment Iran did pay for, and has deposited the money in Iran's accounts after the revolution.

DOC.HEAD: Embargo on Natural Gas to Lithuania to be Partially Lifted Saturday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with blockade to be lifted Saturday, quotes from diplomat. No Pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A member of the Communist Party Politburo confirmed today that the blockade of natural gas to Lithuania will be partially lifted starting Saturday as a gesture of Kremlin good will. Meanwhile, Lithuania's President Vytautas Landsbergis, marking the 50th anniversary of the Soviet occupation of the Baltic republic, said today a Kremlin offer of future sovereignty might be looked upon favorably. Moscow ordered the cutoff of all oil, most natural gas and some raw material shipments to Lithuania in April in an effort to persuade the republic to rescind its independence declaration of March 11. On Wednesday, the Kremlin gave the first sign it may be ready to ease the blockade, perhaps because of mounting domestic opposition to it. The sanctions have idled 26,000 Lithuanian workers. Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov reportedly told Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene on Wednesday that 15 percent of the republic's natural gas supply would be restored. However, there had been no sign of the gas actually arriving. At a news conference today, Politburo member Yuri Maslyukov said natural gas supplies to a large fertilizer plant in Lithuania would be turned back on, as promised in the talks between Mrs. Prunskiene and Ryzhkov. ``At that meeting, as far as I know, there was a request from Prunskiene to supply gas,'' Maslyukov said. ``Ryzhkov gave that instruction, that is 3.5 million cubic meters of gas starting from tomorrow to be supplied to that plant.'' Maslyukov said it was a goodwill gesture from the Soviet Union and a ``reiteration of the Soviet goverment's interest in speeding negotiation.'' A spokesman at the Jonova fertilizer plant, Mysyunas Tautvid, said the company received a telegram confirming that natural gas supplies would be restored Saturday. On Thursday, the Moscow city council discussed sending gasoline to the Baltic republic to ensure it has enough fuel to keep up milk supplies to Russia. The Postfactum news service said Thursday that the council, which is dominated by radical reformers, is thinking of sending gasoline in rail tank cars guarded by council members. Food is always in short supply in the Soviet Union, but with the recent panic buying touched off by the new economic government plan, Moscow officials are especially concerned about keeping their sources of dairy products. The newly elected president of the Russian Federation, Boris Yeltsin, already has promised to send supplies to Lithuania. The presidents of several other republics reportedly told President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Tuesday that the embargo should be stopped. In Lithuania, the republic's Supreme Council legislature held a special session to commemorate the Red Army's entrance into the Baltic republic after a secret Soviet-German agreement placing the area under Soviet control. Algimintas Cekuolis, an adviser to the Supreme Council, quoted Landsbergis as saying that a suggestion by Gorbachev on Tuesday to create a new union of ``sovereign states'' could be seen in a ``maybe positive'' light. But, he quoted Landsbergis as saying, ``We have to have guarantees and clearly visible deeds.'' ``The country that attacked us in 1940 and has committed many acts of international injustice, including now keeping occupied holdings, has to prove its good will with something more substantial than just declarations,'' Cekuolis quoted Landsbergis as saying. Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. All three Baltic republics want back the sovereignty lost at that time.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Vetoes Bill to Allow Political Activity of Federal Workers
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today vetoed a bill to ease a ban against political activity by government workers, saying the measure would destroy the ``essential political neutrality'' of the federal work force. Bush said the legislation to liberalize the 51-year-old Hatch Act would ``inevitably lead to repoliticizing'' the government bureaucracy. It was the 12th veto of Bush's presidency. Congress has yet to override one. Just this week, the Senate sustained Bush's veto of an Amtrak authorization bill by a two-vote margin. In vetoing the Hatch Act measure, Bush said that, ``after all the debate, no real need to repeal the existing Hatch Act has been demonstrated.'' For more than half a century, ``the Hatch Act has successfully insulated the federal service from the undue political influence that would destroy its essential political neutrality,'' Bush said. The bill would substantially erase prohibitions that now restrict the nation's 3 million federal civil service and postal employees to little more than voting. It would allow them to hold office in a political party, to attend political conventions as a delegate and, in some cases, to solicit political contributions from co-workers _ practices now prohibited. Sponsors said that the measure would extend the same fundamental freedoms now enjoyed by the rest of the population to federal and postal workers. But, Bush argued, ``We cannot afford, in the final decade of this century, to embark on a retreat into the very worst aspects of public administration from the last century.'' Bush said the restrictions did not go far enough. ``As one who has devoted much of his life to public service, I take great pride in the integrity of our federal work force,'' said the president, who began his career with the federal government as a House member in the mid-1960s. Bush's veto had been expected. The House approved the measure 334-87 on Tuesday. The Senate passed the same bill last month by a vote of 67-30. That's enough for a veto override. But GOP Senate leaders have expressed confidence they can persuade one or two of their colleagues to change votes to sustain a veto.

DOC.HEAD: Canada Trade Agreement Working Well, Congress Told
DOC.TEXT: A major U.S.-Canadian trade agreement has worked well in its first 18 months although it is plagued by some paperwork problems, businesses from both sides of the border told Congress today. ``Implementation of the free-trade agreement has occurred as smoothly as might be expected and ... the Customs services of both countries performed remarkably under less than ideal circumstances,'' Michael Hachee of the Customs Brokers Association in Champlain, N.Y., testified before the House Small Business Committee. Andrew Vanderwal of Toronto, vice president of Canadian Importers Association Inc., said some paperwork requirements ``create substantial business costs that detract from the trade liberalization'' of the agreement. Witnesses agreed that the problems center around requirements that a product being shipped across the border be accompanied by a ``certificate of origin,'' which must be signed by the exporter. ``This is a very time-consuming and costly process, particularly for firms that ship tens of thousands of different small parts and other items,'' Vanderwal said. Rep. John LaFalce, D-N.Y., chairman of the committee, said he has received complaints in addition to those about paperwork. Some businesses have complained about a lack of practical information on procedures, and others are concerned about administrative problems encountered at the border, LaFalce said. John P. Simpson, deputy assistant secretary of the treasury, said the administration is pleased with the first 18 months under the agreement, which, by 1998, will result in the world's largest free-trade zone. ``The structure of the agreement itself has not been shown to need a major overhaul, and the particular problems we have discovered are being resolved expeditiously with the full cooperation of the Canadian government,'' Simpson said.

DOC.HEAD: Politicians Won't Change Abortion Stance Despite Church Warning
DOC.TEXT: Several prominent Roman Catholic politicians said they wouldn't change their position favoring abortion rights, despite Cardinal John O'Connor's warning that they could be excommunicated. ``I'm prepared to put my soul in the hands of God rather than the cardinal,'' state Sen. Nicholas Spano said in a typical response to O'Connor's warning. But New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, who has sparred with O'Connor over the abortion issue for years, said the pronouncement worried him, even though it appeared consistent with the cardinal`s previous statements. ``I don't like to hear it. How could you? This is something fundamental to our family,'' the governor said Thursday. Cuomo has said he personally opposes abortion, but believes the decision is up to each individual. Cuomo and other New York politicians were reacting to O'Connor's strongest and clearest statement yet on the fate of those who advocate a woman's right to an abortion. It was delivered in an article in Catholic New York, the weekly archdiocesan newspaper. At the same time, a Roman Catholic diocese in Grand Rapids, Mich., is threatening to excommunicate a Democratic candidate for state Senate because she supports abortion rights. A spokesman for the diocese, Michael Ghering, said church officials are investigating Jo McLachlan's pro-choice stand and could decide to excommunicate her. McLachlan said she won't change her position. She is active in Sacred Heart Catholic Church in Evart, in northwestern lower Michigan. ``The issue is a Catholic political position rather than the teaching of the church,'' she said. ``As an American citizen I have a right to dissent and I am a dissenting Catholic. I think the church is wrong.'' Some church experts said canon law does not uphold O'Connor's position. ``He's wrong,'' said the Rev. Richard McBrien, chairman of the theology department at the University of Notre Dame. ``On the question of abortion, the only person clearly subjected to excommunication would be the person who procures the abortion.'' That would be the woman and perhaps her doctor, but not any politicians, he said. ``Mario Cuomo is not performing abortions. Mario Cuomo is not running an abortion clinic on the side,'' said McBrien. ``He (O'Connor) doesn't really have a canonical leg to stand on.'' The Rev. Robert Drinan, a former Massachusetts congressman, agreed that O'Connor's statements were misguided. ``That goes against what the bishops have been saying,'' said Drinan, a Georgetown University Law Center professor. ``I think that won't be taken that seriously.'' But the Rev. Joseph Penna, speaking for the Archdiocese of New York, said that a person could be excommunicated even if they do not directly take part in an abortion. ``It goes beyond who procures an abortion,'' said Penna, of St. Joseph's Seminary in Yonkers. If church officials determined that an individual served as an accomplice to an abortion by ``giving scandal to other people,'' that person could be excommunicated, he said. ``And by giving scandal, I mean a person would look at someone else and say, `If that person can do it, so can I,''' said Penna, speaking of the leadership roles that politicians play in society.

DOC.HEAD: Julian Bond Ordered to Pay Child Support
DOC.TEXT: Former Georgia state Sen. Julian Bond, who admitted fathering the child of a former girlfriend, has been ordered to pay $2,000 a month in child support and $12,500 for the mother's past expenses. Deborah Kaye Moore of Atlanta, a flight attendant, filed a paternity suit in September claiming Bond, 50, was the father of her daughter, now 22 months old. Bond, who reached a divorce settlement with his wife of 28 years the day before the paternity suit was filed, initially denied the child was his. On May 19, he admitted he was the father. A Fulton County Superior Court jury last Thursday awarded Ms. Moore the child support. Ms. Moore's attorney, Lewis M. Groover Jr., said Bond has never had any contact with the child. Bond, who did not return phone calls seeking comment, was remarried in March and lives in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Mass Grave Discovered Near Military Base
DOC.TEXT: The remains of about 10 people, including a child, were found in an unmarked grave near a military base in remote northern Nicaragua, officials said. In a televised news report, two women said they recognized clothing worn by their sons when they disappeared seven years ago. The women said their sons, 17 and 18, were captured by Sandinista soldiers seven years ago. There was no indication of the identities of the remaining bodies. The grave is on Mocoron mountain, 200 yards from an army base north of Wiwili and near Nicaragua's border with Honduras. Wiwili is 175 miles north of Managua. Marta Patricia Baltodano, executive director of Nicaraguan Pro Human Rights Association, said several peasants and Wiwili town council members informed the association's offices on June 4 of the grave's location. Human rights workers were taken to the site three days later, she said. She said that perhaps because of Hurricane Joan, which lashed Nicaragua in October 1988, ``there was a shifting of soil that allowed these bodies to come up to the top.'' In the television report, the mother of Danilo Sobalvarro Zeledon, 18, said she recognized the trousers her son wore when he was picked up by soldiers. ``I'm satisfied (he was found) because I had been looking for him in various prisons throughout Nicaragua,'' she said. ``The last thing I knew was that he was with the Contras ... Now I don't have to keep looking. I entrust him to the Lord.'' The mother of Domingo Flores Palacios, 17, shown at the grave site standing next to a pile of skulls and bones, said: ``My son was wearing these red pants and a red plaid shirt'' when he was taken by the army. Neither woman was identified. They said their sons were captured by the Sandinista People's Army on Oct. 22, 1983, in San Jose Bocay, a small town in northern Nicaragua. Pants, shirts, underwear and nylon ropes were found at the site. It was believed the ropes might have been used to tie the victims' hands. Human rights official Violeta Guevara said the bones of a 7-year-old boy were found among the remains. Andres Altamirano, the Jinotega coroner, said there were the remains of about 10 bodies in the grave. He said the remains were about eight years old. Roundups of young men by both the Sandinista army and Contra rebels were common during the 9-year-old war civil war that left 30,000 people dead. Rebels are now laying down their weapons under agreements signed with the new government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, who took over from the leftist Sandinistas on April 25.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Aide Nominated to Commerce Position
DOC.TEXT: Timothy J. McBride, personal aide to George Bush for the past five years, is being nominated to be assistant Commerce secretary for trade development, the White House announced today. McBride, 31, would succeed Michael Philip Skarzynski. At Bush's side throughout the day, McBride is in charge of the details of Bush's official life _ a job he has held since 1985 when Bush was vice president.
