Bush has not yet selected a replacement for McBride, whose official title is special assistant to the president.

DOC.HEAD: Returned Deserter Discharged From the Marines
DOC.TEXT: Ron Jacko, the deserter who surrendered to the Marine Corps after two decades in Canada, was discharged today, a Marine spokesman said. Jacko was given an ``other than honorable'' discharge and $61.50 before being released outside the gates of the Marine base in nearby Quantico, Va., said Lt. Col. Robert McLean. He also was given physical and dental exams. Regulations required the Marines to provide the exams, plus money equal to three-fourths of a one-way bus ticket to the town from which he entered the service _ in this case, Cleveland. Jacko, 42, deserted the Marines after completing basic training in 1969. He said he opposed the Vietnam war and feared he would be sent there. He has spent the last 21 years in Toronto, where he married and managed health food stores. He decided to turn himself in because he wanted to be near his mother, who is in poor health in Cleveland. ``She just went through three operations in about the last six months,'' he said in a Tuesday interview. ``I want to be able to be there.'' Jacko presented himself at Quantico on Wednesday. After determining there were no other outstanding charges, the base commander, Lt. Gen. W.R. Etnyre, granted the discharge request, the spokesman said. Jacko's attorney said a young Marine gave Jacko a ride to National Airport. ``He knew who he was, too. Ron was sort of bowled over,'' said attorney Tod Ensign of the New York-based Citizen Soldier. That group had helped arrange Jacko's return and pre-surrender publicity, including a trip to Capitol Hill to solicit the support of Jacko's hometown congresswoman, Rep. Mary Rose Oakar.

DOC.HEAD: Miners Leave Square After Outburst of Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Iliescu ordering miners home; Ratiu comment, Roman saying miners not told to beat opponents. Pickup 8th graf pvs, `Mirela Roznoveanu...' Edits to conform.
DOC.TEXT: President-elect Ion Iliescu today ordered miners he had summoned to help put down anti-government riots to go home, but many remained in the capital, clubbing anyone they considered a government opponent. Iliescu's swearing-in as president was postponed amid the chaos. The miners streamed into Bucharest on Thursday, after Iliescu called for their help in countering what he called ``facist'' forces. The miners beat pedestrians and journalists and raided the offices of opposition parties. The state news agency Rompres said Iliescu met with the miners' leaders today and ordered them to leave the capital, and that miners began boarding buses for Bucharest's northern railway station. From there, they were to return on special trains to their homes in the Jiu valley mining region of western Romania. But an hour after the announcement, miners were still roaming central Bucharest. Iliescu was to have been sworn in today at a meeting of both houses of Parliament. But a woman answering the phone at his office, who refused to give her name, said the session was put off until Monday. She would not elaborate. ``This is a death of democracy,'' said opposition leader Ion Ratiu, whose home was ransacked by maurauding miners. ``(It's) the rule of the mob, no respect for human rights. The forces of law and order stand by instead of maintaining law and order.'' Following the December pro-democracy revolution that ousted the hard-line Communist government and set up elections that Iliescu and his National Salvation Front won, Ratiu returned to Romania after 50 years in exile. Despite the latest violence, he said he would stay and fight for democracy. Premier Petre Roman told a news conference today that the miners had been asked to occupy University Square in a peaceful way and all subsequent violence was deplorable. On Wednesday, police broke up a 53-day protest in the square by anti-Communist protesters who distrust Iliescu's ties to the former regime. Government forces later fired on the protesters who attacked government buildings, killing at least five people and injuring more than 350. Then the miners arrived. Mirela Roznoveanu, a journalist with the Romania Libera newspaper, said the miners beat a co-worker and destroyed the editorial offices of the newspaper Thursday. The paper, which had been the main voice of opposition against Iliescu and the government, did not appear today. The violence by the miners Thursday was the latest outburst in the capital's worst street fighting since the bloody December revolution that ousted and executed Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Rompres quoted an unidentified spokesman for the miners as saying nobody had invited them to come to Bucharest. But it was clear they were being given at least logistical support, with municipal buses and army trucks transporting them by the hundreds to key points in the city. On Thursday, unidentified people in a van carrying loudspeakers warned passers-by: ``don't incite the miners ... you would thus give birth to fierce violence.'' The speakers also instructed the miners to grab journalists and take them into the van. ``We will take care of them,'' they said. Dozens of people were assaulted and clubbed by the helmeted miners. About 10 miners besieged the residence of Iliescu critic Dumitru Mazilu for several hours before dispersing, according to Mazilu and a neighbor. Mazilu, the former vice president of the post-revolutionary government, stepped down following charges that he collabrated with the Securitate, the secret police force that killed hundreds during the revolution. The miners were apparently directed by several men who Mazilu said were ``Securitate or former Securitate'' agents. Rompres reported that Marian Munteanu, head of the anti-Iliescu Students' Alliance, was hospitalized with unspecified injuries. Miners near the square boasted they had beaten the student leader. The miners also occupied and ransacked opposition party headquarters, including those of the 21st of December Organization of students who fought against Ceausescu. Other government suporters ransacked the headquarters of the opposition Liberal Party, as well as Bucharest University's Faculty of Foreign Languages.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Injured In Heat Exchange Station Explosion
DOC.TEXT: Nine people were injured in a blast that ripped through a heating station and damaged nearby houses in a town northeast of the capital, the state news agency reported Friday. The explosion, which occurred early in the morning in Mlada Boleslav, 34 miles from Prague, destroyed the station and sent bricks smashing through house windows up to 600 feet away, the CTK agency said. The cause of the blast was not immediately clear. The news agency did not identify the injured or say where they were at the time of the explosion. The Skoda car factory, located about one mile away, stopped production after the blast, CTK said. Experts recommended the factory stop production for security reasons, factory spokesman Jiri Danhelka said. He did not elaborate. Danhelka said none of the injuries was serious. The station was part of a system that carries hot water to nearby houses.

DOC.HEAD: Mudslide Kills 21
DOC.TEXT: Tons of mud and rocks loosened by weeklong rains tumbled down a hill Friday, crushing to death at least 21 people in a central town, police said. The mudslide and rockfall hit Talawakelle, 55 miles east of Colombo, about 4 a.m., when most of the residents were sleeping, police in the town said by telephone. The police, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said rescuers had found 11 bodies and that most of the dead were tea plantation workers. Tea is grown mostly on mountain slopes and tea pickers live in rows of tiny tin shacks at the bottom of the hills. Seven homes, two shops and the town's main bus station were buried by the mudslide, the police said. Mudslides are common during the monsoon season in Sri Lanka's central hill districts.

DOC.HEAD: 7 Deaths Reported as Pistons Celebration Turns Violent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with 7th death. Pick up 10th graf, `A 21-year-old ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DT4, DT6
DOC.TEXT: Detroit Pistons fans celebrating the team's second consecutive NBA championship turned violent today, and at least seven people died and several more were critically injured as thousands packed downtown streets. Police in suburban River Rouge arrested 28 revelers, most on disorderly conduct charges, and there were numerous reports of looting and related violence. Detroit police had no overall count of arrests or violent incidents. In the crush, a car plowed into pedestrians on the city's east side about 1:15 a.m., killing four people and injuring one, Detroit police Lt. Phil Foster said. A 9-year-old boy was pronounced dead at Children's Hospital, a 10-year-old boy and a 15-year-old girl died at St. John's Hospital, and a 21-year-old man died late this morning at Detroit Receiving Hospital, police Sgt. Christopher Buck said. Buck said the driver of the car remained at large. A 19-year-old man was shot to death and a 25-year-old man critically injured at a parking lot at 2:15 a.m., Foster said. He said the lot was packed with revelers and someone shot into the crowd. The streets _ some strewn with glass _ were quiet by dawn, and police who stayed through the night on overtime headed home. A 4-year-old suburban Detroit child was struck and killed by a car during a street celebration in River Rouge, said Lt. David Israel of that suburb's police department. ``The child was excited and ran into the street,'' said Israel, who withheld the name pending notification of relatives. A 21-year-old man fell from the roof of an apartment building during a celebration party and died later at Detroit Receiving Hospital, said hospital spokeswoman Diane Cooper. The 60-year-old owner of a party store was being held by police today after allegedly shooting a 17-year-old man and a 21-year old man who tried to break into the store, Foster said. The teen-ager was shot in the head and listed in critical condition. The other man was being treated for a gunshot wound. Robert Egan, a Mount Carmel Hospital nurse, said fights even broke out in the hospital's emergency room early this morning. ``We were running around like crazy. We registered something like 20 gunshot wounds between midnight and 4 a.m.,'' Egan said. ``It was ridiculous. In my three years here, I've never seen anything like this.'' Several partiers told television crews they were robbed as they stood on the streets and others said people reached into their cars, stealing stereo speakers and wallets, as they tried to drive through the crowds. In Ecorse, next to River Rouge, police reported damage to some businesses but made no arrests, Chief Francis DeCrease said. ``The crowd of about 600 people were partying and got out of hand and busted a scout car window,'' DeCrease said. ``Some people were shooting weapons in the air. They try to treat it like New Year's Eve.'' The violence was reminiscent of 1984 when the Detroit Tigers baseball club won the World Series and more than 100,000 people poured into the streets. Fans stripped, overturned and burned cars, looted businesses and caused widespread damage. One person died. Traffic in downtown Detroit ground to a halt as merrymakers weaved between the cars, hugging and chanting ``Bad boys!'' in the hours after Vinnie Johnson's shot with seven-tenths of a second left gave the Pistons a 92-90 win over the Trail Blazers in Portland, Ore. ``This is better than last year. We're in history now. We're part of a dynasty, we're up there with the Los Angeles Lakers and the Boston Celtics, the only ones to repeat,'' said 28-year-old fan Herb Hayden of Detroit. Detroit police officers were held over a shift to disperse the jubilant throng. The revelers scattered by daylight. The traffic tangle was worsened because streets already were closed for the Detroit Grand Prix that begins today, said police spokeswoman Allene Ray. ``We're trying to reroute traffic, to keep everybody moving,'' she said. Earlier, at The Palace of Auburn Hills, the Pistons' suburban Detroit home court, 21,400 devotees paid $3 each to watch the game on a huge overhead television screen. ``I'm going to stay up all night, party in the parking lot, then party anywhere I can because I know the whole city will be celebrating,'' said Tom Stansell, 21, of Dearborn. Last year, hundreds of carloads of boisterous fans also jammed streets after the Pistons' 105-97 win over the Los Angeles Lakers for a 4-0 sweep of the National Basketball Association finals and their first championship. But that celebration was devoid of the damage and deaths that occurred today. Within minutes after Thursday's game, Mayor Coleman Young scheduled a victory parade Monday in downtown Detroit. ``This team is something our city and Detroiters are very proud of,'' he said. The Pistons were to fly back to Detroit this afternoon.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Get Choice For First Time In Chad
DOC.TEXT: The first contested elections since independence from France in 1960 will be held July 8 for a new national assembly, the government announced Friday. The announcement follows unprecedented democratic elections this week in two other North African countries _ Tunisia and Algeria. The government said 436 candidates will run for 123 assembly seats, and the campaign begins Sunday. The elections are part of constitutional reforms approved by 99 percent of the voters who cast ballots in a national referendum in December that also gave President Hissene Habre another seven-year term. One of the reforms took effect in April with the dissolution of the National Consultative Council, a legislative body chosen solely from the ruling National Union For Independence and the Revolution. Other parties are banned and cannot form to support candidates in next month's elections. Although candidates may belong to the ruling party, all are running as independents. The winners will serve five-year terms. Five seats are reserved for women and one for the disputed Aouzou Strip claimed by Libya, to the north. Chad, a landlocked nation of 5.5 million people, is one of the world's poorest countries with a per capita annual income of about $200. It has been engaged in civil war almost continuously since independence. Habre's overnment currently is fighting rebels who stage lightning raids on border outposts from neighboring Sudan. It widely believed that the rebels receive aid from Libya, but Libya denies this.

DOC.HEAD: Miners Demand Nationalization of Communist Party Property
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 15 grafs to UPDATE with no confidence vote in Communist Party, demand for nationalization of party's assets, comment by U.S. union reps. Pickup 14th graf pvs, ``We don't...' Edits thereafter to TRIM.
DOC.TEXT: Miners from across the Soviet Union today passed a vote of no confidence in the Communist Party and called for the party to relinquish its assets. They also agreed to form an independent union. ``We are workers, but we do not consider the Communist Party of the Soviet Union our party,'' said the resolution. ``We call for a mass exit from the party.'' The resolution demanded that the party relinquish its control over large state enterprises and give up holdings including property and bank accounts filled with members' dues. The resolution, approved by a vote of 308-116, said Communists could no longer present themselves as champions of workers' rights. ``The Communist Party is losing its authority,'' said a resolution passed by the first congress of Soviet miners meeting in the Don Basin coal mining region of the eastern Ukraine. The resolution created a committee to set up the framework of a miners' union free of government or Communist Party control. That framework will be considered at a second miners' congress in Moscow on Aug. 15-16. The push for an independent union opens another rift between Soviets and their government. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has encouraged decentralization, but formation of an independent miners' union would mean the government would have less control over workers who are seen as the backbone of the Communist system. Being outside the government structure would also make it easier for the workers to organize strikes, another threat to the faltering economy. Miners also gave a warm welcome to two American trade union representatives, Richard Wilson of the AFL-CIO, and John J. Banovic of the United Mine Workers of America. Both Americans promised that their unions would assist the new independent Soviet miners' union. ``A free society requires independent trade unions, requires the right of association free of government and party control,'' declared Wilson, who said he was the first AFL-CIO reprsentative to be allowed into the Soviet Union. ``It requires that workers make their own decisions,'' he said. Earlier today, miners backed away from renewing last summer's nationwide coal strike protesting poor mine conditions, housing, food and consumer goods. On Thursday, the 712 delegates representing every coal mine in the country passed a resolution calling for the resignation of Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov and drove the Soviet mining minister from their meeting with angry shouts and demands. Politburo member Yuri D. Maslyukov, the head of the State Planning Commission, told a news conference in Moscow today that the miners' declaration of no confidence in the government was ``a very alarming and serious signal.'' He said the government wanted miners to know that ``we are not going to infringe on the interests of the population, including the miners, but we want to set up a correct policy to get the country out of the situation that it has found itself in.'' The miners miners debated whether to try to take over the existing union or base a new organization on workers' committees formed during the nationwide coal strike that crippled heavy industry last summer. ``We don't know whether a free union is really needed,'' said Yuri Balderov, a member of the Donetsk workers' committee that organized the congress. Some miners have said they feared that breaking ties with the old union, which is under the mining ministry's control, would deny them access to vacation resorts, pensions and other benefits to which they have already made financial contributions. It appeared the miners would not vote to stage another strike, although many delegates to the congress accused the government of failing to fulfill the promises it made to end last July's walkout. Many miners said a strike could do more harm than good. A telegram the miners sent to national lawmakers criticized the government. ``The government of the U.S.S.R. does not have our trust,'' said the telegram, sent Wednesday to the national Supreme Soviet legislature in Moscow. ``We urge workers in other industries to quickly cut their ties with the government,'' said the telegram, read aloud Thursday at the Supreme Soviet. The telegram also criticized an economic reform plan proposed last month by Ryzhkov and defended on national television by Gorbachev.

DOC.HEAD: Small Intestine Transplant Called A Success
DOC.TEXT: Surgeons at a Pittsburgh hospital said they have performed the nation's first successful transplant of a small intestine. The patient, a man shot in the abdomen in October, was kept alive on intravenous feedings until undergoing the transplant at Presbyterian-University Hospital, said Dr. John Fung, assistant professor of surgery at the University of Pittsburgh. ``He is eating but I can't venture to say what will happen in the long term,'' Fung said. ``He's still in the hospital because he is still recovering and we are doing more testing.'' Transplant pioneer Dr. Thomas Starzl and Fung mentioned the surgery Wednesday in a meeting with the University of Pittsburgh's board of trustees. The physicians declined to be interviewed following the meeting, and hospital officials refused to disclose any other details. Fung said the operation was done about two months ago on the patient, who was not identified. Hospital spokeswoman Lisa Rossi said Thursday it was premature to discuss the surgery. She said small intestine transplants previously were attempted at the hospital only as part of three multiple-organ transplant operations. All three patients died. Dr. Ronald Ferguson, chief of transplantation at Ohio State University Hospital in Columbus, said the operation was encouraging. He said very few small intestine transplants have been attempted, and none of the patients survived.

DOC.HEAD: Scientist Who Spied For East Germany Gets 12 Years in Prison
With AM-Germany-Spies, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A court on Friday convicted a researcher for a government scientific agency of passing on information on nuclear research to the East German secret service for two decades. Rolf Dobbertin, an East German national, was sentenced to 12 years in prison. At the start of his trial Wednesday, Dobbertin defended his actions by saying East German intelligence officials had coerced him into providing information. Dobbertin, 55, had testified that he was awarded a grant to study abroad, but was not allowed to accept it unless the secret service approved. ``In our country, nothing could be done without the authorization of the security services,'' he said. ``Don't forget this was during the Cold War. They wanted to be able to contact me at any moment, and I had to learn how to code and decode messages.'' Dobbertin was hired 30 years ago at France's National Center for Scientific Research, and passed on information on nuclear research and other topics to East Germany for about 20 years. The sentence imposed by the presiding judge was harsher than the five-year term requested by the prosecutor. Judge Maurice Colomb asked if Dobbertin still considered himself a Marxist, as he was in his youth. ``Marxism doesn't have a big future in the East,'' Dobbertin replied, referring to the fall of the Communist government in East Berlin in December. Dobbertin was unmasked in 1979 and held in custody for four years during complex legal proceedings before being released on bail in 1983. He had since resumed his post. His superiors at the research center defended him during the trial, saying the documents he covertly transmitted to East Germany contained information that was publicly available.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Say Auto Stockpiles Contribute To Jump In Industrial Production
With AM-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Industrial production jumped 0.6 percent in May, the Federal Reserve said Friday, but analysts said the sharp gain was due mainly to a temporary buildup in automobile inventories. ``I think it was somewhat of a fluke,'' said economist Paul Getman of Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa. ``Excluding motor vehicles and parts, industrial production was up 0.2 percent. That is more in line with the underlying fundamentals.'' Michael K. Evans, head of Evans Economics Inc., a Washington economic forecasting firm, contended the inventory building in the auto industry was due to concern over the expiration of the Big Three auto makers' labor contracts in September. David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a New York government securities dealer, noted that the auto makers reported a drop in output in the first 10 days of June. ``So industrial production is showing only temporary strength and will probably tilt in a weaker direction in coming months as automakers in particular have to scale back production more in line with demands,'' he said. Two government reports earlier this week pointed to slowing consumer demand as the job market weakens and wages fall. Consumer spending, which accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, has been a driving force for the economy for much of the last eight years. Declining consumer spending, combined with tighter restrictions on credit in many parts of the country, ``could threaten to push the economy over the edge into a recession in the second half of the year,'' Jones said. In addition to auto production, Evans said some of the increased output was due to exports which analysts have credited for helping sustain recent U.S. economic growth. The Commerce Department reported Friday that exports helped shrink the U.S. trade deficit so far this year to an annual rate of $92.16 billion, compared to a deficit for all of 1989 of $108.99 billion. Industrial production has risen each month since January except for April, when it was unchanged. But even the flat April figure was an improvement over the 0.4 percent decline first reported last month. Industrial production at manufacturing plants making both durable and non-durable goods rose 0.8 percent in May after slipping 0.2 percent in April. Output of durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last at least three years _ jumped 1.3 percent after a 0.2 percent decline a month earlier. Manufacturing of non-durable goods such as food and clothing was up 0.2 percent following a 0.4 percent gain in April. Output at mines was unchanged in May after a 0.7 percent advance the previous month. Utility production was down 1.1 percent following a 0.7 percent increase in April. The Fed said its industrial production index in May stood at 109.7 percent of its 1987 base, up from 109.0 in April. The Fed also reported the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities _ which usually move in tandem with industrial production _ rose 0.3 percent to 83.6 percent in May. The operating rate measures not only output but also changes in productivity levels. The operating rate at factories producing durable goods rose 0.8 percent to 82.0 percent, while the rate at plants making non-durable goods inched downward 0.1 percent to 84.3 percent. The operating rate at mines was unchanged at 88.9 percent, while it dropped a full 1.0 percent to 84.9 percent at utilities.

DOC.HEAD: Six Chinese Sentenced To Death For Power Line Thefts
DOC.TEXT: Six people have been sentenced to death and 70 to jail terms for stealing power lines in central China and causing repeated power losses, an official newspaper reported. In the past four months, courts in Shanxi province have handled 31 such cases involving 76 people, Legal Daily said Thursday. It said the cases involved 25,895 feet of power lines worth about $2,390. The thefts caused repeated power failures and hindered the irrigation of about 1,230 acres of crops, the newspaper said. It said there were serious economic losses but gave no figures.

DOC.HEAD: Seven More Reputed Red Army Terrorists Captured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with identification of those arrested today, including couple wanted in attack on U.S. base. Pickup 6th, `A day...'
DOC.TEXT: East German authorities today arrested a West German couple wanted for masterminding a string of terrorist attacks, including the 1985 bombing of a U.S. military base, authorities said. The two were among seven terrorist suspects arrested Thursday and today, officials said. One was freed because charges against her had expired. In the past 10 days, the two German governments have made a concerted effort to solve decade-old terrorist cases, sometimes using intelligence information left behind by East Germany's ousted Communist government. The terrorist suspects had apparently hidden in East Germany with the help of Communist authorities. The East German interior ministry said Barbara and Horst Meyer, probably West Germany's most wanted terror suspects, were nabbed today at the main train station in the city of Leipzig after being spotted by travelers. They are wanted in connection with attacks including a car bombing that killed two people and wounded 20 others at the U.S. Air Force's Rhein-Main Air Base near Frankfurt in August 1985. Arrested today with the Meyers was Sabine Elke Callsen, 29, who is wanted in a pair of 1985 bombing attacks, the Interior Ministry said. A day earlier, four suspects _ two married couples with young children _ were arrested in Frankfurt an der Oder and Cottbus, according to Hans-George Fuchs, a spokesman for the West German federal police office in Wiesbaden. At a news conference in East Berlin, Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel said one of those who was taken into custody Thursday, Christine Duemlein, was freed because her West German arrest warrant had expired. The six suspects remaining are believed to be members of the notorious Red Army Faction, a radical leftist group that claimed responsibility for a string of bombings and killings in the 1970s and 1980s. The suspects arrested Thursday are Monika Helbing, 36, and Ekkehard von Seckendorff-Gudent, 49, in Frankfurt an der Oder; and Werner Lotze, 38, and Ms. Duemlein, 41, in Cottbus. Von Seckendorff-Gudent is a physician and holds the title of baron. All had been living under assumed names, Diestel said. The arrests came just days after the capture of two other prominent members of the Red Army Faction, whose members have been among the most sought-after fugitives in West German history. Officials on Wednesday arrested Inge Viett, 46, who had been living under an assumed name in the East German city of Magdeburg. Susanne Albrecht, 39, was arrested June 6 outside her apartment in East Berlin. She told police this week that the former Communist secret police gave her a false identity and helped her settle in the country. Diestel has accused the secret police of harboring Western terrorists. Ms. Helbing, Lotze and Ms. Albrecht have been linked to the kidnap-slaying in 1977 of West German industrialist Hanns-Martin Schleyer and numerous other terrorist crimes. Ms. Albrecht and Lotze also have been linked to the 1977 slaying of Juergen Ponto, the head of West Germany's second-biggest bank. West German authorities have accused Ms. Viett of taking part in the murder of prominent West Berlin Judge Guenter von Drenkmann in 1974. Von Seckendorff-Gudent is accused of membership in a terrorist organization, Fuchs said. That was also the charge in the now-expired warrant against Ms. Duemlein. Von Seckendorff-Gudent was allegedly also a member of the infamous Baader-Meinhof gang in West Germany, an early 1970s forerunner of the Red Army Faction. Lotze and Ms. Helbing also are accused of robbing a bank of $120,000 in the West German city of Nuernberg in April 1979. Hans-Juergen Foerster, a spokesman for the West German federal prosecutor's office in Karlsruhe, said a 1978 warrant issued for Ms. Duemlein expired two years ago. Western officials have long contended that the former Communist regime either endorsed, trained or condoned leftist terrorism. The former secret police known as the Stasi, one of the most skilled and feared intelligence networks in the world, is believed to have trained the secret services of several other countries, and people linked to terrorism.

DOC.HEAD: Patton's 2nd Armored Division Being Deactivated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 8th graf, `The division ...,' to CORRECT spelling of Baja to Beja and add that it is in Tunisia. Picks up 9th graf, `Parts of ...'
DOC.TEXT: Gen. George S. Patton's 2nd Armored Division helped win the Battle of the Bulge, but now it has lost the battle of the budget. The Army has decided to deactivate the unit, ending its colorful history as the armored division with the longest active service record. Formed in July 1940 for European service in World War II, the division is being dismantled 50 years later in anticipation of European peace. ``This division has the most glorious history of any combat unit in the U.S. Army,'' Lt. Charles MacMaster at Fort Hood said Thursday. Patton dubbed the division ``hell on wheels,'' promising it would terrify enemies. Its troops adopted the nickname as their motto. Today, its soldiers still proudly wear ``hell on wheels'' on their division patch. Patton had urged armored units as early as World War I. It took until just before the outbreak of World War II, though, for military technology to advance enough to demand tank support units. For demanding the armored units, Patton was officially reprimanded. But his persistence paid off. The 2nd Armored landed on Omaha Beach, pushed through France, and was the first allied unit to enter Belgium. After moving a record 100 miles in a single night, the 2nd Armored helped win the Battle of the Bulge in the winter of 1944 and was the first American unit to enter Berlin on July 4, 1945. The division had previously been badly defeated in 1943 when 25 of its tanks fought with the British in the Battle of Beja in Tunisia, according to Capt. Jim Bolling. Only one tank survived that battle, and troops nicknamed it the Gallant. Parts of the 2nd Armored also participated in the Korean and Vietnam wars. One of its most famous soldiers was Elvis Presley, who was honored in the 2nd Armored war museum at Fort Hood. Under pressure to cut spending in anticipation of a cutback in European troop strength and more warming of superpower relations, the Army announced Wednesday that it is deactivating the division. That means 3,537 military jobs will be cut by Sept. 30 at Fort Hood. Another 8,615 in the division will be cut by the end of fiscal year 1991. The division's goal _ supporting U.S. troops in Europe _ is less important because ``as the Warsaw Pact disintegrates, the threat is lessened,'' said Army spokesman Maj. Joe Padilla. During peacetime, Army divisions are periodically deactivated. The United States had a record 84 divisions in service after World War II, but now has only 18 active divisions, an Army spokesman said. The 2nd Armored came to central Texas in 1946 when Fort Hood was named Camp Hood. Angry at the prospective loss of military personnel, central Texas residents near Fort Hood filed a lawsuit in state court to try to stop the action. The court has not ruled. ``It has to hurt. I am sure it will,'' said Charles J. Gillen of Lampasas, owner of Gillen's Army Surplus. ``It might take a little time to notice it but residents will,'' Gillen said. ``That includes surplus dealers, although it will help them at first when they will have to sell more. There will be an oversupply of surplus. The government is good about overbuying.''

DOC.HEAD: Bureaucrat Defeats Yeltsin Ally to Become Russian Prime Minister
DOC.TEXT: A bureaucrat was elected prime minister of the Russian republic today, defeating a reformist ally of the federation's president, Boris Yeltsin, the Tass news agency reported today. The new prime minister is Ivan Silayev, who has been a deputy prime minister in the Cabinet of Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov. The victory of a man with ties to the government of Yeltsin's rival, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, may make it more difficult for Yeltsin to pursue changes that go beyond Gorbachev's reform program. On Tuesday, the Russian parliament led by Yeltsin took its first step on a path of more radical reform by approving a resolution that declared that the republic's laws take precedence over Soviet ones. Silayev won 70 percent of the vote in the Russian Supreme Soviet legislature to defeat Mikhail Bocharov, a leader in the Democratic Russia bloc along with Yeltsin and a factory manager who has led experiments with leasing his company from the state, Tass said. Silayev, 60, is a mechanical engineer by training who started his career at the Gorky aircraft factory, Tass said. He moved up to minister of the aircraft industry, and then became minister of the machine tool and instrument-making industry. He became a deputy prime minister of the Soviet Union in 1985 and now heads a bureau that coordinates the actions of four machine-tool ministries. Yeltsin's reform drive is important to Gorbachev's because the federation contains more than three-quarters of the nation's land, including Moscow, and about 80 percent of the Soviet Union's people are Russian.

DOC.HEAD: Returned Deserter Discharged From the Marines After 21 Years Of Self-Exile
DOC.TEXT: An American who has spent half his life in Canada after deserting to avoid Vietnam was discharged from the Marine Corps Friday, 21 years after he left. Ron Jacko, 42, was given physical and dental exams, $61.50 and an ``other than honorable'' discharge before being released outside the gates of the Marine base at Quantico, Va., said Lt. Col. Robert McLean. Jacko had surrendered at the base south of Washington on Wednesday, after telling his story to reporters and his hometown congresswoman, Rep. Mary Rose Oakar, D-Ohio. After determining there were no other outstanding charges, the base commander, Lt. Gen. W.R. Etnyre, granted the discharge request and Jacko was sent on his way ``in a matter of hours,'' said spokesman McLean. ``We want to move as expeditiously as we can in these cases,'' he said. Regulations required the Marines to provide the examinations, plus money equal to three-fourths of a one-way bus ticket to the town from which he entered the service _ in this case, Cleveland. ``It's quite frankly no concern of ours where he goes,'' McLean said. Jacko's attorney said a young Marine gave Jacko a ride to National Airport outside Washington. ``He knew who he was, too. Ron was sort of bowled over,'' said Tod Ensign of the New York-based Citizen Soldier, which arranged Jacko's return and pre-surrender publicity. Jacko said in an interview Tuesday he had spent the past two decades in Toronto, where he managed health food stores. He said he decided to turn himself in because he wanted to be near his mother, who is in poor health in Cleveland. Ensign said Jacko was on his way to New York and then Toronto, where his wife was waiting. He didn't know when they planned to go to Cleveland. Jacko said he was eager to see how his hometown had changed but hadn't decided whether he would settle down in northeastern Ohio or nearby Pennsylvania. He said he opposed the Vietnam war from the outset, but decided to enlist in hopes of pulling an assignment that didn't directly involve Vietnam. Assignment to communications school persuaded him he was likely to be shipped to Vietnam. He fled to Canada while on leave after basic training in 1969.

DOC.HEAD: Tamil Rebels Fire Mortars at Airfield
DOC.TEXT: Tamil rebels fired mortars at a vital airfield in the Jaffna Peninsula on Friday, minutes after a government minister departed following a new round of peace talks, military officials said. At least 275 people, including 137 unarmed policemen massacred by the rebels, have been killed since Monday when Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam gunmen started overruning police stations and military camps along the east coast and the north. The death toll was compiled from reports by witnesses, rebels and military sources. The government has not given an overall toll. The government said its troops switched from defensive to offensive tactics Friday and killed 50 Tigers. A Tiger spokesman acknowledged 50 rebel deaths in the past 48 hours. Justice Minister Shahul Hameed talked with Tamil Tiger leaders for four hours Friday at the rebel stronghold in Jaffna city, military officials said on condition of anonymity. The government did not say what was discussed at the meeting but said Hameed would return to Jaffna on Saturday following consultations with President Ranaisnghe Premadasa. After the talks, Hameed left for Colombo, the capital, from the Palali airbase. Minutes after his military plane took off, rebels fired mortars and machine guns at the airfield, the officials said. They said the attack was primarily a gesture of defiance as the shells and bullets fell short of the airfield, 12 miles from Jaffna. The Tigers have been fighting since 1983 for a separate homeland for the Tamil minority, who say they are discriminated against by the Sinhalese majority that controls the government. Tamils comprise 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 18 million people, while Sinhalese account for 75 percent. As Hameed made a fresh bid for a political solution, fighting raged in the northeast between government troops and the Tigers. Both sides claimed successes. A rebel spokesman contacted by telephone in Jaffna, 185 miles northeast of Colombo, claimed the Tigers were holding on to about 20 police stations captured since they launched their offensive. The spokesman, who uses the codename Jayapala, claimed the Tigers were still attacking in an effort to dislodge troops from all army camps in the north and east. Military officials claimed their troops, aided by air cover, were on the offensive Friday and had retaken at least three police stations: Muttur, Pottuvil and Vavuniya, among the largest in the north and east. In Parliament, opposition legislators charged the government had been ``taken for a ride'' by the Tigers. They accused the government of abdicating its rule to the rebels for more than a year. The Tigers took virtual control of the Tamil-dominated north and east after India withdrew its peacekeeping forces in March following an unsuccessful 32-month mission to disarm the rebels. More than 11,000 people have died in the 7-year-old Tamil insurrection. The latest round of fighting began after a Tamil man told the Tigers he was assaulted by a Sinhalese policeman on Sunday at a police station in the east.

DOC.HEAD: List of Worst U.S. Oil Spills
with PM-, AM-Tanker Blast
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of 10 of the worst oil spills in U.S. history:

1. March 24, 1989, Exxon Valdez, Prince William Sound, Alaska, 10.92 million gallons of crude spilled when the ship ran aground. 2. Nov. 1, 1979, Burmah Agate tanker, Galveston Bay, Texas, up to 10.7 million gallons of oil burned or spilled when two ships collided. 3. Dec. 15, 1976, Argo Merchant tanker, Massachusetts' southeastern coast, 7.6 million gallons of crude spilled when the ship ran aground. 4. Nov. 6, 1985, exploratory well, Ranger, Texas, 6.3 million gallons of oil spilled after a blowout. 5. June 8, 1990, Norwegian supertanker Mega Borg, 4.3 million gallons of light crude in the Gulf of Mexico following an explosion. 6. Jan. 2, 1988, Ashland Oil Co., above-ground storage tank, Jefferson Borough, Pa., 3.8 million gallons of oil spilled when a tank ruptured. 7. July 30, 1984, Alvenus tanker, Cameron, La., 2.8 million gallons of oil spilled after a ship ran aground. 8. Oct. 31, 1984, Puerto Rican tanker, San Francisco, 2 million gallons of oil spilled when a ship caught fire following an explosion. 9. Aug. 18, 1984, Triangle Oil Corp., above-ground storage tank, Jacksonville, Fla., 2.5 million gallons of oil burned after lightning sparked a fire. 10. Nov. 22, 1980, Georgia tanker, Pilottown, La., 1.3 million gallons of oil spilled after an anchor chain caused a ship to leak.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Leader Catches a Cold
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev has been contending with weighty problems like secessionist republics, warring ethnic groups and a crumbling economy. On Friday, he coped with a more common ailment: a cold. Gorbachev worked at home and stayed in touch by telephone, said Anatoly Lukyanov, chairman of the Supreme Soviet legislature. Lukyanov joked that some dreary weather during Gorbachev's trip to the United States 12 days for a superpower summit ago might be to blame for his ``little cold.'' Moscow also has been chilly and rainy for more than a week. ``It seems your American climate and ours coincided,'' Lukyanov told reporters. Lukyanov did not specify what Gorbachev was working on at home, but the Russian Communist Party Congress is next week and Gorbachev is expected to give an address. There was no indication that Gorbachev's ailment was anything more than just what Soviet officials said it was. Back in the pre-glasnost days, when aging Soviet leaders were out of sight for months suffering from serious illnesses, official statements would sometimes say they had a cold. At 59, Gorbachev is the youngest and most vigorous Soviet leader in years. Gregor Gysi, chairman of East Germany's Party of Democratic Socialism, had been scheduled to meet with Gorbachev on Friday. He told a Moscow news conference that the two had talked by telephone instead. ``I have just talked on the phone and I wished a speedy recovery to my colleague and I wished him to go back to his work as soon as possible,'' Gysi said. ``He caught a cold but I know that he is feeling better.'' Although the official English translator described the illness as a cold, East Germany's news agency ADN _ apparently based on Gysi's original comment in German _ quoted him as saying it was an ``infection.'' Gysi met Thursday with Alexander Yakovlev, a member of the ruling Politburo, instead of with Gorbachev. Gorbachev appeared healthy Tuesday, a long and grueling day for him. He gave a major speech to the legislature in the morning. In the afternoon, he met with the presidents of the 15 republics and offered a plan to transform the country into a looser union of ``sovereign states.'' In the evening, he offered separate compromise deals to leaders of the independence-minded Baltic states. The next day, he wasn't feeling too well. Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene was quoted as saying Gorbachev had begged off attending her meeting in the Kremlin with Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov on Wednesday. He said then he wasn't feeling well.

DOC.HEAD: Kassebaum Calls For Halt Of Exports To Iraq
DOC.TEXT:
A farm state senator called Friday for an end to U.S. exports to Iraq because of alleged human rights violations that include torturing and killing children, even though U.S. farmers might be hurt. ``There comes a time when I think some type of sanctions are necessary to send a message,'' Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., said during a Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing on Iraq. ``It would hurt wheat sales in Kansas, that's true. But sometimes we have to stand up and be counted,'' said Kassebaum, whose state is the largest U.S. wheat producer. She made the statement to John Kelly, assistant secretary of state for the Near East and South Asia. Iraq buys significant amounts of U.S. wheat. Under a credit guarantee program, Iraq purchased more than 1 million metric tons of U.S. wheat in 1989 valued at $170 million. It also buys rice, timber, cattle, and commercial goods under credit programs totaling more than $1 billion annually. The Bush administration is being increasingly pressured by Congress to take action against the government of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein because of a human rights record the State Department describes as ``abysmal'' and because of Iraq's efforts to develop nuclear and chemical weapons systems. On Wednesday, a House Appropriations subcommitolice left behind an army of agents and a Pandora's box of 6 million files that can ruin lives, expose collaborators or be a valuable source of information for Western intelligence.
A small group of ``reality'' tourists embark Sunday on a 10-day journey through Tennessee, Kentucky and Virginia billed as ``Appalachia: Third World in the United States.'' The organizers say they hope it will lead the travelers on a path to political activism. From San Francisco.
Republican Mayor Bob Isaac of Colorado Springs takes over this week as president of the U.S. Conference of Mayors, an organization dominated by big-city Democrats who often criticize President Bush. Isaac shares many of their complaints. From Chicago.
Although ``pristine'' is a word that doesn't apply to many Texas beaches, the coastline that will be hit by tar balls from the leaking Mega Borg supertanker still encompasses vital wildlife areas. From South Padre Island, Texas.
A Father's Day feature: Whipped cream, squirt guns and weather balloons are unconventional weapons in the war against drugs, but they are an important part of the arsenal of a doctor whose drug-user son committed suicide. This father and another man have started a group that tries to show kids how to have fun without drugs. From Newton, N.H.
DOC.HEAD: For Monday AMs:
DOC.TEXT:
Two on saving American forests: _A shy little owl is about to slow the flow of log-laden trucks through Northwest timber hamlets, to the outrage of timber workers and the applause of those who want to save remaining virgin forests. From Mossyrock, Wash. _The future of Alaska's immense Tongass National Forest, and that of the people who live off its riches, is in the hands of a congressional conference committee. From Juneau.
From Warsaw: Poland is awash in would-be benefactors, heads of state, ambassadors, governors, business executives and celebrities flooding into the country to talk about what can be done to help the country's economy. Some Poles say they have ``visitor fatigue.''
The revised U.S.-Japan security pact reaches its 30th anniversary this month like an old pair of shoes. They pinched a bit when new, but now are well-worn and familiar. From Tokyo.
From Washington, a report on the deceptions and omissions that contribute to the federal ``tax gap,'' the difference between what is owed and what is actually collected.
From Concord, N.H.: After three months of test voyages for schoolchildren, the state-of-the-art planetarium honoring space teacher Christa McAuliffe is about to open its doors _ and the heavens _ to the public.
After Marcia Biancardi died, reportedly by her own hand, the popular cheerleader's high school classmates pinned notes and flowers on her locker. But school officials removed the mementos for fear they would glorify suicide. Now the case has taken a rare turn: Marcia's mother has been charged with murder. From Beverly, Mass.
DOC.HEAD: For Monday PMs:
DOC.TEXT:
From Washington, an update on the federal government's underfinanced attempt to resolve the savings and loan crisis.
When Nelson Mandela steps off his borrowed private jet Wednesday at John F. Kennedy International Airport for his first look at the United States, he will be enveloped by parades and traffic jams, diplomatic meetings and pushy media circuses, adoring crowds and angry protesters. From New York.
America will lose the economic race with other countries unless business, schools and government take radical steps to boost worker skills, a commission led by two former labor secretaries warns. From New York.
From Manila: A shadowy group of young military officers claims to have organized an underground movement to overthrow Philippine President Corazon Aquino. Whether the organization actually exists _ or only issues press releases _ is a subject of speculation among government officials.
Death-row attorneys want to have Florida's hand-hewn, three-legged electric chair banned. They claim the last inmate executed was not electrocuted but burned to death. From Starke, Fla.
From Yellowstone National Park, a look at an upcoming visit by Soviet teenagers who will work on trail repairs in the park's back-country. The trip stems, in part, from the recent Bush-Gorbachev summit.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Bush Vetoes Easing of Rules on Federal Workers Politicking
With AM-Parental Leave, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush vetoed a bill easing 51-year-old curbs on off-duty political activity by government workers Friday, saying the measure could lead to ``political exploitation and abuse.'' Casting the 12th veto of his presidency two days after the Senate upheld the 11th, Bush said there was no compelling reason to modify the Hatch Act. ``The Hatch Act has upheld the integrity of the civil service by assuring that federal employees are hired and promoted based upon their qualifications and not their political loyalties,'' he said in a veto message to Congress. Robert Tobias, president of the National Treasury Employees Union, representing federal employes in 16 agencies and departments, called the veto ``wrongheaded'' and urged the Senate to override it. Although the measure passed both chambers by more than the two-thirds majorities needed to sustain a veto, Republican leaders have said they expect to be able to switch enough votes in the Senate to sustain the veto. Bush has yet to have a veto overridden. Just Wednesday, the Senate by a two-vote margin upheld his veto of a $2 billion Amtrak authorization bill. The Hatch Act revision would affect 3 million federal employees and postal workers, who are now prohibited from participating in any form of political activity beyond voting. Sent to Bush by a 334-87 House vote on Wednesday, the bill would allow government employees to work in political campaigns on their own time, hold office in a political party and attend political conventions. However, the measure would leave intact prohibitions against running for partisan political office and soliciting money from the public. Sponsors said the measure would extend some of the same fundamental freedoms now enjoyed by most Americans to federal and postal workers. But Bush said he was opposed to any tinkering with the Hatch Act, passed in 1939 to prevent Depression-era government workers from being pressured to work for President Franklin D. Roosevelt's re-election effort. Bush said the easing would ``inevitably lead to repoliticizing'' the government bureaucracy. ``It has been manifestly successful over the years in shielding civil servants and the programs they administer from political exploitation and abuse,'' Bush wrote. ``We cannot afford, in the final decade of this century, to embark on a retreat into the very worst aspects of public administration from the last century,'' he said. Tobias, the federal union official, urged lawmakers to ``hold fast to their commitment to federal workers.'' He said in a statement, ``Senators must maintain their courageous support of reform and not trade their collective conscience for White House cufflinks or breakfast with Bush.'' The Senate passed the same bill last month by a vote of 67-30. That would be just enough for a veto override. But GOP Senate leaders have expressed confidence they can persuade one or two of their colleagues to change votes. In sending the bill back to Congress with a veto, Bush told lawmakers: ``As one who has devoted much of his life to public service, I take great pride in the integrity of our federal work force.''

DOC.HEAD: At Least Ten Dead in Ohio Flooding
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with ten now dead, source of information. Picks up 5th graf pvs: `Gov. Richard ...'
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms swept through central and eastern Ohio, causing flooding that killed at least ten people, left dozens missing and forced hundreds of others from their homes, officials said today. Two creeks just outside this Ohio River village of 4,300 people overflowed when about 4 inches of rain fell Thursday night in about an hour. ``It created a wall of water,'' said Jim Williams of the Ohio Emergency Management Agency. ``The problem we're having right now is accounting for the people we can't find.'' Williams said 40 to 60 people remained unaccounted for at midday. Belmont County's sheriff's Sgt. Bart Giesey said 10 people were confirmed dead. Gov. Richard Celeste declared a state of emergency and surveyed the area. The raging waters knocked homes off their foundations and washed away a bar filled with people in Shadyside, an Appalachian Mountain foothill town. Temporary morgues were set up at Bellaire City Hospital and a funeral home in Shadyside. Four bodies were brought to the hospital from the Shadyside area, hospital spokesman Lawrence England said. England said the four bodies were taken to the Bauknecht Funeral Home in Shadyside. Patty Valloric, director of the funeral home, said seven bodies had been brought there. The Shadyside Fire Department set up a command center at the Jefferson Elementary School to coordinate rescue efforts. Command center spokeswoman Karen Bovek said officials had no complete death toll figure. Authorities were searching for victims in rural areas. ``You're talking miles and miles of country roads that haven't been gotten to yet,'' she said. ``It's a disaster here.'' Shadyside _ about 10 miles south of Wheeling, W.Va. _ is in Belmont County, a mostly hilly, rural area in eastern Ohio. Acting Mayor James Amato said the storms created a deluge that knocked homes off their foundations. ``There are a lot of trailers out in this area that got hit,'' he said. Belmont County Sheriff's Department spokeswoman Judy Phillips said a Shadyside bar full of people was washed away when water caved in the back wall. Two people were accounted for, she said. But she could offer no estimate of how many were in the bar. Shadyside Fire Chief Mark Badia said rescuers pulled people from three cars in Wegee Creek, which flows through Shadyside and into the Ohio River. ``I don't know how to describe it ... you've got to see it to believe it,'' Badia said. There also was flooding in Jefferson County, north of Belmont, and Licking County in central Ohio. The Ohio departments of transportation and natural resources, the State Highway Patrol, the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio and the American Red Cross are assisting state government in assessing the damage, Ohio Emergency Management Agency spokeswoman Stacie Gilg said. About 200 residents were evacuated from their homes in central Ohio after 3 inches of rain fell in an hour, flooding streets and washing out rural roads. Residents from Newark and Marne in Licking County spent Thursday night in three emergency shelters, said Licking County Disaster Services Agency spokesman Neil Snelling. Sixty residents were from one street in Newark. ``Nobody has been hurt, but everything is pretty wet here,'' Snelling said. The Newark Fire Department and other agencies evacuated residents in low-lying areas of Newark and the neighboring village of Marne, said Wayne Tresemer, Licking County Disaster Services director. He said water was standing up to 5 feet deep in some streets on the city's east side, and the Newark Fire Department and other agencies used boats to evacuated some residents. Licking County was already among 14 Ohio counties covered in a disaster declaration issued by President Bush for storms earlier this month, and people who suffered losses from Thursday night's storms will also be eligible for assistance, Ms. Gilg said. In Jefferson County, 50 to 60 residents were evacuated in Adena, where water was 6 to 8 feet deep in streets because of creek flooding. Two inches of rain caused flooding in Franklin County in central Ohio and 3.75 inches of rain was dumped on Holmes County in north-central Ohio, the National Weather Service said. Flood waters in most areas had subsided by Thursday night, the weather service and local authorities said. The forecast for today called for a slight chance of thunderstorms in central and southern Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Government Bans Only Remaining Opposition Group
DOC.TEXT: The Iranian government has banned the country's only remaining legal opposition party after arresting eight of its members, an exiled Iranian group said Friday. The reported actions against the Freedom Movement, led by former Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan, signaled the final crushing of any organized domestic opposition to the cleric-led government. A ruling by the revolutionary prosecutor in Tehran declared the group illegal, according to Ali Safavi, spokesman in Baghdad for the Mujahedeen Khalq or People's Holy Warriors, an Iranian opposition group based in Iraq. There was no immediate confirmation from Iran's official news agency, monitored in Cyprus. Iranian state television reported Thursday night that eight of Bazargan's associates had been arrested. The report said those arrested held secret foreign contacts and acted against Iran's interests during the eight-year Gulf war against Iraq that ended in August 1988. It gave no other details. Among those detained was Bazargan's son, whose name was not given, and Ezzatollah Sahabi, a former planning minister under Bazargan, the Mujahedeen said. Bazargan apparently has not been arrested. Bazargan, a French-educated engineer who was jailed by Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, was selected prime minister by Iranian spiritual leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini on Feb. 23, 1979, a few days after the revolution. But his moderate policies seeking gradual social and economic reforms caused him to fall in disfavor with the fundamentalists. Accused by his opponents of being pro-American, he resigned two days after militants seized the U.S. Embassy in Tehran in November 1979. Since then, Bazargan's small Freedom Movement has been allowed to function as a token opposition party with some freedom to criticize Iranian authorities. The Freedom Movement demanded that Khomeini end the bloody war with Iraq. All other opposition groups were brutally suppressed, mainly during the early post-revolutionary years when the Tudeh, or Communist Party, and other leftist groups were crushed. Bazargan's main political action has been to circulate periodic letters critical of government policies. About a month ago, Bazargan and about 90 others signed an ``open letter'' to President Hashemi Rafsanjani calling for restoration of constitutional rights. The letter condemned the government for trampling on civil liberties and accused it of economic mismanagement and isolating Iran internationally. The letter said ``the country is on the verge of an abyss,'' and that ``none of the principles of freedom, justice and independence have been fulfilled.'' ``What you have produced for the poor are slogans and empty stomachs,'' said the letter, which condemned the government for unemployment, rising prices and the squandering of billions of dollars in oil income. After the letter was made public, Khomeini's successor as spiritual leader, Ali Khamenei, criticized the Bazargan group.

DOC.HEAD: Frank Lloyd Wright House Saved Once, Threatened Again
LaserPhoto NY18
DOC.TEXT: It was built against the odds in 1940 and saved from destruction 25 years ago. Now a lovingly preserved Frank Lloyd Wright house faces a new threat: shifting ground is tearing it apart. And it will cost hundreds of thousands of dollars to save the house, which was built for $7,000. In 1963, the spare little house in then-rural Falls Church lay in the path of progress: Interstate 66. The home's owner and the National Trust for Historic Preservation teamed up to move the house, board by board, to a similarly wooded site several miles away, on the grounds of the Trust's Woodlawn Plantation. That act of salvage could lead to the home's eventual deterioration. The Pope-Leighey house, built in 1940 and named for its first and second owners, was rebuilt in 1964 on a seam of highly unstable clay. To make matters worse, fill dirt was used atop the clay seam. ``It's fair to say when the house was moved and reconstructed, we didn't know as much ... as we do today,'' Pope-Leighey director Linda Cunningham Goldstein said. Cracks more than an inch wide snake through the concrete floors. Smaller cracks are visible in the walls of one bedroom. The National Trust has considered numerous ideas for saving the house a second time. Engineers and Trust officials have largely ruled out another move. ``Every time you rebuild something, you lose something,'' Ms. Goldstein said. ``We have to think very carefully about it if we were to (construct) it a third time.'' Instead, engineers likely will try to stabilize the foundation, perhaps using steel rods or plates. Ms. Goldstein said she expects a decision within a few weeks. The project could cost hundreds of thousands of dollars, but there is no reliable estmate yet, Ms. Goldstein said. A fund-aising arm of the non-profit Trust will make a public appeal for the house, Ms. Goldstein said. The brick, cypress and glass house was built for Loren B. Pope, a young Washington newspaperman who told Wright he made $50 a week. ``There are certain things a man wants during life, and, of life. Material things and things of the spirit. The writer has one fervent wish that includes both. It is for a house created by you,'' Pope wrote in August 1939. Two weeks later, Wright replied: ``Of course I am ready to give you a house.'' Wright, credited with remaking 20th century American architecture, was already famous and highly controversial when Pope made his appeal. Pope's infatuation with the modern architect was not shared by Washington banks, which refused to lend Pope money to build the house. In the end, the Washington Star, where Pope worked as an editor, lent him the money to build the house. He lived there six years. Pope, who is now 80 and runs a research service for prospective college students, is aiding fund-raising efforts by appearing in a documentary filmed at the house this spring. ``The Wright house is a very central part of my life. It was a real adventure for a guy making just $50 a week and no safety nets at all,'' Pope said in a telephone interview from his Washington office. ``It was like living in a work of art,'' he said. The 1,250-square-foot, single-story home features Wright's trademark flat, cantilevered roofs and simple exterior. A cantilever over the driveway forms what was believed to be the world's first carport. ``Of course it's worth saving. It's a prime example of Wright's `usonian' ideas. It's really a unique thing,'' University of Virginia architecture professor and Wright scholar Richard G. Wilson said. ``Usonian'' was Wright's term for a philosophy of affordable family housing entirely different from traditional, rectangular styles. It is the only usonian home open to the public on the East Coast, Ms. Goldstein said. ``It is very small on square footage, but very big on ideas,'' she said. ``There are no little separate spaces for doing this or that. There is instead the one, central living area. Wright really envisioned the family as a family, living in very close proximity.''

DOC.HEAD: Iran, U.S. Settle $600 Million Oil-Company Claim
DOC.TEXT: Iran removed one of the biggest obstacles to renewed trade with the United States on Friday by agreeing to pay a U.S. oil company $600 million for facilities seized during the 1979 Islamic revolution. Two claims totaling $600 million were awarded to the American oil giant Amoco, said an official of the Iran-United States Claims Tribunal. It was the biggest settlement in the arbitration body's nine-year history. The Tehran government has hinted recently that the resolution of financial disputes with the United States might contribute to the release of the six American hostages held by pro-Iranian Shiite extremists in Lebanon. Last month, settlement of a much smaller claims package was announced shortly after the release of American hostages Robert Polhill and Frank Reed. American and Iranian officials at the tribunal have vigorously denied conducting any direct talks on the hostage issue. They said the tribunal deals only with arbitration of financial disputes. The Amoco settlement was among more than $1.8 billion in oil company claims stemming from Iran's Islamic revolution led by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. U.S.-Iranian ties were severed over the holding of hostages at the United States Embassy in Tehran for 444 days by Iranian militants. The tribunal official, in a telephone interview, repeated ``our strong position'' that the arbitration is not tied to the fate of the American hostages in Lebanon. At issue in Friday's settlement were two claims filed by Amoco subsidiaries against the National Iranian Oil Company, according to the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity in line with tribunal policy. The Amoco Iran Oil Co. is receiving $540 million worth of compensation for the seizure of four Persian Gulf drilling fields and the oil terminal on Kharg island, which is Iran's most important oil terminal. The Amoco International Finance Corp. is to receive $60 million for the expropriation of a petrochemical processing plant on Kharg, the official said. Iran derives 90 percent of its foreign currency earnings from oil exports, and President Hashemi Rafsanjani has been making efforts recently to improve and expand trade with the West. However, he has faced strong opposition from Islamic militants who want nothing to do with the United States. Until Friday, a $116 million award made in 1986 to the Sedco firm had been the biggest single settlement by the tribunal since its 1981 inception, according to the official. The firm built drilling platforms in Iran before the revolution. The tribunal was set up as part of the 1980 Algiers Accord, which helped win the freedom of the embassy hostages. The panel has three American judges, three Iranians and three third-nation members. So far it has settled $3.2 billion worth of government-to-government and private claims. Approximately 150 such claims are still pending, according to the tribunal official, who could not specify their total worth. The biggest item still on the tribunal's agenda is an $11 billion claim filed by Iran for military equipment ordered before the revolution and not delivered under the subsequent U.S. embargo. The U.S. government contends that much of the weaponry at issue is not under its control but belongs to private contractors whose bills were never paid by Tehran. Washington claims that the some of the hardware Iran did pay for was sold to private buyers and the proceeds deposited in Iran's bank accounts. Among those items were four warships taken over by the U.S. Navy, the U.S. government has said.

DOC.HEAD: `Brother Can You Spare a Dime?' Composer Dead at 93
DOC.TEXT: Jay Gorney, who wrote the music for the Depression-era classic ``Brother Can You Spare a Dime?,'' has died at age 93. Gorney died of Parkinson's disease Thursday at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged, said his wife, Sondra. ``Brother Can You Spare a Dime?,'' which has lyrics by E.Y. Harburg, was introduced in the 1932 Broadway revue ``Americana.'' Gorney's other Broadway hits included ``Sweetheart Time'' and ``Merry Go Round.'' A native of Russia, Gorney was 6 years old when he moved to the United States with his family. He began writing songs professionally in the 1920's for Broadway revues. Gorney went to Hollywood in 1933 and wrote for the movies. Shirley Temple and James Dunn performed his song ``Baby, Take a Bow'' in the 1934 move ``Stand Up and Cheer.'' His songs were performed in several other movies including, ``Jimmy and Sally,'' ``Moonlight and Pretzels,'' ``Wild Gold,'' ``Lottery Lover,'' ``Redheads on Parade,'' ``The Heat's On,'' and ``Hey Rookie.'' In addition to his wife, Gorney is survived by a daughter and two sons.

DOC.HEAD: Over 160 Arrests in Nationwide Crackdown on Street Gangs and Drugs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with further details, quotes, background. ^By JEFF WILSON
DOC.TEXT: More than 160 of the nation's most feared street thugs were arrested in a two-day nationwide gang roundup targeting members of the violent Crips and Bloods, federal officials said today. Stephen E. Higgins, director of the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, said 11 states were involved in operation Street Sweep and more arrests and drug and weapons seizures were expected through the weekend. ``What began as a Los Angeles problem has now spread to a national one,'' he said. ``This is a significant step to our commitment attacking drugs.'' Arrests were made in California, Louisiana, Arizona, Missouri, Oklahoma, Oregon, Washington and four other states which were not immediately identified. ``Gang members are involved in murders, drive-by shootings, narcotics trafficking, assaults, credit car fraud, robberies and money laundering,'' Higgins said. During a morning news conference, authorities displayed a sample of confiscated weapons. The bureau's national investigation revealed the Crips and Bloods are heavily involved in crack distribution and firearms trafficking, he said. The largest narcotics seizure was nearly 13 pounds of cocaine worth $250,000 in Shreveport, La. The operation began Thursday and continued today. The majority of arrests were in Southern California, where 134 people were taken into custody. The Los Angeles part of the roundup was done with the Los Angeles Police Department's Operation Hammer, extensive anti-gang sweeps that have been undertaken since February 1988. ``Operation Hammer is intended to put as much pressure as possible on gang members who are pushing drugs and carrying guns,'' Police Chief Daryl F. Gates said today. Asked if federal law enforcement felt they would achieve victory in the war on drugs, Higgins said: ``I'm convinced it's a winnable war. We're in it for the long term.''

DOC.HEAD: GOP Sponsor, Democrats Urge Bush Not to Veto Family Leave Bill
DOC.TEXT: Democrats pressed President Bush on Friday to sign a bill guaranteeing workers emergency family leave, quoting 1988 candidate George Bush to support their arguments against his threatened veto. The Republican sponsor of the bill also urged Bush to sign it, saying a veto on such a ``bedrock family issue'' could backfire for the GOP. The family leave bill went to the White House after the Senate approved it Thursday evening on a voice vote. Bush did not respond to a question about it during a photo session Friday. But press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said ``Yes'' when asked if Bush would veto the bill. White House officials have said Bush does support ``flexible family leave policies'' by all employers but believes they should not be mandated by government. The bill's main Republican sponsor, Rep. Marge Roukema, R-N.J., urged Bush not to act until she and other backers could meet with him. She said a veto would leave the Republican Party open to charges it is insensitive to working families. ``The point that has to be considered here is, do we want to be perceived as the party that fights for a reduction in the capital gains tax while we turn our backs on taxpaying, hard-working American families who are in medical crisis,'' she said. The bill passed comfortably in the House last month, although the margin fell 46 votes short of the two-thirds majority that would be needed to override a veto. Senate passage came without a recorded vote. Sponsor Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., said he was ``within two or three votes'' of a two-thirds majority. Bush has vetoed 12 bills so far and hasn't been overridden on any. The new legislation would require business and government employers to provide workers with up to 12 weeks of unpaid medical leave or with leave so they could care for a newly born or adopted child or an ill child, parent or spouse. Employers would have to continue health coverage and then restore a returning employee to his or her previous job or an equivalent position. Seemingly confident the bill has broad public support, Democrats taunted Bush with his own campaign rhetoric. At a news conference Friday, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell read from a campaign speech Bush made to a Republican women's group in Illinois in fall 1988, while Bush was running for president. He quoted Bush: ``We also need to assure that women don't have to worry about getting their jobs back after having a child or caring for a child during a serious illness. This is what I meant when I talked about a gentler nation.'' ``Those are Mr. Bush's words before he became president,'' Mitchell said. ``Now it's up to the president to live up to his words.'' Democrats saw the issue as raising family values in a way that favors them politically, at a time when many are under attack for opposing Bush's constitutional amendment against flag burning. Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., described Bush as ``wrapping himself in the flag and coming out against parenthood.'' The bill would cover about half of all U.S. workers, and is strongly opposed by business groups. It exempts businesses with fewer than 50 employees, and the highest-paid 10 percent within a company. Roukema and several other supporters cited their own experiences during debate. Roukema said she was fortunate enough to be able to stay at home when her child was dying of leukemia. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., said he was able to leave the Senate for prolonged periods when his son Teddy was stricken with cancer. Dodd recalled that Bush cited a similar experience as well _ the death of one of his young children _ during a 1988 debate with Democratic nominee Michael Dukakis. ``Certainly having lived through that experience, he knows what it's like to be in the midst of a family crisis,'' Dodd said. ``That goes on every minute of every day in this country, for thousands and thousands of families.'' Roukema said she had received no response from the White House despite repeated requests for a meeting with Bush and Chief of Staff John Sununu, who pledged to business lobbyists last month that Bush would veto the bill. ``I fully expect that the president will give we Republicans who support this bill the courtesy of a meeting prior to any action,'' she said. ``I'm appealing to him that he not take any action until he hears from people like myself.''

DOC.HEAD: College Building Collapses, 35 Feared Dead
DOC.TEXT: A private school building collapsed Friday in the eastern oil city of Port Harcourt, killing at least 23 students and injuring 60, witnesses and hospital workers said. More than 300 policemen were digging through the collapsed structure for 15 other students feared trapped in the rubble, a police spokesman said. The accident occurred as about 200 students gathered for a debate in a room on the third floor of the building, which was still under construction, said one survivor, 19-year-old Elizabeth Ikaedim. She said many of the students were trapped on a staircase when they tried to flee as the walls began collapsing. The police spokesman said the owner of the building had been arrested. A police source said the building owner did not have a permit for the construction.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Propose Negotiations in Autumn on Tactical Nuclear Weapons
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has urged the Western allies to begin negotiations this fall to get rid of short-range nuclear weapons in Europe, NATO officials said Friday. But alliance diplomats immediately dismissed the suggestion, saying bargaining on nuclear arms should take place only after agreement on an accord to reduce tanks, artillery and other conventional weapons in Europe. ``We will stick to our timetable,'' said one diplomat, who demanded anonymity. ``This is the logical way to proceed. First things first.'' The Kremlin has in the past pressed the Western nations for early talks on nuclear weapons and, sources said, did so again this week in a proposal to the United States in Washington. ``The Soviet Union proposed to the United States to start negotiations on the elimination of SNF (short-range nuclear forces) in the autumn of this year,'' said Florent Swijsen, spokesman for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. He said the offer would be discussed by President Bush and other alliance leaders at a summit July 5-6 in London. Under the proposal, the Soviet Union wants to negotiate the elimination not only of land-based nuclear arms in Europe, but also air-launched systems, the sources said. It also would like to bring France's independent nuclear arsenal into the talks, they said. France belongs to NATO but remains outside its joint military structure. The issue of short-range nuclear weapons in Europe has become increasingly controversial with the easing of tensions between NATO and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. The West's battlefield weapons, most based in West Germany, would hit targets in now-friendly countries in Eastern Europe. The term short-range is applied to weapons with ranges of less than about 300 miles. The Western allies have agreed that there is a ``diminishing need'' for short-range nuclear arms in their arsenal.
