Bush earlier this year cancelled U.S. plans to build a more powerful version of the Lance short-range missile and a modernized 155mm nuclear-tipped artillery shell. Even so, the allies have continued to insist the Western defense requires ``an appropriate mix'' of conventional and nuclear arms ``for the foreseeable future.'' With a reduction in land-based forces, analysts expect NATO to put more emphasis on air-launched nuclear systems. The United States is developing a tactical air-to-surface missile (TASM), which would replace gravity bombs. A West German official said last week, however, that the Bonn government did not want the new weapons based on its territory. NATO foreign ministers last week agreed at a meeting in Scotland to support a Bush suggestion for a speedier timetable for negotiations on short-range nuclear forces. They said those talks could begin ``shortly after'' a conventional arms accord was concluded. At a May 1989 summit, Bush and the other leaders had linked the bargaining to implementation of the treaty. NATO diplomats reiterated their latest position. ``We have got to complete the CFE (conventional armed forces in Europe) agreement and then get on with it,'' said one official, who like the others demanded anonymity. ``There's enough to digest before we get on with SNF,'' he said. Another diplomat said the conventional arms talks were ``quite complicated'' and added: ``We shouldn't complicate them (further) with new topics of negotiation.'' A spokesman for the U.S. mission to NATO, speaking on condition of anonymity, said, ``We note the continuing large imbalance in Soviet short-range nuclear weapons. Elimination of this imbalance is long overdue.'' ``The United States is prepared to enter into talks for the reduction of short-range nuclear systems as soon as the CFE talks are completed,'' he said. The 16 NATO nations and the seven of the Warsaw Pact have said they want to strike a conventional arms deal this year, although Western officials have complained about Soviet foot-dragging. On Thursday, diplomats in Vienna said the two sides were close to agreement on overall limits for tanks and armored combat vehicles in Europe. Moscow and Washington already have agreed to limit their stationed forces in Central Europe to 195,000 on each side. The United States would retain an additional 30,000 troops in Britain and southern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Names Washington Lawyer, Personal Aide To Government Posts
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday announced his selection of W. Lee Rawls, a Washington, D.C., attorney, as assistant attorney general for legislative affairs. If confirmed by the Senate, Rawls, 45, would succeed Carol T. Crawford, who resigned last year. Rawls, a former aide to Sen. Pete V. Domenici, R-N.M., is a managing partner of a Washington law firm. Bush also announced his intention to nominate Timothy J. McBride, his personal aide for the past five years, to be assistant commerce secretary for trade development. McBride, 31, would succeed Michael Philip Skarzynski. At Bush's side throughout the day, McBride is in charge of the details of Bush's official life, a job he also held when Bush was vice president. Bush has not yet selected a replacement for McBride, whose official title is special assistant to the president.

DOC.HEAD: China and Vietnam Hold First Talks Since Border Conflict
DOC.TEXT: The first high-level Chinese delegation to visit Vietnam since a border war in 1979 has ended talks on improving relations between the nations, official Vietnamese radio said. Radio Hanoi said Chinese Deputy Foreign Minister Xu Dunxin and Vietnamese Deputy Foreign Minister Tran Quang Co held discussions in Hanoi on Tuesday and Wednesday. ``The exchange of views took place in a friendly atmosphere and helped enhance the understanding between the two countries,'' said the broadcast, a text of which was seen in Bangkok on Friday. The broadcast said they exchanged views on the 11-year-old civil war in Cambodia and on bilateral relations, but gave no other details. China is the principal backer of three Cambodian guerrilla factions fighting the Vietnamese-installed government in Phnom Penh. Earlier this month in Tokyo, the Khmer Rouge, the strongest guerrilla faction, refused to sign a cease-fire pact. China also refused to support the agreement. China supported North Vietnam during the Vietnam War, but relations became strained in 1978 over border disputes and the treatment of ethnic Chinese in Vietnam. China launched a brief border war in early 1979 in retaliation for Vietnam's opposition to the Chinese-backed government in Cambodia.

DOC.HEAD: You Too Can Resemble the Jut-Jawed Detective
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Even if your chin couldn't cut sheetrock and you don't have a two-way wrist radio, you, too, can look like Dick Tracy _ thanks to a line of Tracy togs and accessories at a department store near you. Nobody held a gun on the shoppers who turned out at Manhattan stores Friday, kicking off the Tracy paraphernalia onslaught by laying out cash for yellow fedoras ($30), Tracy towels ($20) and Tracy T-shirts ($14). Want the great detective's jutting jaw on your face? $50 for a mask. How about a denim jacket with his likeness across the back? $115. A leather bomber jacket with the omnipresent Tracy logo? $195. Or his trademark yellow trenchcoat? $345. Believe it, sweetheart. And stores were giving customers the hard sell on the goods, which were generated by the incredibly hyped Warren Beatty flick that opened nationally Friday. The second floor at Bloomingdale's featured a stack of eight televisions running the movie's trailer non-stop. In another section of The Dick Tracy Shop there, a tape of co-star Madonna belted out ``Vogue'' and songs from the film soundtrack over and over and over ... ``This is all for that movie?'' asked one woman as she handed over $28 for a pair of T-shirts. The Tracy togs were so prevalent that they _ gasp! _ displaced Bart Simpson and family from the top of the T-shirt racks. ``It's great. My wife says they're quite well made, not trashy,'' said Roger Dutton, a Melbourne, Australia, resident who was clutching a pair of towels. ``You pay premium for the premium goods, I guess.'' In another section, lacy bustiers, flapper dresses and other skin-flashing selections worn by Breathless Mahoney (that's Madonna, folks) drew plenty of interest, but not as many buyers. ``If I could get away with this stuff in Kokomo, I'd wear it,'' said Linda Dechert, who was visiting from Indiana. ``I think this stuff will catch on with the younger crowd. Madonna's so popular.'' The Madonna-Breathless outfits aren't as daring as the ones that cling to the singer in the movie. ``Some of her gowns were slit down to the navel. We didn't go quite that far,'' said Elaine Johnson of L.A. Glo, which is handling the clothes. At Macy's flagship 34th Street store, the eighth floor was covered in Tracy yellow, with painted black silhouettes of Tracy and his nemeses Big Boy and Flattop. ``Calling All Crimestoppers to Herald Square'' read a Macy's newspaper ad, and more people than that responded. Although store policy is not to release sales figures, things were going well on Day One of the Tracy explosion. ``Our shop is well-traveled, quite popular,'' said Barbara Lewinski, spokeswoman for the store. ``And once the film opens this weekend, it should get bigger.''

DOC.HEAD: Retail Prices Up 0.2 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Retail prices rose a modest 0.2 percent in May, easing the strain on consumers' budgets for the second straight month after a painful spurt in prices early in the year, the government said Friday. In other economic news, the Commerce Department said the U.S. trade deficit shrank to $6.94 billion in April, the second lowest level in the last six years. And, the Federal Reserve said industrial production rebounded an unexpectedly strong 0.6 percent last month after holding steady in April. The April and May moderation in the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index curbed inflation for the first five months of the year to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.8 percent. That's up significantly from the 4.6 percent rate for all of last year, but down sharply from the worrisome 8.5 percent rate in the first quarter. ``Inflation remains low and under control,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. The better news on inflation was expected by most economists, who said prices are recovering from weather-related increases for food, energy and clothing. Prices for fuel oil and vegetables shot up in January and February in reaction to an unusually severe freeze around Christmas. After that, a warm spell stimulated early sales of more expensive spring clothing lines, sending apparel costs higher. ``What you need to keep in mind here is that the moderation in May is mainly an unwinding of the price spikes you got earlier in the year,'' said economist Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch. ``Although we should be happy to get these kinds of numbers, they are probably understating inflation just as the numbers at the beginning of the year were overstating it.'' Food prices rose only 0.1 percent last month after falling 0.2 percent a month earlier. Energy costs dropped 0.7 percent, the fourth monthly decline following a large increase in January. Prices excluding the volatile food and energy sectors, often taken as a better barometer of underlying inflation than the overall calculation of prices, rose a moderate 0.3 percent after increasing 0.2 percent a month earlier. The various changes put the index for all consumer prices at 129.2 in May. That means a hypothetical selection of goods and services costing $100 in the 1982-84 base period would have cost $129.20 last month, up from $123.80 a year ago. The recent mild inflation meant that Americans' average weekly earnings, after adjusting for inflation, increased 0.3 percent in May. Still, for the last 12 months, earnings fell 0.1 percent. Average weekly earnings in May, before adjusting for inflation, were $344.31, up from $330.86 a year earlier. Both the 17 percent improvement in the trade gap and the moderation of inflation were taken by analysts as a sign of a weak domestic economy, which translates into lower demand for imports and lower prices for goods in general. The industrial production report, although a sign of strength, was considered somewhat of a fluke. Much of it was attributed to a buildup in inventories by the Big Three automakers worried about a strike in September. Opinion was mixed over whether economic weakness will prompt the Federal Reserve to nudge short-term interest rates lower. Bond prices plunged after the reports, a sign that traders believed the economy was not weak enough nor inflation calm enough to trigger an easier monetary policy. But Steinberg, noting the long lag between a change in policy and a corresponding reaction in the economy, said, ``It seems to me the Fed, if it doesn't want to see the economy weaken further, will have to ease sometime in the near future, probably in July.'' The department offered these other details of May consumer prices: _Fruit and vegetable costs fell 2.4 percent, their third substantial drop in a row. Vegetable prices soared 29.2 percent in the first two months of the year before falling 23.6 percent in the next three months. Dairy costs fell for the third consecutive month while prices were up for sweets, fats and oils and beverages. _Fuel oil costs declined 1.4 percent; natural gas, 2.7 percent. Electricity charges rose 1 percent. Gasoline prices rose modestly, but less than usual for the start of the warm weather driving season. Thus, after seasonal adjustment, gasoline prices were reported down 1.6 percent. _Clothing costs fell 0.3 percent. Prices for men's clothing rose 0.4 percent, but the cost of women's and children's clothing fell 1 percent and 2.2 percent respectively. _New car prices edged down 0.2 percent, their fourth consecutive decline in the face of sluggish sales. _The price of medical care jumped 0.8 percent in May for the fourth consecutive month, pushing those costs 9 percent higher than a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Arnold Schwarzenegger, his wife Maria Shriver and their daughter will be their church's ``honorary chair family'' for a benefit this fall. The star of such action thriller films as ``Total Recall,'' ``Terminator'' and ``Conan the Barbarian'' will help promote the Oktoberfest at St. Monica's Catholic Church, Monsignor Lloyd Torgerson said Thursday. ``We are very grateful to the Schwarzenegger family, who are parishioners to our parish, to participate in our event as the honorary chair family,'' said Torgerson, the pastor. Other celebrities who said they would attend include Meredith Baxter-Birney, Lou Ferrigno, Paul Michael Glaser and Cindy Williams. The 10th annual Oktoberfest, beginning Oct. 5, is a three-day fund-raiser to benefit St. Monica's parish, parish schools and local outreach programs for the homeless.

Jean MacArthur, the 91-year-old widow of Gen. Douglas MacArthur, had her long-time pal Barbara Bush at her side Friday when she cut a ribbon to open a new research center of the MacArthur Memorial. Mrs. MacArthur said it was her first speech. ``I left all that to the general,'' she said. ``When I was with my husband during World War II, I visited many of the hospitals and I used to say to myself that I was so proud of the American military because they were so proud of being Americans,'' Mrs. MacArthur said. ``She stood by the general through Corregidor, Australia and Japan,'' Mrs. Bush said of her friend. ``This quiet, gentle woman is loved by all who know her.'' MacArthur commanded American troops in the Pacific during World War II and oversaw the occupation of Japan at the end of the war. He also was commander of United Nations forces in Korea before being relieved in 1951 by President Truman. The $1.1 million expansion of the MacArthur Memorial was paid for through private donations. The city-owned memorial draws 80,000 visitors a year. MacArthur's body is entombed there.

Elizabeth Taylor was home recuperating Friday, ``very weak'' but in good condition after a two-month fight with pneumonia, her spokeswoman said. ``She's doing fine,'' Taylor's spokeswoman Chen Sam said Friday. The violet-eyed actress, with hair coiffed and makeup on, waved and smiled to reporters Thursday night as she was driven from the hospital toward her Beverly Hills home. ``She's very weak from having been in the hospital for a very long time but thank heaven she's home,'' Ms. Sam said. Miss Taylor, 58, will stay home for a couple of months, Ms. Sam said. The New York publicist quoted Miss Taylor as saying, ``I am finally glad to be going home. My sole concern at this time is focused on my getting well and carrying on with my life.'' Miss Taylor was in St. John's since April 16. She had been in the hospital's intensive care unit for treatment of viral pneumonia. At one point in late April, her breathing was assisted by a ventilator. The screen beauty has won two Oscars. She starred in ``Butterfield 8,'' ``Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' and more than 50 other films.

Country music star Randy Travis says his current single record, ``He Walked on Water,'' brings back memories of his own grandfather. The song is about a boy's relationship with his great-grandfather and was written by Allen Shamblin. ``I had a grandfather that I can relate that to, very much so,'' Travis said. ``I used to ride with him on the tractor and go with him in his car everywhere he went, ride on the horse if he was plowing with the horse.'' He says once he ran over his grandfather's hat with his bicycle after being warned to be careful. ``He caught me by the arm, jerked me off that bicycle and popped me one time real good,'' Travis said. ``I ran off and got a few feet from him and picked up a handful of rocks and started throwing them at him. So he started throwing them back at me. ``It was funny, neighbors driving by and here's this man _ he was about 60 at that time _ and his grandkid out there throwing rocks at each other.''

DOC.HEAD: Largest Gold Producers to Curtail Operations
DOC.TEXT: The world's two largest gold-producing companies said Friday they were curtailing operations due to the falling price of gold. More than 7,800 people were to lose their jobs as a result. Anglo-American Corp. of South Africa Ltd. said two of its mining companies _ Free State State Consolidated Gold Mines Ltd. (Freegold) and Vaal Reefs Exploration and Mining Co. Ltd. _ would cut back on their operations. Earlier this week, two other mining groups outside the Anglo-American conglomerate announced job cutbacks involving 1,100 workers. Gold is South Africa's major industry, earning more than half the country's foreign currency. Lionel Hewitt, managing director of Anglo-American's gold and uranium division said the company had made efforts in recent months to maintain existing levels of operation, including cost-reduction measures and deferment of expenditures. ``Despite these efforts, at current gold prices and operating costs, certain mining areas are now incapable of sustaining mining operations at their present levels,'' Hewitt said. The price of gold reached a four-year low of $346.25 per ounce in New York and London before recovering Thursday. It was trading at $347.50 per ounce in New York on Friday afternoon. Hewitt said the cutback would take place over the next nine months, and probably result in the loss of 7,800 jobs at Freegold. He said reducing operations at Vaal Reefs would not necessarily involve loss of jobs, because workers may be assigned to other areas of the mine. ``Vaal Reefs has greater flexibility in the opening of new ore reserves than Freegold,'' Hewitt said. On Wednesday, General Mining Union Corp. announced its marginal operation Stilfontein Gold Mining Co. Ltd. would lay off 500 workers immediately to cut costs in the face of the low gold price. Anglovaal Ltd. said its Loraine Gold Mines Ltd. would lay off 600 workers and reduce production by 10 percent during the next four months. Hewitt said Anglo-American management had invited discussions with union leaders about the curtailments. There was no immediate reaction from the unions. The National Union of Mineworkers, the nations' largest black union, representing some 250,000 black miners, has already declared a dispute and asked for arbitration in its annual wage negotiations with the mining industry. South Africa has the deepest gold mines in the world, and the cost of mining increases with the depth. The relatively cheap labor, with an average black miner earning from $300 to $400 per month, is one reason why South African mines can continue to be profitable at great depths. Curtailing mining operations is considered a serious step, because once a particular shaft is shut down, the infrastructure often deteriorates rapidly. That would make it costly and dangerous to start up again when the price of gold rises.

DOC.HEAD: Leadership Says Legislature Cleared Way for Market Economy
With AM-Soviet-Miners, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Top Soviet leaders declared Friday they had won legislative support for a market economy despite rejection of an immediate price increase for bread and demands for a more detailed blueprint of the transition. Comments by the head of Soviet economic planning and the chairman of the legislature, both members of the Communist Party Politburo, reflected the government's shaky approach to reform despite months of study. The government program presented by Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov last month caused panic buying that left half-empty store shelves even barer. Yuri D. Maslyukov, the chairman of the State Planning Commission, told reporters Friday that the Supreme Soviet legislature was right to posptone the first phase of a bread price increase Ryzhkov proposed for July 1. ``The opinion of the government is that probably, considering the importance of the matter, the decision of the session is correct,'' Maslyukov said. ``We will look into that matter one more time, because a mistake would cost it the confidence of the people.'' Bread is the staple of the Soviet diet, and prices have remained unchanged for decades. But President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, pushing for the economic reform program, told Soviets on the eve of his summit trip to Washington that bread is so cheap that children sometimes use loaves for soccer balls. At the same time, the Soviet government is forced to use up precious hard currency reserves to ensure there is enough grain by importing it, he said. Maslyukov and Supreme Soviet Chairman Anatoly I. Lukyanov, a Gorbachev protege who fulfills many of the functions of a vice president, held news conferences Friday, a day after the legislature finished its spring session, to give the government's evaluation. ``The president and the government have been granted the right to make necessary decisions to prepare the transition to a market economy,'' Maslyukov said. Both acknowledged that the government economic plan required more work. ``It has become clear that new models aren't created on the run, with one wave of the hand,'' Lukyanov said. ``Time is needed, and to take into account many other factors, and to weigh all the details, and to think.'' ``It's a new revolution, in principle. Of course it needs perfecting,'' he said. The plan presented by Ryzhkov had been in the works for months. But after two weeks of debate, the Supreme Soviet told the government to come back with more detailed plans when it reconvenes in September. The plan calls for food prices to be doubled Jan. 1, rapid conversion of state-owned enterprises to stock companies and the gradual sale of stocks to the public. It would permit certain companies and industries to contract directly for their supplies and to sell their products in a free market. Unprofitable firms would go bankrupt. Maslyukov reiterated that the country probably would have its first nationwide referendum on the economic package, but only after more detailed plans are presented to the Supreme Soviet in the fall. The legislature must approve the plan before it is presented for a referendum, which likely will include two main questions _ the speed of economic reform and the methods of compensating consumers for the higher costs. Asked about another key area of economic change, monetary reform, Maslyukov said the Soviet ruble would have to be devalued several times to bring it closer to market values. To make the currency convertible on the world market, the government must drastically cut its budget deficit, he said. That means reducing spending on capital construction, defense and foreign aid, Maslyukov said. By 1993, government plans call for foreign firms to be able to reinvest in the Soviet Union rubles they have earned in the country, and by 1995 for the ruble to be convertible. But other Soviet economic officials have said that such predictions of full convertibility are too optimistic. Deputy Premier Leonid A. Abalkin has said that it likely will take many years to make the ruble convertible.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Performers Get Warm Welcome From Rural Minnesota Hosts
DOC.TEXT: Sixty Soviet dancers, singers and acrobats got a taste of rural Americana with a visit to a dairy farm and a backyard feast of fried chicken, potato salad and beer. ``President Gorbachev didn't have time,'' host Gary Meyer said, referring to the Soviet leader's canceled visit to a Minnesota dairy farm after the Washington sumit two weeks ago. ``Maybe this makes up a little for that.'' The Leningrad State Music Hall troupe picnicked, sang and performed Thursday in this hamlet about 35 miles west of the Twin Cities. They feasted on traditional American backyard fare and washed the meal down with vodka before singing ``America the Beautiful.'' Then it was down the road to Don and Alice Leuer's dairy farm. Mrs. Leuer welcomed the performers with 20 dozen chocolate chip and peanut butter cookies. ``It is like a fairy tale here,'' said Irena Charchevnikova, a dancer. ``There is a very warm feeling from the people, and we feel very much at home.'' Meyer's wife, Sara, arranged the grassroots cultural exchange during a visit last weekend to Minneapolis, where the troupe is performing. The troupe was scheduled to perform at the Orpheum Theatre in Minneapolis through the weekend before going to Chicago. It is the first U.S. tour of the 24-year-old troupe, which has performed in more than 40 countries.

DOC.HEAD: Government Urged to Improve Safety Before Arms Plant Restart
DOC.TEXT: The chairmen of two congressional committees urged Energy Secretary James D. Watkins on Friday to take new steps to improve safety practices at the Savannah River nuclear arms plant before allowing it to resume operation. Watkins should insist that operators of Savannah River's nuclear reactors, which make tritium gas for nuclear warheads, meet the safety standards of the commercial nuclear industry, said Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, and Rep. Mike Synar, D-Oklahoma. ``It is critical ... to change the disturbing mindset of complacency that has been embedded at the Savannah River plant for many years,'' Glenn said. ``The Energy Department still has a long way to go.'' The legislators were responding to a report by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, that said the Savannah River operation had not yet made sufficient improvements in safety practices and attitudes. The GAO report said that under current Energy Department plans, the reactor operators at Savannah River would not be required to meet commercial industry training standards prior to restart. The report recommended that Watkins require Westinghouse Savannah River Co., which runs the plant for the government, to carry out a comprehensive plan for changing the ``safety culture'' there before it resumes reactor operation. The plant is on a 315-square-mile federal reservation near Aiken, S.C. The report also said that efforts to further improve safety practices and attitudes, in addition to several other management and environmental issues, could delay the planned restart of Savannah River reactors by as much as two years. Watkins has said he hopes to have the first of the three active Savannah River reactors back in operation by January, although no final restart date has been set. The reactors are the nation's only source of tritium, a radioactive gas that must be replenished in warheads because it decays at a rate of 5.5 percent a year. The reactors were closed down in 1988 because of safety, mechanical and management problems. Last week two environmental groups, the Natural Resources Defense Council of New York and the Energy Research Foundation of Columbia, S.C., filed suit in federal court in Aiken challenging Watkins' plan for restarting the reactors. The suit demanded that restart be blocked until the department completes construction of a cooling tower for reactor discharges, or until President Bush exempts the plant from the Clean Water Act on national security grounds. The tower is scheduled for completion in 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Four West Germans Accused of Terrorism Arrested in East Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with East Germany government retracting statement that married couple and third person arrested, other details; CORRECTS that four others arrested Thursday night; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Germany-Spies, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: East German police said Friday they arrested four West German fugitives, striking a major blow to the core of West Germany's leftist terrorist movement. All four were arrested late Thursday. One was later freed because charges against her had expired; it was not certain whether West Germany would file the charges again. The East German government initially said it also had captured three other wanted fugitives but retracted that statement late Friday. ``The three people arrested today in Leipzig are not the hunted Red Army Faction terrorists Barbara Meyer, Horst Ludwig Meyer and Sabine Callsen,'' the government-run news agency ADN said in a brief news flash. It gave no explanation for the earlier, incorrect information issued by the Interior Ministry and did not say whether the three arrested were even suspected of being involved in terrorist activities. Despite the erroneous report, the arrests of the four fugitives in Frankfurt an der Oder and Cottbus _ together with two arrests on Wednesday _ were significant for West German authorities. Authorities consider the fugitives to be among the leaders of the Red Army Faction terror gang, which waged a murderous war against West German capitalism in the 1970s and 1980s. All had been living in East Germany under assumed names, and West German officials said the arrests go a long way toward confirming long-held suspicions that East Germany's former Communist government once harbored terrorists. Bonn government spokesman Hans Klein told reporters the federal government had indications for several years that East Germany's former secret police sheltered the fugitives. Klein said, however, the indications were vague and that West Germans would have run into ``an iron wall'' had they tried to raise the issue with the former East German leaders. In East Berlin, Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel told a news conference he was unable to confirm widespread speculation that terrorists had used East Germany as a base for attacks. But he promised to seek prosecution of any former officials who harbored the terrorists under the Communist regime. In Hamburg, conservative West German lawmaker Eduard Lintner demanded the extradition of ousted Communist leader Erich Honecker to face charges of having supported terrorism. Authorities identified those arrested Thursday as Monika Helbing, 36, and Ekkehard von Seckendorff-Gudent, 49, arrested in Frankfurt an der Oder; and Werner Lotze, 38, and Christine Duemlein, 41, arrested in Cottbus. Ms. Helbing and Seckendorff-Gudent are married, as are Lotze and Ms. Duemlein. Ms. Helbing and Lotze allegedly were involved in the 1977 kidnap-slaying of West German industrialist Hanns-Martin Schleyer and numerous other terrorist crimes. Ms. Duemline was wanted on charges of being a member of a terrorist organization to overthrow the state, and an arrest warrant was issued for her in 1978. It was dropped in 1988 after the warrant expired by law, and East German officials she was freed after her capture because it had not been renewed. Ekkehard von Seckendorff-Gudent was wanted as a Red Army Faction sympathiser. As a doctor, he had a permanent visitors pass to a Hamburg prison, which authorities said he gave to suspected terrorists to visit jailed compatriots. As East Germany and West Germany move toward unification, the countries are cooperating closely. Now, West German wanted posters are seen throughout the East, and other fugitives among two dozen hard-core leaders could be arrested. The retraction late Friday leaves the Meyers some of West Germany's most-hunted fugitives. The couple is accused of a car bomb attack that killed two people and wounded 20 others at the U.S. Air Force's Rhein-Main Air Base near Frankfurt in August 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Enlistee Sentenced to 10 Years for Espionage
DOC.TEXT: An Air Force enlistee was sentenced Friday to 10 years in prison without parole for attempting to sell secrets to the Soviets. U.S. District Judge Sidney A. Fitzwater imposed the sentence on former Airman Ronald Craig Wolf, 35, who pleaded guilty in February to one count of attempting to transfer national defense information to the Soviet Union. FBI Special Agent Bobby R. Gillham said agents began investigating Wolf in 1989, when they received information that he intended to sell sensitive classified information to the Soviet Union. Wolf was arrested in May 1989 after selling information to an undercover FBI agent posing as a Soviet agent. Wolf enlisted in the Air Force in July 1974 in Dallas. He held a security clearance and received training in Russian before his 1981 discharge. He transcribed sensitive communications while serving in the Far East, Gillham said. Wolf had been working in automobile sales since his discharge, the FBI said. Wolf was arrested near the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport, where he had planned to fly to the Soviet Union to defect after meeting with the undercover FBI agent, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Donates 25,000 Tons of Corn to Honduras
DOC.TEXT: The United States has donated 25,000 metric tons of surplus corn to Honduras as part of an expanded food-aid package, the Agriculture Department said Friday. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager of the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said the corn's value is $2.2 million. The grain will be sold by the Honduran government to the private sector to help meet food and industrial needs. Proceeds from the sales will be earmarked to provide food assistance to needy families and to help farmers in projects to increase production and marketing. Dickerson said the program is carried out by the U.S. Agency for International Development. The corn donation boosts Honduran food aid to $3.4 million from an initial $1.2 million announced on March 9, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Paraguayan Leader Meets Bush, Asks Trade Benefits
DOC.TEXT: Paraguayan President Andres Rodriguez asked President Bush for trade benefits Friday. Bush sought increased Paraguayan efforts on anti-drug operations, officials said. The two met briefly in the Oval Office during a stopover by Rodriguez en route to Taiwan and South Korea. ``President Bush told President Rodriguez that we would like to cooperate more intensively with Paraguay to prevent drug traffickers from establishing a foothold in that country,'' said Bush's press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. U.S. officials have expressed concern that Paraguay is becoming an increasingly active transshipment point for drugs produced in other South American countries. Dozens of private airstrips have been reported in remote sections of Paraguay used by drug trafficking planes. While Rodriguez is seen as making some efforts against illegal drugs, his cooperation so far has not been effective, said one official who spoke only on condition of anonymity. Rodriguez asked Bush to restore the system of Generalized Special Preferences trade benefits for Paraguay, Fitzwater said in a statement. The GSP is designed to allow third-world nations to ship their products to the United States duty free or with low tariffs. Under U.S. regulations, countries that violate basic labor rights can be denied the GSP privileges. Paraguay is among the nations to be sanctioned in recent years on such grounds. In a photo session before their meeting, Rodriguez expressed hopes Bush would help his country's new move toward democracy. Rodriguez, a military general, was elected last year after he overthrew dictator Gen. Alfred Stroessner. ``I feel very confident that the leader of the world's democracies will help me in Paraguay to replant democracy in this transitional period that we're going through,'' Rodriguez told Bush at the start of their session. Bush said the United States is ``pleased with this noble beginning you've made and watching with great interest'' as Paraguay undertakes reforms. Rodriguez later characterized his brief meeting with Bush as ``marvelous.'' The Paraguayan later had lunch with Vice President Dan Quayle, who visited Paraguay in March. Quayle said that during that visit he had pressed Rodriguez for progress on human rights and labor rights. A 1990 State Department report on human rights in Paraguay said the Rodriguez government has taken significant steps to reverse repression that was prevalent under Stroessner, but greater strides are needed. The report said government corruption remained a problem.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Leaders Seeking U.S. Support for Middle East Peace
DOC.TEXT: Israeli leaders said Friday they were seeking U.S. support to ``start from the beginning'' with Middle East peace initiatives. The new position emerged as the Israelis responded to sharp remarks by Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who urged Israel's new right-wing government to move to resume the stalled peace process. Baker, testifying before a Senate committee on Wednesday, recited the telephone number of the White House switchboard and said: ``When you're serious about this, call us.'' But Foreign Minister David Levy said in an interview published Friday that Israel must ``clarify to the United States that a peace move is fateful for us and cannot depend on a `yes' or `no' answer to one single question.'' The question Levy referred to was Baker's October proposal for a preliminary Israeli-Palestinian dialogue in Egypt. The talks would be toward ending the 30-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule of the territories. At least 717 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians and 45 Israelis have also died. The Palestinian delegation to any peace talks, according to Baker, should include people living in exile and those who have homes in both the occupied territories and annexed east Jerusalem. The formula was intended as a compromise between Israel's refusal to talk to the Palestine Liberation Organization and the PLO demand that Palestinians outside the territories be included in talks. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's conservative Likud bloc, fearing Baker's terms would lead Israel to de facto negotiations with the PLO and raise the issue of Jerusalem, has failed to give a positive answer. In March, Likud's coalition with the center-left Labor Party fell apart over Shamir's stalling. Shamir formed a new government Monday. ``The answer to Baker was not negative, but we have to remember that the train got off the tracks, both because of Baker's questions and because the government fell apart,'' Levy told the daily Yediot Ahronot. ``Therefore you cannot say now: we set the train in motion from exactly the same spot, despite the fact there are no tracks,'' he said. A top Shamir aide, Yossi Ben-Aharon, said Friday: ``We are asking to start from the beginning ... to get the process on a track that will not lead us to negotiations with a delegation composed by the PLO, and that will lead us into the danger of a Palestinian state.'' ``It is unacceptable that they (the Americans) return exactly to this point and propose the same questions to the new government that has been formed,'' Ben-Aharon said on Israel army radio. Israel, in accordance with its May 1989 peace initiative, says Palestinian representatives should be chosen in elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The plan also offers Palestinians an interim period of self-rule, with their final status to be determined in later negotiations. Baker said Wednesday: ``there won't be any dialogue, there won't be any peace'' if Israel's new government makes unacceptable demands for Palestinian participation in peace talks. Meanwhile, dozens of police patrolled East Talpiot and two neighboring Arab villages where the stabbing of an 11-year-old Jewish schoolboy Thursday set off anti-Arab riots. No further incidents were reported, however. Also Friday, Arab writers' groups protested the arrest of poet Shafik Habib, detained on suspicion that his latest collection of poems could incite anti-Israeli violence. Habib was taken from his home in the village of Deir Hana near Nazareth on Wednesday. At the United Nations, Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar on Friday deplored the throwing of a tear-gas grenade by Israeli forces into a maternity and children's clinic in the Gaza Strip this week. In all, 57 infants were treated for inhaling tear gas. The incident occurred when Israeli soldiers persuing Arab stone throwers ran into the U.N. health center.

DOC.HEAD: AM-Farm Bureau Explosion, CORRECTIVE, ^Eds: Members who used a0718 or a0409 1st Ld - Writethru, AM-Farm Bureau Explosion, sent June 13 under a Switz City, Ind., dateline, are asked to use the following.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press on Wednesday erroneously identified a gasoline storage plant where explosions injured three workers as the Greene County Farm Bureau Co-op. The plant is actually the Indiana Farm Bureau Co-operative Association's Switz City fuel terminal.

DOC.HEAD: Congressmen Criticize Keeping Executives After Taking Over S&Ls
DOC.TEXT: House Democrats criticized savings and loan bailout officials Friday for hiring high-paid consultants, keeping executives of failed thrifts on the job and continuing to pay others who perform no work. Congress is hearing ``growing reports of overpaid individuals running (government)-held institutions ... of officers from failed institutions staying on the government payroll with six-figure salaries,'' said Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., chairman of the House S&L bailout task force. ``At a time when it is reported that the total cost to the taxpayer is growing at an ever-increasing rate, why is the (Resolution Trust Corp.) continuing these megadollar salaries for a work product that at best is mediocre and at worst is a proven failure?'' he asked. Vento cited three cases: _Two government-controlled thrifts in Orange County, Calif. _ Mercury Savings and Western Empire Savings _ continued to pay six former officers even though they no longer worked for the institutions. _Wallace Associates, a Salt Lake City firm, received $500,000 to manage Midwest Savings Association in Minneapolis for a year. _The managing agent at Franklin Savings Association in Ottawa, Kan., is receiving $220,000 for his first six months on the job. RTC chief executive officer David Cooke said that in the California institutions, top executives were placed on paid administrative leave until their thrifts were placed in receiverships and their employment contracts could be legally broken. Cooke said the agency usually is able to break such contracts swiftly but in the case of some large, complex institutions must maintain them for several months. ``Some of these sweetheart management deals they cut for themselves ... are almost ironclad legally,'' said Michael J. Martinelli, the RTC's regional director in Kansas City, Mo. In the case of Midwest Savings, the consulting firm was replacing even higher paid executives, Martinelli said. The manager hired for Franklin Savings was worth his salary because he had the expertise necessary to deal with the thrift's complex securities portfolio, he said. Cooke said top executives were retained at 211 of 351 thrifts seized by the government through April 13. Of those, salaries remained unchanged at 124, were lowered at 51 and raised at 36. Salary reductions for top executives at seized thrifts have saved taxpayers nearly $35 million, he said. ``It is important to understand that in many cases the senior management in institutions taken into conservatorship are not dishonest or incompetent and are not the ones who caused the institution to fail,'' he added. However, Rep. James McDermott, D-Wash., questioned whether any employees of a failed thrift above the level of secretary or teller should be retained when a new government-controlled thrift is created. ``The question is, `Are you allowing the virus that took down one S&L to move to the next S&L?''' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Indians Say Treaty Disputes Should be Settled Locally
DOC.TEXT: A group of Indians from Wisconsin tribes told county government representatives Friday they should negotiate settlements to their problems instead of forming a national organization to challenge treaties. ``To me it's sad we can't sit down in our own areas and resolve our problems,'' Purcell Powless, chairman of the Oneida tribe, told a meeting run by the Wisconsin County Association. ``Whether you like me or not, I'm here and my people are going to be here a long time,'' he said. Powless was among 12 tribal representatives who spoke to the conference of county officials working to form a national coalition on federal Indian policy. ``I don't believe there is a need for the things they are trying to do,'' said Joe Bresette, a Chippewa Indian and executive director of the Great Lakes Inter-Tribal Council. ``There is a presumption that there is us and them. We don't believe that.'' Trouble erupted at the first meeting of the coalition last January in Salt Lake City, because Indians were excluded. This time, the coalition organizers complied with the Indians' desire to speak earlier than originally scheduled. The idea for a coalition arose from a dispute between the Chippewa Indians in Wisconsin and 20 counties over timber rights. The Indians say federal treaties give them the right to harvest on 1.8 million acres of land the counties claim. The case is pending in federal court with briefs due June 26 from both sides on whether the treaties should be reopened. Mark Rogacki, executive director of the Wisconsin County Association, said the dispute led his group to contact counties in other states with similar problems. ``There are common threads of Indian policy that run through the country,'' said Rogacki. ``We want (federal government officials) to conduct hearings all across the nation to find out what the problems are.'' He said the issues now in courts could be eliminated if Congress adjusted the treaties. Eighteen county representatives from five states were at the conference, which was called to discuss how to get the National Association of Counties to make the coalition a part of its activities, said Rogacki. Rita Kenshena, tribal attorney for the Menominee tribe, said she and the other Indians hoped to stress the need to work locally to settle the disputes. ``The Indian tribes are more informed about their governments and treaties (than the county officials),'' she said. Keith Ferris, chairman of the conference, said he planned to ask the tribes in Wisconsin whether they would be willing to re-establish a local board that brought together county and tribal leaders to discuss the various problems that arise.

DOC.HEAD: Kansas Firm Wins Permit for Iowa Tests
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department said Friday it has issued a permit for the first field trials in the United States of genetically engineered corn. The permit clears the way for BioTechnica Agriculture Inc. of Overland Park, Kan., to begin its tests this month in Lisbon, Iowa, said James W. Glosser, administrator of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service. Glosser said the tests will continue through the summer and that the company's procedures were designed carefully so as not to disturb the environment. The corn being tested differes from standard seed only in that it contains genetic marker genes. These will allow scientists to map more exactly the locations on chromosomes of genes that determine the corn's characteristics, including yield and resistance to diseases. Once the genes are located, researchers can manipulate and eventually introduce them into new corn varieties and other crops as well. Glosser said BioTechnia scientists already have examined the experimental corn plants in the greehouse and want to repeat the studies under field conditions. The corn project follows announcement earlier this week of similar field trials for soybeans and rice. Monsanto Agricultural Co. of St. Louis won approval for field tests of generically engineered soybeans this summer in Arkansas, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kentucky, Missouri, Nebraska, Ohio, Tennessee and Virginia. Those experiments are being conducted to test soybean tolerance to the widely used herbicide glyphosate, also known commercially as Roundup. Scientists at Louisiana State University in Baton Rouge, are testing rice that has been altered so its genes can be mapped for later manipulation and use in new varieties.

DOC.HEAD: Pair Crash While Trying to Promote World Peace
DOC.TEXT: A single-engine plane on the next-to-last stop of a 48-state peace tour crashed near an airport runway Friday, killing both people on board, authorities said. The plane, attempting to set a speed record for flying to state capitals, struck the top of a tree in a park about a half-mile short of the Yeager Airport runway, where it was attempting to land at about 8:30 a.m., said Sgt. Vic Gazitano of the Kanawha County Sheriff's Department. The plane spun around and landed on its nose, with the right wing torn off in several pieces, Gazitano. Killed were retired Air Force Col. Frank Martineau, 69, of Bethesda, Md., and Marjorie Zeuch, 67, of Warwick, R.I., said Maj. Robert Wolfe of the Air National Guard in Charleston. ``He had fuel on board and the landing gear was down,'' said Frank Gurish, a Federal Aviation Administrator investigator at the scene. ``It would appear he was of the notion he was on a normal landing pattern. It was on course. It was just lower than he should have been.'' Martineau, an editor of Association Trends, a national weekly newspaper for associations, and Zeuch, president of the World Friendship Association in Warwick, were on the last leg of a 4,000-mile peace promotion trip, said Chuck Davenport, managing editor of Association Trends, based in Bethesda. ``The main purpose of `Operation Appleseed' was to present state charters for the World Friendship Association, a 2-year-old charitable organization dedicated to bringing ordinary people of the world closer together for permanent peace,'' Davenport said. Martineau and Zeuch were scheduled to complete the trip Friday afternoon at Washington National Airport in Virginia. A friend of Martineau said the two had met through their common interest in flying. ``She had this mission of spreading friendship and Frank thought this would be a good project for the association to be involved with,'' said Ed Cornish of Bethesda, whose son is married to Martineau's daughter. The plane, which began its journey May 29 in Providence, R.I., took off from Columbus, Ohio, at 7 a.m., Ohio Aviation Chief John Cornett said. Cornett said the pair had arrived Thursday afternoon in Columbus. ``I'm trying to get a handle on it myself. It's very tragic because they were very nice people,'' Cornett said.

DOC.HEAD: North Testifies for Several Hours
DOC.TEXT: Oliver North testified for several hours Friday afternoon before a federal grand jury investigating the Iran-Contra scandal. It was the former White House aide's third appearance this month before the panel, which is delving into the affair as part of the 4{-year-old criminal investigation by independent counsel Lawrence Walsh. Iran-Contra prosecutor Craig Gillen was seen entering the room where the grand jury is meeting at the U.S. Courthouse. North declined to comment after his latest round of testimony. He left the grand jury room several times to confer with his attorneys. As part of the latest phase in its investigation, Walsh's office is trying to determine the precise roles that President Reagan, then-Vice President George Bush and other administration figures played in the affair. Mary Belcher, a spokeswoman for Walsh's office, declined all comment.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Fundamentalists: Algerian Win is 1st Step Toward Power
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS one graf for 12th `The Islamic' to CORRECT to say no candidates were women, sted men; pickup graf 13 pvs, `Many Algerians...'
DOC.TEXT: Moslem fundamentalists said Friday their victory in this week's local elections marks a first step toward taking power, but they appealed to supporters to guard against trouble from ``enemies of Islam.'' Many Algerians abandoned Western garb for traditional dress Friday, and some fundamentalists entered bars and restaurants to tell owners to curtail alcohol sales in the wake of Tuesday's election gains. The leader of the victorious Islamic Salvation Front, Sheikh Abassi Madani, denies his party is fundamentalist. However, it backs the imposition of Islamic law in Algeria, where rule has been secular. After the vote, hundreds of fundamentalists celebrated all night in Algiers, the capital. They paraded through the streets with banners reading ``God is great!'' and ``Islamic Republic!'' ``The army and people are with you, Madani!'' youths shouted. Madani, at a prayer service Friday attended by about 30,000 people, said Algeria had ``taken the first step on the path toward an Islamic solution.'' However, the front's No. 2 official, Ali Belhadj, told worshipers that ultimate victory depended on ``vigilance at all times against the enemies of Islam in Algeria and abroad, especially in France.'' He did not identify them. His movement's unexpectedly strong victory alarmed many Moslem moderates at home, in France and elsewhere. France was the colonial ruler of this North African nation until it became independent in 1962, and Tuesday's elections were the country's first multiparty voting. Belhadj said Algerians who opposed the front should move to France. Right-wing French leaders have warned the front's victory will lead to a mass exodus of Algerian refugees to France, where millions of North Africans already live. In Algiers, several dozen human rights and women's rights activists announced Friday the formation of a coalition. The new ``Forum for Democracy'' will work to protect civil liberties and ensure a full civic role for women, its leaders said. The Islamic front relegates women to a subservient role. None of its candidates were women. Many Algerians who normally wear Western clothing appeared on the streets Friday in traditional garb _ men in floor-length shirts called ``khamisses'' and women wearing veils and scarves. Khadija Messaoudi, a founder of the new rights coalition and president of a women's group, said many women donned the traditional clothing ``in order to go out in the streets'' without harassment., Madani has said women will not be forced to wear the Islamic scarf, or hijab, but his followers have steadily pressured female students and teachers to adopt the traditional garb. Though fundamentalists seized power in the 1979 Islamic revolution in Iran, many Arab states suppress their fundamentalist movements. Iran's official media has cheered the Algerian win, saying, ``In this favorable terrain, Islam can spread very quickly.'' Pressing a bid for political power in Algeria, Madani has asked the government to dissolve Parliament and hold early elections. He has also suggested a coalition with the ruling National Liberation Front. Officials have not responded to either request. Madani told journalists Friday his party, if it won legislative elections, would be willing to operate under President Chadli Bendjedid, whose five-year term expires at the end of 1993. Madani has not ruled out the possibility that he would seek the presidency. His party won 60 percent of the municipal councils at stake in Tuesday's elections.

DOC.BYLINE: Flooding from the Central Plains to the Central Atlantic Coast. ^By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms covered large sections of the country Friday and caused flooding from the central Plains to the central Atlantic Coast. In the Ohio River town of Shadyside, Ohio, a flash flood caused fatalities and left many missing or homeless. Gov. Richard Celeste declared a state of emergency and National Guards were being sent to the area. A wall of water near Lindsay in eastern Nebraska carried 18 cars out of a parking lot, and flooding forced the evacuation of a three-block portion of Platte Center. In southern Nebraska, flooding closed underpasses near Grand Island. Flooding spread thorugh east-central and northeast Kansas and over west-central Iowa. The Salyersville fire department in eastern Kentucky was flooded with seven inches of water and roads were closed. Flooding was also reported in West Virginia and Delaware. Showers and thunderstorms extended across the Carolinas and fell in Virginia, West Virginia and southwest Pennsylvania. Rain also fell on sections of Tennessee, Alabama, Georgia, Kansas, Louisiana, Missouri, Iowa, Nebraska, Minnesota, Wisconsin and South Dakota. And showers reached from west-central and eastern Arkansas across northern Mississippi. Rainshowers were scattered from northwestern North Dakota across northern Montana and along the northern Pacific Coast. Cities receiving the heaviest rainfall included Lynchburg, Va., with 1.75 inches and Topeka, Kan., with 1{ inches. In 45 minutes, more than three-quarters of an inch of rain fell in Aberdeen, S.D., and caused minor street flooding. Temperatures climbed into the 100s across extreme southwest Tennessee and unusually hot weather along with high humidity covered Arkansas. The low temperature for the Lower 48 early Friday was 28 degrees at Truckee, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Girl Survives Flood After Spending Night in Ohio River
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT missing girl's age to 12 sted 13 and to include her last name; CORRECTS missing girl's first name from Carrie to Kerrie; INSERTS two grafs after 15th graf pvs, `Amber suffered ...', with quotes from grandmother
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Flash Flood, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A 9-year-old girl said she was swept down a creek into the Ohio River during a flash flood and stayed alive for seven hours by hanging on to logs and ``just drifted'' until she reached shore Friday morning. Amber Colvin was in her family's home playing a card game with a neighbor when the storm hit Thursday night. The house started to fill with water. Amber said her 12-year-old friend, Kerrie Trigg, wanted to get in the bathtub. ``We got in the bathtub, and the water was over our heads and then the house collapsed,'' Amber said from her Bellaire City Hospital room. She doesn't know why they got in the tub but remembers Kerrie being hit on the head, knocking her out. Kerrie was still missing on Friday. ``I tried to save her,'' Amber said. ``I almost drowned. I was swept out of the house.'' Amber was swept down Wegee Creek and then into the nearby Ohio River. Although she can only swim a little, she said she kept kicking her legs and hung on to two logs. ``I had them for a long time,'' she said. ``I just drifted.'' She said she was in the water from about 11 p.m. to 6 a.m. She tried to work her way to the shore to get to a factory where her father worked. She reached shore about seven miles from her home. Her mother, Karen, said the last time she saw her daughter was at 9:30 p.m. She said she and her husband, Dennis, went into town to do some shopping but could not return and didn't know until 2 a.m. that their house was swept away and Amber was gone. The Colvins stayed at the Jefferson Elementary School, where authorities set up a command center to coordinate rescue efforts. They eventually were told that Amber was found alive. Amber's parents met the emergency squad as it went through Shadyside. ``I can't begin to tell you how she looked. I don't know who was in shock more _ me or her,'' Karen said as tears swelled in her eyes. ``Her hands and feet had no color. She had her senses, but you just could tell she had been in the water. All she talked about was Kerrie. We prayed all night.'' Amber suffered no broken bones. She was listed in fair condition in the hospital, suffering from scrapes and other minor injuries. Kerrie's grandmother, Shirley Trigg, was being counseled at the school. ``The doctors say you have to have hope, something about miracles. Miracles do happen, but this is a nightmare,'' Trigg said. Thursday night's thunderstorms caused flash flooding across a wide area of central and eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia and western Pennsylvania. The floods closed roads, damaged homes and forced hundreds of people to evacuate homes. But no place was hit with anything approaching the ferocity of the flooding in Shadyside. About 5.5 inches of rain fell between 7:30 p.m. and 11 p.m., turning two Ohio River tributaries outside the village of 4,300 people into torrents.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Says It Has Foiled IRA Attacks
DOC.TEXT: The West German government, fighting an outbreak of IRA violence, said Friday it has thwarted a number of planned attacks by the terrorist group. The announcement came the same day the Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility for an explosion Thursday that damaged an unoccupied building at a British Army training center near Hameln, West Germany. No one was hurt in that blast. On June 2, the IRA shot and killed a British Army major in Dortmund, West Germany. ``We must concentrate on trying to prevent such attacks. In the past few weeks, we have succeeded in preventing a number of further attacks planned by the IRA,'' Interior Minister Wolfgang Schauble told European Community justice and interior ministers. They were in Dublin for a two-day meeting. Schauble refused to give details of the foiled attacks, but he said improved cooperation between police forces on the European continent that had curbed the IRA's activities. ``I am sure and convinced that the leeway for the IRA on the Continent is getting smaller and the search pressure which emanates not only from the Germans but also from our neighboring countries, Belgium and the Netherlands, is very high,'' he said. ``The fact that we have succeeded in preventing a number of attacks in recent weeks shows that our cooperation is working.'' The 12-nation European Community ministers has passed a terrorism prevention plan that includes ``hot pursuit'' across borders, a central computer for collecting intelligence and improved security at airports, train stations and ferry ports. The predominantly Catholic IRA is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland and unite the 60 percent Protestant province with the 95 percent Catholic Irish Republic. Many of its attacks are in Northern Ireland and Britain, but it has often attacked British targets in Western Europe as well. In Friday's announcement, the IRA also claimed responsibility for a bomb at a mansion in rural England that belonged to Lord McAlpin, formerly a leading member of the governing Conservative Party. No one was hurt in that blast on Tuesday. At Friday's meeting of the so-called Trevi Group, the European ministers also agreed set up a central drug intelligence unit in Europe to fight international trafficking. The Trevi group was created in Luxembourg in 1976 to coordinate security efforts in the European Community.

DOC.HEAD: Residents See Wall of Water Sweep Away Their Homes, Families
With AM-Flash Floods Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Tears, prayers and stories of homes and families swept away were offered Friday by residents who saw flash floods gush from hilly coal fields and sweep through their village. ``I just couldn't get to them. I hollered as loud as I could,'' said Herman Adams, who wept as he recounted seeing the trailer home containing his daughter and two grandchildren carried off by the surging Pipe Creek on Thursday night. ``It happened so fast.'' At a disaster center set up in this Belmont County village in the eastern part of the state, Adams waited Friday with others for word about the fate of missing relatives. About 200 people came and went during the day from the center, located at Jefferson School, seeking news of missing friends and relatives. Trailer homes appeared to be hit hardest when water surged from the Belmont County highlands down the Wegee and Pipe creeks past Shadyside and into the Ohio River, said Jim Williams, chief of staff of the Emergency Management Agency. ``Any mobile home in the path of the water is gone,'' said Mead Township Trustee Gregg Warren. The two creeks in Mead Township were turned into raging rivers after 5.5 inches of rain fell there in less than 3{ hours. ``It's hard to explain. It's unbelievable. A creek you could walk across with water up to your ankles in some places rose 15 to 25 feet,'' said Gregg Warren, a Mead Township trustee. Adams said he had eaten dinner with his daughter, Sue, and her two children at their trailer home Thursday night and returned to his house about 200 feet away when he heard the sound of rushing water. ```What the heck is that,' I thought. I have a window facing the creek. I looked out and saw the water'' about 3 feet high. ``The water was all around the trailer. I hollered and hollered. They couldn't hear me. The water was too high. I couldn't get to them. ``And then they were gone,'' Adams said. He lowered his head and wept. A neighbor, Becky Glaser, said Adams' wife had died recently. She put an arm around Adams and comforted him. ``I lost everything, too,'' Mrs. Glaser said. ``I'm wiped out but my family, I have three children, are fine. Thank God. ... I just stood there and watched my car and his car getting washed away.'' A dozen mattresses were spread across the floor of the Jefferson School. People huddled together in small groups. Tina Street said she had been sent to the school to identify some bodies, but saw none there. ``I saw them pull Debbie, my sister-in-law, out of the water this morning about 7. She and my brother, Bart Graham, and their child disappeared last night. They haven't found Bart or the child yet,'' Ms. Street said. Because she lives on a hill, Ms. Street said, her house was spared. ``But I saw whole houses go. Cars and trucks were floating away and the creek took out a bridge. The water took everything in its path.''

DOC.HEAD: Serbian Journalists Complain of Bias in Belgrade TV News
DOC.TEXT: Independent journalists' groups in Serbia complained Friday of bias in Belgrade TV coverage of an anti-communist rally and demanded criminal charges be brought against the communist director. ``We consider that television reports before, during and after the opposition rally ... represent a drastic violation of journalistic ethics,'' said a statement released by Belgrade Television's independent employees union. More than 30,000 people from the one-party state of Serbia, the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics, demonstrated in Belgrade on Wednesday demanding free elections and an end to Communist rule in their state. The main rally ended peacefully, but police later used clubs to disperse demonstrators who went to the TV station to demand coverage of their demands and the resignation of Dusan Mitevic, a communist official appointed to head the state-run TV last year. Belgrade TV and Serbia's state-run press have described the rally as ``a betrayal of Serbia'' and its participants as ``fascist hooligans.'' They demand a purge of reporters from Belgrade's independent radio station, which gave comprehensive coverage to the event. A similar protest about coverage was made against the newspaper Politika, an outlet of Serbia's ruling Communists, by 37 Politika reporters. Its story Thursday on the rally was headlined, ``The Anti-Serbian Gathering Was Unsuccessful.'' The Politika reporters said ``the course of democratization cannot be stopped by police batons ... or one-sided reporting.'' They said prominent public figures, including authors and university professors, were among about 100 people beaten in front of the station and this could not be kept secret. Several TV news announcers refused to report what the journalists' union termed ``propaganda fabrications'' and later were fined and suspended, according to the statement carried by the national Tanjug news agency. Serbia is the only Yugoslav republic that has not held or scheduled free elections for local legislatures. The state's Communist authorities reject Western-style democracy and say elections will not be held before the lengthy process of adopting a new constitution is completed. Serbia's state-run media said 7,000 people ``and curious onlookers'' participated in the rally. Independent reports said 30,000 to 50,000 people attended.

DOC.HEAD: Warsaw Pact Admits Mistakes in Hungary, Czechoslovakia
DOC.TEXT: The Warsaw Pact admitted past errors, including the 1968 invasion of Czechoslovakia and the Soviets' crushing of the Hungarian uprising 12 years earlier, East Germany's defense minister said Friday. After a three-day Warsaw Pact meeting outside East Berlin, the Soviet commander of the group's military forces acknowledged dissent within the ranks of the once rock-solid alliance. With last year's pro-democracy revolutions in Eastern Europe, the seven-nation Warsaw Pact has been facing increasing pressures from within. East German Defense Minister Rainer Eppelmann has even predicted the breakup of the pact's military structures by the end of this year. ``The defense ministers for the first time clearly discussed the past errors of the Warsaw Pact,'' Eppelmann told a news conference following the meeting in the suburb of Strausberg. Eppelmann specifically mentioned as examples the Warsaw Pact invasion to put down the Prague Spring revolution by reform Communists in 1968, and the Soviets' repression of an anti-Communist revolt in Hungary in 1956. ``The situation has changed so much that relics from the division of the continent must be overcome,'' Eppelmann told reporters. He did not say in what form the Pact admitted the errors. However, Defense Minister Miroslav Vacek of Czechoslovakia said earlier his colleagues ``apologized to a certain extent'' for the military intervention 22 years ago. Speaking about this week's meeting, the Soviet commander of Warsaw Pact forces said there were ``differences of opinion regarding the prospects of the Warsaw Pact.'' Gen. P.G. Lushev also acknowledged differences on the ``development of the function and character'' of the pact, but he appealed to Moscow's allies to continue fulfilling their obligations. Hungary and Czechoslovakia have already received promises of large pullouts of Soviet troops from their nations. ``As long as there is a Western alliance, there will be a Warsaw Pact,'' Lushev said. The military alliance was founded in 1955. It has been a counterbalance to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the Western alliance, during the Cold War. The coming unification of the two Germanys was one of the dominant questions at the defense ministers' meeting. Eppelmann, the East German defense chief, said he was suggesting Sept. 1, 1992, as the date for full unification. That date is far later than the general timeframe envisioned by West German officials.

DOC.HEAD: Iliescu Thanks Miners for Helping Quash Anti-Gov't Demonstrations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, Random attacks ... DELETING reference to mining area; SUBS 10th graf, Ratiu said ... DELETING unnecessary attribution; SUBS 28th graf, La Cinq ... ADDING western Romania as site.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BUC1,2,3,6
DOC.TEXT: President-elect Ion Iliescu on Friday ordered home thousands of club-wielding coal miners after thanking them ``with all my heart'' for helping hunt down anti-government demonstrators. Iliescu's inauguration, scheduled for Friday, was postponed following three days of rioting, arson and mayhem in this capital of 2.2 million residents. Random attacks by the miners terrorized Bucharest in the country's worst violence since the December revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Many miners were seen leaving Friday. State radio said at 10 p.m. the situation in Bucharest ``is beginning to normalize.'' At a news conference, Premier Petre Roman acknowledged the government held little sway over the mob of miners who indiscriminately attacked passers-by in the capital, beat journalists and ransacked opposition party headquarters. In Washington, a Bush administration official said non-humaritarian aid to Romania will be withheld to protest the violence. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said aid programs being considered would be held up ``until the democratic process has been restored.'' He said $80 million in food aid and $1 million in medical aid would not be affected. Miners trashed the home of Ion Ratiu, chief of the opposition National Peasant Party, who called the violence a ``death of democracy.'' ``(It's) the rule of the mob, no respect for human rights. The forces of law and order stand by instead of maintaining law and order,'' he said. Ratiu said he was briefly detained Thursday night and his colleagues were beaten by miners. Police and army units normally charged with law enforcement had watched without intervening as miners, loyal to Iliescu, assaulted scores of people. Roman said the pit workers had been asked only to peacefully occupy University Square, and that the government deplored all subsequent violence. Wednesday's police crackdown on a 53-day protest in the central square set off riots in which demonstrators threw firebombs at police headquarters and the Interior Ministry and overturned vehicles. Soldiers fired on the rioters. The miners _ whose benefits greatly increased following the revolution _ streamed into the capital early Thursday after Iliescu pleaded for help to put down what he called a ``fascist'' revolt. At least five people died, and figures published Friday by the state news agency Rompres said 367 people were injured, with 112 still hospitalized. The demonstrators say the government _ led by Iliescu and his National Salvation Front and elected overwhelmingly in free elections on May 20 _ is dominated by former Communists who they say continue Ceausescu's repressive policies. The demonstrators want former Communist leaders, including Iliescu, banned from holding public office for 10 years. On Friday, Iliescu told cheering miners at the National Exhibition hall in northern Bucharest, ``You are a strong force with much civic discipline, people you can trust in good times and bad.'' State television broadcast part of the meeting, in which he thanked them ``with all my heart.'' Later, authorities began putting miners on buses for the city's northern railroad station. They were to return on special trains to their homes in the Jiu valley mining region of western Romania, Rompres said. It said Iliescu met miners' leaders Friday and ordered them to leave the capital. Tens of thousands were reported to have come to Bucharest. Several packed buses inexplicably turned back into the city core, stopped and disgorged hundreds of miners. On Boulevard Magheru, the central street leading from University Square, scores of marauding miners lashed out at random with wooden clubs at shoppers and kicked at a fallen man. Others chased foreign journalists into the nearby Intercontinental Hotel. Romanians watching from balconies whistled in derision and shouted anti-government slogans. Pedestrians jeered as they fled the miners. Doormen and other hotel personnel strained to keep the main glass doors shut as hundreds of soot-stained miners pushed trying to get in. An assistant hotel manager pleaded with a TV crew to stop filming the action from a 10th- floor balcony, saying the mob was dangerous. But by Friday evening, University Square was clear of miners and journalists saw none on the drive from the square to the train station. Police and soldiers with submachine guns told people in the square not to form crowds. Iliescu was to have been sworn in Friday at a meeting of both houses of Parliament. But a woman answering the phone at his office, who refused to give her name, said the session was put off until Monday. The French TV network La Cinq said it protested to Romanian authorities that miners and security forces beat two of its journalists and damaged their equipment. La Cinq broadcast an interview by Laszlo Toekes, the ethnic Hungarian pastor whose threatened arrest in Timisoara, western Romania, touched off December's revolution that culminated in the Dec. 25 execution of Ceausescu and his wife, Elena. ``I condemn without equivocation all the traitors of this new regime and its leader, Iliescu, who can be considered as a direct continuation of Ceausescu,'' Toekes said. ``I think we will have to have a second revolution.'' The miners devastated opposition party headquarters on Thursday, beating or threatening party leaders and damaging their homes. Miners invaded the offices of Romania Libera, Romania's largest independent newspaper with a circulation of more than 800,000, and a frequent critic of the government. Romania Libera journalist Mirela Roznoveanu said the miners beat a co-worker. The paper did not appear Friday. Printers and distributors loyal to Iliescu refused to handle it. Roman expressed regret over the attack, telling reporters criticism of government was healthy. Rompres quoted an unidentified spokesman for the miners as saying nobody invited them to come to Bucharest. But city buses and army trucks transported them by the hundreds to key points in the city. Rompres reported that Marian Munteanu, head of the anti-Iliescu Students' Alliance, was hospitalized with injuries. Miners were heard boasting they had beaten Munteanu. Among opposition party headquarters trashed were those of the 21st of December Organization of students who fought against Ceausescu.

DOC.HEAD: Protests, Economic Threats Lodged After Romanian Crackdown
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Western leaders on Friday threatened to block economic pacts with Romania following a harsh crackdown on anti-government demonstrators. Many leaders decried the crackdown as a return to repressive tactics used by ousted Communists. Coal miners using clubs were recruited to help police put down pro-democracy protests in the Romanian capital of Bucharest. At least five people were killed and 367 injured in the worst violence since the December revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. The demonstrators claimed the freely elected government led by President-elect Ion Iliescu is dominated by former Communists. ``I am not saying they should not restore a decent degree of order,'' said British Foreign Office Minister William Waldegrave. ``What I am saying is that the way they are responding, the rhetoric they are using and the calling out of the old `rent-a-mob,' just as Ceausescu used to do, are signs that fill us with despondency.'' The European Community, which hailed the fall of Ceausescu, will hold up a trade and economic cooperation accord finalized this week, said Bruce Millan, a member of the community's executive commission in Brussels. ``I can give an absolute assurance that we will not proceed with that ratification procedure in the kind of circumstances that face us in Romania at the moment,'' Millan said in Strasbourg, France, in an address to the EC Parliament. Other EC officials said there has been no final decision on suspending the accord. The 12-nation group will consider the pact Monday. Millan also hinted that Romania may lose aid from a more than $2 billion fund created to assist former communist countries. In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said non-humanitarian aid programs to Romania would be help up ``until the democratic process has been restored.'' He said $80 million in food aid and $1 million in medical aid would not be affected. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov said Romania was trying to change from an ``authoritarian regime to a state of the rule of law.'' ``There is no smooth road to that,'' he said. The Hungarian Foreign Ministry on Friday issued a communique expressing anxiety over events in neighboring Romania. ``Resort to violence, the use of brutal methods so familiar from before, arrogance and organized aggression against political opposition is irreconcilable with European norms,'' the communique said. France, which claimed four embassy staff members in Bucharest were attacked during the crackdown, lodged a strong protest with the Romanian charge d'affaires, Sabin Pop, in Paris. The governing Socialist Party in France accused Iliescu of ``methods of repression ... which evoke the worst practices of Stalinism.''
