The British Foreign Office summoned Romania's senior envoy in London, Nicu Bujor, and warned that Britain will find it difficult to give aid. British officials also protested about the storming of the home of opposition leader Ion Ratiu, head of the Romanian National Peasant Party, who is in exile in Britain. The 23-nation Council of Europe said Romania was regressing politically. ``It is not by this route Romania will rejoin the Europe of human rights and freedoms,'' said the council's secretary-general, Catherine Lalumiere. Protests were also issued by several Western countries, including Austria, Italy, Spain and Sweden. Japan, in a statement by the Foreign Ministry, accused the Romanian authorities of an ``escessive use of power.'' Exiled King Michael of Romania said Iliescu was moving to restore a communist dictatorship, and urged the West to withhold aid. ``I am profoundly disgusted to see where and how low these people are leading my country,'' he said in Geneva. ``Anything that is not a Communist is a fascist. It's the same old story.'' A statement by several labor groups, including the International Miners' Federation, said they ``strongly condemn the (Romanian) government's action aimed at using the work force in repressive action.''

DOC.HEAD: Miriam Makeba Sees Change in South Africa After 31 Years of Exile
DOC.TEXT: Singer Miriam Makeba said Friday she has seen many changes in her home country after being exiled for 31 years, but ``apartheid is still alive.'' ``I can come home but I cannot vote,'' she told a news conference after a one-week visit to see her family and pray at her mother's grave. The 58-year-old singer mentioned that laws are still intact restricting black ownership of land and segregating education and residential areas. ``My impressions are that there are some cosmetic changes. I see we are all sitting here together without police coming to say, `What are you doing?' That is something,'' she said. She indicated some disagreement with the African National Congress and other people about whether she would be breaking the organization's boycott on entertainers performing in South Africa if she sang in public at home. Ms. Makeba said, ``I believe as a South African the cultural boycott does not apply to me. It depends on the comrades of the (ANC) cultural desk. There is some kind of confusion.'' She said she does not know if she will live in South Africa permanently, but she wants to return and perform, and bring her children and grandchildren. ``It would be a shame for me to die tomorrow before I come back to sing before you, because that is something I look forward to the most, to come back and sing before the South African people, where I do not have to translate my songs,'' she said. Ms. Makeba has long supported the ANC. Her songs were banned in South Africa in 1962 when she spoke in favor of the organization at the United Nations. Ms. Makeba sang one song extemporaneously and without accompaniment when called to the stage at a Johannesburg nightclub this week. She said visiting her mother's grave was her only program. She left South Africa in 1959 at the age of 27 to make a movie musical and appear on television in the United States, but received a one-year contract to sing at the Village Vanguard in New York. When her mother died in 1960, the year the African National Congress was outlawed, Ms. Makeba was denied permission to return home and attend the funeral. After landing in Johannesburg on a flight from her home in Brussels, Belgium last Sunday, Ms. Makeba went immediately to her mother's grave in Soweto. ``I tried to make a prayer. I just choked, and all I did was weep,'' she said. ``I sat on my mother's grave ... and I cried like a baby. And I was happy, because we believe that wherever they are, a mother sees what we do. They listen to what we say. And I just consoled myself that wherever her soul is, she now knows that her baby is here, and she came to say, `Mama, I am back.'''

DOC.HEAD: Greenpeace Protests Arrival of British Aircraft Carrier
DOC.TEXT: Greenpeace environmental activists in inflatable boats stuck radiation symbols on the hull of the British aircraft carrier Ark Royal on Friday to protest nuclear weapons. Authorities arrested five protesters on charges of mischief and failure to comply. The carrier arrived Friday in Halifax, on the Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia. The protesters buzzed the British vessel in seven small boats. They attached some radiation symbols to the boat and painted on others. Six of them climbed to the top of a two-lane bridge spanning Halifax harbor where they unfurled a banner that asked Prime Minister Brian Mulroney to ``just say `no' to nuclear warships.'' Greenpeace, which advocates nuclear disarmament, says the British ship carries nuclear weapons. They have organized a series of such protests this year against British and U.S. naval vessels.

DOC.HEAD: Bus Passenger Sits in for Replacement Greyhound Driver Unable to Drive Stick
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Similar version on financial wires
DOC.TEXT: A bus passenger took the wheel Friday after a replacement driver for strike-plagued Greyhound told riders he didn't know how to use a stick shift. Greyhound officials said Diane Monteiro, a licensed bus driver for another company, drove the bus from Delaware to New York City while the ill-trained replacement sat back and left the driving to her. The replacement driver started at a junction in State Road, Del., and ``it was obvious very quickly that he could not drive that bus,'' said Greyhound spokesman George Grazley. Trained by Greyhound, the driver was operating a Carolina Coaches bus under an arrangement with Greyhound, which also owns Trailways. ``When he started to pull off, it sounded like he had clutch trouble,'' said passenger Rosa White. ``Then we get down the highway and we get to the big trucks. He almost ran us into one of those. He was swerving. ``And he made an announcement that (the company) hadn't trained him to shift the gears and he didn't know how to drive the bus.'' Ms. Monteiro took the wheel, calmed passengers and the replacement driver ``just got in a seat and went on and relaxed instead of watching what she was doing,'' Ms. White said. ``We don't know how the guy got through the training school without knowing all of that,'' Grazley said, adding that the driver was promptly fired. He refused to identify the driver. ``Greyhound seems to have adopted a new slogan. It's called, `Go Greyhound and leave the driving to you,''' said Harold Mandlowitz, president of Local 1202 of the Amalgamated Transit Union, which has been on strike against the nation's only intercity bus company since March. The woman made a stop at a Greyhound terminal in Newark, N.J., and continued to New York, where the bus arrived between 7 a.m. and 8 a.m., Ms. White said. Efforts by The Associated Press to contact Ms. Monteiro for comment were not immediately successful. The bus company she works for was not disclosed. Grazley said Dallas-based Greyhound is investigating. ``We're going to find out how he got through school,'' Grazley said. ``The fact that he got through school without learning how to drive a stick shift doesn't mean that others did. We have not had other mistakes like this.'' The 6,300 drivers in the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions launched their strike on March 2 over wages and job security. Greyhound filed for bankruptcy protection last week. The company has been operating with about 3,000 replacement drivers.

DOC.HEAD: 2 Live Crew Rocks Chicago _ Even Before Arriving
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: Law officials say they have no action planned for 2 Live Crew's concert Friday, but the controversial rap group still submitted its profanity-laced lyrics to the state's attonrey's office for approval. Cecil Partee, an attorney with Cook County State's Attorney's Office, reviewed the lyrics and ``finds them personally offensive,'' said spokesman Dan McCullough. ``But he has stated ... that he will not take any action himself to prevent the concert from happening or to otherwise intervene unless the Chicago police make an arrest,'' McCullough said. Police said they had no plans regarding the concert, since the state's attorney's office has historically made the determination on what is and isn't obscene. ``We're not going to deviate from that,'' said spokeswoman Tina Vicini. In Huntsville, Ala., 2 Live Crew's scheduled Saturday night performance was canceled by civic center officials who said the concert promoter didn't obtain proper insurance for the show. Contracts by the Von Braun Civic Center require promoters to have liability insurance coverage by a company licensed in Alabama. 2 Live Crew's promoter has an insurance carrier licensed in another state, civil center officials said Friday. Luther Campbell and another member of the Miami-based group were arrested in Florida last weekend after they played songs from their sexually explicit ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' album at an all-adult show. A Florida record store owner who sold the album also was arrested. The arrests followed a federal judge's ruling that the album violates Florida's obscenity law. The ruling is being appealed. Friday's concert was scheduled for the the International Amphitheatre, The former home of the stormy 1968 Democratic National Convention. The Amphitheater's general manager said he expected a crowd of about 6,000 for the 10,000-seat arena. ``The last couple of days, sales have picked up,'' said Michael Balog, general manager of the theater. He said 2 Live Crew has performed twice there in the last eight months with no media attention, and added that the amphitheater's audience was urban and more sophisticated than the southern locales where the band has run into problems. ``Kids who come to the show know the lyrics and know what to expect,'' he said. Meanwhile, the Chicago-based civil rights organization Operation PUSH was offering a ``clean'' alternative to Friday's 2 Live Crew performance with a speech and performance by rapper Kool Moe-Dee.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used the obituary on Joe Wright included in the AM-Deaths column which moved as a0784 on June 14 are asked to use the following:
DOC.TEXT: An Associated Press obituary of Joe Wright on June 14 was erroneously datelined Wilmington, Del. Wright, one of the Wilmington 10 who protested what they said were racial injustices in New Hanover County, North Carolina, schools during the early 1970s, died Wednesday in Wilmington, N.C.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards $7.6 Million to Widow of Prison Writer's Victim
DOC.TEXT: A jury awarded nearly $7.6 million Friday to the widow of a young actor stabbed to death by prison writer and Norman Mailer protege Jack Henry Abbott. Abbott, who wrote the best-seller ``In the Belly of the Beast,'' acted as his own attorney in the wrongful death civil trial. The suit was filed by Ricci Adan, 32. Abbott is serving a 15-year-to-life prison term for killing her husband, Richard Adan, 22, outside a Manhattan restaurant where he worked in 1981. Abbott, 46, killed the actor-waiter with a single stab wound to the heart. In his sometimes sneering testimony, Abbott claimed that Adan didn't suffer because his death was sudden. The jury found otherwise. It awarded Mrs. Adan $5.575 million in compensatory damages for lost income, and $2 million for her husband's pain and suffering before his death. About $100,000 Abbott earned from his book remains frozen in an escrow account set up in case he lost the suit. Another $15,000, also earned from his writings, is being held by the state Crime Victims Board. Outside the courtroom, Mrs. Adan and her family whooped, shouted and hugged each other to celebrate. Abbott asked presiding Justice Carol Arber. ``This is a little excessive, your honor, wouldn't you say?'' The judge told Abbott he could appeal, but he did not say whether he would. ``In the Belly of the Beast'' was composed of prison letters Abbott sent to Mailer from 1978 through 1981. During those years, Abbott was imprisoned first for bank robbery and then for fatally stabbing another inmate. Mailer supported Abbott's parole, largely because of his writing talent. Abbot killed Adan six weeks after leaving prison. Mailer has been unavailable for comment on Abbott's latest court drama. Mrs. Adan said the judgment ended years of pain. ``It's been a nightmare,'' she said. ``He's not just a speck of dust anymore. He's not just a victim, or a piece of paper _ he's a human being. And he can rest now.'' Abbott disputed an expert who said the fledgling actor could have earned $17 million by age 65. Abbott said those calculations assumed Adan ``would have been a movie star of the caliber of Paul Newman.' Kenneth Fishman, one of Mrs. Adan's attorneys, was unimpressed by Abbott's legal talents, saying he would have flunked him in a law school class. ``He had a certain feel for the courtroom, having spent so much time in so many of them,'' Fishman said, ``but he always had his ego in the way.'' Fishman noted that Abbott asked every witness, every juror, the judge and virtually every other person he spoke to whether they had read his book. Naomi Zack, the State University of New York philosophy instructor Abbott married last September while in prison, was not in court for the verdict. She had been present almost every day during the two-week trial and was the only witness Abbott called.

DOC.HEAD: Poland Calls Out Troops to Open Highway Blocked by Farmers
DOC.TEXT: The Solidarity-led government Friday sent police with clubs and tear gas to open a highway blocked by farmers angry about a drop in milk prices. The farmers left in the face of the show of force, agreeing to suspend their protest at least until discussions with Solidarity Chairman Lech Walesa. He was expected to arrive Saturday. Protesters moved aside tractors blocking the two-lane highway at Wisniewo, a rural community 80 miles northwest of Warsaw. The highway is the main road between Warsaw and the northern port of Gdansk. The blockade of highway E-7 began late Tuesday after farmers learned the local dairy cooperative was reducing the price it would pay for milk to 2 cents a quart. Walesa was caught in their blockade Thursday when he was being driven from his home in Gdansk to Warsaw for a flight to a meeting of the International Labor Organization in Switzerland. The labor leader told the farmers their dispute was local, but he said it was ``justified.'' He pledged to come back to help them resolve it if necessary. The government stuck to its vow not to make special concessions that would deviate from the economic reform program designed to transform the socialist economy into a market-driven system. It refused to bargain with railway workers during their strike in May, but Walesa negotiated a return to work that was followed by a pay increase. Because the road blocked by the farmers is considered an international highway, the government announced Friday that it was obliged under agreements with other countries to keep it open. It told the farmers that it would resort to force if necessary. Traffic was being diverted to other highways and several columns of police vehicles, carrying officers armed with truncheons and tear gas, arrived in Wisniewo at dusk. Some officers were in armored vehicles, and some came with water cannons. ``It will be a second Romania,'' some townspeople called out when three helicopters suddenly appeared over their village. It was a reference to the bloody Romanian revolution in December. Hundreds of local residents sympathetic to the farmers milled around the streets late Friday. However, the police vehicles parked along the side of the road, and there was no confrontation. Andrzej Wojtkowski, a local resident, said farmers had been complaining for months but only got the attention of authorities when they blocked the road. ``It's not a local problem. It is a problem for the government,'' he said. He said the local dairy would not be in such trouble if not for the high interest rates imposed by the government in January to combat inflation. According to Wojtkowski, the dairy has reduced the price it will pay for milk by more than half since April, and farmers have no other potential buyer in the area. Farmers on Friday donated their milk free to hospitals and apartment buildings but refused to sell it to the dairy.

DOC.HEAD: Supertanker Oil Spill Fed to Microbes
With AM-Tanker Blast, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Trillions of hungry microbes ate their way through an oil slick Friday as officials counted on an experimental method to help with the cleanup from the wrecked Norwegian tanker Mega Borg. ``This is breakthrough technology,'' Texas Land Commissioner Garry Mauro said of the process called bioremediation. Rolling in open seas aboard a 41-foot Coast Guard boat, officials sprayed a square acre in the Gulf of Mexico that was intermittently laced and blanketed by oil. Bioremediation uses naturally occurring bacteria that have been bred as super-eaters to break down oil into harmless fatty acids that later are eaten by marine life, said Carl Oppenheimer, who developed the process. Oppenheimer, a University of Texas microbiologist who has been working on the process for 15 years, predicted success. Within one or two days, there will be a clear square acre in the middle of the slick, he said. ``I think it is going to open the door now to bioremediation on a much wider scale,'' he said. Skeptics have criticized Oppenheimer's work, Mauro said, because the concept is so simple. Oppenheimer would only say of the experiment, ``It's been a long time coming.'' He said some tests have been performed on controlled spills in inner harbor areas but never on the open sea. Bioremediation was applied last month for the Exxon Valdez spill in Alaska. Microbes were used to clean some rocks on the shore of the Prince William Sound. Officials here allowed a test on the slick from the Norwegian supertanker that exploded June 8. ``We need bioremediation,'' said Texas Water Commission Chairman B.J. ``Buck'' Wynne III. ``This is a man who had an idea and no one would listen. He hasn't been able to get through all the snake oil salesmen.'' Oppenheimer said crews would return later to retrieve samples of the water that was treated with the microbes. He said there would approximately 5.3 billion microbes per square centimeter. About 100 pounds of the sand-like substance was mixed with sea water and sprayed onto the slick. Oppenheimer said the slick, about three miles southeast of the Mega Borg, probably was about one-eighth of an inch thick. Markers were set to track the movement of the area that was treated. He said he believed the process could remove about 90 percent of the oil, compared with the 5 or 10 percent he said skimmers could remove. Oppenheimer described skimmers as ``mostly cosmetic.''

DOC.HEAD: 11-State Street Gang Sweep Nets More Than 170 Arrests
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with more arrests, adds Texas to list of states; picks up 5th graf pvs, ``Authorities at...
DOC.TEXT: An 11-state sweep targeting street gangs that export drug dealing from California ghettos to other states netted more than 170 arrests, authorities said Friday. The action dubbed operation Street Sweep began Thursday, with hundreds of federal agents and local law officers moving in on members of the Crips and Bloods, violent gangs spawned in poor Southern California neighborhoods. By late afternoon Friday, 174 arrests had been made, officials said. ``What began as a Los Angeles problem has now spread to a national one,'' said Stephen E. Higgins, director of the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. Arrests were made in California, Louisiana, Arizona, New Mexico, Texas, Missouri, Oklahoma, Oregon, Washington, and two other states that weren't identified because warrants were still being served. Authorities at a news conference to announce the sweep displayed a sample of confiscated weapons, but did not detail the quantity of weapons or drugs seized. A national investigation by the bureau revealed the rival Crips and Bloods were heavily involved in crack cocaine distribution and firearms trafficking nationwide, Higgins said. ``Gang members are involved in murders, drive-by shootings, narcotics trafficking, assaults, credit car fraud, robberies and money laundering,'' he said, adding the operation was ``intended to send a message to violent street gangs.'' More arrests were expected through the weekend, ATF spokesman Jack Killorian said from Washington, D.C. ``This was not a search and investigative operation. It was an arrest operation,'' Killorian said. ``Most of the arrests were fugitives and the majority were charged with federal weapons charges.'' The sweep focused on Southern California, where 134 arrests were made in Los Angeles, Orange, Riverside, San Bernardino and San Diego counties. Arrests in Louisiana were related to a January seizure in Shreveport of nearly 13 pounds of cocaine worth an estimated $250,000, Killorian said. Higgins was unable to say if those arrested were gang leaders. ``They aren't formally structured in that sense, (but) these are people who control a fair amount of the (drug) market,'' he said. Although outnumbered by drug traffickers, law enforcement officers' efforts to eradicate drug dealing could prevail, he said ``I'm convinced it's a winnable war,'' Higgins said. ``We're in it for the long term.''

DOC.HEAD: Pope Meets Mandela, Blesses His Anti-Apartheid Struggle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Mandela in the Netherlands, details, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto ROM6, LaserColor ROM7
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Friday greeted South African anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela and blessed his efforts to destroy the system of racial segregation. But the pontiff did not directly answer Mandela's request to support economic sanctions to keep pressure on South Africa's white leaders. Papal spokesman Joaquin Navarro said the Vatican considers sanctions a political issue but that apartheid was an ethical problem that is proper for the pope to address. John Paul received Mandela in a 25-minute audience, part of the African National Congress deputy president's six-week tour of Europe, Africa and North America. As reporters were let into the pope's private library at the end of the talks, John Paul told Mandela, freed Feb. 11 after more than 27 years in prison, ``Thanks be to God that we can meet.'' The pope in the past has praised Mandela as a ``man who suffers for the rights of his people'' and the Vatican last year issued a major document on racism harshly condemning apartheid. Turning to reporters, Mandela explained that the ANC believes sanctions need to be maintained and ``I asked them (the Holy See) to express themselves very clearly on this issue. ``I asked our father (the pope) to bless this initiative because we are sure his blessing would help because his stands on issues like apartheid and anti-Semitism have been so clear they have won respect from the whole world.'' John Paul then said in English: ``God bless your initiatives.'' In a later news conference, Mandela said the pope indicated Vatican officials ``were putting moral pressure to induce the South African government to abandon apartheid.'' He added that John Paul had not asked the ANC to give up armed struggle. ``If an oppressor uses force and brutality in addressing the legitimate aspirations of the people, the people are entitled in a defensive manner to adopt or resort to violence too,'' he said. He added that the pontiff ``apparently understands the position better than some of you (journalists) do.'' In a statement issued after the meeting, the Vatican said the audience granted to Mandela was ``further confirmation of the Holy See's commitment in favor of a peaceful political evolution in South Africa'' and the ``progressive overcoming of the system of apartheid.'' Under apartheid, South Africa's 28 million blacks have no vote in national affairs and the 5 million whites control the economy. Mandela said he was ``very encouraged'' by his talks Friday afternoon with Premier Giulio Andreotti, a Christian Democrat. Mandela asked Italy for financial and material support for the ANC as it reorganizes, a spokesman for the premier said. At the news conference, Mandela made one of his harshest attacks on black leaders Lucas Mangope, the head of the nominally independent homeland of Bophuthatswana, and Mangosuthu Buthelezi, the head of Inkatha, a Zulu-based conservative political organization that opposes sanctions. Asked why they had not been included in negotiations between the government and the ANC, Mandela said Mangope had been kept in power by white authorities. ``I don't think that he is any factor at all in what is going on in South Africa today,'' Mandela said. He said Buthelezi agreed ``to work with the government on projects which we do not believe are in the interests of the black people.'' Later Friday, Mandela flew to the Netherlands for a two-day visit that was seen as recognition of that nation's opposition to apartheid. He and his wife, Winnie, arrived on an Italian Air Force jet at a Dutch navy air base outside The Hague. His visit will include a breakfast meeting Saturday with Dutch leaders, including Premier Ruud Lubbers. Mandela is also expected to meet Queen Beatrix at her palace, an unusual honor for non-governmental visitors.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Sides With FCC: Dump `Fin-Syn' Rules
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Also on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department on Thursday sided with the major television networks in their fight to regain the right to own or be able to sell their programs in the lucrative rerun market. The department said it supported a 1983 conclusion by the Federal Communications Commission that allowing TV networks to have a financial interest and syndication rights in the programs they broadcast would not hurt competition. ``It appears that, in purchasing television entertainment programs, the networks compete not only with each other, but also, increasingly, with other purchasers of television entertainment programs,'' the department said in a filing with the commission. It urged the commission ``to eliminate the financial interest and syndication rules unless the record demonstrates that they are necessary to protect the public interest in competition.'' The FCC in March said it would reconsider 1970 rules that prohibit ABC, CBS and NBC from having an interest in their programs or selling them in syndication. The FCC had postponed beginning its inquiry until Thursday to give the interested parties one last chance to work out an agreement to alter the rules, known as ``fin-syn.'' Producers and the networks have been engaged in often-acrimonious talks to change the rules ever since 1983. The talks failed this week again, and the commission began accepting comments Thursday. FCC Chairman Alfred Sikes, who has said he wants some changes in the rules, said he was disappointed but not surprised that the parties did not reach agreement. The FCC earlier this year granted Fox Broadcasting Co. a waiver from the fin-syn rules so it could continue to grow into a true network. Fox also is a syndicator and it is owned by a major Hollywood producer, Twentieth Century Fox Film Corp. Fox Inc. Chairman Barry Diller on Thursday, in a statement in Los Angeles, said there was an ``urgent need to review the rules and to revise the definition of a network.'' He said the FCC should be encouraging companies such as Fox. In 1983 the FCC tentatively decided to eliminate the financial interest rule and narrow the syndication rule to prohibit only network participation in domestic syndication of prime time programs. But it delayed the proceeding under pressure from Congress and President Reagan and urged the interested parties to find a solution themselves. In March the FCC officially terminated that inquiry and began the new one. Networks argue that the fin-syn rules give undue market power to producers and impede the networks' abilities to compete in the increasingly multinational program marketplace. Advocates of the rules claim they have helped small producers flourish and have led to more diversity in programming. The Justice Department told the FCC that ``If the networks do not have significant market power, it appears that the practices prohibited by the rules would not, in these circumstances, create such power.'' ``It also appears unlikely that the rules significantly constrain the exercise of any market power that the networks may possess, but we cannot conclusively rule out that possibility.'' The department conceded it was possible that removing the rules ``could result in wealth transfers from producers to networks.'' ``But this would not warrant retaining the rules unless such transfers would be accompanied by an adverse effect on program output and thus a decrease in social welfare,'' the department said. It said increased competition in the program production market and efficiencies gained through network ownership of financial interests and syndication rights would benefit the public.

DOC.HEAD: Water Wall Hits Ohio Town; 11 Dead, 51 Missing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE to show that missing persons all from flood area, describe location of victims, move up reference to 51 missing, DELETE comment of unnamed firefighter; Picks up 14th graf, `Some of ... '
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PG1-3; LaserColor PG100; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Torrential thunderstorms sent a flash flood surging through a valley into this Ohio River town, killing at least 11 people, leaving 51 missing and scores of others homeless Friday, authorities said. Raging floodwaters late Thursday swept homes off foundations and washed away cars. About 200 people were reported evacuated in central Ohio. ``The valleys are choked with debris,'' Gov. Richard Celeste told reporters after flying over the hilly Appalachian region in eastern Ohio. ``A wall of water wiped a path through the area.'' The governor declared a state of emergency, and dispatched about 50 National Guardsmen to the area. The Federal Emergency Management Agency declared Belmont County, which includes Shadyside, and Jefferson and Franklin counties disaster areas, making federal aid available to residents. Seventeen counties now have been declared disaster areas because of flooding or tornadoes since May 29. Ten bodies were taken to the Bauknecht Funeral Home in Shadyside, said Bob Bell, funeral director. One body was taken to Bellaire City Hospital, he said. Chuck Vogt, Belmont County coroner's investigator, also said there were 11 confirmed dead. Earlier, Fire Chief Mark Badia had said 14 adults and two children were dead. The names of the victims have not been released. County Sheriff Tom McCort, who said he was running the recovery effort, said 51 people in Shadysville and Meade Township, where the two creeks run south of the village, were missing as of 8:45 p.m. The list was compiled through telephone inquiries with townspeople and relatives and interviews with people evacuated from the area. About 200 people came and went from a Shadyside disaster center during the day, seeking news of missing friends and relatives. Vogt said two bodies were found in the Ohio River and one was found in a field next to the river after water receded. He said the rest were found in the creeks, which flow into the river. Some of the bodies were taken to a funeral home that set up a temporary morgue in Shadyside, about 10 miles south of Wheeling, W.Va. Officials from Ohio, West Virginia and the U.S. Coast Guard were searching the Ohio River for survivors and bodies, and Badia said National Guardsmen were to continue searching the creeks throughout the night. At least five houses along Wegee Creek were washed away, and two cars were floating in water in one of the basements. Anything that was still standing was covered with at least 6 feet of debris such as trees, appliances and furniture. The National Weather Service issued no flood warning before the disaster, although it did issue a flood watch, said Al Wheeler, deputy meteorologist in the bureau's Cleveland office. Weather service offices in Cleveland, Akron, Columbus and Pittsburgh showed the storm had diminished over eastern Ohio when it had actually intensified, Wheeler said. Thursday night's thunderstorms caused flash flooding across a wide area of central and eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia and western Pennsylvania. The floods closed roads, damaged homes and forced hundreds of people to evacuate. But no place was hit with anything approaching the ferocity of the flooding in Shadyside. About 5.5 inches of rain fell between 7:30 p.m. and 11 p.m., turning two Ohio River tributaries outside the village of 4,300 people into dangerous torrents. About 35 buildings, including a tavern, were damaged along Wegee Creek, and 50 buildings were hit by a flood along Pipe Creek, four miles south of Wegee Creek, said Dick Quinlin, Belmont County emergency services coordinator. Part of the tavern was washed away when water caved in the back wall, said Judy Phillips, a sheriff's department spokeswoman. She said two patrons were accounted for, but she could offer no estimate of how many were inside at the time. One man was found clinging to a bar stool, said state Sen. Robert Ney, whose district includes Shadyside. ``I've never seen anything of this magnitude. There was no warning,'' Ney said. Rescuers pulled people from three cars in Wegee Creek, which flows through Shadyside and into the Ohio River, said Badia. ``I don't know how to describe it. ... You've got to see it to believe it,'' Badia said. One resident, Robert Ramsey, said his wife, Rose, was crushed to death in their house by the water. There was no complete accounting of deaths, said Karen Bovek, a spokeswoman at a Shadyside Fire Department command center set up an a school. ``You're talking miles and miles of country roads that haven't been gotten to yet,'' she said. ``It's a disaster here.'' There also was flooding in Jefferson County, north of Belmont, in Licking County in central Ohio, and in northwestern West Virginia and western Pennsylvania. ``It's a pretty good mess, especially in the northern end of the county,'' said Clarence Weston, a dispatcher with the Marshall County Sheriff's Department in Moundsville, W.Va. ``We had 3.5 inches of rain in a two-hour period last night.'' Most of the problems in West Virginia were confined to road closures and basement flooding. At least 25 people were evacuated during the night in the Pittsburgh suburb of Etna, where some homes had up to 5 feet of water in their basements, said borough manager Bill Skertich. They returned to their homes Friday. Landslides were reported in the Pittsburgh area, and many city streets were closed during the storm. The flooding was more serious in Licking County, Ohio. Wayne Tresemer, the county's Disaster Services director, said water was standing up to 5 feet deep in some streets in the town of Newark, and the fire department and other agencies used boats to evacuate some residents. Two inches of rain caused flooding in Franklin County in central Ohio and 3.75 inches of rain was dumped on Holmes County in north-central Ohio, the National Weather Service said. In Jefferson County, just north of Belmont County in the eastern part of the state, 50 to 60 residents were evacuated in Adena, where water was 6 to 8 feet deep in streets because of creek flooding. Flood waters in most areas had subsided by Thursday night, according to authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Microbes Applied to Gobble Oil from Tanker
With AM-Tanker Blast-Oil Eaters-Glance
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Crews on Friday began spraying oil-eating microbes on the slick surrounding the burning supertanker Mega Borg in the first open-sea release of the bacteria to clean up a spill. The Coast Guard boosted its estimate of the amount of oil released into the Gulf of Mexico to 4.3 million gallons, making it the nation's fifth largest spill. The fire was extinguished Friday afternoon, but officials said they would have to wait at least 24 hours for the ship to cool before removing the remaining oil. The ship could catch fire again, Coast Guard Ptty Officer Todd Nelson said. ``There are no flames, however it's still real hot and if we walk away from it right now, it may reflash,'' Nelson said. The Coast Guard had said the first tar balls from the leaking Norwegian supertanker could wash ashore late Friday on Bolivar Peninsula, across the bay from Galveston Island. But county officials said they had no unusual reports of oil on shore. ``We don't anticipate the oil will come before Sunday. We're prepared,'' said Galveston City Manager Doug Matthews. Crews on four fireboats also continued spraying water on the 886-foot ship, which exploded and caught fire late last Friday, 57 miles off Galveston. Gray smoke spewed from the rear section of the vessel. More than two dozen smaller boats used skimming devices to suck up or corral the rusty brown oil trailing from the tanker. Salvage crews said they had skimmed 146,389 gallons of oil. The Coast Guard said most of the light African crude evaporated or burned, and less than 22,000 gallons remained in the water. The Coast Guard would not elaborate on how it reached the 4.3 million gallon estimate for the spill. The spill earlier had been estimated at 3 million gallons. The worst oil spill in U.S. history was last year when the Exxon Valdez ran aground, spilling nearly 11 million gallons of heavy crude on the Prince William Sound in Alaska. In the experimental use of the microbes, officials working on a Coast Guard boat mixed the bacteria with sea water and sprayed it on a section of the 30-mile-long slick. About 100 pounds of microbes were sprayed over an acre in a procedure that lasted about 30 minutes Friday afternoon. Officials will check the area Saturday to see if the experiment was successful. The process, known as bioremediation, has never been tried on an oil spill in open seas, although lab experiments have been successful, said Texas Land Commissioner Garry Mauro. Bioremediation has been used for years to clean up hazardous waste sites, treat sewage and wastewater, extract oil from tight geologic formations and clean some rocks on shore after the Exxon Valdez accident, Mauro said. At Valdez cleanup sites, workers have been applying nitrogen and phosphorous fertilizer that promotes growth in the sand of the naturally occurring bacteria. The bacteria eats the oil and reduces it to a fatty substance that fish can eat. When the oil runs out, the microbes die. On shore, Galveston officials kept an eye on the advancing slick. ``We have not had any indication of any oil coming ashore,'' Pat Hallisey, executive director of the Galveston County Beach Park Board, said Friday. ``We're keeping our fingers crossed.'' Coast Guard Petty Officer Gene Maestas said there were some ``streams of oil,'' but the captain of the port ordered skimmers to collect them. The largest sheen of oil extended from the vessel about 10 miles to the northwest, with two additional patches beginning 10 miles farther. The slick nearest to land was about 25 miles away. Firefighters on the Mega Borg pumped oil from a leaking cargo tank into another tank to try and cut off the fuel source from the fire. Previously, firefighting efforts have consisted mostly of showering water on the vessel. ``This could improve the situation,'' Coast Guard Capt. Tom Greene said. ``We're planning to work on this in conjunction with putting out the fire.'' Crews also pumped water from a tank on the left side of the boat to help stabilize the ship. Its rear section has been awash and listing slightly to the left. In Galveston, a Norwegian maritime panel ended three days of questioning surviving crew members in hopes of finding what caused the explosion and blast. They asked third mate Jaipal Singh Mahlawat to elaborate on a fuel leak discovered in the ship's pump room six hours before the explosion. ``I saw the pump man, he was screwing a coupling back to stop the oil from leaking,'' Mahlawat said. ``No oil was leaking. He had already wiped it out.'' The pump man, Putham Mahamood, testified Thursday through a translator that he performed ``no measurable repair work'' the day of the explosion. The Mega Borg's chief engineer told the panel Thursday one of the vessel's pumps was leaking fuel about six hours before the explosion, and a Norwegian shipping inspector said some other pumps were overdue for an inspection. The hearing panel will send its fact-finding report to the Norwegian maritime investigative bureau, which will determine if the ship is seaworthy and if there is any criminal liability. Of the 41 people aboard the ship, two crewmen were killed, two are missing and presumed dead and 17 were injured, none seriously.

DOC.HEAD: `Price of Fame,' Written By and Starring Charles Grodin, Opens Off-Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: Roger Carstairs is a movie star who once was big box office. Then they had to team him with a female star to sell tickets. In his most recent picture, he was forced to share billing with a horse. And now he's making a movie with a creature from outer space. Guess who gets more attention? Desperation time in Hollywood is the theme of ``Price of Fame,'' Charles Grodin's desperate little comedy that arrived Wednesday at off-Broadway's Roundabout Theater. Grodin also stars as the fading actor, but it's a mistake. He's too laid-back in the role. Grodin is not neurotic enough playing the star who compulsively checks the grosses of his latest bomb of a movie or tries to fend off an inquisitive female magazine interviewer. It's this magazine reporter _ a shrill performance by Lizbeth Mackay _ who sets the plot in motion. She has been assigned by her editor, who is also her boyfriend, to do a hatchet piece on Roger. What she doesn't know is the editor's previous girlfriend was once stolen away by Roger. Things get complicated and a tad improbable when Roger maneuvers the reporter into bed before the interview is over. Naturally, the boyfriend shows up in Act 2 before a confusing and bittersweet final curtain. Grodin the playwright softens the ending by having the actor reconcile with his son, a slightly dopey lad who works on the movie as a gofer. But even that is unexpected since there was no hint of a problem between the two for most of the two acts. Grodin never lets us see why this movie actor was special. He's more like an accountant than a big star. Consequently, whatever happens to him elicits little interest. And his jokes about Hollywood are pretty tame, especially from someone with first-hand knowledge about how the movie business game is played. The slow-moving direction by Gloria Muzio doesn't help. The rest of the actors, including Jace Alexander as the son and Joseph R. Sicari as a talkative makeup man, labor mightily to liven things up. But the overall effect is much energy expended for little result. One interesting footnote to the production: Appearing in a small role is Jeanne Berlin, Grodin's co-star in the wonderful film, ``The Heartbreak Kid.'' The actress is wasted here, the most glaring example of another promise left unfulfilled by this insider's tale of Tinseltown.

DOC.HEAD: Social Democrats Give Qualified ``Yes'' To German Economic Merger
DOC.TEXT: The opposition Social Democrats gave half-hearted approval Thursday to economic merger with East Germany, saying they won't fight it but that Chancellor Helmut Kohl is to blame for any untoward consequences. Their action removes the last political obstacle to launching the economic and monetary union that takes effect July 2. Merging the currencies and other economic mechanisms will mark a huge step toward formal German unification. The left-of-center Social Democrats made their decision at a special leadership meeting on Thursday that included Oskar Lafontaine, the party's nominee for chancellor in West German elections set for Dec. 2. Lafontaine has harshly criticized the treaty between the two Germanys. But his position deeply divided the Social Democrats and speculation arose that he might quit his candidacy because of internal feuding. Lafontaine remains popular, however, and has decided to stay in the race. Party leaders agreed Thursday the party should not try to block the merger treaty, but at the same time they washed their hands of any responsibility if the merger brings unwelcome results. One leader, Norbert Gansel, said the party sees economic merger as ``unavoidable and necessary'' because of the high expectations it has produced in East Germany. But he said the party was not offering an ``uncritical yes.'' Reading from a leadership statement, Gansel said Kohl's government will bear sole responsibility if ``dramatic problems'' arise from the economic merger. Gansel even left the door open for individual party members to vote against the merger when the treaty comes up for parliamentary ratification on June 21 and 22. He said any lawmaker voting against would not be acting ``outside of solidarity'' with the rest of the party. Experts say up to 2 million East Germans could lose their jobs as antiquated factories go bust. That could produce unrest in East Germany. Another concern is that West Germans will face hefty tax increases to pay for rebuilding East Germany's economy. Kohl's government insists tax increases will not be needed. For weeks, the Social Democrats tried to get Kohl's government to change the treaty to provide more job protection for East Germans. But the party was reluctant to press its objections to the merger treaty too strongly, lest it anger East Germans eagerly awaiting the anticipated fruits of economic merger and overhaul of the battered East German economy. The Social Democrats still want to be in a position to reap a political windfall, however, if Kohl's economic merger plans produce severely negative effects.

DOC.HEAD: President Goes To The Show
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, his wife Barbara and several friends and family members, attended Thursday night's opening at the Kennedy Center of ``Starlight Express,'' the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical set on roller skates. The Bushes were joined by their son and daughter, Jeb Bush and Doro LeBlond, as well as Houston oilman Will Farish, his wife Sarah, and their children, Laura and Bill. The stage at the Kennedy Center opera house was extended with a circular ramp to accommodate the allegorical musical about a competition between steam, diesel and electric locomotives. The theater was filled to capacity with Bush sitting in the presidential box at the center of the first tier. The night out on the town came six days after Mrs. Bush's 65th birthday and two after the president's 66th.

DOC.HEAD: Lebanon Torn by New Battles in Christian Zone, South
DOC.TEXT: Renewed factional battles broke out across Lebanon Thursday as rival forces battled for control of the Christian enclave and an Israeli-backed militia fought leftists in the south. Two people were wounded in the clash between the leftist Popular Nasserite Organization and the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army militia in the hills to the east of Sidon, provincial capital of south Lebanon, police said. The Nasserite Organization, a predominantly Sunni Moslem group, fields the largest militia in Sidon, 25 miles south of Beirut. The 3,000-member South Lebanon Army helps patrol the security zone that Israel declared in south Lebanon in 1985 to guard against cross-border guerrilla raids. Police said no casualties were reported in the mortar, machine gun and rocket-propelled grenade exchanges between Christian troops loyal to rebel Gen. Michel Aoun and militiamen of Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces. The inter-Christian battles in east Beirut and Christian communities to the north eased off Thursday morning, but tension remained high in the enclave. At least 1,036 people have been killed there and 2,774 wounded since the fighting broke out Jan. 30. It has been some of the worst inter-Christian fighting in Lebanon's 15-year civil war, which has more often pitted Christians against Moslems. A truce in the inter-Christian showdown was declared May 17, but violations have been frequent.

DOC.HEAD: Party Expels Mayor for Suggesting Help for Socialists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to make it only National Front seat, not first. Party had seats until 1988
DOC.TEXT: A rising conservative politician was suspended by fellow party members for suggesting an alliance with the governing Socialists in one district to battle a far-right candidate. The move could be the first step in expelling Grenoble Mayor Alain Carignon from the Rally for the Republic Party and was seen by some as symbolizing disarray and weakness in the traditional right. Carignon, 41, a former environmental minister, angered party leaders by publicly endorsing an alliance with President Francois Mitterrand's Socialists to oppose a candidate from the far-right National Front party in a district election runoff Sunday in Villeurbaine, a suburb of Lyons. National Front leader Jean-Marie Le Pen favors expelling Moslem immigrants from France and has been accused of anti-Semitism. About 4 million of France's 55 million people are immigrants, many Africans from former French colonies. Although the Republic party does not support the National Front's platform, it is a bitter rival of the Socialists. Republic party leaders have urged its supporters to abstain from voting in Sunday's elections. On Sunday, National Front candidate Pierre Vial received 27.3 percent of the vote in Valleurbaine to defeat conservative party candidates. Vial faces Socialist candidate Nathalie Gauthier, who had 36.8 percent of the vote. The Republic party finished third with 17 percent of the vote. ``It's a moral question,'' Carignon said, urging voters to ``form a barrier to the extremist candidate.'' Carignon was suspended Tuesday on grounds he violated party policy of abstaining from voting for other party candidates. The suspension could lead to Carignon's expulsion. If expelled, he would retain his mayor's post but without formal party backing. ``We cannot continue to show our electors this spectacle of disorder,'' said party secretary general Alain Juppe. Carignon served as environment minister when Republic party leader Jacques Chirac was prime minister from 1986 to 1988. The National Front won 12 percent of the vote in national elections in 1988. It recently won its only seat in the 577-seat National Assembly.

DOC.HEAD: `Six Degrees of Separation' by John Guare Opens Off-Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: Let's not waste words. ``Six Degrees of Separation'' by John Guare is a crackling good play, a snappy, smart tale of Manhattan, made even more intriguing because it is based on a real incident. The production, which opened Thursday at the Mitzi Newhouse Theater in Lincoln Center, is also wonderfully funny and inventive, not only in its unexpected plot twists but in the way director Jerry Zaks brings out its darker, more serious moments. Guare, who used a newspaper story as the starting point for his play, has created a scathing, satiric look at the fads, foibles and follies of living in Manhattan, circa 1990. The news article told of a hoax involving a young man who claimed to be the son of actor Sidney Poitier and how he duped several prominent New York families. In Guare's play, just about everyone is a con man. Even its upper-crust, liberal hero and heroine, Flan and Ouisa, are not above pulling a scam of sorts. He's an art dealer who courts wealthy foreigners. You know, says the wife, the kind of people who can't scrape together enough money for dinner but can come up with $2 million for a second-rate Cezanne. But these East Siders meet their match in Paul, a young man who shows up at their apartment. The lad, claiming to a friend of their college-age children, has just been mugged. The couple embrace him, especially after he says he is Poitier's son. The youth cooks dinner for them and is invited to stay. He promises to introduce them to his father and even get them jobs in a movie version of ``Cats'' that his father allegedly is directing. He also dazzles them with conversation about his college thesis on ``The Catcher in the Rye.'' Only later do the entranced couple learn he is a fraud. His cover is blown when Flan's lawyer and his wife tell a similar story. It seems they were duped by Paul the previous week. And Guare adds a third victim _ a physician who allows Paul to stay over in his brownstone. The unraveling of Paul's real identity won't be revealed here, but the detective work involves the children of these wealthy people. The kids are portrayed as adolescent gargoyles, blaming their parents for everything that has gone wrong in their lives and determined to make them suffer. Guare has captured their revenge hilariously, particularly in a diatribe for actor Evan Handler who plays a spiteful son railing against his father. The play then turns serious when Paul's flim-flam takes in a naive couple from Utah, babes in the big city. The consequences of his deceptions are tragic. Guare weaves all the stories together, the one link being the young man who has been able to affect _ for good and ill _ so many lives. The entire cast is first-rate, but special mention should be made of the three leads. Stockard Channing makes the baffled, bewildered matron a figure of sympathy by the end of the play. John Cunningham is the epitome of WASP pomposity as her husband. James McDaniel is astonishing as Paul, portraying him as victimizer and victim, too. Tony Walton's stylized set is mostly a series of picture frames and a couch or two strewn on the playing area. But they work brilliantly to suggest a variety of locales including a bench in Central Park. The odd title, ``Six Degrees of Separation,'' refers to a concept articulated by Ouisa as she ponders how she and her friends were brought in contact with Paul. Everybody on the planet is separated from everybody else by only six people, she says, adding that the trick is to find the right six people. Guare has not only found the right people but put them on stage with dazzling results.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Challenges Citizenship Of Alleged Former Nazi Guard
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT spelling of Stutthof.
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department moved Thursday to revoke the citizenship of a California man accused of persecuting prisoners while he was a guard at three Nazi camps during World War II. The complaint charged that between November 1943 and March 1945 Johann Ziegler, of Hemet, Calif., was a SS guard at unnamed German concentration camps in Kaunas, Lithuania, and Stutthof, Poland, and at Gutenhafen, a slave-labor subcamp in Stutthof. ``During that time, thousands of prisoners died as a result of execution, subjection to slave labor under inhumane conditions, starvation, disease from unsanitary conditions, torture, and other methods of killing,'' Neil Sher, head of the Justice Department's Nazi-hunting unit, said in a statement. The complaint, filed in federal court in Los Angeles, charges that Ziegler concealed his membership in the SS Death's Head Battalion and the SS Guard Battalion when he applied for U.S. citizenship. Ziegler is accused of persecuting civilians because of their race, religion, national origin or political views, according to the complaint. Thirty-two former Nazis living in the United States have been stripped of their citizenship and 27 removed from the country as a result of the Justice Department's continuing investigation.

DOC.BYLINE: Cuban Museum Hit by Terrorist Bombing
DOC.TEXT: A Cuban art museum targeted by exile hard-liners for showing works by artists considered sympathetic to communist Cuba was ripped by a terrorist bomb Thursday for the second time in two years. A ``high-order explosive'' blew out the front of the Cuban Museum of Arts and Culture in Little Havana at 1:09 a.m., said FBI spokesman Paul Miller. ``This is a terrorist incident,'' he said. The museum was closed at the time, and there were no injuries. No arrests have been made, and Miller would not comment on whether the FBI's anti-terrorism task force in Miami had any suspects. It was the 17th Cuban-related bombing or attempted bombing laid to terrorists in the area in three years. The blast damaged artwork inside, scattered debris along the street outside, broke windows in nearby buildings and left a small crater in the sidewalk. ``It did a considerable amount of damage to the front of the building, including structural damage to the roof,'' Miller said. Damage to the art, pieces by 16 Cuban artists who arrived on the Mariel boatlift in 1980, was estimated at $10,000, Miller said. Preliminary estimates of damage to the building ranged into the tens of thousands. ``There is nothing very controversial that we're exhibiting now,'' said museum Director Osvaldo Monzon. He said the display ``is something that I'm quite proud of ... the art of artists who came from Mariel and have succeeded greatly.'' In May 1988, a small pipe bomb blew out the front door while art from Cuba was on display. Thursday's explosion wasn't caused by a pipe bomb. FBI experts will analyze evidence from the scene to determine what it was, Miller said. ``The FBI and Miami Police Department believe this is the 17th device since May 1987 of a terrorist nature ... attributed to individuals who have targeted individuals, businesses and museums they believe may advocate better relations with Castro's Cuba,'' he said. Most of the bombs have been small devices placed outside buildings and homes at night. Before Thursday, the most recent bombing was at an optical store in suburban Hialeah last September. The bombing in May 1988 occurred during a controversy in the city's Cuban community over the handling of works by artists considered sympathetic to Cuban President Fidel Castro. The day after the bombing, 17 of the museum's directors and five top officials resigned, saying the institution had lost touch with the community and the trauma suffered by Cubans on their island homeland. Monzon vowed Thursday that the museum would not be intimidated. ``We will continue,'' he said. ``Political pressure and terrorists will not discourage us.''

Congress is sending President Bush a bill requiring employers to give workers up to three months' unpaid leave for family emergencies, and Bush must decide whether to make good on his veto threat. The Senate gave final approval to the family leave bill in a voice vote Thursday night after only brief debate. Passage, the culmination of a four-year effort by supporters, was a bit anticlimactic. Republican opponents conceded they could not defeat the House-passed bill and did not seek a recorded vote. Democrats, confident that the measure is popular with voters, immediately sought to turn up the political pressure on Bush to sign the bill.

Airlines will have to use better X-ray machines and pay closer attention to checked-in luggage under new federal directives responding to a presidential commission on terrorism. Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner and Federal Aviation Administration chief James Busey announced several security steps Thursday, including creation of two high-level posts to oversee transportation security. Busey said airlines would be required to replace older, less-sensitive X-ray machines with modern ones that have higher detection standards for carry-on luggage. X-rays, however, cannot detect plastic bombs. Metal detectors that passengers walk through also would have to be upgraded under the new orders.

Police in many states have a green light to use sobriety checkpoints to combat drunken driving, but some _ including a Supreme Court justice _ say that tactic will not work. The high court on Thursday upheld Michigan's checkpoint program and, by extension, similar operations in most states. Critics say checkpoints, where all motorists heading in one direction are pulled over and detained briefly, are not as efficient as other methods used by police to catch drunken drivers or keep them off the road. ``We must begin to assure that every community will make checkpoints a key element of an all-out campaign to finally rid our roads of the menace posed by drinking drivers,'' said Micky Sadoff, national president of Mothers Against Drunk Driving.

Gulf Coast residents braced for tar balls to wash ashore today from a 30-mile oil slick left by the burning Mega Borg. No one knew Thursday where the globs of tar would wash up, but the west end of Galveston was a likely spot, Coast Guard Capt. Thomas Greene said. State officials were to dump oil-eating bacteria on the brown slick today. The Norwegian supertanker continued to spew oil today from a tank ruptured by a fire whose cause is the subject of a hearing in its third day.

Gen. George S. Patton's 2nd Armored Division helped win the Battle of the Bulge, but now it has lost the battle of the budget. The Army has decided to deactivate the unit, ending its colorful history as the armored division with the longest active service record. Formed in July 1940 for European service in World War II, the division is being dismantled 50 years later in anticipation of European peace. ``This division has the most glorious history of any combat unit in the U.S. Army,'' Lt. Charles MacMaster at Fort Hood said Thursday. Patton dubbed the division ``hell on wheels,'' promising it would terrify enemies. Its troops adopted the nickname as their motto. Today, its soldiers still proudly wear ``hell on wheels'' on their division patch.

For 40 years, the Army grumbled about Pvt. Beetle Bailey. He's a real misfit, they said. Lazy. No spit and polish. Drives the Sarge nuts. He'll never make corporal. Let him peel potatoes forever. Then one fine day, somebody in the Pentagon with silver stars on his shoulders looked around the table and told the men with silver eagles on their shirt collars: Hey, you know, the little guy's funny. Yes, sir! they all replied, nodding in unison. And so it was that an incredulous Mort Walker, a cartoonist who once slogged through the mud at Fort Leonard Wood, Mo., as an Army draftee in World War II, was ushered into the Pentagon on Thursday and given a hero's welcome.

DOC.NOTE: $Adv 18
For Release Monday AMs, June 18, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Drought to Drenched: Farmers Hope Latest Cloud Has Silver Lining
DOC.TEXT: Two years ago, Carl Marriott's farm fields were dusty, his soybeans were shriveled, his prospects bleak. This spring, he has a different brown, sickly crop, but there's a different culprit: rain. Yes, rain, the manna from heaven Midwest farmers hoped and prayed for these past few years, has flooded fields, delayed planting and damaged crops. But survivors of one _ or even two _ consecutive droughts aren't complaining. ``We just roll with the punches. We've got options we can pull out of the bag when it's wet,'' said Marriott, a southern Illinois farmer who may lose a quarter of his waterlogged wheat crop. ``When it's dry, there's nothing we can do.'' ``We've been biting our tongues,'' said Mark White, a Chariton, Iowa, farmer whose fields were parched in 1988 and '89, then too muddy to work all last month. ``I'll take a wet year over a dry year anytime. At least you've got a chance to grow something.'' After the most devastating decade in half a century, marred by drought, high interest rates and plummeting land values, many farmers have entered the 1990s with one of the wettest springs in recent times and the brightest outlook in 10 years. ``The farmer is in the best shape he's been since 1980,'' said Gregory Hanson, an economist at the U.S. Agriculture Department. ``We've got rising land values ... rising sales, rising investment. I'm not trying to paint a Pollyanna picture _ on the other hand, there's the famous rubber ball theory of economics: What bounced down is now bouncing up.'' Though an unseasonably cool, wet spring may prevent a bumper crop, the economic forecast is promising: cash income for the farm sector, which includes government subsidies, has been projected at $55 billion to $59 billion for 1990 _ a record if it reaches the outer limit and better than last year's estimated $54 billion. Hog and cattle prices are at or near record levels, corn prices are up because the surplus is down, farm exports have increased, land values are expected to rise about 4 percent in 1990 _ about the same level they did in 1989 _ and machinery sales have jumped by 50 percent in the last four years. ``When I look at the farm economy, I look at a growth sector,'' Hanson said. ``Ten years ago, it was a sector ready to take a fall.'' The national farm debt, which peaked in 1983 at $206 billion, could dip to as low as $145 billion in 1990, he said. Farmers who survived the '80s are smarter and more careful about their purchases, said Neil Harl, an economics professor at Iowa State University. ``Some have been burned, some were singed, some were just close to the heat,'' he said. At the same time, he added, ``Lenders are more cautious and conservative.'' As the new decade begins, some signs of a turnaround are due to the weather, some to a reversal in economic fortunes. For example: _ In Kansas, a record winter wheat crop is forecast for 1990 _ 460.2 million bushels, more than double last year's drought-battered 213.6 million bushels. ``They're laughing,'' Jim Shroyer, extension agronomist at Kansas State University said of the farmers. ``They're really looking forward to harvest. This really lifts their spirits.'' Nationally, winter wheat production is expected to reach a nine-year high of 2 billion bushels, despite some losses from wet weather. _ In Iowa, land values jumped nearly 45 percent from 1986 to 1989, though they're still far below 1981 peak levels. Less than one in five farmers had significant money troubles last year, compared with a third in 1986, Harl said. _ In Minnesota, state officials say soil moisture is the best it has been since November 1986. Despite such optimistic signs, drought persists in areas, including Florida and parts of Colorado. In California, in its fourth straight dry year, reservoirs are low enough that the state and U.S. Bureau of Reclamation cut in half the amount of this year's irrigation water to farmers. And in the upper Midwest, even though puddles in the fields make people smile _ a recent wet spell in North Dakota was dubbed the ``million-dollar'' rain _ they haven't convinced anyone the drought is over. ``By no means are we out of the woods,'' said Tim Edman, special assistant to South Dakota Gov. George Mickelson. ``If we go back to the 90-degree-plus windy, dry weather conditions, we could be facing a problem very quickly just as serious as the last two years.'' In 1988, all of South Dakota was declared a drought disaster area; last year, it was two-thirds of the state. While many cursed the drought, others now say rainy, cool weather is no blessing. In Michigan, for example, some apple growers say it's reduced their crop. In Missouri, a fourth of the corn is in poor or very poor shape, and planting is five weeks behind schedule. And in Illinois, pastures with water belly-high to the livestock and fields too muddy to put a tractor in have farmers worried. ``It's rained so much our wheat is full of blight,'' said Herman Krone, who welcomed then-President Reagan to his shriveled southern Illinois farm fields in 1988. ``Instead of ripening, it's dying in standing water. ... It's been 43 years since I've seen something like this.'' But it's too early to make dire predictions, and dry, sunny days last week allowed many farmers to get back into the fields. Some also say as time runs out to plant corn, they may switch to soybeans, which have a later growing season. That's an option for Marriott, a fourth-generation farmer who normally would have planted all his corn by now but had completed less than 5 percent by the second week of June, a situation to which he's resigned. ``Farming is hills and valleys,'' he said. ``You have good crops some years, and some years, good prices _ seldom together.'' ``It's either feast or famine,'' said Bill Million, agriculture extension adviser in Adams County, in western Illinois. ``Farmers are just taking it one day at a time.'' Not long ago, Million said, they looked to the skies for salvation _ rain. ``Now they're praying for it to stop _ just a bit,'' he said. ``Typical human beings, we're never satisfied.''

DOC.HEAD: Hero's Welcome Planned for Black South African Apartheid Foe
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A hero's welcome awaits Nelson Mandela in the United States, where the black nationalist leader will lobby for continued sanctions against South Africa and millions of dollars in support for the anti-apartheid movement. Since his release Feb. 11 after more than 27 years in prison, Mandela has been cheered at rallies across Africa and Europe. A jubilant reception is expected in the United States for the deputy president of the African National Congress movement, who is especially revered among blacks who waged the civil rights battle of the 1960s. President Bush and Congress will receive Mandela in Washington during his eight-city, 10-day visit, which begins Wednesday in New York and features parades, rallies and a speech at the United Nations. The other cities on his itinerary are Boston, Atlanta, Miami, Detroit, Los Angeles and Oakland, Calif. Mandela's chief mission is to lobby the U.S. government to maintain the limited economic sanctions imposed in 1986 after protests over South African policies of apartheid, or forced segregation. American politicians, movie stars, businessmen and black organizations all are scrambling to share in the glow of his fame _ or at least have their pictures taken with him _ but Mandela has remained modest, and acknowledges debts to U.S. supporters of the anti-apartheid movement. ``The blacks in the United States have been in the front lines of the struggle against apartheid,'' he said recently. ``The (U.S.) government itself would not have taken the steps which they have adopted if there was no pressure from the masses of Americans.'' American public pressure has contributed to the withdrawal of more than half of the 300 U.S. companies that were operating in South Africa since the mid-1980s. Many U.S. universities and municipal governments have withdrawn investments in companies that remain. The release of Mandela, who was imprisoned after being convicted of sabotage and plotting to overthrow the white minority government, came days after President F.W. de Klerk lifted a 30-year ban on the ANC. Now Mandela is hoping to raise millions of dollars to help formally re-establish the ANC presence inside South Africa. The efforts include his public appearances, private fundraising dinners and even the sale of sneakers and T-shirts sporting the ANC colors. Some Western governments have indicated a fresh willingness to reconsider sanctions against South Africa in view of reforms instituted by de Klerk, who brought about Mandela's release. Last month in Brussels, de Klerk urged the 12-nation European Community to end its sanctions because of ``dynamic'' changes, including the prospect of black-white talks on ending policies of racial segregation. South Africa's white minority rule governs 5 million whites, 28 million blacks and about 3 million people of mixed race. Apartheid establishes a racially segregated society in which blacks have no vote in national affairs. The de Klerk administration has met some, but not all, of the conditions set by Congress for lifting limited sanctions it imposed in 1986, overriding a veto by then-President Reagan. ``The United States is the only country which has incorporated a measure in its legislation making it an offense to trade (some items) with South Africa,'' Mandela said. ``I will applaud the United States for this.'' But ties between the ANC and the U.S. government are relatively new. The ANC, with offices in more than 30 countries worldwide, only last year established a Washington office. In 1988, the Defense Department listed the ANC as a ``terrorist'' organization. The State Department disagreed publicly with the description, but has urged the ANC to abandon its largely ineffective guerrilla campaign. There have been other obstacles. Reagan's opposition to sanctions and his ``constructive engagement'' policy, which stressed the maintenance of working ties with the white-led government, drew harsh criticism from the ANC throughout the 1980s. At anti-apartheid rallies, blacks often denounced Reagan in the same breath with former South African President P.W. Botha. About half the ANC leadership, though not Mandela, also are members of the South African Communist Party. The ANC's guerrilla campaign has been backed by the Soviet Union, although military aid is declining. In Angola, ANC guerrillas have fought alongside Marxist government troops battling the U.S.-backed UNITA rebels. Since his release, Mandela has praised Cuba's Fidel Castro, embraced Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat and visited Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi, the man for whom one of Mandela's grandsons is named. Yet Mandela has proven skilled enough as a politician to win the endorsement of U.S. Jewish groups despite his support for Arafat. Abraham Foxman of the U.S. Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith said after meeting Mandela in June that ``no Jewish organization should have reservations'' about the Mandela visit. He added: ``I will probably raise my voice and proclaim he is a friend.'' Mandela will spend time with two of his daughters studying in Massachusetts. Zenani Dhlamini, a student at Boston University, is the daughter of Mandela and his current wife, Winnie. Mandela's daughter by his first wife, Makaziwe Mandela-Amuah, studies at Amherst College. Skeptics say Americans are fixated on Mandela the legend rather than the man. ``What people want is a saint, a sort of moral celebrity,'' wrote Simon Barber, Washington correspondent for the South African financial paper Business Day. At home, Mandela faces critics ranging from right-wing whites who call him a terrorist to militant blacks who accuse the ANC of ``selling out'' by pursuing negotiations with de Klerk's government. Any criticism in the United States is likely to be tame by comparison. ``Woe betide the policymaker, politician, scholar or journalist who evinces the slightest skepticism,'' Barber wrote. ``This is particularly true in the U.S., where the civil rights movement has adopted Mandela as a sort of Martin Luther King reborn.''

DOC.HEAD: Fiery Mrs. Mandela Now Smiles Silently at Her Husband's Side
With BC-Mandela-US
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela is taking center stage during his lobbying mission for black nationalism in South Africa, but controversy still swirls around his wife. Winnie Mandela will accompany her husband on his eight-city, 10-day tour of the United States, which starts Wednesday in New York. The woman who once shouted down police and was accused of beating men with whips, has been standing demurely by his side during the couple's tours of Africa and Europe. A year ago, some of South Africa's most prominent anti-apartheid leaders denounced Mrs. Mandela, accusing her of ``violating human rights in the name of the struggle against apartheid.'' The South African attorney-general is considering whether to prosecute Mrs. Mandela in connection with a case of kidnapping and assault in which one of the victims later was found dead. Her former chief bodyguard, Jerry Richardson, has been convicted of kidnapping, assault, and murder in connection with the stabbing death of a 14-year-old black activist, James ``Stompie'' Moeketsi Seipei. He was abducted Dec. 29, 1988, and his body recovered eight days later. Three black men testified at Richardson's trial that they and the teen-ager were abducted, taken to Mrs. Mandela's home and beaten by Mrs. Mandela, who then let her bodyguards continue the assaults. The judge ruled their testimony had ``the ring of truth.'' The trial of Mrs. Mandela's former driver and seven others who stayed at her house originally was scheduled for May 29, but has been postponed until September, said Klaus von Lieres und Wilkau, attorney-general for the Johannesburg region. He said his office ``has reserved a decision on whether to prosecute (Mrs. Mandela) or not. At this stage, we have not taken a decision.'' Mrs. Mandela has been the focus of controversy, or at least attention, many times before. She was under police restrictions almost continuously from 1963 to 1986, was arrested numerous times and held in solitary confinement for 17 months in 1969-70. During nationwide unrest from 1984-87, she appeared at the funerals of slain activists and gave militant speeches, urging blacks to harbor guerrilla fighters and take the ``armed struggle'' to white neighborhoods. Without explaining why, the government lifted her restrictions on movement and speech in 1986, shortly after she told a rally: ``With our boxes of matches and our necklaces, we shall liberate this country.'' It was an endorsement of the gruesome ``necklace'' killings in which militants set burning, gasoline-soaked tires around the necks of black political opponents, policemen and their families. The African National Congress in exile disavowed the statement by the wife of its effective leader. Some say Mrs. Mandela was not equipped for the public position thrust upon her as the spokesman for her imprisoned husband and his outlawed movement. She married Mandela in 1958, when she was a 24-year-old social worker and he was a 40-year-old ANC leader. Four years later, he was arrested. Mandela once wrote from prison that he wondered ``whether any kind of commitment can ever be sufficient excuse for abandoning a young and inexperienced woman in a pitiless desert.'' When her husband was freed and came home to Soweto, Mrs. Mandela, a 56-year-old grandmother, said she was glad to become a housewife, a job she had never had a chance to do. ``I've been giving orders, and now I have to take them,'' she said.
