DOC.HEAD: With BC-Mandela-US
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts about Nelson Mandela: NAME: Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela. AGE: 71. BORN: July 18, 1918, in Transkei, the son of a Xhosa tribal chief. TITLE: Deputy President of the African National Congress. ARRESTED: August 5, 1962. SENTENCED: November 1962 to five years hard labor for leaving the country illegally and inciting blacks to violate the law by striking. Sentenced in June 1964 to life imprisonment for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the government. IMPRISONED: 27 years. RELEASED: February 11, 1990. CURRENT POLITICAL OBJECTIVE: Mandela says dialogue between the South African government and the ANC is the only way to a peaceful future. He wants the government to free all prisoners convicted of politically motivated crimes, stop police from firing on black protesters, and end the state of emergency in the Natal province, where ANC supporters are battling members of the rival Inkatha organization. When those conditions are met, he says, the ANC and the government can enter into negotiations, apparently including other political organizations, to develop a new non-racial, democratic constitution based on a one-person, one-vote system. CURRENT TOUR: Mandela is in the midst of a six-week tour of Africa, Europe and North America to thank the world for pressuring the South African government to remove the ban on the ANC and free him and his colleagues. He also is urging that economic, cultural, diplomatic and sports sanctions be maintained against South Africa until apartheid is completely abolished.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, June 17

DOC.TEXT: New York Stock Exchange Chairman John J. Phelan Jr. unveiled a five-step plan to trade securities after daytime hours with the goal of round-the-clock trading by the year 2000. The scheme proposes two brief sessions after the market's close initially, then moving to a stock auction three times a night, some form of conventional trading overnight and finally 24-hour dealing. ``We want to do it, but not if it becomes too expensive,'' Phelan told a news conference Thursday in Nashville, Tenn., after meeting with officials from regional brokerage J.C. Bradford & Co.

A monthly drop in energy prices helped offset higher food costs in May and held overall wholesale prices to a moderate 0.3 percent increase, the government said. Analysts said the soft increase in the producer price index, released Thursday, was encouraging news on the inflation front, especially after a severe cold spell drove up prices last winter.

Domestic advertising spending is expected to increase 7.5 percent to $140 billion in 1991 following disappointing growth this year, according to a prominent forecaster. Robert J. Coen, who heads the forecasting unit at the advertising agency McCann-Erickson, said Thursday he reduced his earlier projection of a 6.2 percent gain this year to a more modest 5.3 percent, which would put spending at $130.4 billion.

Members of Congress have attacked the administration's request for more money to rescue savings and loans, accusing the White House of delays in prosecuting a growing backlog of fraud cases. The criticism greeted Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady Thursday after he warned the House Banking Committee that the thrift cleanup likely would run out of money before the end of the year.

Donald Dixon, former head of Vernon Savings and Loan Association, has surrendered to the FBI to face 38 counts that include conspiracy, fraud and furthering racketeering. Dixon surrendered Thursday, one day after he was indicted by a federal grand jury on charges that he used thousands of dollars from Vernon Savings on pleasure trips, prostitutes and illegal contributions to politicians. Prosecutors say he and his thrift exemplified the abuses that led S&Ls into disaster.

The Bush administration is insisting that Japan honor commitments to open its markets to American and other foreign goods. U.S. negotiators have grown concerned over what they perceive as Japanese foot-dragging in recent trade talks, which are aimed at reducing the United States' $49 billion trade deficit with Japan. Critics say Japan's intransigence is directly linked to the Bush administration's decision to lessen the threat of economic sanctions against Japan by removing the country from a section of trade law known as Super 301.

The Soviet legislature has ordered a two-month delay in an unpopular threefold increase in bread prices, a centerpiece of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's market reforms. The Supreme Soviet voted overwhelmingly Thursday to have the government produce another version of the plan in September, easing the effect of price increases. Bread prices, the staple of the Soviet diet, would have risen July 1. The increase was part of an economic program that touched off panic buying in Moscow.

The debt-ridden owner of 7,000 7-Eleven convenience stores has sweetened a deal to pay off its bondholders. Southland Corp. also said Thursday it would not pay $69 million in interest due on two bond issues Friday, a move that an analyst said opens up the possibility of an involuntary bankruptcy petition being filed. Southland, suffering disappointing sales and earnings growth, has been strained by debt associated with its $4.9 billion leveraged buyout in 1987, which gave control of the chain to Dallas' Thompson family.

The company that makes Mazola Corn Oil has agreed to stop using advertisements that imply the product alone can reduce cholesterol, officials say. The agreement announced Thursday between CPC International Inc. and the Federal Trade Commission came after attorneys general in 10 states questioned the advertised claims.

The stock market was down slightly Thursday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which slipped 3.72 points Wednesday, lost another 1.48 to close at 2,928.22. Bond prices seesawed on conflicting economic signals but finished substantially higher. Gold fell sharply while the dollar finished mostly higher. Gold futures prices fell below $350 an ounce for the first time in nearly four years. Prices of silver, soybeans, livestock and meat futures also fell; crude oil futures fell but other energy futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: NYSE Unveils Plan for 24-Hour Trading
LaserPhoto NS4 of June 14
DOC.TEXT: After 198 years of trading stocks only during the daytime, the New York Stock Exchange plans to phase in a 24-hour market by the end of the decade to meet increasing competition from overseas. Big Board chairman John J. Phelan Jr. on Thursday unveiled a five-step plan expected to begin later this year that would allow access to the nation's largest exchange after the current 4 p.m. Eastern time close. ``There is some volume going overseas, and we'd like to capture some of that volume back,'' Phelan said in Nashville, Tenn., where he was meeting with officials from a regional brokerage. Round-the-clock trading is already a reality in the foreign currency and U.S. Treasury bond market, where dealers conduct transactions via telephone and computer links. But the concept has stirred controversy at the stock exchange because it could lead to replacing the powerful ``specialists,'' who today regulate the flow of trading, with computers. ``It's an incredible surprise,'' one veteran specialist who asked not to be named said. ``The incredible thing is that the floor hasn't lynched anyone yet.'' Nevertheless, the exchange has been pressured by new technology and competing markets that allow traders to buy and sell Big Board-listed stocks domestically and abroad when the NYSE is closed. The London exchange, which eliminated its specialists and trading floor when it went electronic four years ago, and the Tokyo market have siphoned the most business. The steps outlined by Phelan would begin with two brief sessions after the market's normal close. Subsequent phases would involve stock auctions held several times a night, some form of conventional trading overnight and finally 24-hour dealing. Market experts said that by phasing in the plan, the NYSE could stimulate after-hours interest. The exchange could determine, for instance, whether the floor should stay open round-the-clock or whether after-hours trading be strictly electronic. ``The limiting factor here is the demand, it's not the technology,'' said Eric K. Clemons, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School. ``What if you had a 24-hour market and nobody came?'' ``What the NYSE wants to do is make sure institutions feel they have no choice, that if they want to trade a (major U.S.) stock, the only place to trade is New York,'' he said. Exchange officials said they planned to implement the first two phases of the plan by the end of the year, assuming member firms agree. This level would involve sessions that could last one to two hours and handle activity mainly related to program trading. In the third phase, expected to begin in 1991, the exchange would hold auctions of each listed stock at 8 p.m., midnight, and 5 a.m. Eastern time. Each stock would trade once at each auction with trades combined at a single price. More than 1,700 stocks are listed on the exchange and all could be included in the auctions. Phelan said the fourth phase would involve ``some sort of rudimentary trading during the night.'' It could begin by 1992. The final step _ non-stop, round-the-clock trading _ is five to 10 years off, exchange officials said. ``I'm not skeptical about it long term. But I think short term there is a serious question whether there is a lot out there, and that's (what) we're proposing to do with steps,'' Phelan said. Current trading hours are 9:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. Eastern time. Trading ran from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. on weekdays and 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays from 1873 until 1952, when weekend trading was abolished and weekday activity extended until 3:30 p.m. An extra half hour was added in 1974 and 1985. Market players estimate the NYSE has lost 10 million to 20 million shares a day of trading to foreign markets, where many U.S. companies now list their securities. Also, other domestic markets that offer after-hours trading via computer pose a threat. Big Board volume has slumped since the stock market crashed in 1987 and has averaged about 156 million shares daily this year. Several Wall Street professionals questioned whether there is enough demand to sustain after-hours trading. They said an attempt merely to regain volume lost to London might fail because certain trades there can be conducted with less public scrutiny. Others said after-hours trading could grow once a system is in place. ``The very fact that it's available might encourage more and other types of activities,'' said Jack A. Conlon Jr., managing director in charge of equities for Rothschild Inc.

DOC.HEAD: West German Settles Insider Trading Charges With SEC
DOC.TEXT: A West German computer executive has agreed to settle U.S. civil charges of using inside information to avoid a $2,000 stock loss. The executive lives in Germany but worked for an American company and was charged with illegal insider trading in the company's shares. Without admitting or denying wrongdoing, Wolfgang Marcour, of Wiesbaden, West Germany, settled a civil complaint filed Thursday by the Securities and Exchange Commission at federal court in Washington. It was the second small insider trading case the SEC brought this week against foreign nationals. On Monday, a New York banker and his bond-trader wife, both Japanese nationals, agreed to pay $99,000 in penalties and restitution to settle unrelated insider trader charges. Unlike Marcour, they both lived in this country. Marcour, 47, agreed to pay the U.S. government $2,062 in trading losses he avoided, as well as $358 in interest. Marcour's West German lawyer, Michael Siebold, was traveling and could not be reached for comment, SEC officials said. According to the SEC complaint, Marcour, who lives and works in West Germany, sold 500 shares of Apollo Computer Inc. stock in July 1988 _ allegedly with knowledge that Apollo's sales for that quarter ``would be significantly lower than expected.'' At the time, Marcour was an international sales manager at Apollo's wholly owned European subsidiary, Apollo Domain Computer GmbH, and handled the account of Siemens AG, a major West German electronics company. Harry J. Weiss, an associate director of the SEC's Enforcement Division, said Marcour was subject to U.S. securities laws because ``an employee of an American public company who happens to be based in a foreign country is under the same legal duties to his employer as an American-based employee of the same company.'' Apollo Computer, based in Chelmsford, Mass., was acquired by electronics giant Hewlett-Packard Co. in May 1989. Weiss would not comment on how the SEC obtained information about Marcour. The United States does not have a formal cooperation agreement on securities law violations with West Germany. He said that even sales managers could be subject to insider trading sanctions if ``they are able to observe information that is material but non-public, not available to the public, and then trade on it for their own benefit.''

DOC.HEAD: S&P Lowers Chrysler, Ford Ratings; Affirms GM
DOC.TEXT: In a reflection of the pressures facing U.S. automakers, a leading rating agency has lowered its credit rankings for Chrysler Corp. and Ford Motor Co. Standard & Poor's Corp. said Thursday it was downgrading the outstanding debt of the nation's No. 2 and No. 3 automakers by one notch. The action was particularly troublesome for Chrysler because it left the struggling company with S&P's lowest investment grade rating. S&P said the nation's Big Three automakers were faced with severe problems in a sagging market and slumping economy. It left General Motors Corp.'s rating unchanged, however, saying GM was better positioned to withstand the pressure. The move came one day after Moody's Investor Services Inc., another major rating agency, said it was reviewing Chrysler's credit and would decide by the end of the month whether to downgrade the company. Chrysler's stock fell 25 cents a share to $15.62{ on the New York Stock Exchange Thursday. Ford was unchanged at $46.37{ and GM fell 37{ cents to $49.62{. ``Chrysler has derived the bulk of earnings in recent years from such niche products as the minivan and sport-utility vehicles,'' said S&P Vice President Scott Sprinzen, ``and pressure from competing product offerings is mounting.'' Recently, Ford and GM began selling four-door sport-utility vehicles that compete directly with Chrysler's Jeeps. Sprinzen said Ford was raising its capital spending, which will force it to delay reducing the huge debt amassed in the recent acquisitions of The Associates Corp., a financial organization, and British automaker Jaguar PLC. Those two purchases cost Ford nearly $6 billion. S&P dropped Ford one notch to double-A-minus from double-A. The new rating still is one of the agency's higher investment grades. Chrysler was dropped one notch from triple-B to triple-B-minus, S&P's lowest investment-grade level. Anything lower and Chrysler's debt would be considered to be junk bonds. Chrysler spokesman Tom Houston said the downgrade was unwarranted. ``Moreover, Chrysler also notes that just recently the market readily accepted the landmark offering of $1.1 billion 30-year Auburn Hills Trust certificates, thereby expressing high confidence in the company over a very long term,'' Houston said. In April, Chrysler announced it would sell its yet-to-be-completed technical center in Auburn Hills, north of Detroit, through 30-year certificates and then lease it back. The deal was expected to raise nearly $800 million. Chrysler's first quarter profits fell 80 percent to $71 million. Sales of its North American-made cars and trucks were down 13 percent this year as of June 10. The company's share of the U.S. car market has slipped to 11.4 percent from 13.1 percent a year ago; its portion of the truck market dropped to 21.8 percent from 23.2 percent last year. Spokesman Tom Foote said Ford was disappointed with S&P's decision. The company's balance sheet is strong ``and we expect our investments to lead to further strengthening of our financial situation,'' he said. Ford reported first quarter earnings of $506.2 million, down 70 percent from a year ago. Its sales of cars and trucks were down 8.8 percent through June 10. The company's share of the U.S. car market stood at 27.9 percent, down from 30.2 percent last year; its truck share slipped to 34.2 percent from 34.4 percent. Sprinzen said even though GM faced increased competition and the possibility of lower profit margins, it was in a better position than Ford or Chrysler. ``These problems have not reached the extent, relative to GM's current ratings, that a reassessment of its credit quality is warranted,'' he said. Recently, auto analyst Ronald Glantz of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in San Francisco recommended that Ford and Chrysler investors switch to GM because GM was more likely to raise its stock dividend next year. GM's first quarter earnings fell 54.3 percent to $710 million. Its combined car and truck sales through June 10 were off 4.8 percent from last year. Its share of the car market slipped nearly 1 percentage point to 46.1 percent; in trucks, it gained to 40.5 percent from 39.3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Southland Announces Restructuring, Missed Bond Payment
DOC.TEXT: The head of the bondholders' committee for debt-ridden Southland Corp. remains optimistic that the company can get back on its feet with a new, sweetened restructuring plan. One of the company's bondholders scoffed at the new plan and said he would reject the offer. Southland, owner of 7,000 7-Eleven convenience stores, on Thursday enhanced its debt swap proposal to bondholders. The new plan would slash the amount of control the founding Thompson family will have. The company also said it would not pay $69 million in interest due on two bond issues today, which opens up the possibility of an involuntary bankruptcy petition being filed against Southland. The bondholder proposal, which Southland called the second phase in its attempt to climb out from under $1.8 billion in debt, would cut the stake that the Thompson family and other existing shareholders will have to 6.5 percent, compared with 15 percent in an earlier proposal. The company is offering bondholders $550 million in exchange for $1.76 billion in outstanding securities. In addition, bondholders and preferred stockholders would share 18.5 percent of the company's common stock. The new offer would give bondholders about $200 million more than an earlier plan. The first phase of the restructuring, announced in March, called for Southland's Japanese partners, Ito-Yokado Co. Ltd. and Seven-Eleven Japan Co. Ltd., to pay $400 million cash for 75 percent of the company. But the Japanese investors agreed to hold off consummating that deal until August 15 pending a debt restructuring. ``Assuming an agreement can be reached over the next couple of days, the hope is that a specific proposal would be filed with the SEC (Securities and Exchange Commission) by about the middle of next week,'' said John Gordon, president of Deltec Securities Corp. of New York and head of a bondholders committee that worked out the agreement with Southland management and others. Gordon said he was ``enthusiastic'' about the negotiations and said it provided an opportunity for Southland to ``really get back on its feet.'' Suffering disappointing sales and earnings growth, Southland has been strained by debt associated with its $4.9 billion leveraged buyout in 1987, which gave Dallas' Thompson family control of the chain. The company lost $69.4 million in the first quarter. It completed the sale of its Citgo subsidiary in January to raise $661.5 million in cash. The initial $350 million bond buyout offer was made shortly after that sale. Gordon called the initial offer ``totally unacceptable,'' but said he was impressed with the negotiations this week that led to the improved offer. At least one other bondholder was not as enthusiastic. ``It's incredible the size of the pill that they're asking bondholders to swallow,'' said Jay H. Lustig, head of the high yield department for Drake Capital Securities Inc. of Santa Monica, Calif. ``They're asking bondholders to forgive $1.2 billion in debt in exchange for 18 percent of the company. They have absolutely zero shot of getting 100 percent acceptance,'' he said. A missed interest payment Friday raises the possibility that Southland could be forced into involuntary bankruptcy if a payment or agreement is not worked out in 30 days, Lustig said. Gordon said he was optimistic the parties would reach an agreement that would avoid such a move. Lustig was not. ``I know one bond holder who's not tendering the bonds,'' he said. ``You're talking to him.''

DOC.HEAD: Four Arrested for Alleged Tax Evasion in Hostile Takeover Case
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors have arrested four men accused of evading taxes on profits made on the stock of the company that was the target of the first hostile takeover in Japan's corporate history. The four apparently profited from inside information on the takeover attempt, prosecutors said. But because the transactions occurred before Japan tightened insider trading regulations in April 1988, they were arrested only on suspicion of tax evasion, the prosecutors said Thursday. The four were arrested last Wednesday and prosecutors searched their homes and offices Thursday. The Tokyo District Public Prosecutor's Office said the four allegedly concealed income totaling the equivalent of $10.1 million from stock transactions in 1987 in shares of Kokusai Kogyo, a Tokyo-based aerial surveying firm. Kokusai Kogyo was taken over in December 1987 by the Koshin Co., known for its stock speculation activities. When the takeover attempt began in May 1987, Kokusai Kogyo shares were trading at about 2,000 yen, or $13. In an effort to maintain control, Kokusai Kogyo began buying back shares. By October 1987, the price had soared to 7,000 yen, or $45.60. Prosecutors identified those arrested as Norio Ishibashi, 49, Hiromitsu Hamaguchi, 50, and Yoshinori Wakisaka, 47, all former officials of Kokusai Kogyo. Also arrested was Eiji Sakai, 53, a financial firm president. Prosecutors also said they were searching for Jiro Tomishima, 39, president of a subsidiary of Kokusai Kogyo, on suspicion of tax evasion. A senior official at the prosecutor's office, speaking on condition of anonymity, said, ``We are certain that he is out of country, but we cannot say at this point whether we have sent our investigators overseas nor have we requested cooperation from foreign investigatory agencies.'' Ishibashi, who was in control of Kokusai Kogyo's accounting, bought more than 500,000 shares for himself during the takeover battle and netted a profit of about $3.97 million, prosecutors said. They said the other three arrested men earned profits ranging from $1.69 million to $2.08 million. The four used dummy accounts to dodge taxation, prosecutors added.

DOC.HEAD: Students, Teachers Get Free Stock to Allow Company to Join NYSE
DOC.TEXT: It may have appeared to be another marketing come-on, but a stock giveaway was big business for Kent Electronics Corp. Kent mailed free stock certificates to 1,518 graduate students and faculty members at the University of Houston's College of Business Administration in an effort to get its shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange. ``I thought it was like the promise of receiving a free gift for attending a time-share vacation resort,'' said Dale Rude, associate professor of management. ``I read it and was amused and put it aside,'' said doctoral student John Michael Bryant, who said he expected a follow-up sales pitch. ``I'm studying for a degree in marketing so I read all my junk mail, seeing what the trends are.'' The shares, which closed at $11.50 on the American Stock Exchange Thursday, were given away to satisfy a requirement for listing on the Big Board, said Morrie Abramson, chairman of the electronics products distributing company in Houston. Kent, a 17-year-old company with annual revenues of about $40 million, met all but one of the standards for listing _ the one requiring at least 2,200 shareholders. Kent had only 1,200. So the company bought 1,518 shares of its stock on the open market for more than $17,000. Using a mailing list supplied by the university, Kent sent a certificate for one share to each graduate student and faculty member in the business school. And it worked. The company expects to begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange July 6. ``There was nothing, in our judgment, that was very creative about it,'' Abramson said. He figures it was an appropriate way to show his appreciation. In 1956, he graduated from the University of Houston with a bachelor's degree in business administration. He now serves on the Dean's Executive Advisory Board, a group of about 50 Houston business leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Program Launched for Environmental Acceptability
DOC.TEXT: Consumers who are worried about the ozone or overcrowded landfills will soon be able to look for a new environmental seal of approval when deciding what to buy in the supermarket. An independent, non-profit organization called Green Seal will test products for their ``cradle-to-grave'' impact on the environment and award seals _ a bold green check arched over a blue globe _ to those that meet its standards. ``We're trying to harness the most powerful forces we have available in the United States, the forces of the marketplace, to try to achieve environmental goals,'' Denis Hayes, chairman of Earth Day 1990 and chairman and chief executive officer of Green Seal, said Thursday. At a news conference at the New York Academy of Sciences, he said Green Seal will start early next year by awarding seals in five product categories: light bulbs, laundry cleaners, house paint, toilet paper and facial tissue. These products were selected because they are used in almost every household in the country and some are clearly friendlier to the environment than others, said Norman Dean, the program's executive director. Hayes said Green Seal will not issue seals for food. In April, the American Heart Association yanked its seal of approval program for foods low in sodium, cholesterol and saturated fats after the federal Food and Drug Administration said it would not support the program. The FDA said what goes on food labels is a government responsibility. Green Seal Inc. was founded last year by Rena M. Shulsky, a partner in a Manhattan real estate firm and president of a Boston-based media consulting firm. She said she came up with the idea while standing in a grocery store aisle, wondering which laundry detergent would be friendlier to the environment. ``I thought, `Why doesn't someone put a seal on these things? A little seal of approval would help me get out of the supermarket a lot quicker.' '' Green Seal's first task will be to determine the standards by which the products will be judged, said Dean. In doing so, it will examine the full life cycle of each product category _ from raw material to when the consumer recycles it or throws it into the garbage. The organization intends to solicit advice from manufacturers of the products, public interest organizations, trade associations and government officials in establishing its criteria for awarding seals. Once the standards are set, companies _ at their own cost _ may submit their products for testing by independent laboratories selected by Green Seal. Products that get the Green Seal check of approval will be licensed to use the seal logo in their advertising for a three-year period. The licensing fees will be structured on a sliding scale to prevent hardship for smaller companies. According to a poll conducted by Research & Forecasts Inc. for Green Seal, 79 percent of those surveyed said they would be more likely to purchase a product with the Green Seal, if choosing between two products of the same price and equal quality. Green Seal is not the first seal-of-approval program for environmentally preferable products. West Germany has had a program for 10 years, Canada for three years and Japan for a couple of years, Hayes said. Also, Green Cross Certification Co., based in Oakland, Calif., launched an environmental certification program for products in April with three West Coast grocery chains and one in Phoenix. Three food chains in the northeast and Canada will join the program in July, said Stan Rhodes, president of Green Cross.

DOC.HEAD: Koito's Labor Union Denounces Pickens
DOC.TEXT: The Koito Manufacturing Co. labor union on Friday denounced an attempt by Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens to get a seat on the company's board of directors. It was the first time the union had publicly denounced Pickens, who controls the largest equity stake in Koito, and several proposals he intends to submit to a shareholders meeting later this month. ``The union is against the proposals because they ignore the company's responsibility to take care of its employees,'' union Chairman Hideki Yoshioka said in a statement. Koito's labor union resolved Thursday that it is against all seven of Pickens' proposals, which will be voted on at the company's June 28 shareholders' meeting, ``because they would destabilize Koito employees' living conditions if they are approved,'' said the union chief. Among the proposals are a demand that four Americans, including Pickens, be appointed to Koito's board of directors. They also call for publication of the company's pricing policies, according to Kanji Ishizumi, Pickens' lawyer. Last week, Pickens mailed letters and videos to about 4,100 Koito shareholders, asking for stockholder proxies for the vote on his proposals. Yoshioka called Pickens' proposals ``greenmail,'' or buying up a company's shares in an attempt to force it or a friendly affiliate to buy them back at a higher price to regain control. He said the union wants board members from Koito, who are familiar with the company operation and will be understood by employees. According to Koito spokesman Mikio Tsuruta, Koito shareholders have recently received some harassing newsletters from ``a group that seems to have links with the underworld, although we're not certain if Pickens is involved.'' Sokaiya, or professional racketeers, use their legal right as shareholders to attend general shareholders meetings, where they threaten to embarrass the company if they are not paid off beforehand. Of the more than 4,000 shareholders, only about 100 normally attend shareholders' meetings, with many of the rest sending proxies, Tsuruta said. Since his Boone Co., a U.S. investment firm, obtained the largest equity stake in Koito last year, Pickens has been fighting unsuccessfully against Koito management in an attempt to gain a seat on the board of directors. Pickens has said his battle with Koito illustrates how investment opportunities are closed to foreigners in Japan, but the company says it is concerned about Pickens' true intentions.

DOC.HEAD: Honeywell Seeks Import Ban on Some Minolta Cameras
DOC.TEXT: Honeywell Inc. has asked the government to ban imports of autofocus cameras made by Minolta Camera Co. Ltd. of Japan, alleging that the cameras infringe on four Honeywell patents. A lawsuit filed by Honeywell against Minolta in 1987 is still about two years from trial, Honeywell officials said Thursday. In hopes of getting relief more quickly, Honeywell asked the International Trade Commission to act, Christopher J. Steffen, Honeywell's chief financial officer, told a news conference in Washington, D.C. ``Today, with its extremely popular Maxxum camera, Minolta enjoys annual worldwide sales of $1 billion on its camera products while Honeywell is denied millions of dollars in royalties as our lawsuit moves very slowly through the courts,'' Steffen said. In addition to the Maxxum, Minolta's Af-Tele and Freedom Dual models would be affected. The Minneapolis-based international controls company asked the ITC to step in under a 1988 amendment of the Tariff Act of 1930. The law makes it illegal for overseas companies to engage in unfair methods of competition, including infringing on U.S. patents, when importing or selling products in the United States. The 1987 lawsuit, filed in federal court in New Jersey on a change of venue from Minnesota, says Minolta used four Honeywell patents in Minolta cameras, including the SLR Maxxum. Honeywell also contends that Minolta breached a 1979 contract calling for Honeywell to share patented technology and trade secrets. Minolta was restricted to using only Honeywell-manufactured autofocus modules under the contract, Honeywell said. Instead, Honeywell alleges, Minolta used Honeywell autofocus technology while developing a module of its own. Minolta said Thursday that Honeywell's patent claims are ``invalid and unenforceable.'' In a statement issued through its New Jersey office, Minolta also said that federal court was the ``proper forum for this dispute'' and it called the original allegations ``baseless.'' Minolta also said Honeywell's petition violates a 1988 agreement by both parties that federal court in New Jersey would be the exclusive forum for resolving the dispute. ``We today asked the federal court to uphold this agreement and order Honeywell to withdraw its complaint,'' Minolta said. Honeywell, however, said Minolta's allegations are unfounded. Honeywell said the 1988 agreement was meant to discourage multiple court filings and not to affect an administrative action such as an ITC filing. The trade agency has 30 days to decide whether it will review the case, said Honeywell spokeswoman Susan Eich. If it does, a decision could come within a year, she said. Ed Carroll, an ITC spokesman, said that if the ITC agrees to investigate, the case would be heard by an administrative law judge, who would make an initial determination to the commission. The commission then would decide whether to accept the judge's determination. If it does, that decision would go to President Bush. The president has 60 days to ``do something with it. If he does nothing at all, the commission decision stands'' and would automatically go into effect, Carroll said.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Investigating Airline Activities in Pittsburgh
DOC.TEXT: USAir operations at Greater Pittsburgh International Airport are under federal scrutiny for possible antitrust violations, according to the airline's parent company. The U.S. Justice Department ordered USAir Group Inc. to turn over documents and other information relating to USAir activities at the airport, where it is the largest tenant. The request came May 31 in an action known as a civil investigative demand, USAir said. The existence of the probe was disclosed by USAir in connection with the issuance of $84.6 million in revenue bonds for the construction of a new terminal being built at the airport. USAir said it was informed by the Justice Department that other airlines and other airports are being investigated. The names of the other carriers and airports were not disclosed. Justice Department spokesman Frank Kelly declined to comment on the nature of the investigation. He said a civil investigative demand is equivalent to a subpoena but does not mean a civil or criminal action has been undertaken. USAir spokesman John Bronson said the airline would comply with the Justice Department's request and was gathering all relevant documents. He said he did not know the exact nature of the Justice Department inquiry. The solicitor for Allegheny County, which has a business relationship with USAir relating to the new terminal, said the request for information appears to be part of a broader probe. The investigation likely involves fares charged by airlines at hub airports, said Ira Weiss. A report issued last year by the federal General Accounting Office found that fares charged at 15 hub airports were about one-fourth higher than fares charged at 38 other airports served by a larger number of carriers. The study found that fares charged at Pittsburgh were as much as 8 cents per mile more than fares at the 38 airports. Weiss said one aspect of the USAir probe involves its dealings with the county. The airline and the county negotiated a long-term lease two years ago for the construction of the new $592 million terminal. ``Any time you have the Justice Department conducting an inquiry of this nature, it's a cause for alarm,'' Weiss said. ``There's no reason to believe there's anything inappropriate about USAir's role at the existing terminal or at the new midfield terminal, and we're confident at the conclusion of this proceeding that things will proceed as they are,'' he added. According to the bond statement, the Justice Department is examining possible violations of the Sherman Act by ``conduct, activities or proposed action relating to restrictions on facilities at the airport.'' The Sherman Act makes it illegal for companies to restrain trade in the United States or with foreign countries or to conspire to do so. It also prohibits monopolizing trade or commerce in the United States or with foreign countries or attempting or conspiring to do so. Weiss said he thought the investigation arose out of USAir's large share of traffic at the Pittsburgh airport. In 1987, the Justice Department opposed the merger of USAir and Piedmont airlines, but dropped its objections after determining the consolidation would not hurt competition.

DOC.HEAD: CFTC Commissioner Unfazed By Criticism of Dual-Trading Plan
DOC.TEXT: Commodity Futures Trading Commissioner Fowler West was unfazed by a pair of studies concluding the CFTC's proposed curbs on dual trading are based on flawed research methods and insufficient data. ``You could probably go on and on and on and on and find academics who would quarrel with certain conclusions and methods,'' West said Thursday after the studies' authors presented their findings to the CFTC staff in Washington. ``Their objections seem to me to be highly technical in nature,'' West said in a telephone interview from his Washington office. The studies by researchers at the University of California at Berkeley and Duke University were funded by the nation's eight major commodity exchanges, whose leaders are fighting the CFTC plan. The findings may provide the exchanges with more ammunition with which to defend dual trading, the controversial but legal practice among floor brokers of trading for their customers' accounts and their own at the same time. West said the objections would be considered along with other public comments the CFTC has gathered since announcing its proposal in January. The public comment period ends July 9. Critics contend dual trading provides opportunities for brokers to cheat their clients. But exchange leaders say the practice increases market liquidity and cost efficiency. A study of dual trading conducted last year by the CFTC disputed the purported economic benefits of dual trading. The CFTC in January proposed a test ban on dual trading in certain markets, a move the exchanges viewed as the first step toward outlawing the practice. The exchange-sponsored studies examined the process that led to the CFTC proposal and found it flawed. The Duke researchers' complaints included accusations of measurement errors and inconsistencies in the CFTC study. The Berkeley analysis said the CFTC failed to weigh dual trading's benefits against the costs and ignored its functional effects on markets. ``These deficiencies undermine the study's conclusions as well as its use as a basis for dual-trading curbs,'' the researchers said. Their conclusions were in a statement issued jointly by the Chicago Board of Trade, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and six other major U.S. commodity exchanges. The Chicago Mercantile Exchange has proposed its own, less-severe curbs on dual trading as an alternative to the CFTC plan. Spokesman Andrew Yemma said he saw no conflict between the Merc's proposed dual-trading restrictions and its support for the two university studies.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Shrank in April
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds last 8 grafs. This moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. trade deficit shrank dramatically to $6.94 billion in April, the second lowest level in the past six years, the government reported today. The Commerce Department said the 17 percent improvement from a March deficit of $8.36 billion came entirely from a big drop in imports, which offset a smaller decline in U.S. export sales. Imports totaled $39.25 billion in April, 6.2 percent lower than March, with the decline attributed primarily to lower demand for foreign oil and a big drop in auto imports. Exports fell by 3.5 percent to $32.3 billion. But this was considered only a small drop off an all-time high of $33.5 billion set in March. America's trade performance has been a pleasant surprise so far this year, with the deficit showing a much larger improvement than many analysts thought possible. Through the first four months, the deficit has been running at an annual rate of $92.16 billion, compared to a deficit for all of 1989 of $108.99 billion. Many analysts are now forecasting that the 1990 deficit will drop below $100 billion for the first time since 1983 as export growth remains strong enough to offset a growing dependence on foreign oil. That would spell good news for the Bush administration, which is counting on a strong trade performance to keep the economy out of a recession. Over the past three years, fully one-third of overall U.S. economic growth has been supplied by surging export sales. The April deficit of $6.94 billion was the smallest since a February imbalance of $6.10 billion with both months turning in the best trade performance since a $5.7 billion imbalance in December 1983. For April, both oil imports and auto imports were down by about $1 billion each. The 20 percent drop in oil imports to a total of $3.75 billion reflected a drop in the volume of shipments and price. America imported 7.55 billion barrels a day, down from 8.42 billion in March, while the average price per barrel fell to $16.57, down from $18.18. Imports of foreign cars declined by 16 percent to $3.68 billion, with shipments from Japan leading the decline. On the export side, there were small declines in a number of categories including a $150 million fall-off in computer shipments, a $200 million decline in shipments of telecommunications equipment and a $130 million drop in U.S. shipments of aircraft engines. As usual, the biggest deficit was with Japan, a $4 billion imbalance, up from a $3.6 billion deficit in March. The United States actually posted a surplus with Western Europe of $1.4 billion, double the March surplus. Other deficits included $800 million with Taiwan and $600 million with China, which recently won a one-year extension on its most-favored-nation lower tariffs from the Bush administration.

DOC.HEAD: Talks May Have Significant Effect on Trade Imbalance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to correct cycle designator.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Japan Trade, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Japan and the United States are going down to the wire on talks that experts say could make a real difference in the long run to reduce Japan's fat trade surplus. Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama travels to the United States today for talks with Secretary of State James A. Baker III in San Francisco. Ten days later, trade negotiators from the two countries meet in Tokyo. The goal is to work out the final report on the Structural Impediments Initiative, the plan to revamp Japan's economic structure and increase the availability of imported products. ``For 15 years Japan talked about opening the market for individual items, and the trade balance got worse,'' said economist Richard C. Koo of the Nomura Research Institute. ``For the next five years they tried ... adjusting exchange rates, and that didn't work either. Structural changes are the only thing left,'' he said. The U.S. Commerce Department said the trade imbalance with Japan was $49 billion last year, down from a record $56.3 billion in 1987 but still huge compared to 1980's $9.9 billion. The goal of the economic talks is to strengthen an April interim report hailed by both countries as a success. At that time, Japan agreed to increase public works spending, reform its complex distribution system to make it easier for large retail stores to break in, crack down on monopolies and work on lowering land prices. All the reforms should make Japan more accessible to imports. Since then, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu has expressed displeasure with U.S. pressure to extend the reforms beyond what Japan promised, while U.S. officials have charged Japan with reneging on its promises. Koo said one impetus for change is the Japanese people. They are demanding imports, indicating Japan is evolving into an international consumer society after 40 years of managed trade and sacrificing to build production, he said. The rise in consumerism is reflecting in a declining savings rate, said economist Susumu Kato of Goldman Sachs. The rate is now about 16 percent of income, compared with about 24 percent in the 1970s. That's still well above the U.S. rate of about 5 percent. The rise of the yen in recent years has helped reduce the trade imbalance by making exports more expensive and U.S. imports cheaper here. The dollar fell from an average 249 yen in 1985 to 127 yen in January 1989. The dollar has rebounded, averaging nearly 154 yen in May. That has helped decrease the trade surplus temporarily by raising the dollar value of imports, but economists worry that in the long run the yen's weakness will worsen the trade deficit. Japan actually increased its exports to the United States 4.5 percent last year, the Commerce Department said. But the surplus fell because the United States increased its exports to Japan by 18.2 percent to $44.6 billion. Some of the increase came in products that the United States had been trying to get into Japan for years. U.S. beef imports rose 38 percent to $879 million, computers were up 79 percent to $2 billion and wood was up 37 percent to $3.5 billion, according to the Japan External Trade Organization. U.S. industry officials caution that while the percentage figures look impressive, they arise from small bases. Huge imbalances remain in motor vehicles and electronics, each worth about $20 billion a year to Japan. Kato predicts Japan's surplus with the U.S. won't drop below $15 billion to $20 billion even if negotiations succeed in opening the Japanese market completely. ``We supply VCRs, computers, all kinds of electronic products,'' he said. ``As long as the demand exists, we'll export.''

DOC.HEAD: SEC Approves Western Union Plan to Exchange Debt Notes
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved a Western Union Corp. plan to swap $530 million in debt for new notes and stock in an effort to avert bankruptcy. The company plans to issue new notes and common shares in exchange for up to $530 million of its outstanding debt, including 19\ percent senior secured notes due Dec. 15, 1992, and 16 percent notes due June 15, 1991. A $51 million payment on the notes is due Friday. The offering begins today and runs through July 13. Western Union has told federal regulators that mounting interest payments could force it to see bankruptcy court protection. Under the offer approved Thursday, for each $1,000 in face amount of the old notes, Western Union would issue two classes of new notes and common stock. Note holders would receive $450 worth of new first priority notes due Sept. 14, 1992, $550 worth of 8 percent second priority notes due Dec. 31, 1995, 150 common shares, 225 Class C common shares and 275 Class D common shares. The company could opt to extend the maturity date of the new notes to Dec. 15, 1995, for first priority and to April 30, 1997, for second priority. The offer is part of a Western Union recapitalization plan that also includes a proposed reclassification of the company's Class A senior preferred shares and Class B convertible preferred shares into common shares. The company is proposing to issue 50 common shares for each Class A share and 10 common shares for each Class B.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Will Veto Family Leave Legislation, Spokesman Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 6 grafs to include Bush veto vow; picks up 4th graf, Subs pvs graf 6, `The president ...' with 4 new grafs to include Republican co-sponsor on political ramifications. This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will keep his pledge to veto legislation requiring employers to give workers up to three months' unpaid leave for family emergencies, his spokesman said today. The Senate gave final approval to the family leave bill in a voice vote Thursday night after brief debate. Passage, the culmination of a four-year effort by supporters, was a bit anticlimactic. Republican opponents conceded they could not defeat the House-passed bill and did not seek a recorded vote. At the White House, Bush was asked this morning during a photo session whether he would veto the legislation as the White House had threatened. Bush did not reply, but his press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, said, ``Yes,'' when asked the same question as reporters filed out of the photo session with Paraguay's President Andres Rodriguez. The remark immediately drew a complaint from the bill's chief Republican sponsor, Rep. Marge Roukema, R-N.J., who called the bill ``a bedrock family issue.'' ``The political implications, I think, are very dicey,'' Roukema said in a telephone interview. ``The point that has to be considered here is, do we want to be perceived as the party that fights for a reduction in the capital gains tax while we turn our backs on taxpaying, hard-working American families who are in medical crisis,'' she said. Bush, according to his spokesmen, supports voluntary leave but contends that forcing employers to provide the leave amounts to excessive government intervention in the workplace. Democrats, confident that the measure is popular with voters, immediately sought to turn up the political pressure on Bush to sign the bill. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, quoted from one of Bush's own 1988 campaign speeches, in which he seemed to support just such employee leave guarantees. He quoted Bush as saying: ``We also need to ensure that women don't have to worry about getting their jobs back after having a child or caring for a child after a serious illness.'' ``It's time to see if President Bush advocates the same policies as president as he did on the campaign trail when he sought the presidency in 1988,'' said Mitchell, D-Maine. Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., the bill's sponsor, said in an interview that he would try to meet with Bush to urge he sign the measure. Dodd noted that the public veto threats were delivered by Bush's spokesmen and aides. ``He has not personally said anything,'' Dodd said. ``I'd like to go meet with him and make my case. We think we've got a strong case to make here.'' Opponents said they were counting on a presidential veto and were confident they had the votes to sustain a veto in the House. The bill passed comfortably in the House last month, although the margin fell 46 votes short of the two-thirds majority that would be needed to override a veto. ``There simply are not the votes available to us to frustrate passage,'' said Sen. Thad Cochran, R-Miss., an opponent of the bill. ``We concede the Senate's will is to pass this bill. ... Tonight, we've lost.'' The bill requires business and government employers to provide workers with up to 12 weeks of unpaid medical leave or leave for the care of a newly born or adopted child or an ill child, parent or spouse. It exempts businesses with fewer than 50 workers, and workers who are the highest-paid 10 percent within a company. Employers would have to continue health insurance benefits for those on leave and restore a returning employee to his or her previous job or an equivalent position. Business groups have strongly opposed the bill. Their lobbyists met with White House chief of staff John Sununu on May 7 and said he promised them Bush would veto the bill if sent to his desk. Presidential spokesmen later repeated the veto threat. Senate passage came after leaders worked out a bipartisan agreement to take up the bill quickly and avoid a roll call vote. Dodd joked that he had come ready for a floor fight and was a bit disappointed by the lack of one. ``I've learned long ago you don't argue about a victory when you get one,'' he said. ``I'm also convinced that had it come to a (recorded) vote we would have prevailed.'' Dodd acknowledged he might not have enough votes in the Senate to override a veto, but said he was close. Opponents contend the bill would be costly and burdensome for businesses, and represents a government intrusion into affairs best left to business and labor. Supporters said nearly all industrialized nations already provide such minimum job security to workers, and many have provisions for full or partial pay. The bill also would cover federal employees, with even more generous leave provisions. It would cover House employees but not employees of the Senate.

Stock prices fell today as the market absorbed the impact of a quarterly ``triple witching hour.'' The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 9.16 to 2,919.06 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 9 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 403 up, 746 down and 577 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 91.66 million shares at midmorning. The government reported that the consumer price index rose 0.2 percent in May, not far from most advance estimates. Separately, the Commerce Department said the nation's trade deficit shrank to $6.94 billion last month from $8.45 billion in April, registering a larger-than-expected decline. But analysts said it was hard to gauge investors' reactions to either of those developments in the midst of the witching hour, involving a series of expiring options and futures on stock indexes. As the process began of settling multiple transactions involving those contracts and individual stocks, a preponderance of sell orders showed up in a good many blue-chip issues. Losers among the volume leaders included Exxon, down \ at 47~; Philip Morris, down { at 43~; General Motors, down \ at 49], and International Business Machines, down [ at 120}. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell .60 to 197.38. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .60 at 363.70.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 467.18 up .08 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Prices Rise Modest 0.2 Percent in May
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 grafs after 6th graf pvs `According to...' to UPDATE with White House reaction. This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Falling vegetable and fuel oil prices in May held consumer inflation to a modest 0.2 percent for the second consecutive month, the government said today. For the first five months of the year, the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index has advanced at an annual rate of 5.8 percent. That's up significantly from the 4.6 rate for all of last year, but down sharply from the worrisome 8.5 percent rate in the first quarter. The good news was expected by most economists, who said prices are recovering from a cold weather jolt at the beginning of the year. ``Just as first quarter inflation was overstated, inflation (in April and May) was understated,'' said economist Michael K. Evans, a Washington-based consultant. ``We're almost sure price increases are going to get bigger again next month.'' In other economic news, the Commerce Department said the U.S. trade deficit shrank dramatically to $6.94 billion in April, the second lowest level in the past six years. Many analysts are now forecasting that the 1990 deficit will drop below $100 billion for the first time since 1983. According to the Federal Reserve, industrial production rebounded an unexpectedly strong 0.6 percent in May after no change in April. An earlier estimate by the central bank had showed production falling in April. The operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose 0.3 percentage point to 83.6 percent in May. White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said that ``despite the temporary increase in the first quarter, over the last 12 months consumer prices have increased 4.4 percent. Inflation remains low and under control.'' As for the trade figures, he noted that the deficit in the first four months of the year was 10 percent lower than in the same period of 1989. ``This is an encouraging downward trend,'' Fitzwater said. Today's mild inflation report, which was anticipated, and the strong industrial production report, a surprise, combined to push bond prices lower in early trading this morning. Traders took the reports as a sign that inflation has not yet moderated enough nor the economy weakened sufficiently to cause the Federal Reserve Board to relax its tight monetary policy and allow short-term interest rates to fall. The Labor Department said price of fruit and vegetables fell 2.4 percent, the third substantial drop in a row. Vegetables soared 29.2 percent in the first two months of the year before falling 23.6 percent in the next three months. Food overall in May rose just 0.1 percent after edging down 0.2 percent in April. Dairy product costs fell for the third consecutive month in May while prices were up for sweets, fats and oils and beverages. Energy prices fell 0.7 percent, the fourth monthly decline following a large increase in January. Fuel oil fell 1.4 percent, and natural gas, 2.7 percent. However, electricity charges rose 1 percent. Gasoline prices rose modestly, but less than usual for the start of the warm weather driving season. Thus, after seasonal adjustment, gasoline prices were reported down 1.6 percent. Excluding the often volatile food and energy sectors, prices rose a moderate 0.3 percent following a 0.2 percent rise in April. Economists consider this so-called core rate a better indication of underlying inflation because it moves less erratically. New car prices edged down 0.2 percent, the fourth consecutive decline in the face of sluggish sales. Apparel prices, which had been up sharply earlier in the year because a warm February got spring sales off to an early start, fell 0.3 percent last month. The price of men's clothing rose 0.4 percent, but women's and children's clothing fell 1 percent and 2.2 percent respectively. The price of medical care jumped 0.8 percent in May for the fourth consecutive month, pushing those costs 9 percent higher than a year ago. The various changes put the index for all consumer prices at 129.2 in May. That means a hypothetical selection of goods and services costing $100 in the 1982-84 base period cost $129.20 last month, up from $123.80 a year ago. Wholesale prices, which rose 0.3 percent in May, have behaved more moderately than consumer prices. The Labor Department's Producer Price Index is up at only a 4 percent annual rate so far this year, down from 4.8 percent for all of last year. Economists point to the different composition of the two indexes as an explanation for their divergence. The producer index is composed entirely of prices for goods, while services account for about 55 percent of the consumer index. Because unemployment remains low, at 5.3 percent over most of the last year, services, and the cost of services, have been less affected by the economic slowdown engineered by the central bank. Today's release of consumer prices is the earliest in 30 years, according to Labor Department analyst Patrick Jackman. The report is usually released around the 27th of the month, but increasing use of computers is allowing the department to release it earlier, he said. This month's producer report, released Thursday, came out a bit later than usual. As a result, the two reports were issued on consecutive days for the first time in recent memory.

For Release PMs Friday, June 15
DOC.HEAD: No Excuses, Just Pay The Bill
DOC.TEXT: Retail sales are down, and installment credit has begun to cool. Housing starts are off too, and cars aren't selling at rates envisioned by carmakers. Manufacturing jobs have been shrinking for months. After his usual quarterly survey of smaller businesses, economist William Dunkelberg appropriately summed up the condition, the mood and the outlook for the economy in one terse sentence. ``The economy isn't going anywhere in particular,'' said Dunkelberg, dean of Temple University's School of Business and Management, ``and its going `anywhere' at a rather slow and erratic pace.'' The giving and taking and getting and spending of the marketplace has indeed slowed to a shuffle, and the best thing that can be said for it is that after nearly eight years of expansion you can't expect much more. Still, Americans adjusted to expansion in that time, and they didn't care how they got it _ by borrowing and leveraging or by working two jobs or by putting off having a family or sometimes by increasing productivity. Now that expansion is threatened, they angrily try to place the blame _ on the Japanese who restrict their marketplace, on the Reagan administration and its budget deficits, on spendthrift Congresses. President Bush comes in for his share, and so does Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, who seeks to reduce inflation to zero even if the shuffle becomes a crawl. The weather gets blamed too. It was the viciously cold weather last December, you may remember, that kept people from looking at houses to buy. It was a rather cool spring in some areas, it is said, that depressed retail sales below expectations. Some folks even blame the Commerce Department, contending that the figures are never what they seem to be after the inevitable revisions are completed, and the seasonal adjustment factors are re-examined for accuracy. While any of these reasons might possibly have something or other to do to some degree with slowing the expansion, there are, in contrast, some very hard facts that almost certainly have much to do with bringing on that condition. Debt, for example. Not just consumer debt, but municipal debt, state debt, federal debt, corporate debt. As any householder can attest, debt can keep things moving just as certainly as if it were income. But then comes the limit. Big spender that it is, Washington seems to be calling for a halt. The Fed very definitely is. Many households have imposed their own limits. Banks suddenly seem appalled at their own lending practices and are calling in loans. Then there is corporate debt, alpine dimensions of it. Like others, corporations can haul around a debt burden for a long time, expecting all the while that improving conditions will allow them to begin cutting it. When that doesn't happen, and when demand for products slows, and when interest rates remain high instead of falling, as they had anticipated, then the burden becomes onerous _ and then more so as the slowdown continues. The debt burden of corporate American soared in the 1980s to about 67 percent of gross national product from 47 percent in 1970. The ratio of interest expense to corporate earnings more than doubled to 40 percent. While the percentages might surprise, the reasons why might not. Junk bonds, after all, are familiar to everyone these days. Before them, most corporate takeovers, mergers and leveraged buyouts involved bundles of debt. In the late 1980s, about half of all funds raised by nonfinancial companies were borrowed. Compare that with the two previous decades, when three-quarters of all money raised by America's companies was in the form of equity. There are many big differences between debt and equity, and one of them is that holders of corporate equity don't threaten when there's a recession. They might sell their shares, but many will hold steady until the skies brighten. Those who lend money do not have that same commitment. They want their loans repaid, and they don't want to hear about the bad weather or poor sales or the company's need to spend on machinery. No excuses, please. Just pay the bill, with interest.

DOC.HEAD: Shameless Self-Promotion Socks Trump, But Don't Write Him Off
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new 6th graf to reflect missed bond payment, picks up 6th graf pvs, His situation... DELETES penultimate graf, At week's..., to conform
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY304 of June 13
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump begins his best-selling guide to entrepreneurial success, ``The Art of the Deal,'' by declaring: ``I don't do it for the money. I've got enough, much more than I'll ever need.'' The same man lately has been telling a parade of bankers to his Trump Tower office in midtown Manhattan that money _ about $100 million _ was precisely what he needed. After a decade of buying hotels, casinos, aircraft and land, a decade in which Trump came to personify the rich braggart and shameless self-promoter, he's been slowed down by simple math; he's taking in less than he needs to finance his debts _ $770,000 a week less, according to Forbes magazine. The bankers seem willing to help Trump, but _ given a drop in the value of the 44-year-old developer's Manhattan real estate and in the tenuous revenue projections from his Atlantic City casinos _ not entirely on his terms. Trump had to put up new collateral and ``he's trying to sell the yacht, the plane and the helicopters,'' said a source familiar with Trump's affairs, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ``You know, the smaller assets.'' His situation worsened by the end of last week, when he missed a payment on bonds used to finance one casino and reportedly faced growing reluctance by some key lenders over granting him at least $60 million in additional credit. Whatever its resolution, Trump's cash crunch threatens his prized ability to control his empire, do his deals, indulge in his extravagances. Above all, it has weakened his most impressive edifice _ his legend, which lured tourists to his hotels, gamblers to his casinos, celebrities to his Manhattan apartment towers. It may even have led bankers to give too much credit for his own good. ``People tend to be mesmerized by his personality and his attitude and his record,'' says Benjamin Schore, real estate professor at Columbia University's business school. ``Sure, bankers are affected by it. They're human.'' The story of Donald J. Trump has been told many times, often by Donald J. Trump: How he dreamed of expanding his father's real estate business; how he obtained tax breaks and built the Grand Hyatt Hotel when no one else was building anything in Manhattan; how he snapped up the site for Trump Tower; how he wore burgundy suits. Whatever his taste, young Trump was by most accounts a single-minded, hard-working developer. Unlike some older and more successful competitors, he wasn't afraid to get his patent leather shoes _ which matched his suits _ dirty at construction sites. Trump also developed a reputation for hiring the best people and paying them accordingly, and for financing his projects by taking on partners. He put his name on everything he built or bought. ``The name sells,'' Trump once said. ``It's all a game, really.'' In the mid-1980s bargains became more scarce, and Trump increasingly paid top prices to buy and fix whatever he wanted, including the Plaza Hotel, the Eastern Airlines shuttle service and the unfinished Taj Mahal casino. Trump operated on two assumptions: that the New York real estate he owned got more valuable by the day, and that any other acquisitions would soar in value if adorned with his name. Banks happily helped. When Trump bought what became the Trump's Castle casino from Hilton Hotels, a group of banks lent him the down payment and gave him a five-year grace period for the first repayment. ``Bankers have all this money coming in. They've got to get it out (in loans) and they've got to get it back,'' said Schore, explaining why banks such as Citibank and Chase Manhattan loaned to Trump so eagerly. What Trump calls ``the beat up Trump months'' began in February because of a dispute with his wife, not his bankers. Donald and Ivana Trump were breaking up. Mrs. Trump's determination to seek a large share of her husband's assets focused attention on their real worth. Trump kept a straight face, even when he scrapped free coffee on the Trump Shuttle and announced it was for sale, a year after he bought it. ``Cash is king'' he announced, explaining that he wanted to be able to grab bargains as prices dropped. Then Forbes magazine reported Trump's worth, which it had estimated at $1.7 billion in 1989, had sagged to about $500 million. Publicly, Trump was ridiculing the article; privately, he was calling bankers for more cash. His problem became clearer two weeks ago, when banking sources confirmed he was conferring with lenders who wanted more collateral. New York tabloids covered that story like they did Trump's marital mess. The newly opened Taj Mahal, which Trump had touted as `the eighth wonder of the world'' was called the ``eighth blunder of the world.'' Trump's denunciations of others for his problems betrayed the strain he faced. When a brokerage analyst questioned Trump's Taj revenue projections, he threatened to sue the brokerage. The analyst was fired. When reporters asked him about disappointing shuttle and casino revenues, he blamed employees, including two respected casino executives who had died in a helicopter crash. Trump's reputation for commanding staff loyalty also suffered with the resignation of Jack O'Donnell, president of the Trump Plaza casino, who said he was sick of Trump's interference. For example, O'Donnell said, one weekend in May Trump stalked a baccarat pit, watching a Japanese gambler who had won more than $6 million in February. The gambler eventually lost $10 million, and Trump cut him off before he had a chance to recover. The guest stormed off to another casino. In a business where you're never supposed to ``sweat the action,'' Trump's behavior reflected inexperience, O'Donnell said. Trump's attitude toward wealthy Japanese emerged as another liability that some said could haunt him. In his heyday Trump would blast the Japanese as economic exploiters; the next minute he'd say their desire for Manhattan real estate made his own properties extremely valuable. But now, weary of Japan-bashing by Trump and others, Japanese investors are increasingly reluctant to buy well-known American properties. This has narrowed the field of affluent buyers whom Trump may need some day. Trump is by no means finished _ especially if the Taj Mahal meets his expectations. Nor is he the only developer under pressure in the economically depressed Northeast. ``Trump is going to be in exceptionally good company,'' predicts Michael Cohen, a real estate expert. ``Most of the developers and bankers in New York were too confident,'' says Schore. ``They felt that even if they did make a mistake, they'd be bailed out by the rising market. They forgot about cycles.'' Will Trump survive? ``If I had to bet, I'd bet on him,'' says Schore. ``He's a very skilled developer, and hopefully this will teach him to avoid too much financing.'' But as he tries to extricate himself by selling, stalling or renegotiating, Trump must face a reality he described in ``The Art of the Deal:'' ``The worst thing you can possibly do in a deal is seem desperate to make it. That makes the other guy smell blood, and then you're dead.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday June 17

DOC.HEAD: Pathe Extends MGM-UA Tender Offer Again as Deadline Looms
DOC.TEXT: Pathe Communications Corp., still trying to -arrange financing for its $1.2 billion bid for MGM-UA Communications Co., today extended its tender offer to June 22, one day before the deal's final deadline. It was the second week-long extension of the offer by Pathe, a producer and distributor of movies controlled by Italian financier Giancarlo Paretti. Parretti earlier had extended the deadline until Friday. Whether and how Parretti can finance the deal has been the subject of tremendous speculation. He previously tried and failed to buy smaller Hollywood companies. The offer expires on June 23, according to his agreement with MGM-UA and Tracinda Corp., the holding company through which Beverly Hills billionaire Kirk Kerkorian controls MGM-UA. Last year, a bid by the Qintex group in Australia to buy MGM-UA for $1.5 billion fell through for lack of financing. Qintex outbid media mogul Rupert Murdoch, whose financing seemed assured, by $100 million, but was unable to finance the deal. MGM-UA Chairman Jeffrey Barbakow, who Kerkorian has promised a $30 million bonus when MGM-UA is sold, declined to say if Kerkorian would retain a 2 percent stake in MGM-UA. Kerkorian, in filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, has indicated he may do so. That would reduce Parretti's price by about $20 million. Jeanne Ouellette, an MGM-UA spokeswoman, said she wasn't sure about Kerkorian retaining a stake in the company, but said the deal was expected to go through even if it comes down to the final deadline. ``The outside date has always been the 23rd,'' she said. Parretti has paid $200 million in cash down payments. He also has guaranteed MGM-UA $75 million in fees from distributing three upcoming Pathe releases, including ``The Russia House'' with Sean Connery and Michelle Pfeiffer and ``Quigley Down Under'' with Tom Selleck. Time Warner Inc. has agreed to lend Parretti $650 million in return for a lien on the United Artists film library and distribution rights on that library and new MGM, Pathe and United Artists films for 20 years. The balance of the offer is expected to be funded by short-term loans and asset sales by Pathe-affiliated companies in Europe, and the possible resale of MGM-UA stock or of new Pathe shares after the merger.

DOC.NOTE: $adv18
For release Monday June 18
DOC.HEAD: Researchers Trying to Pin Down Cause of Executive Death
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Arthur W. Ewy was a successful accountant with 37 years experience when a management change forced him to retire from the board of Gates Rubber Co., a manufacturer of belts and hoses. Within six months, Ewy was dead of a heart attack. His son Rodger said he died of a broken heart, caused by forced departure from the Denver company that put him out to pasture like an aging racehorse. Some medical experts have a different term for this _ early executive mortality. ``Men are dying not with their boots on, but with their retirement plans clutched in their hands,'' said Dr. Alan Sherman, a Palo Alto, Calif., psychiatrist who has studied post-retirement executive deaths. G. Dale Meyer, an assistant business professor at the University of Colorado, is directing a study commissioned by Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Co. to determine if executives forced into retirement tend to die soon after losing power. Meyer's team, which includes physicians, has just begun working. ``We're trying to see if this is folklore, or if it's real,'' Meyer said. A number of businessmen say it's real. Justin Dart, creator of Dart Industries, issued a statement when he was 72: ``I want my death and my retirement to be simultaneous.'' Three years later in 1980, he merged his corporation with Kraft Inc. and died. Armand Hammer, 92, chairman of Occidental Petroleum Corp., William C. Norris, 78, founder of Control Data Corp., and J. Peter Grace, 77, chairman of W.R. Grace & Co., are all among top executives who refused to retire rather than relinquish power. Norris stepped down as chairman of his company four years ago but remains a powerful board member. ``A time arrives when, for a variety of possible reasons, the successful entrepreneur thinks retirement. Yet being an entrepreneur, this individual can't fathom the traditional meaning of the term retirement,'' Meyer said. ``Nothing, absolutely nothing, in this individual's view of the world relates to the retirement concept. ``Bureaucrats and corpocrats, the corporate equivalent of bureaucrat, place comfortable retirement as a high priority throughout their careers. They look forward to doing nothing...they dream of travel, golf, fishing, dilettantism and perhaps a hobby,'' said Meyer. ``This is not to say that all who eagerly anticipate retirement do it well. Increasingly, the emptiness of it all, the unstructured meaningless, the loss of vital interests, is being viewed more negatively. The loss of purpose, it is now known, can create early illness and even death,'' he said. Nonetheless, early executive mortality remains a medically undocumented syndrome. Although anecdotal examples of premature deaths after retirement have been chronicled, there are plenty of executives who survive and thrive after getting out of the workaholic rat-race while relatively young. Perhaps the best-known recent instance is that of Peter Lynch, 46, the widely respected manager of the highly profitable Magellan mutual fund of Fidelity Investments in Boston. After 13 years of running the fund, he called it quits last month to spend more time with his family. Still, Lynch's story does not reflect a more common occurence: executives who are pushed into retirement before they're ready. Their numbers have been growing in recent years, partly because of the restructurings, mergers and staff reductions that have reshaped much of American business. Moreover, few companies teach potential retirees for a second career that might extend their useful life. Henry Kates, chief executive of Mutual Benefit Life Insurance, had more than a corporate interest in doing something about it. Kates was sitting in a conference room at a Phoenix hotel in 1979 when William T. Earls, a 69-year-old company field manager and good friend, rose to give his retirement presentation. Midway through, Earls died of a heart attack. In the years that followed, five more of his senior managers died soon after retirement. Mary Ann Green, a spokesman for the insurance company, said the study was commissioned to determine how companies could better prepare managers for retirement. She said it has nothing to do with insurance or insurance rates. ``Our CEO felt not enough was being done to help these people who had contributed so much to the company,'' she said. ``He believes most corporations aren't aware of this problem.'' Meyer said he plans to contact the Fortune 500 companies to ask them for statistical figures on executives who retired successfully and found second careers or occupations, vs. those who did not and died early. He said preliminary research suggests a second career may be crucial to former executives. ``Those who do not find that second challenge, a second start, are in great danger of dying sooner than their cohorts,'' he said.
