DOC.HEAD: Increasing Competition Spurs Plans for Off-Hours Market
DOC.TEXT: The New York Stock Exchange's decision to phase in 24-hour securities trading during the 1990s comes amid intensifying worldwide competition that is eroding the Big Board's market share. Regional stock exchanges, foreign markets and independent electronic services offering cheaper trading are offering investors alternatives for trading NYSE stocks. Meanwhile, other exchanges and private services are offering off-hours trading in the rush to capitalize on new technology that lets investors trade securities almost whenever and wherever they want. ``Anyplace else where you can trade securities represents competition,'' John W. Bachman, managing partner of the St. Louis brokerage Edward D. Jones & Co., said Friday. ``If the New York Stock Exchange is determined to remain what many people believe is the strongest market in the world, they can't ignore it,'' he said. NYSE Chairman John J. Phelan Jr. on Thursday unveiled a five-step plan to trade securities after the exchange's traditional daytime hours. The plan would culminate in 24-hour trading by the end of the decade. Round-the-clock trading already is reality in the foreign currency and U.S. Treasury bond markets, where dealers conduct transactions via telephone and computer links. The two Chicago futures markets plan to begin computerized, extended-hours trading in November. While the NYSE remains by far the nation's largest exchange _ and the world's second-largest behind Tokyo _ its market share has eroded and profitability slumped in recent years. The Big Board handled only 69.2 percent of all trades in its listed stocks last year, an all-time low. The exchange's net income fell to $6.29 million last year from $10.45 million in 1988. The NYSE still dominates the volume of trades, but it has lost significant market share to smaller regional exchanges. The Chicago-based Midwest Stock Exchange, for example, last year accounted for 10.3 percent of the trading in NYSE stocks, up from 3.33 percent in 1979. Industry experts also say erosion has occurred overseas, where U.S. companies are listed on foreign exchanges. The London exchange, which went electronic four years ago, and the Tokyo market have siphoned the most business. In London, the value of trading of U.S. securities totaled the equivalent of about $2.5 billion in May. Another and possibly bigger threat to the NYSE is the so-called ``third market'' of firms that trade stocks off of the exchange floor. The Big Board is concerned that its large member firms could shift some of their business to off-exchange trading. The third market's share of NYSE-listed stock trades rose to 7.4 percent of overall Big Board trading through May this year from 3.1 percent in the same 1989 period. By skirting the NYSE floor, third market firms offer a cheaper and more anonymous way to conduct trades. This electronic alternative to the Big Board includes off-exchange firms such as Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities, which can handle trades in 275 of the NYSE's 1,700 listed securities; the electronic trading system Instinet; and Crossing Network, an after-hours system that matches up trades. The fully automated National Association of Securities Dealers plans to start trading up to 300 over-the-counter stocks starting at 4 a.m. in September, a direct challenge to the London Stock Exchange. And the American Stock Exchange said that on Monday it would outline a joint venture with the Chicago Board Options Exchange, the Cincinnati Stock Exchange and the financial information company Reuters for trading stocks and options and unregistered securities electronically around the world. How can the 198-year-old NYSE guarantee its future? Eric K. Clemons, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, said the Big Board has to ``make sure institutions feel they have no choice, that if they want to trade a (major U.S.) stock, the only place to trade is New York.'' Meanwhile, NYSE competitors and other exchanges welcomed Phelan's proposal to gear up for 24-hour trading. The steps would begin later this year with two brief sessions after the market's normal close. Subsequent phases would involve stock auctions held several times a night, some form of conventional trading overnight and finally 24-hour dealing. Andrew Yemma, a spokesman for the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, said the NYSE moves would help develop an underlying cash market in stocks on a 24-hour basis that would add liquidity for futures and options trading. ``It will increase the awareness and attract greater liquidity to off-hours trading,'' said Linda R. Coleman, executive vice president of Instinet, which is owned by Reuters Holdings PLC. ``That can only benefit us because it will atrract more trading to our order-flow system.'' Third-market leader Bernad Madoff said the increased competition faced by the NYSE is a healthy byproduct of a changing financial world. ``Their concern is not necessarily the concern of the rest of the industry,'' Madoff said. ``Like any business, their loss has been someone else's gain.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Ruling Backs Discounts for Cash Customers
DOC.TEXT: A high court judge on Friday backed the government's plan to permit retailers to charge cash customers less than those who use credit cards. Justice Derek Hodgson rejected a suit filed by the credit card company Visa International, which sought an order blocking the government's proposed action. Visa International said Britain would be the first country in Europe to permit differential pricing. ``The real decision is going to be made in the marketplace. We think that is the most important,'' said a spokeswoman for Visa International, speaking on condition that she not be identified. However, she said the company had not reviewed all the legal papers and had not ruled out a further appeal. The government decided to introduce the two-tiered system after the Monopolies and Mergers Commission decided last August that Visa and its member banks were part of a complex monopoly. An existing ``no discrimination'' rule, which bans traders who accept Visa cards from imposing any surcharge on transactions, operated against the public interest, the commission said. Visa has more than 21,000 member banks and mortgage lenders worldwide. Bernard Hughes, a spokesman for the Retail Consortium, which represents 90 percent of the British retail industry, welcomed the judge's ruling. ``We hope it will clarify the situation and that Visa will end its objections,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: From Neon Visors to Corn Cob Litter: Pet Items Extravagant, Functional
DOC.TEXT: The cat litter that transforms waste into a disposable rock seems like a good idea, although the neon doggie sun visors appear flamboyant enough to make Lassie blush. From functional to extravagant, a wide array of pet products is on display through Saturday at the industry's annual trade show in Atlanta. Is your pet unhappy because it cannot show the world which NFL team is its favorite? Maybe it would like a dog sweater, leash or dinner bowl emblazoned with the San Francisco 49ers logo. Or perhaps a replica helmet bird feeder. Has your hamster become bored in its old-fashioned cage? Put them into a new, multicolored modular model with a looping overhead plastic walkway. Are the goldfish uncomfortable in their little bowl? Try an acrylic designer aquarium-coffee table. Among the 485 exhibit booths at the American Pet Products Manufacturers Association show are myriad makers of pet foods, animal litter, bird cages and other standard pet store fare. Karen Long MacLeod, editor of the trade publication Pet Age, said the offbeat items aren't as frivolous as they may seem. A major thrust of the industry, she said, is to provide products that make pets more a part of the family, rather than just passive creatures. ``It's important to get kids and adults to think about their pets and bring them into the family, not just look at them as disposable things,'' Ms. MacLeod said. ``Those products are designed to keep pets healthy and to have fun.'' Particularly in the areas of food and litter, the industry is very research driven, she said. ``It's a pretty healthy industry,'' Ms. MacLeod said. ``We see it in the number of new companies entering the industry and staying in, and in shows like these. An industry that's stagnant wouldn't be doing it.'' Judging from the number of exhibitors featuring litter, keeping pets sanitary isn't simple. Several companies are offering a solidifying clay litter that has been developed over the last few years. When a cat wets this litter, the clay coagulates into a hardened ball that can be scooped out and disposed of. The powdery litter comes in a jug and the pet owner simply adds more to the box as the old portions are discarded. ``You don't ever dump it. It's used up,'' said Mike Bennett, a sales representative for Sanex Corp. of Houston, whose litter is called Better Way. A few booths away, Mounds, Ill.-based Absorbent Clay Products was displaying its version of the solidifying litter, which is aimed at affluent consumers. ``It's a superior clumper _ no doubt about it,'' said Ed Odom, Absorbent's vice president of research. There's more than one way to keep pets clean. Bed-O' Cobs, a Maumee, Ohio, maker of corn cob litter, was displaying its product, which the company says is best for bird cages and small animals. Cedar is the most widely used bedding for small animals, but corn cob is catching on, said Ted Weaver, Bed-O' Cobs' product manager. Unlike other materials, corn cob absorbs moisture from the bottom up, keeping the surface near the animal drier, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Misses Payment on Bonds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf with two grafs on Moody's downgrading; bid prices for bonds.
DOC.TEXT: Developer Donald Trump announced he will not make payments due today to holders of Trump Castle casino's junk bonds. Trump was due to make principal and interest payments of about $30 million on the bonds used to finance the Atlantic City hotel and casino. He has a 10-day grace period to make the payment following today's scheduled due date, bankers have said. The brief announcement from Trump said negotiations with banks are continuing. Trump has been talking with his bank lenders, whom he owes about $2 billion, and had reached a tentative agreement for $60 million in new loans earlier this week. The agreement has been said to be in jeopardy as other bank lenders have balked at the arrangement that would have given them equity in some of Trump's properties in return for the loan and a suspension of payments. The Trump Organization said an interest payment due today on Trump Plaza bonds had been made and a May 15 interest payment on Taj Mahal was paid. Trump spokeswoman Norma Foerderer said the company would have no further comment beyond the news release. In reaction to the announcement, Moody's Investors Service Inc. lowered its rating on Trump's Taj Mahal bonds and Plaza bonds. Bids for Trump Castle bonds were off about 2 cents, trading at 56 cents on the dollar, and bids for Taj Mahal bonds were steady around 79 cents on the dollar. John Moran, a bond trader at Advest Inc., said bids had gone lower shortly after the announcement, but he doubted there were any takers. Bids for bonds on the healthiest of Trump's three casinos, the Trump Plaza, were trading in a narrow range in the low to mid 50s, Moran said. Trump's once gleaming image as a booming developer with a Midas touch has been tarnished by the slumping New York city real estate market and disappointing results from his Atlantic City casinos. As trustee for the Castle bonds, First Fidelity Bancorp, of Newark N.J., oversees the interests of bondholders. The bank has also loaned Trump $75 million. Paul Levine, spokesman for First Fidelity, said the bank would have no comment on the announcement. Trump's major bank lenders, Citicorp, Bankers Trust Corp. of New York, Chase Manhattan Bank and the Manufacturers Hanover Bank had reached an agreement with the flamboyant developer earlier this week. However, other banks needed to complete the deal were reportedly hesitant. Among those were First Fidelity and Midlantic Banks Inc., of Edison, N.J., according to a report in this morning's editions of The New York Times. Some bankers suggested bondholders might scrutinize the role of First Fidelity as both bond trustee and major lender if he fails to make the payment, the Times reported.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Extend Losses
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed moderately to sharply lower Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade, in active selling that occurred late in an otherwise lackluster session. Forecasts for near-ideal weather conditions in the Midwest through mid-July have weighed on corn and soybean prices all week. Late in Friday's session, prices of both commodities fell low enough to trigger substantial new selling. The significant marks were $2.75 a bushel in the December corn contract and $5.88 in the July beans, said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``Yesterday, we held those support levels,'' he said. ``But late today, renewed selling pushed the market down through those levels and we just collapsed.'' Wheat futures settled 2 cents to 5\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in July at $3.28 a bushel; corn was 4 cents to 7 cents lower with July at $2.83 a bushel; oats were unchanged to 2{ cents lower with July at $1.38{ a bushel; and soybeans were 9 cents lower to 1 cent higher with July at $5.85 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Highest Closes in Dow Jones Industrials Average
With AM-Wall Street
Largest Gold Producers to Curtail Operations
DOC.TEXT: The world's two largest gold producing companies announced curtailment of their mining operations Friday due to the plummeting price of gold. Anglo American Corp. of South Africa Ltd. said two of its mining companies, Free State State Consolidated Gold Mines Ltd. (Freegold) and Vaal Reefs Exploration and Mining Co. Ltd., would cut back on operations in moves that will cut at least 7,800 jobs. Earlier this week, two other mining groups outside the Anglo-American conglomerate announced job cutbacks involving 1,100 workers. The price of gold reached a 4-year low of $346.25 per ounce in New York and London before recovering on Thursday. Gold is South Africa's major industry, earning more than half the country's foreign currency. Lionel Hewitt, managing director of Anglo-American's gold and uranium division, said the company in recent months had tried several programs to maintain existing operating levels, including cost reduction measures and deferment of capital expenditure. ``Despite these efforts, at current gold prices and operating costs, certain mining areas are now incapable of sustaining mining operations at their present levels,'' Hewitt said. He said the curtailment of operations would take place over the next nine months and probably result in the loss of 7,800 jobs at Freegold. He said reductions at Vaal Reefs would not necessarily eliminate jobs because workers may be assigned to other areas of the mine. Operating reductions at Freegold would reduce its gold production by less than 1 percent, while the proposed action at Vaal Reefs likely would improve production, Hewitt said. On Wednesday, General Mining Union Corp. announced its marginally operating Stilfontein Gold Mining Co. Ltd. would lay off 500 workers immediately to cut costs in the face of low gold prices. Anglovaal Ltd. said its Loraine Gold Mines Ltd. would lay off 600 workers and reduce production by 10 percent in the next four months. Hewitt said Anglo American management had invited discussions with union leaders about the curtailments. There was no immediate reaction from the unions. The National Union of Mineworkers, the nations' largest black union, representing some 250,000 black miners, has already declared a dispute and asked for arbitration in its annual wage negotiations with the mining industry body. Curtailing mining operations is considered a serious step. Once a particular shaft is shut down, the infrastructure often deteriorates rapidly, making it even more costly and dangerous to resume operations when the price of gold rises.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower In U.S., Mixed In Europe
DOC.TEXT: The dollar lost ground in domestic dealings and finished mixed in Europe in volatile trading Friday following the release of a flurry of U.S. economic data. Gold prices advanced but were unable to recover from Thursday's $5-an-ounce selloff. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $349.50 a troy ounce, up $2.70 from late Thursday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $348.50 an ounce, up $2.65 an ounce. The government reported that the nation's trade deficit shrunk dramatically to $6.94 billion in April and that consumer inflation held to a modest 0.2 percent gain in May. Both reports were in line with expectations and had little impact on currency dealings. But a Federal Reserve report showing a 0.6 percent rebound in May's industrial production took the market by surprise. ``This was the first time in several weeks that an economic number was reported actually stronger than the market had expected,'' said Marc Chandler, an analyst at MMS International in Chicago. The dollar initially rallied, both in Europe and the United States, on the notion that the Federal Reserve won't be inclined to lower interest rates to stimulate production. Lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less attractive to investors. But a bout of profit-taking swept European markets, where the dollar closed lower against most currencies, and carried through to U.S. dealings. Activity was ``very heavy and very choppy,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. Rumors circulated in the market that West Germany's Bundesbank and the Bank of Japan are poised to intervene in coming days to support their local currencies _ at the expense of the dollar. ``With the idea that the central banks might act to limit further dollar gains, many wanted to take profits ahead of the weekend,'' Chandler said. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 154.52 yen, up 0.99 yen from Thursday. Later in London, the dollar was quoted lower at 154.10 yen. In New York the dollar closed at 153.90 yen, down from 154.20 yen on Thursday. In London the pound fell to $1.7060, from $1.7080 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.7090 to buy one pound, more expensive than Thursday's $1.7080. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.6885 West German marks, down from 1.6948; 1.4330 Swiss francs, down from 1.4355; 5.6806 French francs, down from 5.7015; 1,239.00 Italian lire, down from 1,244.50, and 1.1709 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1713. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.6915 West German marks, down from 1.6920; 1.4340 Swiss francs, up from 1.4330; 5.6910 French francs, down from 5.6940; 1.9065 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9045; 1,241.00 Italian lire, down from 1,242.75; and 1.1698 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1700. Gold prices were mostly higher. In London, gold traded at a late bid price of $347.50 per troy ounce, up from $345.25 late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal was quoted at $347.25 an ounce, up from $345.50. In Hong Kong, gold slipped to $346.75 an ounce from $348.95. Silver prices were unchanged to higher. On New York's Comex, silver for current delivery settled at $4.811 a troy ounce, up from Thursday's $4.770. In London, silver traded at a late bid price of $4.80 an ounce, unchanged from Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Prices Slip
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices fell Friday due to oversupply, as well as the approach of a contract expiration, analysts said. The contract for July delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, fell 51 cents to $16.62 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercentile Exchange. Later contract months posted smaller losses. The price of the July contract had fallen 45 cents Thursday. ``I think that the problem with the crude market is the high level of crude stocks,'' said William Byers, an analyst at Bear, Stearns & Co., who said the price decline also was connected to next Wednesday's deadline for trading the July contract. ``Nobody wants it, since they're basically awash in crude oil,'' he said. The market saw a corresponding drop in home heating oil, with the July contract off 0.13 cent to 48.37 cents a gallon. Heating oil was off 0.07 cent the day before. Among refined petroleum products traded on the New York Merc, wholesale unleaded gasoline for July delivery rose 1.39 cents a gallon to 61.51 cents. The contract had risen 1.27 cents the day before. Subsequent months were mixed. Byers said prices have been up because this is motorists' peak driving period. Prices for natural gas were mixed, with the July contract unchanged from $1.547 per 1,000 cubic feet. The August and September contracts were down while October and November were up.

DOC.HEAD: New Jersey Says Allstate Lawsuit Not a Federal Matter
DOC.TEXT: State officials asked a federal judge Friday to relinquish jurisdiction in a lawsuit filed by Allstate Insurance Co. that claims New Jersey's new automobile insurance law is unconstitutional. Douglas Eakeley, first assistant state attorney general, said U.S. District Judge John W. Bissell should abstain from considering Allstate's grievances because the same case can be litigated properly at the state level. Allstate, New Jersey's largest insurer, says the state's new law violates the company's rights under the Fifth and 14th Amendments because the law unfairly forces the insurance industry to pay $1.4 billion to the state high-risk insurance pool. Part of the Fifth Amendment says the government cannot take private property without just compensation, and the 14th Amendment upholds a right to challenge governmental actions. Bissell reserved decision on the matter. Earlier, Bissell refused a request by the Liberty Mutual Insurance Group and Continental Insurance Co. of New Jersey to move cases being handled at the state administrative level to the federal level. Liberty also has a separate federal case pending that seeks to block the insurance law. State Farm Insurance Co. is seeking the same action in state Superior Court. The state's 15 insurance servicing carriers, including Allstate, Liberty, State Farm and Continental, are named in a state lawsuit claiming they overbilled the state-run Joint Underwriting Association. The case is being handled by an administrative law judge. The insurance law requires the industry to pay the $1.4 billion during the next seven years to help eliminate a $3.1 billion debt amassed by the JUA pool for high-risk drivers. The JUA, which costs every New Jersey motorist $222 per car on their annual policy, is to be eliminated under the law. New Jersey's car insurance rates are among the nation's highest. Floyd Abrams, a prominent constitutional lawyer representing Allstate, argued Friday that under the federal Tax Injunction Act, the state should not be allowed to collect surcharges and other assessments from the company in the form of a tax. ``This is a segregated fund which is applied only for the single purpose of paying off the JUA debt,'' Abrams told Bissell. ``We think that based on case law ... that neither the assessment nor surcharge is a tax. We believe it is paying a private debt.'' Eakeley responded that the surcharge every motorist pays because of the JUA losses are ``hardly a private debt.'' Gov. Jim Florio, who signed the insurance law March 12, has maintained that the insurance industry financially benefited from the JUA and contributed to its financial woes. Florio said there are provisions in the law that ensure auto insurance companies can make a fair profit.

DOC.HEAD: Amoco Pleased With Iran Settlement, But Says Earnings Impact Muted
With AM-Iran-US, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Amoco Corp. said Friday it was pleased by Iran's agreement to pay $600 million for Amoco facilities that were seized during the Islamic revolution, but that the effect on earnings would be lowered by taxes and an unrelated charge. The company said it expects to recognize the all-cash settlement in its second-quarter results, provided it receives the money by the end of June. Amoco said in a statement from its Chicago headquarters that the effect of the settlement on net income will be ``largely offset'' by the as-yet undetermined income taxes it must pay on it, and by an unrelated charge the company will take against the cost of future environmental clean-ups. Spokesman Mike Thompson indicated the taxes and clean-up provision would total more than $300 million. In addition, a statuatory fee of about $6 million will be deducted by the U.S. government, the company said. Amoco stock rose 25 cents a share to close at $52.12{ Friday on the New York Stock Exchange. The settlement was the largest in the history of the Netherlands-based Iran-United States Claims Tribunal, an arbitration body set up in 1980 to mediate financial claims. ``We have been discussing things with the Iranians and we were pleased to reach the settlement,'' Thompson said. The case had been in the tribunal for nine years, said Thompson, adding that without Friday's agreement, it could have dragged on for several more years. Two Amoco subsidiaries had filed claims against the National Iranian Oil Company. Under terms of the agreement, Amoco Iran Oil Co. will receive $540 million for the 1979 seizure of four Persian Gulf drilling fields and the oil terminal on Kharg island, Iran's most important oil terminal. Amoco International Finance Corp. was awarded $60 million for the expropriation of a petrochemical processing plant in which Amoco had a half-interest.

DOC.HEAD: British Stock Market Experts Puzzled by Big Board Plan
DOC.TEXT: British stock market experts said Friday they were puzzled by the New York Stock Exchange's plan to begin after-hours trading to an effort to recapture trading of U.S. stocks now conducted overseas. The experts said such trading is relatively small in Europe, and it also is not clear that the business will grow much in coming years. But they also said the proposals were too sketchy to determine their implications. One trader, however, was enthusiastic, saying, ``I see this as a major plus for internationalization.'' Big Board Chairman John J. Phelan Jr. on Thursday unveiled a five-step plan to phase in a 24-hour market by the end of the decade to meet increasing competition from overseas. The steps would begin with two brief sessions after the New York market's normal close at 4 p.m. Eastern time. Later, stock auctions would be held several times a night, followed by some form of conventional trading overnight before 24-hour dealing eventually is introduced. A spokeswoman for London's Stock Exchange, speaking anonymously in keeping with British practice, said Thursday, ``We ourselves have no plans to extend trading hours. However, the exchange continues to respond to traders' needs.'' The London exchange in March moved up its session half an hour to between 8:30 a.m. and 4:30 p.m., in respone to demand for earlier trading. The London exchange went electronic four years ago under the sweeping ``Big Bang'' deregulation, which placed the execution of trades on computer screens. By contrast, the NYSE still executes trades through the interaction of stock brokers and specialists on the exchange floor. London's specialists are required to continuously make markets in stocks during the exchange's official hours, but investors are allowed to buy and sell shares anytime via computer. The Big Board's move probably is in response to NASDAQ's plan to begin operating during European hours in the third quarter of this year, said Tim Williams, who runs trading in U.S. stocks for the London investment firm County Natwest Woodmac. NASDAQ, or National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotations, is an American, screen-based, over-the-counter market. ``It's a bit difficult to understand really what they (the Big Board) are going to accomplish by it,'' Williams said Friday. ``The fact of the matter is most of the business here is reasonably small. Whether it can be developed is debatable.'' The London exchange said the value of trading in U.S. stocks in London came to the equivalent of about $2.6 billion in May, representing just 5 percent of the total foreign stock trading of $50.3 billion. About $46.9 billion worth of British stocks were traded that month, it said. Europe's exchanges currently are focusing their attention on creating a single market for trading European stocks, which represent 65 percent of foreign stock trading on London's exchange. Most trading in U.S. stocks in London is handled by the major U.S. brokerage firms which have London operations. A spokeswoman for one of them, Morgan Stanley & Co., said, ``We support the stock exchange initiative which responds to the stock market environment.'' Firms that aren't members of the New York exchange can trade U.S. stocks in Europe without following Big Board regulations. ``It's really very difficult to know what the implications are going to be because they're very sketchy about what they want to do,'' Williams said about Phelan's plan. Investors are unlikely to be willing to wait around for the appointed time or agree to an auction, he said. He also said he didn't think investors would be willing to risk leaving an overnight order with a broker because a market development could occur while the investor is asleep. He noted that London brokers place overnight orders in Tokyo. ``But we're used to it,'' he said. ``I'm no sure there is going to be global trading,'' he added. But the enthusiastic London trader, who didn't want to be identified, said, ``We welcome any kind of competition in Europe. The freer or open the market is, the better it will be not only for traders but also for the investment community.'' He said the Big Board being open during the European morning probably would generate more European business because it would ``legitimize'' trading in U.S. stocks on this side of the Atlantic. Many European traders now only consider a New York price on a U.S. stock ``legitimate,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bonds Tumble on Belief Fed Won't Ease
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices tumbled Friday on economic reports that led traders to conclude the Federal Reserve did not plan to lower short-term interest rates soon. In its sharpest one-day drop since mid-April, the Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond tumbled 13-16 point, or $8.13 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which rises when prices fall, climbed to 8.42 percent from late Wednesday's 8.34 percent, which was the lowest for the long-term bond since late January. Economists said they were surprised at the sharp drop, which came despite news on inflation and the federal trade deficit that normally would give bond prices a boost. They attributed the bulk of the decline to a Fed report that industrial production rebounded an unexpectedly strong 0.6 percent last month after holding steady in April. The market had expected a 0.3 percent rise. Some analysts said the market should have dismissed the gain in industrial production because it was caused mainly by a buildup in inventories by the Big Three automakers concerned about a possible strike. Signs of a strong economy tend to weaken bonds, because of concerns that inflation will rise and erode the value of such long-term fixed-income investments. The Labor Department reported retail prices rose a modest 0.2 percent in May, bringing the rise in the Consumer Price Index for the first five months of the year to 5.8 percent. That news should have been favorable for credit markets. In addition, the Commerce Department said the U.S. trade deficit shrank to $6.94 billion in April, the second lowest level in the last 6 years, another positive sign. Ray Stone, managing director of Stone & McCarthy Research Associates Inc., said the market declined following a financial wire report citing unnamed Fed officials who reinforced a view they weren't close to lowering interest rates. Traders believed the economy was not weak enough nor inflation calm enough to trigger an easier monetary policy. Falling interest rates boost the value of existing bonds because their rates of return are higher and therefore more valuable. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments fell 3-16 point to 9-32 point, intermediate maturities fell 13-32 point to { point, and long-term issues fell as much as 13-16 point, according to Telerate Inc., the financial information service. The movement of a point equals a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 4.78 to 1,160.55. Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 7.93 percent as the discount gained 2 basis points to 7.68 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 8.02 percent as the discount gained 6 basis points to 7.62 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 8.03 percent as the discount rose 6 basis points to 7.49 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8\ percent, unchanged from late Wednesday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds fell 1-16 point to 91}. The average yield to maturity rose to 7.50 percent from 7.49 percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Carrier Launches New Ad Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Struggling Eastern Airlines will launch a ``100 days'' advertising campaign aimed at boosting consumer faith in its service, the airline's court-appointed trustee said Thursday. The campaign will hit the airwaves Sunday evening in 33 Eastern-served markets. It features trustee Martin Shugrue answering questions from employees and promising that service will improve each day over the 100-day period. ``Yes, we have a large, deep hole to climb out of,'' Shugrue tells workers in one commercial. The carrier has been in Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization since a crippling strike that began in March 1989. A bankruptcy judge appointed Shugrue to run the airline in April after creditors became frustrated by the management of Eastern's owners, Texas Air Corp. ``I don't think honesty is risky,'' Shugrue told reporters in unveiling the campaign. ``I don't think candor is risky, although it can be controversial.'' The initial commercial, showing Shugrue fielding questions at an Eastern hangar here, will be followed by an ad showing him talking with passengers aboard an Eastern flight. The multimillion-dollar campaign is the first for Eastern by Ogilvy & Mather, the New York advertising agency that Shugrue hired in one of his first acts as trustee. He declined to give the campaign's precise cost. The campaign is aimed at driving home Eastern's on-time and friendly service and ending confusion among consumers, Shugrue said. ``We're running a good airline. We're not getting credit for it,'' he said. The airline's May passenger figures were ``horrible,'' he said, but June has shown an upturn. Shugrue said the carrier will recall union pilots based upon needs, not by seniority as the union has demanded. The pilots union ended its sympathy strike in support of the Machinists last November but has discussed returning to the picket lines because of the recall issue. ``I expect pilots who aren't working to return to Eastern and get going,'' Shugrue said. ``Everybody has to understand the economics of operating this company.'' Talks are continuing with the Machinists union, which remains on strike, he said. ``I'm not Pollyannish about it,'' Shugrue said of his pledge to bring labor peace to Eastern. ``There's too much history on this property. I am optimistic.'' Eastern employees applauded enthusiastically while watching Shugrue's news conference. ``I think he has credibility. If anyone can mean long-term viability and Eastern remaining independent, he can,'' said Dennis Cirroti, a 24-year Eastern pilot who returned to work last August after striking.

DOC.HEAD: Inside Trader Siegel Sentenced To Two Months In Prison
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with details from sentencing; CORRECTS age to 42 and date of plea to February 1987.
DOC.TEXT: Martin A. Siegel, who allegedly took suitcases filled with cash from Ivan Boesky in exchange for inside information, was sentenced Friday to two months in prison. U.S. District Judge Robert J. Ward cited Siegel's contrition and cooperation with prosecutors in giving him one of the shortest prison terms meted out in Wall Street's insider trading scandals. Siegel, a mergers specialist for the investment firms Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and Kidder, Peabody & Co., was one of the first Wall Street figures to cooperate with prosecutors after being implicated by Boesky, the notorious stock speculator. Boesky, in recent testimony in another case, said he gave Siegel suitcases of cash for inside information on takeover attempts. Siegel has admitted swapping stock tips with former Goldman, Sachs & Co. trader Robert Freeman. ``Over the last three and a half years, I have tried to do everything in my power to make up for these mistakes,'' Siegel said in a statement to the court. He pleaded guilty in February 1987 to conspiracy to violate securities laws and tax evasion. In addition to the prison time, Siegel was sentenced to five years probation during which he must perform 3,000 hours of community service. No fine was given. Siegel previously agreed to give up more than $9 million in cash and assets to settle civil charges brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Ward chided Siegel for his conduct, saying, ``In short, there is no excuse for what he did. ... What we have here, we've seen far too many times before in the financial community.'' Siegel's cooperation led to the controversial insider trading cases against Richard B. Wigton and Timothy L. Tabor, two of Siegel's associates at Kidder, Peabody, and Freeman, formerly head of arbitrage at Goldman, Sachs. The arrests in 1987 of the three traders, one being led from his office in handcuffs, stunned the financial community and led to widespread predictions that more Wall Street professionals would be implicated in the scandal. The government alleged Freeman made profitable stock deals on inside information about takeover attempts supplied by Siegel, and that Wigton and Tabor made trading decisions using the tips from Freeman. The case eventually was dropped when the government said it needed more time to gather evidence. But last year, after more than two years of investigations, prosecutors announced they would bring no charges against Wigton and Tabor. Freeman agreed to plead guilty to one count of mail fraud and admitted he received inside information in January 1986 from Siegel and used the tip to execute various trades. He was sentenced in April to four months in prison and a $1 million fine. Assistant U.S. Attorney Neil Cartusciello recommended Siegel receive a lesser sentence because he cooperated and Freeman did not. While at first saying Siegel should be ``terribly ashamed'' for what he had done, the prosecutor went on to praise his ``thorough and open'' cooperation. Cartusciello said almost all the information supplied by Siegel was corroborated independently. The prosecutor said Siegel's testimony against Freeman was especially important because the type of scheme they carried out was rarely detected by employers or investigators. The terms of Siegel's probation require he perform 2,400 hours of community service at a community college in Jacksonville, Fla., where he lives, and another 600 hours of community service unrelated to his financial skills. Siegel was to surrender at a yet unspecified facility sometime before July 15. According to court papers, Boesky paid Siegel $700,000 for stock tips over four years. The payments were in exchange for information he gave Boesky about corporate takeover battles he waged as an investment banker at Kidder, Peabody. Boesky, who pleaded guilty to one felony count to settle the biggest insider trading case, was recently released after completing two years of a three-year prison sentence.

DOC.HEAD: Liquidating Carrier Sells $57 Million Worth Of Assets
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge Thursday approved bids totalling $59 million for Braniff's most valuable assets. The Orlando-based airline is liquidating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act and received $7 million more than originally planned for the assets. Once fearful of recovering nothing, creditors will now receive at least a few pennies on the dollar. The biggest single sale at U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Orlando went to Orix Group. The Tokyo-based financial services company bid $47.8 million for Braniff's rights to buy 74 A-320 jets from Airbus Industrie. It plans to use the planes to start a new equipment leasing division. AVSA S.A.R.L. and Airbus Service Co. Inc. ended up with some Airbus spare parts for $7.1 million. Both companies are affiliates of the Airbus consortium, which is based in Toulouse, France. IAE International Aero Engines AG outbid the two Airbus affiliates to nab some engine spare parts for $4.4 million. Based in Switzerland, IAE is an international consortium that makes aircraft engines. Before Orix and IAE came forward as bidders, the Airbus affiliates had agreed to pay roughly $52 million in cash for the aircraft contracts and spare parts. That sales agreement was contingent on no higher bids being received. ``Not only is this a good deal from the debtor's point of view, but it's a great deal,'' said U.S. Bankruptcy Judge C. Timothy Corcoran III.

DOC.HEAD: Directors Take Anti-Takeover Steps
DOC.TEXT: Directors of Reebok International Ltd., faced with the prospect of nearly one-third of the company's stock on the market, have adopted a series of anti-takeover defenses to keep corporate raiders away from the sneaker company. Pentland Industries PLC of England announced it would sell the 31.5 percent of Reebok stock it owns. In response, the directors of the Stoughton-based manufacturer of sneakers and casual wear adopted a shareholder rights plan Thursday. It entitles stock-owners to buy additional shares at a greatly reduced price in the event of a takeover attempt. The issuance of new stock would make it expensive for a buyer to take control of the company. Reebok also announced its board will take advantage of a new Massachusetts law and create three classes of directors, which lengthens the time it would take to install an entirely new board. Pentland Industries, a shoe manufacturer and investment company in Finchley, England, helped Reebok to success in the early 1980s. It loaned money to Paul Fireman, chairman of Reebok, and provided him with letters of credit after Fireman bought the rights to distribute Reebok shoes from a small British company. ``They've made a lot of money with it,'' said Paul F. Duncan, Reebok's chief financial officer. ``It's been an extraordinary investment for them. ... Pentland has expressed a desire to sell their shares and get on with whatever else they want to do in life.'' The reason for Pentland's desire to sell its Reebok stock was not disclosed. Fireman and Rubin had a cross-agreement under which either had first right to buy the other's shares if placed on the market. It was not known whether Fireman would buy Pentland's stock in Reebok. Fireman and his wife own 14.5 percent of Reebok shares.

DOC.HEAD: Pathe Extends MGM-UA Tender Offer Again as Deadline Looms
DOC.TEXT: Pathe Communications Corp. on Friday extended its $1.2 billion offer for MGM-UA Communications Co. to June 22, one day before the final deadline to complete its complex package for financing the buyout. It was the second week-long extension of the tender offer by Pathe, a movie producer and distributor controlled by Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti. But even previously skeptical analysts said it now appears Pathe is in the final stages of paperwork on the deal. ``They appear to be very close to being able to complete the transaction,'' said Jeffrey Logsdon, an entertainment industry analyst at the Crowell Weedon & Co. stock brokerage. The $20-per-share offer expires June 23, according to Parretti's agreement with MGM-UA and Tracinda Corp., the holding company through which Beverly Hills billionaire Kirk Kerkorian controls MGM-UA. To help the deal along, Kerkorian has said he may keep about $20 million in stock _ a fraction of the $800 million his 40 million shares would bring him if all were sold. Pathe spokesman Craig Parsons said it hasn't been decided if Kerkorian will keep the $20 million in stock. Parsons also said a French economic minister's blockage Friday of Pathe's attempt to acquire a controlling interest in the Pathe Cinema theater chain in France was unrelated to the MGM-UA deal. Parretti has made cash down payments of $200 million. Time Warner Inc. has agreed to lend him another $650 million in return for a lien on the United Artists film library and distribution rights on that library and new MGM, Pathe and United Artists films for 20 years. The rest of the financing has been a topic of broad speculation. But Parretti revealed details of the complex package this week: mainly short-term loans and asset sales by Pathe-affiliated companies in Europe, and the possible resale of MGM-UA stock or sale of new Pathe shares after the merger. Merely completing the paperwork for the non-U.S. banks involved in the lending for the deal is likely to be a logistical nightmare, Logsdon said. Last year, a bid by Australia's Qintex group to buy MGM-UA for $1.5 billion collapsed for lack of financing. Qintex outbid media mogul Rupert Murdoch by $100 million. But Qintex was unable to come up with a $50 million down payment and Murdoch refused to get back in the bidding. In structuring the Pathe buyout, Kerkorian has assured himself he can pocket the $200 million in cash even if the deal collapses. Parretti also has guaranteed MGM-UA $75 million in fees from distributing three upcoming Pathe releases, including ``The Russia House'' with Sean Connery and Michelle Pfeiffer and ``Quigley Down Under'' with Tom Selleck. Jeanne Ouellette, an MGM-UA spokeswoman, said she wasn't sure about Kerkorian retaining a stake in the company, but said the deal was expected to go through even if it comes down to the final deadline.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Opts For NBC's Ad Payback System
DOC.TEXT: ABC on Thursday adopted NBC's ratings formula for calculating the ``make good'' free ad time it gives to advertisers on shows delivering lower ratings than the network promised. CBS executives issued a statement at the close of the business day in which CBS endorsed NBC's statistical formula, but said nothing about whether CBS, too, would adopt the formula in its make-good policy. ABC urged unity among advertisers and broadcasters. ``A uniform stewardship policy is in the best interest of the entire advertising and television network communities,'' ABC said in a statement released by spokeswoman Janice Gretemeyer. CBS had been expected to endorse the plan, which comes at the start of the fall season's $4 billion ``upfront'' ad market, which brings in nearly half the $9 billion to $10 billion ad revenue estimated the fall season. All three networks blame this season's overall ratings decline on the ``people meter'' system used by the A.C. Nielsen Co. to gather viewership figures in 4,000 homes nationwide. ABC initially said it would adjust its ratings based on average viewing since 1987, when the ``people meter'' became the industry standard. NBC, which estimated its loses from lower ratings at $100 million, proposed an eight-year Nielsen ratings trend as a baseline, using a statistical technique called ``regression analysis'' to project TV usage. NBC would give away make-good time only when TV usage equals or exceeds the prediction derived from Nielsen's historical data. ``If the usage that we find is equal to or greater than our forecast, then we don't dispute the shortfall and we pay off,'' said Nick Schiavone, NBC's vice president for sales and marketing research. CBS, without elaboration, issued the following statement: ``The process of regression analysis as outlined by NBC is, in principal, acceptable to us.'' It wasn't immediately clear what the network meant. David Poltrack, CBS' vice president for research, was gone for the day and could not be reached for comment, said spokeswoman Betsy Wagner. Nielsen, which earns $22 million annually from the three networks, insists its people meter system is not flawed and that fewer people are watching network television. A viewer in a people meter household `logs on'' to the device. The previous system recorded what was being viewed, but not who was watching. Critics of that system cited ``button fatigue'' as the cause of inaccurate numbers. ABC said the problem of ``the unexplained volatility and viewing losses reported by Nielsen'' still must be addressed by broadcasters, advertisers and their agencies.

DOC.HEAD: Tomkins Pays $550 Million for Philips Industries
DOC.TEXT: Philips Industries Inc. has been acquired by Tomkins PLC of the United Kingdom for about $550 million, the two companies said Friday. Shareholders of both companies must approve the merger. Tomkins plans a vote in July, and Philips in August. ``I strongly support this transaction and intend to vote my shares in favor of the merger,'' said Jesse Philips, a director and founder of the Dayton-based company who owns about 5.1 percent of the outstanding common shares. Philips manufactures components for residential, commercial and industrial buildings, manufactured housing, recreational vehicles and the transportation industry. Its 1989 sales were $927.5 million. Tomkins owns and operates manufacturing and distribution businesses in the U.S. and the United Kingdom. Its principal U.S. businesses are the Murray Ohio Manufacturing Co., which makes power mowers and bicycles; and Smith & Wesson Corp., which makes firearms. Tomkins reported sales of $1.1 billion for 1989. The sale price amounts to about $18.50 per share of Philips stock, about 32 percent over the selling price of Philips common shares on June 4, the day before the announcement of an agreement in principle. Philips stock closed Friday at $17.875 on the New York Stock Exchange, up 25 cents. Tomkins said it is financing the acquisition through an offering of shares of its stock in the United Kingdom.

DOC.HEAD: Orange Juice Futures Collapse On Weak Demand, Rumored Price Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Orange juice futures prices collapsed Friday, reflecting weak demand, a larger government estimate of the Florida crop and unsubstantiated rumors of Brazilian price cuts. On other commodity markets, pork futures plunged while cattle futures were mixed; precious metals rebounded; energy futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans fell. Frozen concentrated orange juice futures settled 5 cents to 10.65 cents lower with the contract for delivery in July down 10.65 cents at $1.795 a pound. The contracts are traded on the New York Cotton Exchange. The selloff followed a Florida Citrus Department report Thursday that U.S. consumption of non-concentrated orange juice was about 15 percent below a year ago during the four weeks ending April 21. Movement of Florida orange juice has averaged less than 3 million gallons per week for several months ``and that's just not good,'' said Ernie Thomas, a commodity specialist with Merrill Lynch Consumer Markets in Winter Haven, Fla. He attributed some of the slack demand to the higher prices for orange juice following the Christmastime freeze that wiped out a quarter to a third of the Florida crop. The 1989-90 Florida harvest came in a little larger than the government had feared, though. In a crop report Tuesday, the Agriculture Department pegged the final tally at 110.1 million boxes, 2 million above the previous month's estimate. Brazil, meanwhile, had a record orange harvest last year of roughly 300 million boxes. Because of the Florida shortfall, Brazil now supplies about half of the orange juice sold in the United States, Thomas said. Rumors that Brazilian processors have cut their prices were not confirmed but contributed to the market's decline. Near-term hog and pork-belly futures fell their permitted daily limits for the second straight day on the the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, reflecting sluggish demand for pork products and indications of ample hog supplies. Cattle futures finished mixed, with strength in the cash market helping to offset spillover selling from the pork pits. Live cattle settled .40 cent lower to .10 cent higher with June at 76.67 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .07 cent lower to .12 cent higher with August at 84.65 cents a pound; live hogs were .55 cent to the limit 1.5 cents lower with June at 61.17 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .92 cent to the limit 2 cents lower with July at 66.45 cents a pound. Gold and silver futures rebounded slightly from two days of steep losses on New York's Commodity Exchange. Analysts attributed the buying to pre-weekend account-reconciling. Gold futures settled $2.50 to $3.10 higher with June at $349.50 a troy ounce; silver was 4 cents to 4.9 cents higher with June at $4.811 a troy ounce. Crude oil futures fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange due to oversupply and the approaching expiration of the July crude contract, which goes off the board Wednesday. Strong demand for gasoline pushed nearby gas prices up sharply. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 14 cents to 51 cents lower with July at $16.62 a barrel; heating oil was .05 cent to .83 cent lower with July at 48.37 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .05 cent lower to 1.39 cents higher with July at 61.51 cents a gallon. Grain and soybean futures closed moderately to sharply lower on the Chicago Board of Trade, extending recent losses amid active selling that occurred late in an otherwise lackluster session. Forecasts for near-ideal crop weather in the Midwest through mid-July have weighed on corn and soybean prices all week. Late in Friday's session, prices of both commodities fell low enough to trigger substantial new selling. Wheat futures settled 2 cents to 5 cents lower with July at $3.28 a bushel; corn was 4 cents to 6{ cents lower with July at $2.83 a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 2{ cents lower with July at $1.38{ a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 6{ cents lower with July at $5.86 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Gains, Stocks Marginally Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei and comments
DOC.TEXT: The dollar remained higher against the yen Friday morning and share prices gained marginally on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The dollar was trading at 154.36 yen at late morning, up 0.83 yen from Thursday's close of 153.53 yen. After opening at 154.50 yen, the currency ranged between 154.25 yen and 154.57 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues gained 8.10 points to close the morning session at 32,676.21. The index rose 296.34 points on Thursday. Currency dealers said the dollar's higher opening reflected its levels reached in overnight trading overseas. Kozo Yoshida, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank, said the dollar remained in a narrow range. ``Everyone is basically waiting the release of the latest U.S. trade figures,'' Yoshida said. The U.S. Commerce Department is scheduled to announce the nation's merchandise trade figures for April later Friday. Some traders say the deficit may show a significant decline to about $7.2 billion from the previous month's wider-than-expected $8.45 billion deficit. On the stock market, the Nikkei index moved little with many investors taking a wait-and-see position because of the yen's weakness and lower bond prices, securities dealers said. The price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond fell to 87.87 points from Thursday's close of 88.09. That boosted the yield to 7.00 percent from 6.955 percent.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Trump-Bonds Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of recent developments in Donald Trump's life. September 1980 _ Trump opens the Grand Hyatt hotel, restored with the help of a $120 million New York City tax break. April 1983 _ Trump Tower, complete with marble atrium and waterfall, opens on Fifth Avenue in New York and becomes the city's newest tourist attraction, giving Trump nationwide fame. Fall 1983 _ Trump buys New Jersey Generals of the United States Football League. 1987 _ Writes ``Trump: The Art of the Deal.'' May 14, 1984 _ Harrahs hotel-casino at Trump Plaza opens in Atlantic City, N.J. The Harrahs reference later was dropped from the name. June 17, 1985 _ Trump Castle hotel-casino opens in Atlantic City. August 1986 _ USFL, including New Jersey Generals, suspends season. March 31, 1989 _ Trump buys Eastern Airlines' shuttle between Boston, New York and Washington. The $365 million deal is a revision of an agreement reached in October, 1988. Oct. 10 _ Three top Trump casino executives are killed in a helicopter crash as they return to Atlantic City from New York. February 1990 _ Reports surface that Trump and his wife Ivana of 13 years are considering divorce. Model Marla Maples is linked romantically to Trump. April 2 _ Trump's Taj Mahal hotel-casino opens in Atlantic City. April 27 _ The Wall Street Journal publishes a story in which Trump discloses he is considering selling the shuttle to raise cash. Trump insists he is not having cash-flow trouble, but simply wants to be in a better position to take advantage of the slumping real estate market. June 11 _ Trump confirms a tentative agreement with bankers that would provide him another $60 million in loans and a temporary suspension of debt payments. In exchange, the banks would get equity in some of his properties. June 15 _ Trump misses a payment deadline for interest and principal on bonds for Trump Castle after failing to get a final agreement with the banks. Negotiations continue with bankers over a bailout.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Airlines Seeks Approval for Moscow, Leningrad Routes
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines sought U.S. Transportation Department approval Friday to open routes to Moscow and Leningrad. Northwest said it is prepared to extend its Boston-Amsterdam nonstop service to include both Moscow and Leningrad beginning next May 1. The airline would fly four times a week on an Amsterdam-Moscow-Leningrad route using 294-seat McDonnell Douglas DC-10 aircraft. The route application is the result of an air service agreement signed during the recent Bush-Gorbachev summit under which four U.S. airlines will be designated to fly to the Soviet Union. Northwest is America's fourth largest airline, serving 20 countries in Asia, North America and Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Misses Junk Bond Payment On Casino; Talks Continue With Banks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, But other ... with two grafs to UPDATE with First Fidelity resigning as bond trustee, edits to conform. Picks up 10th graf pvs, Spokesmen for ...; INSERTS graf after 18th graf pvs to include amount Trump would owe without bond buyback. ^LaserPhotos NY7, TN1
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump missed a payment due Friday on junk bonds used to finance one of his Atlantic City resorts, the harshest signal yet of the troubles plaguing his tottering real estate empire. Trump has a 10-day grace period to make the payment of an estimated $31 million in interest and principal on bonds used to finance his Trump Castle hotel-casino. But the failure to meet Friday's deadline nevertheless brought him a step closer to default, which theoretically could force a bankruptcy filing to defend the flamboyant developer from collateral-seeking creditors. ``What this tells us is he has not been able to reach a deal with his banks,'' Michael Mulvaney, a bond analyst with Moody's Investors Services Inc. said of the missed payment. ``He has the grace period to work it out. If he doesn't work it out, then you've got the possibility of default.'' Separately, Moody's, a major Wall Street credit rating firm, on Friday lowered its ratings for bonds used to finance the Trump Taj Mahal and Trump Plaza hotel-casinos. Moody's said the missed payment for Trump Castle showed the potential for weakened finances at the other two resorts. A statement issued by the Trump Organization announcing the missed payment said negotiations were continuing with lenders to get more money and restructure loans. Trump and his main bankers tentatively had agreed a week ago to a bailout that would have provided him another $60 million in loans and a temporary suspension of payments. In exchange, the banks would have gotten equity in some of his properties. If the deal had been finalized he would have had the cash to make Friday's bond payment. But other banks involved in the deal reportedly balked at the plan. First Fidelity Bancorp of Newark, N.J., and Midlantic Banks Inc. of Edison, N.J., reportedly were the main holdouts. Midlantic would not comment on the situation Friday. Late Friday, First Fidelity announced it would resign as trustee for the bondholders once a successor is found. The bank said it wanted to avoid the appearance of a conflict of interest in its role as both a bank lender and overseer of bondholders' interest as trustee. Spokesmen for his four major bank lenders _ Citicorp, Chase Manhattan, Bankers Trust and Manufacturers Hanover _ either would not comment or did not return telephone calls. Trump has been beset by a slumping real estate market in New York, and disappointing results from his three Atlantic City casinos and the Trump Shuttle airline. His real estate holdings, which also include New York's Plaza Hotel and Trump Tower, were built largely with funds borrowed with junk bonds and bank loans. Trump owes banks an estimated $2 billion and bondholders another $1 billion. The ongoing negotiations have raised speculation that bankers want more authority over operation of his properties, possibly even naming new managers and leaving Trump only as a figurehead. The negotiations also have caught the eye of the New Jersey Casino Control Commission. ``It's always a matter of concern when any casino is in difficulty,'' said Tom Flynn, a commission spokesman. Also, the New Jersey Division of Gaming Enforcement has been auditing Trump's properties for more than a month. The DGE, an arm of the state Attorney General's office, has characterized the audit as routine. Friday's payment was due on two bonds issued to finance the Trump Castle, one paying 13.75 percent due in 1997 and one paying 7 percent due in 1999. Trump, who bought back many of his bonds at a discount on the open market, owes about $12 million in interest and $10 million in principal on the 13.75 percent bonds and about $9 million on the 7 percent bonds, according to Sheila O'Connell, a bond analyst with Duff & Phelps, a Chicago investment firm. The total amount Trump would owe if he had not bought back any bonds is $42.6 million. In the first three months of 1990, Trump Castle lost $8.4 million, the largest loss among the 12 casinos in Atlantic City. Trump Castle recorded improved gross gaming revenues for the first three months of the year, but failed to maintain those gains after the Taj Mahal opened April 2. Trump Castle's ``win'' in May fell 17.3 percent from a year earlier to $17.9 million. The ``win'' is the amount of money a casino wins at gaming tables and slot machines and does not account for operating expenses, depreciation, debt service, taxes and other charges. For May, the Taj Mahal broke its own citywide record for win with $36.5 million, or $1.18 million a day. Trump Plaza, helped by a $10 million windfall from an unlucky Japanese high roller at the baccarat table, posted a win of $31.3 million, up 23 percent from May 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Bell Atlantic, U S West To Build Czech Cellular Phone System
DOC.TEXT: Two regional phone companies, Bell Atlantic and U S West, have been selected by the Czechoslovakian telephone authority to build a cellular phone system in that nation, the companies said Friday. Under the contract signed Friday, Bell Atlantic and U S West will form a joint venture company with the Czech Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications that also will advise the ministry on rebuilding the nation's phone network, the companies said in a statement. The joint venture will be 51 percent owned by the ministry and 49 percent by the two U.S. companies. No value for the deal was disclosed. Construction of the cellular system is expected to start in the fall, the companies said. U S West, based in Englewood, Colo., already is building a cellular system in Hungary. Steven Andrews, president of U S West International, said the addition of the Czech system ``gives us a firm base from which to build a wireless network serving Eastern European customers.'' Bell Atlantic, based in Philadelphia, owns local phone companies in the mid-Atlantic region. U S West subsidiaries provide phone service in 14 Western states. On Thursday, Bell Atlantic and Ameritech, a regional phone company based in Chicago, announced they and two New Zealand companies will buy that nation's government-owned phone system.

Retail prices rose a modest 0.2 percent in May, easing the strain on consumers' budgets after a painful spurt in prices early in the year, the government said. The April and May moderation in the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index curbed inflation for the first five months of the year to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.8 percent. That's up significantly from the 4.6 percent rate for all of last year, but down sharply from the worrisome 8.5 percent rate in the first quarter. The latest figures were released Friday.

Industrial production jumped 0.6 percent in May, but analysts said the sharp gain was due mainly to a temporary buildup in automobile inventories. Meanwhile, the Commerce Department reported Friday that exports helped shrink the U.S. trade deficit so far this year to an annual rate of $92.16 billion, compared to a deficit for all of 1989 of $108.99 billion.

Donald Trump has missed a payment on junk bonds used to finance one of his Atlantic City resorts, the harshest signal yet of the troubles plaguing his tottering real estate empire. Trump has a 10-day grace period from Friday to make the payment of an estimated $31 million in interest and principal on bonds used to finance his Trump Castle hotel-casino. But the failure to meet Friday's deadline nevertheless brought him a step closer to default, which theoretically could force a bankruptcy filing to defend the flamboyant developer from collateral-seeking creditors.

Martin A. Siegel, who allegedly took suitcases of cash from Ivan Boesky in exchange for inside information, has been sentenced to two months in prison. U.S. District Judge Robert J. Ward on Friday cited Siegel's contrition and cooperation with prosecutors in giving him one of the shortest prison terms meted out in Wall Street's insider trading scandals.

British stock market experts said they were puzzled by the New York Stock Exchange's plan to begin after-hours trading to an effort to recapture trading of U.S. stocks now conducted overseas. The experts said Friday such trading is relatively small in Europe, and it also is not clear that the business will grow much in coming years. NYSE Chairman John J. Phelan Jr. on Thursday unveiled a five-step plan to trade securities after the exchange's traditional daytime hours. The plan would culminate in 24-hour trading by the end of the decade.

Top Soviet leaders say they have won legislative support for a market economy, despite rejection of an immediate price increase for bread and demands for a more detailed blueprint of the transition. Yuri D. Maslyukov, the chairman of the State Planning Commission, told reporters Friday that the Supreme Soviet legislature was right to posptone the first phase of a bread price increase Ryzhkov proposed for July 1. Bread is the staple of the Soviet diet.

Iran has agreed to pay Amoco Corp. $600 million for facilities seized during the 1979 Islamic revolution, removing one of the biggest obstacles to renewed trade with the United States. Two claims totaling $600 million were awarded to the American oil giant, an official of the Iran-United States Claims Tribunal said Friday. It was the biggest settlement in the arbitration body's nine-year history.

The world's two largest gold producing companies say they plan to curtail their mining operations due to the plummeting price of gold. Anglo American Corp. of South Africa Ltd. said Friday that two of its mining companies, Free State State Consolidated Gold Mines Ltd. (Freegold) and Vaal Reefs Exploration and Mining Co. Ltd., would cut back on operations in moves that will cut at least 7,800 jobs. The price of gold reached a 4-year low of $346.25 per ounce in New York and London before recovering on Thursday. Gold is South Africa's major industry, earning more than half the country's foreign currency.

House Democrats have attacked savings and loan bailout agency officials for hiring high-paid consultants, keeping executives of failed thrifts on the job and continuing to pay others who perform no work. Congress is hearing growing reports of overpaid individuals running government-held institutions, and of officers from failed institutions staying on the government payroll with six-figure salaries, said Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., chairman of the House S&L bailout task force.

The Dow Jones industrial average churned ahead to a new closing high Friday, in what was otherwise a mixed session for stocks. The average of 30 industrials rose 7.67 points to 2,935.89, surpassing its previous closing peak of 2,935.19 reached on June 4. Bond prices tumbled on discouraging economic reports. Gold prices advanced, while the dollar lost ground. Gold and silver futures rebounded slightly. Livestock and energy futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans fell.

DOC.HEAD: Cineplex Selling Theaters in Eight States
DOC.TEXT: Carmike Cinemas Inc. said Friday it is buying 24 movie theaters in three Southeastern states from Toronto-based Cineplex Odeon Corp. for about $11 million. Separately, Toronto-based Cineplex Odeon said it was selling 38 theaters in five Midwest and Western states that are part of its Plitt Theaters Inc. subsidiary to Plitt Amusement Co. Inc. of Los Angeles. The theaters being purhased by Columbus-based Carmike are in North Carolina, South Carolina and Tennessee and include 96 screens. ``As part of our ongoing, long-term expansion strategy, this acquisition will open new markets to Carmike,'' said Michael W. Patrick, Carmike's president and chief executive officer. Theaters in the three states that are not part of the Carmike deal will be returned to the landlords, closed or sold, Cineplex said. The Plitt theaters being sodl are in the states of Utah, Idaho, Minnesota, Oregon and Washington. That deal is valued at $31.8 million. Cineplex Odeon President Allen Karp said the theater sales were part of the Canadian company's strategy of focusing on its principal markets. Cineplex, which has been under financial pressure, said it will use proceeds from the sales to pay down its long-term debt. After the sales, Cineplex will have 1,550 screens in 390 locations in the United States and Canada.
